On Wed, 2004-06-30 at 17:10, Michael P. Hopcroft wrote:
> I have some documents that I acquired on a system that uses Digital 
> Rights Management (DRM) to control copying. Fair enough. But now I'm 
> contemplating a switch to Linux (Wondows is breaking down too many 
> times) and there is no Linux PDF reader that is reocgnized by DRM. Some 
> of these files cost me money, and I was wondering what I should do to be 
> able to conitnue reading them (after I find a way to transfer them from 
> my windows drives to the same drives formatted in Linux).

Do you know which DRM format they used?  I will see what I can find.
There was a package from Russia that removed pretty much all of the PDF
DRM formats.  I will see if I have a copy.

> P.S. IS there a way to get any Linux distro to recongize a CD burnder 
> and burn CDs with it? Last version of Linux I attempted with would 
> repcognize my printer (no surprise -- USB color inkjet) but also 
> wouldn;t recongize my DVD player drive as such or ym DVD Recorder drive 
> as such.

Fedora core 2 works fine with my DVD recorder.  You just need a current
version of cdrecord with the DVD extensions.  (Which Fedora ships with.)

For burning DVDs and /or CDs I recommend k3b.  It has the look and feel
of Nero and handles all sorts of tasks.  It is a kde app.  Quite cool.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jul  1 08:45:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Jul  1 08:45:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <1088690898.2277.1294.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
References: <1088690898.2277.1294.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
Message-ID: <2818-90696@sneakemail.com>

On Thu, 1 Jul 2004, Marv lamsokvr-at-xprt.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I need to get a Digiatal Camera.
>
> Recommendations??

There are enough variations out there to meet pretty much any criteria you
have.  Here are some criteria that are often overlooked:

Focus
-----

Many, many cameras I've tried focus poorly.  The LCD is too small to tell
that the image is blurry, so you won't know until you upload it to your
PC, which is usually too late to re-shoot.  A true digital SLR won't have
this problem ($1000ish), nor do some of the cheaper fixed-focus cameras
($100-200ish).

It's often hard to tell if a given camera is fixed focus or not based on
the specs.  Any camera with an optical zoom won't be fixed-focus.  (And
digital zoom is a complete waste since all it does is enlarge the pixels
from the CCD.)

Time Before Ready
-----------------

Some cameras seem to take an eternity to "boot up", others have a
significant lag between when you hit the button and when the photo is
taken.  This might not seem like a big deal, but after missing a few great
shots, somehow this becomes very important.

Size
----

Many digital cameras are small enough to tuck into a pocket at all times.
This is great since good photo chances can show up at off times.  There's
really no need to get a larger one unless it's a digital SLR.

Battery Life
------------

If you get a camera that will run off alkalines, it's possible to keep it
in that same pocket I just mentioned for weeks and still be able to shoot.
Rechargable NiMH batteries lose power slowly over several weeks-- often to
the point where they don't work when you want them too.  For any expected
shooting (vacation, special event, etc.) you'll want to use rechargables,
but for just having the camera ready, alkalines are great.

Megapixels
----------

Far, far, far less important than the marketing arms of the camera
companies would have you believe.  An out-of-focus high resolution photo
is just as crappy as an out-of-focus low resolution photo.

Summary
-------

I've been very happy with my Olympus D-380, though it's been discontinued.
It is fixed-focus, which means it shoots very quickly and each photo past
about 24" is guaranteed to be in perfect focus.  (There is no delay
waiting for the AF system to decide where to focus, then move the lens to
that spot.)  It's also small, with very good battery life.  Best of all, a
full setup with larger SmartMedia card, PCMCIA reader, and appropriate USB
cable was only $220.  The camera works great with recent versions of
Linux via USB, and the PCMCIA reader even works with older versions of
Linux.

For some raves about the Canon A70, try here:

http://www.kenrockwell.com/canon/a70.htm

  -- Steve



From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jul  1 09:01:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Jul  1 09:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] DRM Documents
In-Reply-To: <40E3566F.4020800@mphpress.com>
References: <40E3566F.4020800@mphpress.com>
Message-ID: <16061-47818@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 30 Jun 2004, Michael P. Hopcroft michael-at-mphpress.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I have some documents that I acquired on a system that uses Digital
> Rights Management (DRM) to control copying. Fair enough. But now I'm
> contemplating a switch to Linux (Wondows is breaking down too many
> times) and there is no Linux PDF reader that is reocgnized by DRM. Some
> of these files cost me money, and I was wondering what I should do to be
> able to conitnue reading them (after I find a way to transfer them from
> my windows drives to the same drives formatted in Linux).

I'm having the same difficulty with some Adobe eBooks.  Unfortunately, the
only way to view them is not available:

-----
http://www.adobe.com/support/ebookrdrfaq.html#linux
-----

The Acrobat 6.01 DRM features seem to work under Windows/VMware.  I
haven't tried them with WINE, but I suspect there may be problems since
the software actively tries to cease working if run in an unfamiliar
environment, e.g. under a debugger:

-----
http://www.adobe.com/support/ebookrdrfaq.html#de-bugger
-----

The only solution I've seen so far would be to print them to a PS file and
convert it.  (The new version of Adobe won't print to a printer configured
locally to print to a file, so you'll have to use a network printer that
prints to a file.)  The resulting PS file contains several lines
threatening dire DMCA consequences for removing them and won't print or
convert using a stock Ghostscript.  Since this is being done on content
that has already been licensed to me for the purposes of interoperability,
the DMCA restrictions shouldn't apply.  However, I'm not a lawyer, and I'm
not saying that I've actually done this.

Some of the info here will explain how to convert these PS files into
something that will work for you on Linux:

(Gallery of Adobe Remedies)
http://www-2.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Adobe/Gallery/

Remember to let the companies distributing Adboe eBooks know how unhappy
you are with the format.  Without this feedback, they'll assume that we're
all happy with the horrible fair use restrictions on it.

  -- Steve



From root at loraksus.org  Thu Jul  1 10:13:02 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Thu Jul  1 10:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <1088690898.2277.1294.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
Message-ID: <8336D90466D5@loraksus.org>

Avoid HP. Well, their peasant, sub-$200 consumer stuff anyways, although I
suppose that goes for all manufacturers * <--- BIG STAR

If you have a bunch of money, the Canon 1DS is very nice and should be
dropping in price / leaving shelves in the next couple weeks as canon
releases a new version. For about $700-800, the Canon EOS 300D can be bought
and there is a hacked firmware which gives you a bunch of features found in
the next level camera (mirror lock up, etc). 
That said; if you're just going to be snapping pics of parties and stuff and
really don't care too much about photography, don't spend a ton unless you
feel like blowing dough.

* - If you DO like photography (I don't want to sound like a pessimist or
cynical bastard - BUT . . .) you're probably not going to be thrilled with
the quality of anything under $250-300, so you might as well go a step or
two up.

You will be shocked and amazed at the higher end stuff like the 1DS / 10D,
although they have a sticker price that is equally shocking (and 35mb images
at full res in RAW mode). If you find a Canon D30 / D60, consider those as
well, although they have been end of life'd for a while now but are really
nice compared to the other stuff. 
I know a bunch of people who went for cameras in the $400-$600 range but
then upgraded to a better model in a couple months, you might want to try
out something a bit "higher end" and see if you like it - you might save
yourself some money in the long run. 

I've heard the Nikon coolpix series is a decent, more or less portable
cameras, a wee bit expensive but you might want to try one out.

Battery life is great, but you should try to get something that takes NIMH
AAs. If you don't have a charger, etc, yet, expect to get one.

Avoid cameras with plastic lenses like the plague. There is a reason webcams
are $30 and look like crap. A real lens is nice, and helps a lot with
pictures (especially at night).
Digital zoom is useless, but you know that, so ignore those numbers. It
should be called digital crop but some marketing troll decided to put a
positive spin on things. 
You're probably not going to be happy with the quality of night pics in a
ccd camera. - I threw together a couple sample pics - check the capitol
records night pic - and just expect that on pretty much every night photo
unless you get a tripod / beanbag and do a 10 sec exposure. 
http://vehiclehitech.com/samples/ 
Those pics are pretty good, but there were a lot of crap ones too. You can't
really zoom in though, the resolution / quality just isn't quite there.
Those were shot with a HP 850 which is a fairly decent camera, although I'd
go a bit higher if I was going to buy a camera. I had 4 hp 720s in a row,
all broke within a month of me getting them (and right before / during
trips). HP was nice enough to send me the 850 as a replacement after a
little bit of whining on my part. I sort of want to rag on their products,
but a lot of their stuff has gotten much better in the last year (at least
in cameras) and their support / customer service is excellent in this area -
they even speak English as a first language!

BTW, there are a bunch of websites selling the HP 215 for $75 or something,
avoid that - it's a crap camera that is 3 years old (worth maybe $25), I'm
not sure why so many places have extra stock, just a word of warning. I had
one and it sure likes batteries (like 40 pics = 4AAs). 

Check out www.dpreview.com for a bunch of sample pics / reviews from a ton
of cameras - they are aimed toward the higher end cameras, but they have a
bit of midrange stuff too. 

/blah blah blah soapbox etc

As others have said it depends on what you want. 

IMHO, it's hard to go wrong with either Olympus or Nikon. Cannon is good
too, but they have a history of mucking with things in ways that makes
life hard for Linux developers. 

I have an Olympus 5060 - which is a 5 Megapixel range-finder style camera.
I like that configuration because it is smaller and lighter than the SLRs
and because you can use the LCD as a viewfinder - which you can't do on
most SLRs. The downside is that you can't change lenses.

Steve's Digicams is a good place to read up on digital cameras. He has
reviews of all most all of the current models:

http://www.steves-digicams.com/

Dan

From kevinc at doink.COM  Thu Jul  1 11:46:02 2004
From: kevinc at doink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Thu Jul  1 11:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] FW: SUMMARY - Mandrake Graphical Boot
Message-ID: <20040701184436.8B4444054@joseph.doink.com>

I posted this to alt.os.linux.mandrake.  Maybe it'll help someone 
here?

TTFN...



------- Forwarded Message

**************************************************
Date:    30 Jun 2004 21:50:43 GMT
From:    nobody at tek.com (Kevin)
Subject: SUMMARY - Graphical Boot
**************************************************

Judging from google, a lot of folks have tried to get rid of
graphical boot and go with a text boot.  By graphical/text boot
I'm talking about the boot process that happens after one chooses
the kernel, or operating system, via lilo or grub.  I had a funny
experience with this and thought I'd share so that google will
have one more answer to go with the bizillion questions.

I've been installing Mandrake 10.0 official time and time again
so that I can automate the process as much as possible.  The
saved package list really helps; I wish the "auto install" would
work.  The last time I installed the graphical booting went away,
and I couldn't get it back.  While troubleshooting it here's what
I learned:

- I can configure the boot process to some extent via the
  "configure your system" -> "boot" -> "boot loader" sequence.
  When configuring the "boot loader" select a kernel, choose
  "modify", click "advanced" and notice the display selector.
  Setting it to "normal" will provide text boot.  Setting it to a
  frame buffer will provide a graphical boot, except...

- Between my two installs I doubled my RAM, ending up at 1GB.
  This caused the install process to default to Mandrake's
  kernel-i686-up-4GB kernel.  The previous kernel I used,
  kernel-2.6.3.7mdk only addresses 896MB of RAM; this kernel was
  installed too, but the other kernel is the default.

- As it turns out all of the kernels I have on my system
  responded as expected to my choice of a graphical boot up,
  except for the kernel-i686-up-4GB kernel.

I suppose I could build a custom kernel that would provide for
graphical boot and for my RAM size, but I think I'll just live
with the text boot.

I hope this helps someone.....

-- 
PLEASE post a SUMMARY of the answer(s) to your question(s)!
Unless otherwise noted, the statements herein reflect my personal
opinions and not those of any organization with which I may be affiliated.

------- End of Forwarded Message






From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jul  1 11:57:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Jul  1 11:57:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <2818-90696@sneakemail.com>
References: <1088690898.2277.1294.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
	<2818-90696@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <861xjv36ad.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Steve" == Steve Bonds <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com> writes:

Steve> Focus -----

Steve> Many, many cameras I've tried focus poorly.  The LCD is too
Steve> small to tell that the image is blurry, so you won't know until
Steve> you upload it to your PC, which is usually too late to
Steve> re-shoot.

Can't say for sure, but the "focus" problem could be an issue of the
auto-exposure shutter speed.  Used to be the rule of thumb was
anything under about 1/64 second (or whatever it was) shutter speed
hand-held would be blurred.  So, in low-light conditions, the camera
is going to open up the aperture (as much as possible, maybe not much)
and slow down the shutter speed, the latter having a blurring effect.
If a flash makes it not blurry, then shutter speed is your problem.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com



From publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com  Thu Jul  1 12:07:02 2004
From: publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com (Ovid)
Date: Thu Jul  1 12:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Parsing HTML with Perl
In-Reply-To: <20040701012102.11748.32408.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040701190533.42936.qmail@web60810.mail.yahoo.com>

> From: Matt Alexander <lug at phxlinux.org>
> I'm trying to use Perl to parse out "records" from an HTML page.  I'm able
> to identify the beginning of a record with the following tag:
> 
> <TABLE border=0 width=500 class='A'>
> 
> or
> 
> <TABLE border=0 width=500 class='B'>
> 
> ...but I have no obvious way to find the end of a record except by the
> next starting tag.  There could be numerous additional table tags embedded
> in a record so I can't do anything simple like this:

I'm replying to the digest, so my apologies if this has already been answered.

You may wish to check out HTML::TreeBuilder.  You can read an article about it at
http://search.cpan.org/~sburke/HTML-Tree-3.18/lib/HTML/Tree/Scanning.pod

If you feel more comfortable with procedural parsing, check out HTML::TokeParser::Simple. 
http://search.cpan.org/~ovid/HTML-TokeParser-Simple-2.2/

The trick here would be to identify your start table tag and then only identify the end of a
record when you don't have any intervening table tags to "pair" with the closing tag.  The
following is untested and should be considered pseudo-code and probably has bugs.

  use HTML::TokeParser::Simple;
  my $parser = HTML::TokeParser::Simple->new($html_doc);
  my @records = fetch_records($parser)

  sub fetch_records {
    my $parser = shift;
    my @records;
    while (my $token = $parser->get_token) {
      do { $token = $parser->fetch_token } until $token && is_start_record($token);
      my $html = '';
      while ( ! is_end_record($token) ) {
        $html .= $token->as_is;
        $token = $parser->fetch_token;
      }
      pushd @records => $html;
    }
    return @records;
  }
    
  sub is_start_record {
    my $token = shift;
    return $token->is_start_tag('table')
        && $token->return_tag('width')  == 500
        && $token->return_tag('border') == 0   # we've have problems with undef borders
        && $token->return_tag('class')  =~ /^[AB]$/;
  }

  my $TABLES == 0;
  sub is_end_record {
    my $token = shift;
    if ($token->is_start_tag('table')) {
      $TABLES++;
    }
    elsif ($token->is_end_tag('table')) {
      $TABLES--;
      return 1 unless $TABLES;
    }
    return;
  }

Cheers,
Ovid
      

=====
Silence is Evil            http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/philosophy/indexdecency.htm
Ovid                       http://www.perlmonks.org/index.pl?node_id=17000
Web Programming with Perl  http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/cgi_course/

don't  announce

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu Jul  1 13:16:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)

Subject: [PLUG] Customer Service from Hell
In-Reply-To: <80581672004C@loraksus.org>
References: <80581672004C@loraksus.org>

Karol Kulaga wrote:

>Everyone whines about spam, I get like 4, maybe 5 a week and a couple from
>Prince Mugkrubo. I haven't set up a filter because I haven't seen the need
>to. I've had this domain and email for about a year. 
>
>The main thing I do is to create a special email for each company I give my
>email address to - i.e. netflix at loraksus.org or visa at loraksus.org, as soon
>as one of these asshole companies sell my email, I kill the addy and bitch
>and moan incessantly to the company (I'm unemployed, it's fun screwing up
>the AHT of phone monkeys while eating fudge striped cookies). 
>"Don't sign up for stupid shit" is also a great way of not getting spam. 
>
>/Of course, now somebody is going to post this email on the web and I will
>get 1000s of spams a day. . . 
>
>On a side note, dlink support is about as useless as linksys but the kicker
>is that they are 24-7 and extremely fun to call when you are just about to
>pass out from consumption of massive amounts of alcohol. Vonage support is
>bloody useless, but I've ranted about that before and there isn't a need to
>repeat my angst. I've actually spoken to a couple people at dlink who
>weren't brain dead, but my experiences with linksys have always been with
>someone who would find it intellectually challenging working at burger king.
>
Who needs to sell your email address?  Can't someone just guess it?  I 
don't see how bank
numbers are safe either unless you need the correct social security 
number.  I have a lot of
spammy maillog entries, but very little actual spam.  Being unreliable 
for unknown clients
is fairly affective at stopping spam.  If people couldn't use fake or 
forged addresses, it
would be easier to filter based on source.  Lot less work and more 
accurate than content
filtering.

IM2000 would probably increase the amount of mail.  If the notifications 
of this protocol
are always safe, IM2000 could be used to reduce filtering and anti virus 
checking.  Only
allowing recipients to get an address for an attachment, instead of the 
attachment itself,
could discourage people who want to send junk anonymously.  A good 
filter system
should allow you to filter by ignoring.  The notifications could be 
timed out and auto
deleted for example.




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jul  1 13:43:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Jul  1 13:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
Message-ID: <20040701204147.GA27564@gate.kl-ic.com>

My wife and I are pretty happy with the Canon Powershot A40 we purchased
1.5 years ago.  It uses a compact flash card, and we have a PCMCIA 
adapter that fits the laptops and mounts nicely under Linux.  It is also
physically compatable with microdrives, should I ever go hog wild and
need to take 1000 pictures at once.  It uses 4 standard AA cells, either
NiMH or standard.  I carry an extra 4 batteries in the pouch, along with
an extra flash memory, and carry a car charger on trips.

The Canon takes good, sharp pictures without a lot of fuss - the focus 
is close to the pixel resolution on this 2MPix unit.  Complaints - the
autofocus results in a long "shutter lag" between pushing the button and
taking the picture.  This makes taking pictures out the window of a Shinkansen
bullet train highly problematical. :-)  Also, the power-up defaults to the
flash in dark conditions, and you have to remember to turn it off if you
don't want it.  That is more a matter of individual preference, though.

The main thing to remember about digital cameras is "take LOTS of pictures!"
Hold down that button and get three or four shots;  the only thing it 
costs you is a little sort and discard time.  

And for advice on the high end stuff, Randal Schwartz is the king of
the cameras.  Talk to him if you want to go hog wild.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From john at meissen.org  Thu Jul  1 13:46:02 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Thu Jul  1 13:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Digital Cameras
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Thu, 01 Jul 2004 12:50:02 PDT.)
             <20040701195002.10925.52194.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20040701204512.C0FB622178@john.meissen.org>

Someone already mentioned dpreview.com. Other sites to check are
  http://www.steves-digicams.com/
  http://www.imaging-resource.com/
  http://www.photo.net/
  http://www.digitalcamera-hq.com/
  http://www.computer-darkroom.com/
  http://www.dcresource.com/index.shtml

A lot depends on how much money you want to spend. I wouldn't recommend
anything below 3 megapixels.

I have a Nikon 990 that I've been using for about 4 years. It's been
very good to me. It was ~$1,000 when it was new. Now cameras like the
8 megapixel Minolta Dimage A2 are in that price range. A friend got
one and sent me a picture he took... it was stunning, and I'm now
suffering from severe envy :-P 

I also second the recommendation to get one with AA batteries and get a
set of good NiMH rechargables. My Nikon ate alkalines like butter in a
hot sun, but I'm still using the 8 NiMH's I bought 4 years ago, and
they seem to last almost forever. Quality counts, though. I've seen
cheap ones that don't last any longer than alkalines. I got mine from
Thomas Distributing (http://www.thomasdistributing.com) Their combo
(http://www.thomasdistributing.com/mhc401fs.htm) is a good deal, and
the current batteries are almost 50% more capacity than the ones I
got 4 years ago.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jul  1 14:14:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Jul  1 14:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <861xjv36ad.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <1088690898.2277.1294.camel@clark2.kosmal.net> <2818-90696@sneakemail.com>
 <861xjv36ad.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <2195-45085@sneakemail.com>

On Thu, 1 Jul 2004, Russell Senior seniorr-at-aracnet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Can't say for sure, but the "focus" problem could be an issue of the
> auto-exposure shutter speed.  Used to be the rule of thumb was anything
> under about 1/64 second (or whatever it was) shutter speed hand-held
> would be blurred.  So, in low-light conditions, the camera is going to
> open up the aperture (as much as possible, maybe not much) and slow down
> the shutter speed, the latter having a blurring effect. If a flash makes
> it not blurry, then shutter speed is your problem.

The Olympus D380 I mentioned has a fixed f/4 aperture, so I get to see
motion blur a lot.  When the background is sharp and the two people
standing close up on the left/right are blurry, it wasn't motion blur.
;-)

This camera is never out of focus unless I shoot too close (under 2' from
the camera or so.)  It has a "macro" mode that drops the aperture to f/8
and allows focus down to about 12" and makes it damn near impossible to
handhold without motion blur except in full sun...

  -- Steve

just fine.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jul  1 18:38:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jul  1 18:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407011818520.15548@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0407011051040.28296-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407011811200.17698@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407011818520.15548@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407011836270.17698@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 1 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Thu, 1 Jul 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > Uh, as far as I know, there's only one digital rangefinder camera on
> > the market (and I'm not completely sure it's even on the market yet).
>
>   If by 'rangefinder' one means a separate view window for composing the
> exposure, rather than viewing through the lens, then my 1995-vintage
> Olympus D-340L is a rangefinder-type digital camera.

That's not what's meant by "rangefinder camera".

A rangefinder is a type of camera that has a built-in device for measuring
distance based on the principles of triangulation. The photographer
focuses the camera by superimposing two slightly different views of a
scene with the rangefinder.

J.

From mcintoshrt at comcast.net  Thu Jul  1 19:09:02 2004
From: mcintoshrt at comcast.net (Robert McIntosh)
Date: Thu Jul  1 19:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 10, SMBFS Mount /etc/fstab Problem
Message-ID: <40E4C337.5040909@comcast.net>

Hi,

I upgraded from Mandrake 9.1 to 10.0 and am experiencing some difficulty 
with mounting smbfs from /etc/fstab.  Here's the error:

kernel: smbfs: mount_data version 1684370019 is not supported.

Here's my /etc/fstab:

/dev/hda3 / ext3 defaults 1 1
/dev/hda2 /boot ext3 defaults 1 2
none /dev/pts devpts mode=0620 0 0
none /mnt/cdrom supermount 
dev=/dev/hdc,fs=auto,ro,--,iocharset=iso8859-1,codepage=850,umask=0 0 0
/dev/hdd /mnt/cdrom2 auto 
umask=0,user,iocharset=iso8859-1,codepage=850,noauto,ro,exec 0 0
none /mnt/floppy supermount 
dev=/dev/fd0,fs=auto,--,iocharset=iso8859-1,sync,codepage=850,umask=0 0 0
/dev/hda1 /mnt/windows ntfs iocharset=iso8859-1,ro,umask=0 0 0
none /proc proc defaults 0 0
/dev/hda5 swap swap defaults 0 0
//spotted/finance /home/robert/mnt/SPOTTED/finance smbfs3 
credentials=/home/robert/.fsmbpassword,uid=robert 0 0
//spotted/robert /home/robert/mnt/SPOTTED/robert smbfs3 
credentials=/home/robert/.smbpassword,uid=robert 0 0

The behavior is somewhat predictable.  From bash, I can navigate around 
in the mounted directory and perform normal command-line file work, no 
problem.  Attempting to browse to it from KDE makes the system very 
unstable, produces the following error message, and will lock up:

"Window with title "file:/home/robert/mnt/SPOTTED/robert - Konqueror" is 
not responding.  This window belongs to application konqueror (PID = 
3350, hostname=localhost).

Do you wish to terminate this application?  (All unsaved data in this 
application will be lost.) "

Looking for tips and help.

Thanks!
Robert



From root at loraksus.org  Thu Jul  1 19:09:06 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Thu Jul  1 19:09:06 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407011836270.17698@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <852205216DEE@loraksus.org>

Although that is the more or less agreed upon definition, some cameras have
the "focusing" beam thingy (Patent by Microsoft Probably Pending) which
allows them to judge the distance to an object in order to properly set the
auto focus.  The distance is stored in the EXIF data as part of the picture
which also stores shutter speed, etc. The info is nice to have, but I don't
know of a camera on the market that doesn't save that data (I think some of
the earlier coolpix cameras might of have not. Or something.)

In most cases, I've seen this to be shockingly accurate (assuming the camera
is focused on the proper thing, etc, etc) and I've sometimes used it as a
measuring tape for long distances when one isn't handy for distances up to
about 70 meters. 

I would strongly recommend getting a camera that has this feature - although
it is nice to be able to disable it for weddings and other such events,
where a red / ?? grid / beam, etc is not the most desirable and shows up a
bit too well in home videos.

From bsr at spek.org  Thu Jul  1 21:51:02 2004
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Thu Jul  1 21:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <861xjv36ad.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <1088690898.2277.1294.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>	<2818-90696@sneakemail.com> <861xjv36ad.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <40E4E98C.6060906@spek.org>

Russell Senior wrote:
> Used to be the rule of thumb was
> anything under about 1/64 second (or whatever it was) shutter speed
> hand-held would be blurred.  

It's highly dependent on your focal length - the rule of thumb for hand 
held shooting that I go by (and which has served me well) is never shoot 
shutter speeds slower than 1/"focal length" rounded to the nearest 
hopefully faster shutter speed your camera supports - eg: with a 50mm 
lens don't shoot slower than 1/60 shutter, on a giant 600mm telephoto 
don't shoot slower than 1/750.

Unfortunately every not-expensive digicam that I've seen never tells you 
things like what your focal length is in a zoom situation, but they 
might exist.

--Brent



From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Thu Jul  1 22:04:02 2004
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Thu Jul  1 22:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Camera
In-Reply-To: <861xjv36ad.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <1088690898.2277.1294.camel@clark2.kosmal.net> <2818-90696@sneakemail.com> <861xjv36ad.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <291CDA8A-CBE5-11D8-BF4B-000D932AA1FC@parkrose.k12.or.us>

On Jul 1, 2004, at 11:56 AM, Russell Senior wrote:
> Used to be the rule of thumb was anything under about 1/64 second (or 
> whatever it was) shutter speed hand-held would be blurred.

I heard a variation on this as use a shutter speed that is at slowest 
the reciprocal of the focal length of the lens, the rationale being 
camera shake is more noticeable at greater magnifications, so higher 
shutter speeds are necessary to freeze that motion. 1/60 sec at 60mm, 
1/120 at 120mm, etc. Of course the numbers get skewed for non-35mm 
cameras and digital SLRs.

I just dropped the big dollars on a Nikon D70. So far, I like it.

The ~1.5X magnification over a 35mm SLR is great if you like telephoto 
shots (my 210mm acts like a 300mm now) but you lose wide-angle 
capability at the same time. That's a bummer cause you pay a lot to get 
that really wide, almost fisheye effect. Oh, and digital noise doesn't 
have nearly the same nice character as film grain.

--
Dan Young
Parkrose School District

From minndawg at gmail.com  Fri Jul  2 09:13:02 2004
From: minndawg at gmail.com (Jeremy Laforteza)
Date: Fri Jul  2 09:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Compatible Wireless PCMCIA card
Message-ID: <1fd5051a04070209043a97e079@mail.gmail.com>

Hello, 

Semi-new Linux user here wondering if any of you had any input on a
pcmcia wireless card I could purchase for my Compaq Presario laptop.
I've looked into various models and some groups say that if it's TI
based that it will not work, maybe if you're very very lucky, but if
it's Broadcom based then chances are that drivers are available. The 3
cards that I've researched and emailed manufacturers about, as well as
searched the net, say that there's nothing for Linux. I prefer
802.11g. Anyone know of any decently priced models that will work with
RH7.3 2.4.18 that I could purchase in the downtown area?

-- 
WOOOOOSAAAAA!



From griffint at pobox.com  Fri Jul  2 10:20:02 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Fri Jul  2 10:20:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Compatible Wireless PCMCIA card
In-Reply-To: <1fd5051a04070209043a97e079@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1fd5051a04070209043a97e079@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20040702171925.GA18895@aracnet.com>

On Fri, Jul 02, 2004 at 09:04:49AM -0700, Jeremy Laforteza wrote:
> Hello, 
> 
> Semi-new Linux user here wondering if any of you had any input on a
> pcmcia wireless card I could purchase for my Compaq Presario laptop.
> I've looked into various models and some groups say that if it's TI
> based that it will not work, maybe if you're very very lucky, but if
> it's Broadcom based then chances are that drivers are available. The 3
> cards that I've researched and emailed manufacturers about, as well as
> searched the net, say that there's nothing for Linux. I prefer
> 802.11g. Anyone know of any decently priced models that will work with
> RH7.3 2.4.18 that I could purchase in the downtown area?
>

There are Linux TI drivers in the works (acx100.sourceforge.net) but
the driver is still pretty immature. So it's probably best to continue
avoiding TI chips for now.

One thing to watch out for is D-Link cards. D-Link has a nasty habit
of replacing the guts of their product without changing the model number
that's printed on the box. The DWL-G650 for example, which I was
investigating just moments ago, has used at least two and maybe three
different chipsets, the Prism GT, the TI ACX100, and some Atheros chipset.

D-Link did the same with the DWL-650 (no 'G'). We were trying to get one
working at the last PLUG monthly clinic. It was some new varient. We
never did figure out what was inside.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jul  2 10:53:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] Compatible Wireless PCMCIA card
In-Reply-To: <20040702171925.GA18895@aracnet.com>

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407021049050.19298@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 2 Jul 2004, Terry Griffin wrote:

> There are Linux TI drivers in the works (acx100.sourceforge.net) but
> the driver is still pretty immature. So it's probably best to continue
> avoiding TI chips for now.

  The 3Com 3CRWE154G72 is a Prism54 card that does b and g. It does work
with my Slackware-9.1/2.4.24 system. According to the folks at EmperorLinux
it is even easier to get it working on the Red Hat flavors.

  Whether or not it's available locally I've no idea.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul  2 11:09:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Fri Jul  2 11:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] IP header compression...  RESOLVED
In-Reply-To: <40E4780C.1020003@robinson-west.com>
References: <83D2B3744A9C@loraksus.org> <40E4780C.1020003@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <40E5A1F8.9040102@robinson-west.com>

Michael Robinson wrote:

> Karol Kulaga wrote:
>
>> http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc1144.html
>>
>>
>>
>> _______________________________________________
>> PLUG mailing list
>> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>>  
>>
> Thank you.  Wow, looks kinda tricky.  Seems like there are
> a lot of assumptions about what won't change.  It might have
> been easier to implement another protocol and generate a
> tcp/ip stream at the destination.
>
> Hopefully, ip header compression is the only thing special that
> XP uses to connect.  I want to know if XP is using pap or chap
> though.  It appears that wvdial can handle that though.
>
> Well, the RFC says 1990, I know that 6.2 isn't that old.
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Resolved.  It wan't needing header compression after all.  Turns out,
wvdial's config file shouldn't have had extra spacing on the username
and password lines.  I also used quotes.

Thanks for the help though ;-)

     --  Michael Robinson

From gepr at tempusdictum.com  Fri Jul  2 13:17:02 2004
From: gepr at tempusdictum.com (gepr at tempusdictum.com)
Date: Fri Jul  2 13:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] C++ & Fortran Programmers Wanted
Message-ID: <16613.49664.860209.749952@eris.dischordia.net>

... for marketing research.

Just a note on this thread started by Ron awhile back....

I didn't go to the C++ and Fortran product test they wanted; but,
they called me for a different one and I went.

The person at Intel who conducted the test suggested to me that Linux
users are scarce in the Pacific Northwest.  I was shocked.  She
defended the statement by saying that they can't seem to get linux
users to come in to give them feedback.

It was a very pleasant experience and they NEED feedback from 
open source types, given what I saw... plus you get some pocket
change for going in.

Further, she wants people who talk alot and have opinions about
software, how it should be, what it should do, etc.... So, I encourage
you guys to subject yourselves to it.  I think giving them feedback
about how to build software we like will help us in the long run (even
if we have to be video taped and have strange Intel people examining
our mannerisms ;-).

Message-ID: <16613.52759.791789.793157@eris.dischordia.net>

Rich Shepard writes:
 > On Fri, 2 Jul 2004 gepr at tempusdictum.com wrote:
 > 
 > > She defended the statement by saying that they can't seem to get linux
 > > users to come in to give them feedback.
 > 
 >   And this from a marketing person? If you have tools that meet your needs
 > available to you at no cost why would you want to go out and spend a lot of
 > money on replacements? Did you offer her a clue card?

Well, technically, I don't know if she's a marketing person.  She
conducted the interview/test/whatevery-you-call-it.  For all I know,
she's a primate scientist studying how well we respond to working in
cubicles.

One might buy a replacement for their extant tools for any number of
reasons.  Tech support, the ability to blame someone else for
something, because your boss told you to, because your company made a
deal with Intel, because you have to get rid of your extra budget this
fiscal year or else next year's will be smaller, or because someone on
your board of directors doesn't believe in open source tools, etc.
Who knows?

In any case, I'll gladly use whatever works, money or not.  It just
so happens that the open source stuff works most of the time.

 > > It was a very pleasant experience and they NEED feedback from open source
 > > types, given what I saw... plus you get some pocket change for going in.
 > 
 >   Why do they need the feedback? For the benefit of ...?

So they can learn what it takes to make software that meets our
standards.  Either way you cut it, even if they use the feedback to
make better software that they sell, then it's still better software.
Or, perhaps, since they're a hardware company, they'll commit more
resources to building open source software.

But it benefits _us_ (and PLUG, specifically) to convince others to 
think like us.  Spread the word... advocate... all that hooha.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jul  2 14:17:05 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jul  2 14:17:05 2004
Subject: [PLUG] C++ & Fortran Programmers Wanted
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407021326220.19741@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <16613.49664.860209.749952@eris.dischordia.net>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407021326220.19741@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0407021353320.11745@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 2 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>> She defended the statement by saying that they can't seem to get 
>> linux users to come in to give them feedback.
>
>  And this from a marketing person? If you have tools that meet your 
> needs available to you at no cost why would you want to go out and 
> spend a lot of money on replacements? Did you offer her a clue card?

Intel has been uneven in its support of Linux, but it's contributed a 
bunch of code to the kernel. Some of it is support for Intel hardware 
(e100, e1000, and IA64 stuff), but Intel also contributed a bunch of 
the ethernet-bonding code and a smaller amount of ethtool code. Intel 
has also been the prime mover in getting a reference implementation of 
the Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) into the kernel.

It also recently announced that the next generation of Intel BIOS code 
will be released under an open-source license.

I think it's a good step if Intel is actively doing Linux Q/A on new 
products, hardware or software. I think that's what we *want* 
commercial companies to be doing. I, for one, am glad when companies 
like AMD, Sun, NetworkAppliance, Intel, etc. treat Linux as a serious 
platform.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From aaron at ultravolt.net  Fri Jul  2 20:07:01 2004
From: aaron at ultravolt.net (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Fri Jul  2 20:07:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Software RAID autodection problem
Message-ID: <45563.127.0.0.1.1088823965.squirrel@www.ultravolt.net>

I?m dabbling in software RAID 0, and found some enlightening howtos to get
me started, but I?m having a problem with the autodetection process. I
managed to find one reference to the problem on google and it didn?t help
me much. I?m hoping someone can point me in the right direction. Here?s
the kernel message output:

md: md driver 0.90.0 MAX_MD_DEVS=256, MD_SB_DISKS=27
md: Autodetecting RAID arrays.
 [events: 00000002]
 [events: 00000002]
md: autorun ...
md: considering hdc1 ...
md:  adding hdc1 ...
md:  adding hdb1 ...
md: created md0
md: bind<hdb1,1>
md: bind<hdc1,2>
md: running: <hdc1><hdb1>
md: hdc1's event counter: 00000002
md: hdb1's event counter: 00000002
kmod: failed to exec /sbin/modprobe -s -k md-personality-2, errno = 2
md: personality 2 is not loaded!
md :do_md_run() returned -22
md: md0 stopped.
md: unbind<hdc1,1>
md: export_rdev(hdc1)
md: unbind<hdb1,0>
md: export_rdev(hdb1)
md: ... autorun DONE.


I can bring the array up fine manually, but for some reason during boot
that strange personality error comes up and it stops md0. I'm running
CentOS 3.1, and my /etc/raidtab file looks like this:

# cat /etc/raidtab
raiddev /dev/md0
raid-level 0
        nr-raid-disks   2
        persistent-superblock   1
        chunk-size      64
        device  /dev/hdb1
        raid-disk       0
        device  /dev/hdc1
        raid-disk       1


TIA!

Aaron

From ehem at m5p.com  Sat Jul  3 13:19:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sat Jul  3 13:19:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Software RAID autodection problem
In-Reply-To: <20040703134320.28454.79680.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200407032018.i63KILmM068885@m5p.com>

>From: "Aaron Ten Clay" <aaron at ultravolt.net>
> I?m dabbling in software RAID 0, and found some enlightening howtos to get
> me started, but I?m having a problem with the autodetection process. I
> managed to find one reference to the problem on google and it didn?t help
> me much. I?m hoping someone can point me in the right direction. Here?s
> the kernel message output:

> kmod: failed to exec /sbin/modprobe -s -k md-personality-2, errno = 2
> md: personality 2 is not loaded!
> md :do_md_run() returned -22
> md: md0 stopped.

> I can bring the array up fine manually, but for some reason during boot
> that strange personality error comes up and it stops md0. I'm running
> CentOS 3.1, and my /etc/raidtab file looks like this:
> 
> # cat /etc/raidtab
> raiddev /dev/md0
> raid-level 0
>         nr-raid-disks   2

This sounds like you've built the RAID-0 support as a module and your
kernel doesn't have initrd support. At boot time it attempts to load the
devices, but kernel modules aren't available so it can't deal with it.

So either make use of an initrd, or rebuild your kernel with the RAID-0
support built in.


--

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jul  3 18:49:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] Setting up Wireless-G Access Point

  This must look like a broken record. But, I cannot get to the setup page
for the new (arrived yesterday afternoon) Linksys WAP54G. The default IP
address is 192.168.1.254.

  I connected the unit to my notebook with a regular cat5 cable, set eth0:1
on the notebook to 192.168.1.128, and tried pinging the WAP's IP address as
well as loading the Web page. No luck. "Destination Host Unreachable".

  Reset and power cycled the unit. Same results.

  Tried eth0:1 IP addresses of 192.168.1.28 and 192.168.1.208. Same results.

  Removed the regular cable and tried a cross-over cable. Same results.

  Put the WAP on the wireline switch and tried from the notebook. Same
results.

  Go into the den, fire up the ThinkPad and log in: I can ping other hosts
on the LAN as well as external hosts. Ergo, the WAP is working. But, I
cannot configure it.

  Would someone _please_ explain to me what step I've missed here? I want to
set the WAP up with some level of security and know that I can access the
admin page when I want to do so.

  That I have wireless access from a portable but cannot get to the admin
page puzzles and frustrates me. It is beyond my knowledge to know why
there's a problem and what to do about it.

Thanks,

Rich

Just a question.  Which port are you trying to reach the admin page
from?  You need to be on a port that is on the inside net side of your
device.  Cannot come through the device to the internal net.

Ken
CAD2CAM.COM

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Jul  3 20:30:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Jul  3 20:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up Wireless-G Access Point
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407032005140.25250@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407031836480.24990@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <1088906514.7997.20.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407032005140.25250@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407032025100.17698@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 3 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sat, 3 Jul 2004, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:
> > Just a question. Which port are you trying to reach the admin page from?
> > You need to be on a port that is on the inside net side of your device.
> > Cannot come through the device to the internal net.
>
>   Which port? I've no idea. All 192.168/16 are internal. My LAN sub-net
> is 192.168.55/24, that's why I added the 192.168.1/24 sub-net to eth0 on
> my notebook.

When Ken asks "which port", he is asking which physical port on the
Linksys box.  Presumably, this is one of those standard jobs that has a
"WAN" or "broadband" port and (usually) four standard ethernet ports in
addition to the WAN ethernet port.

He is guessing that you can't get to the admin interface through the WAN
port (this is the default configuration for most of those devices).

You wrote earlier that the AP was working... did you try to get to the
admin interface from the wireless connected machine (i.e., the Thinkpad in
the den)?

Also, you might want to see if there's a small documentation problem and
maybe the admin interface defaults to 192.168.1.1 or something.

You could even do something like this:

for a in `seq 1-254`; do ping -c 1 192.168.1.$a; done

Of course, that assumes the thing will respond to a ping on the admin
interface.

As a more general question, is it possible to view the equivalent of the
arp table for a wireless connection?  Or is it all broadcast?

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

> Linksys box.  Presumably, this is one of those standard jobs that has a
> "WAN" or "broadband" port and (usually) four standard ethernet ports in
> addition to the WAN ethernet port.

  No. This is strictly an access point: no hub, no switch, no router. There
are two sockets on the back: one RJ-45 for the network connection to a
switch/hub and one power connection. The BEFW11S4 is a Leatherman(R)-tool
type unit: 4-port hub, WiFi access point, Internet router.

> You wrote earlier that the AP was working... did you try to get to the
> admin interface from the wireless connected machine (i.e., the Thinkpad in
> the den)?

  No. Good idea. I'll try that.

> maybe the admin interface defaults to 192.168.1.1 or something.

interface is assigned the default IP address of 192.168.1.254.

> for a in `seq 1-254`; do ping -c 1 192.168.1.$a; done
>
> Of course, that assumes the thing will respond to a ping on the admin
> interface.

  The other units did so I suspect that this one will, too.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sun Jul  4 12:25:03 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sun Jul  4 12:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up Wireless-G Access Point
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407040825330.7565@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407031836480.24990@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1088906514.7997.20.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407032005140.25250@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407032025100.17698@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407040825330.7565@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1088969071.22382.59.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sun, 2004-07-04 at 08:30 -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> This is strictly an access point: no hub, no switch, no router. 

If it is strictly an access point, then it isn't going to bridge your
wireless and wired networks together, which I think is what you want.

All an access point does is connect wireless computers together - think
of it like a switch for wireless networks.

Most of the time, access points with ethernet ports are also wired-
wireless bridges, but not always, I think.  You might google up the
specs for yours and see what it is...

-- 
Rob                                |  If not safe,
   Jabber: athlonrob at axpr.net   |    one can never be free.

Just curious.

Dale



On Sunday 04 July 2004 08:30 am, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sat, 3 Jul 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > When Ken asks "which port", he is asking which physical port on the
> > Linksys box.  Presumably, this is one of those standard jobs that has a
> > "WAN" or "broadband" port and (usually) four standard ethernet ports in
> > addition to the WAN ethernet port.
>
>   No. This is strictly an access point: no hub, no switch, no router. There
> are two sockets on the back: one RJ-45 for the network connection to a
> switch/hub and one power connection. The BEFW11S4 is a Leatherman(R)-tool
> type unit: 4-port hub, WiFi access point, Internet router.
>
> > You wrote earlier that the AP was working... did you try to get to the
> > admin interface from the wireless connected machine (i.e., the Thinkpad
> > in the den)?
>
>   No. Good idea. I'll try that.
>
> > Also, you might want to see if there's a small documentation problem and
> > maybe the admin interface defaults to 192.168.1.1 or something.
>
>   Both the printed sheet and the embedded pdf manual state that the admin
> interface is assigned the default IP address of 192.168.1.254.
>
> > for a in `seq 1-254`; do ping -c 1 192.168.1.$a; done
> >
> > Of course, that assumes the thing will respond to a ping on the admin
> > interface.
>
>   The other units did so I suspect that this one will, too.
>
> Rich



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jul  4 14:30:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Jul  4 14:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up Wireless-G Access Point
In-Reply-To: <200407041418.50914.dale@zeutenhorst.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407031836480.24990@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407032025100.17698@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407040825330.7565@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <200407041418.50914.dale@zeutenhorst.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407041422290.8624@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 4 Jul 2004, Dale Zeutenhorst wrote:

> When you plugged the laptop in to the wureless hub, were you----
>  - using a standard cable to go between your wireless hub and your laptop?
>  - or did you plug the laptop in to your switch and then the switch in to the
> wireless hub?
>  - or were you plugged your laptop in to it, were you using a cross-over
> cable?

Dale,

  Yes.

  All of the above.

  My original message yesterday laid out the tests I ran: notebook->wap via
regular cat5, notebook->wap via cross-over cat5; notebook->wap via lan.
Access attempts via 192.168.1/24 subnet and my network subnet.

  When the intermittent BEFW11S4s were working I could ping them from any
host (naturally) and I could access the admin page from the same subnet to
change its IP address so it was reachable from any host on the lan.

  I see the lights flicker now and then on the WAP, but that's not when any
host (here) is accessing it wirelessly. So there is communications at some
level; that's why mozilla returns "connection refused" sometimes.

  Aggrevating the problem is that Linksys will provide no support for any
network OS other than a flavor out of Redmond.

Rich

On Sun, 2004-07-04 at 13:49 -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   The latter is just what the wap54g does. I have difficulty generating a
> mental image of how a wireless access points works without being tied to a
> network. After all, it is a point of access to ... the network. No?

An access point essentially provides the infrastructure to create a
wireless network - it doesn't require a wired network (although most of
the time a wired network will be connected to the wireless network
somehow).

>   Anyway, that's what it's designed to do. See the attached .ps. I don't
> know how to get firefox to print a landscape-oriented file so the right side
> is truncated. But those missig images are of cat5- and USB-connected hosts
> on the LAN.

The file didn't come through - but that's a good thing.  You shouldn't
send attachments, especially ones as large as postscript prints usually
are, over mailing lists... post 'em on the web and send a URL to the
list.  :-)

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jul  4 15:20:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Jul  4 15:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up Wireless-G Access Point
In-Reply-To: <1088978304.22380.62.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407031836480.24990@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
 <1088906514.7997.20.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407032005140.25250@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407032025100.17698@shaft.bitmine.net> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407040825330.7565@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
 <1088969071.22382.59.camel@dell.linux.box>  <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407041344560.8624@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <1088978304.22380.62.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407041500030.8989@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 4 Jul 2004, AthlonRob wrote:

> An access point essentially provides the infrastructure to create a
> wireless network - it doesn't require a wired network (although most of
> the time a wired network will be connected to the wireless network
> somehow).

  Well, not to pick nits, Rob, but it has to provide access to _something_.

  Anyway, I took desparate measures ... and they worked! In addition to
describing what I did I'll add my interpretation of why it took these
machinations to get results.

  1.) Fire up VMware. Load supplied cd-rom disk in drive. Wait for autorun
to kick in.

  2.) Up comes the WAP54G setup wizard! I change the IP address to one
that's on my subnet and save the settings. Hoo-ha!

  3.) Try to access the WAP54G using firefox-0.8 on a workstation; won't
accept the default password ("admin"). Hmmm-m-m-m. Fire up opera and point
it to the same IP address. _Now_ it accepts the default password. Change the
password and save the settings. I'm shown that the settings are saved, but I
cannot return to the setup pages (using the "Continue" button). I assume
that's because I need to log in again using the new password.

  4.) Go pack to the virtual desktop running firefox, point it to the new IP
address, leave the username field empty and enter the new password. Et
voila! I'm there!

  5.) Add the two MACs and specify the unit is to allow access from only
those numbers, disable the SSID broadcast and save things.

  Whew! My take on this soggy saga is that the damned unit is hardwired to
work _only_ with Microsoft OSes and browsers. That's why I could not access
it using anything on linux until I changed the IP address to the local
subnet by running the supplied setup application on the virtual win98. And,
in my situation, firefox identifies itself as firefox while opera identifies
itself as IE<something>. I belive that's why I could initially access the
WAP's admin pages using what it thought was a jen-you-whine Microsoft
browser. Once the password was reset it didn't matter any longer.
Considering that Linksys notes on it's home page that its drivers are open
sourced, you'd think they'd make it easier for us to get to the darn
hardware.

  So, back to business: do I add a WEP key (or a key for one of the other
encryption schemes it supports?

Thanks, all of you,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jul  4 16:25:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Jul  4 16:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WiFi -- almost there!
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407041618420.8989@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I figured out how to work the two interfaces on my Sony when the WiFi card
is plugged in and the cat5 cable is not. I can now ping the local network
hosts, but I cannot ping externally.

  I added a default route using 'route -add' and both 'route -n' and 'netstat
-rn' show the gateway for both eth0 and eth1. As an interesting aside, I see
that ifconfig shows both interfaces up, but only eth1 is running.

  So, the wifi interface (eth1) is up, it has a route and gateway, and I can
navigate wirelessly around the internal lan but not externally. As the
gateway is the same for both interfaces and I have no problems with the
wireline connection I'm puzzled why there's a problem with the wireless.

  On the IBM the wifi interface is working just fine both internally and
externally.

  You folks have been fabulously helpful with this entire sorry mess. I have
one small step left to take: wifi connection to the 'Net. Suggestions
greatly appreciated.

TIA,

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jul  4 17:34:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Jul  4 17:34:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on IBM ThinkPad 600E
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407041713170.9182@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I need to get the sound running on my finacee's ThinkPad 600E. RealPlayer
works fine, but it's silent.

  According to a couple of google sites, one of which references the other,
the proper driver is cs4232. So, I added that to /etc/modules.conf and told
/etc/rc.d/rc.local to load it upon boot, then I manually loaded it with
modprobe. But, no sound. Also, there's no aumix on that box -- if that makes
any difference.

  One site I mentioned above got it working running Slackware-9.1; same
distribution I installed on the ThinkPad. What I don't know is what else he
has installed that I don't 'cause it ain't workin' here.

  Following found on a SuSE Web site:

# Sound chipset: Multimedia audio controller: Cirrus Logic CS 4610 (rev 01)
# Works with the kernel driver for cs4232 in the emulation mode. No special
settings are necessary to achieve the emulation mode.
# One needs the following lines in /etc/conf.modules

alias char-major-14 cs4232
options cs4232 io=0x530 irq=5 dma=1 dma2=0

to get wav and mp3 file playing working. The driver will not survive an APM
suspend / resume, reload it after an suspend / resume.
# Quality of sound is even better than on my desktop PC.

ALSA of 6.4 (0.5.5+) works with the following modules.conf entries:

alias char-major-14      soundcore
alias char-major-116     snd
alias snd-card-0         snd-card-cs4236
alias sound-slot-0       snd-card-0
alias sound-service-0-0  snd-mixer-oss
alias sound-service-0-1  snd-seq-oss
alias sound-service-0-3  snd-pcm-oss
alias sound-service-0-8  snd-seq-oss
alias sound-service-0-12 snd-pcm-oss

options snd snd_major=116 snd_cards_limit=1
options snd-card-cs4236 snd_index=0 snd_port=0x530 snd_cport=0x538 snd_irq=5
snd_dma1=1 snd_dma2=0 snd_isapnp=0

post-install snd amixer set Master 100% unmute;amixer set PCM 100% unmute;
amixer set Aux,1 100% unmute

Aux,1 is the Channel for CD-in, APM suspend / resume support for the
Thinkpad will be included in future ALSA releases.
Currently do an rcalsasound restart after an suspend / resume cycle.

After editing /etc/modules.conf, be sure to do an depmod -a and then, if you
use ALSA, run rcalsasound restart to load the ALSA driver.
To test ALSA, you can run
aplay /usr/share/sounds/alsa/whistle.au

or

aplay /usr/share/sounds/wav/applause.wav

if you installed the snd_wav package. If you use alsa, you can use alsamixer
and gamix to setup the channels.

  Do I need alsa as well as the cs4232?

Thanks, folks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

Subject: [PLUG] SCO IP license
Message-ID: <20040705070115.565.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>

This text appears on SCO's Web site. For just
$700/seat, you can have McBride's blessing for your
Linux server!

"Many customers are concerned about using Linux since
they have become aware of the allegations that Linux
is an unauthorized derivative work of the UNIX?
operating system. These customers unknowingly received
illegal copies of SCO property and many are running
critical business applications on Linux. Some
customers have asked their Linux distributors to
indemnify them against intellectual property
infringement claims in Linux. Due to the limitations
of the GPL and lack of adequate IP controls in Linux,
such customers have been unable to obtain satisfactory
assurances, whether through adequate indemnification
programs or otherwise, from distributors that their
use of Linux will not cause them exposure to liability
for this use.

SCO has an obligation to stockholders, customers and
employees to protect the value of its assets. SCO is
also sympathetic to the end-user?s predicament. SCO
has determined that it can accommodate both conditions
by offering a license that cures the IP infringement
in Linux. This new license is called "SCO Intellectual
Property License for Linux" and applies to commercial
use of the Linux 2.4 and later versions. The license
insures that Linux end users can continue to run their
business uninterrupted without misusing SCO's
Intellectual Property. 

End users who purchase this license are granted the
right to use the SCO IP in Linux in binary format
only. The license is available immediately and can be
purchased by credit card through our online store.



=====

From brian at brianquade.net  Mon Jul  5 05:50:02 2004
From: brian at brianquade.net (Brian Quade)
Date: Mon Jul  5 05:50:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] halt doesn't work with certain distros
Message-ID: <40E94E47.5020802@brianquade.net>

I have a server with no monitor so I usually use halt (or shutdown -h) 
to shut it down when I need to.  It shuts down fine with Red Hat 9 and 
Fedora Core 2, but with debian 3.0r2 and slackware 10.0, the hard drives 
sound like they power down but the power supply fan keeps running.  Even 
if I press the power button, it won't shut down (but it does with Red 
Hat and Fedora).  The only way to completely power the machine down 
after running debian and slackware is to hit the reset button and then 
the power button and the whole machine powers down.  I thought it might 
be something in my BIOS power management, but nothing I change in there 
seems to work and Red Hat halt the machine no matter how my BIOS is set 
up.  Does anyone know what the difference could be or how to make this 
work with the GNU distros?

setup a newer verson 2.x of the WAP54G a few weeks ago for an apartment 
and that I stay at when I need to be at my company's headquaters and the

point. I wish I could get my company to pay for VMWare so I didn't have 
to dual boot. Since the laptop isn't mine I'm not going to spend my own 
money outside of the SuSE distro to get the thing to run Linux.

firewalling but it does provide WPA security using either TKIP or AES 
encryption  that works well with both Linux via the "wpa_supplicant" 
daemon or under WinXP.

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jul  5 10:25:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jul  5 10:25:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] halt doesn't work with certain distros
In-Reply-To: <40E94E47.5020802@brianquade.net>
References: <40E94E47.5020802@brianquade.net>
Message-ID: <1089048283.1131.9.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2004-07-05 at 05:49, Brian Quade wrote:
> I have a server with no monitor so I usually use halt (or shutdown -h) 
> to shut it down when I need to.  It shuts down fine with Red Hat 9 and 
> Fedora Core 2, but with debian 3.0r2 and slackware 10.0, the hard drives 
> sound like they power down but the power supply fan keeps running.  Even 
> if I press the power button, it won't shut down (but it does with Red 
> Hat and Fedora).

Hold the power button in for 10 to 15 seconds.

>   The only way to completely power the machine down 
> after running debian and slackware is to hit the reset button and then 
> the power button and the whole machine powers down.  I thought it might 
> be something in my BIOS power management, but nothing I change in there 
> seems to work and Red Hat halt the machine no matter how my BIOS is set 
> up.  Does anyone know what the difference could be or how to make this 
> work with the GNU distros?

You probably need to change kernels, I always compile mine from source,
so I don't have a recommendation.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree




From ehem at m5p.com  Mon Jul  5 13:31:01 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Mon Jul  5 13:31:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] halt doesn't work with certain distros
In-Reply-To: <20040705134232.28533.73277.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200407052030.i65KULb2023316@m5p.com>

> 
> --__--__--
> 
> Message: 1
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] Setting up Wireless-G Access Point
>From: Brian Quade <brian at brianquade.net>
> I have a server with no monitor so I usually use halt (or shutdown -h) 
> to shut it down when I need to.  It shuts down fine with Red Hat 9 and 
> Fedora Core 2, but with debian 3.0r2 and slackware 10.0, the hard drives 
> sound like they power down but the power supply fan keeps running.  Even 
> if I press the power button, it won't shut down (but it does with Red 
> Hat and Fedora).  The only way to completely power the machine down 
> after running debian and slackware is to hit the reset button and then 
> the power button and the whole machine powers down.  I thought it might 
> be something in my BIOS power management, but nothing I change in there 
> seems to work and Red Hat halt the machine no matter how my BIOS is set 
> up.  Does anyone know what the difference could be or how to make this 
> work with the GNU distros?

Doing a `modprobe apm` and then running halt /might/ do it. One of the
other kernels Debian offers might have APM built in and be able to do the
soft power off on halt. Otherwise you'll need to build a kernel with APM
or ACPI built into the kernel.


--

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul  5 13:43:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jul  5 13:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] halt doesn't work with certain distros
In-Reply-To: <200407052030.i65KULb2023316@m5p.com>
References: <200407052030.i65KULb2023316@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051338230.12953@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 5 Jul 2004, Elliott Mitchell wrote:

> Doing a `modprobe apm` and then running halt /might/ do it. One of the
> other kernels Debian offers might have APM built in and be able to do the
> soft power off on halt. Otherwise you'll need to build a kernel with APM
> or ACPI built into the kernel.

  I believe some motherboards require that the power switch be held a long
time regardless of whether or not apm is available. The portables shut
themselves down (one with apm the other with acpi), but the workstations
don't. On the newest one (running Slackware-9.1) the message is 'system
halted', but I need to hold in the power switch for quite a few seconds
(haven't timed it but it seems like a long time) before it shuts off. For as
infrequently as these machines are turned off it's no big deal. I'd think a
server would be up almost always so it should be a non-issue.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul  5 14:57:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jul  5 14:57:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring Netgear FVS318
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051445380.12953@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I just spent a few minutes setting up and configuring my new Netgear
FVS318 firewall/VPN/Barista. It seems too simple! So I would appreciate a
sanity check before I try putting it online to replace the venerable
floppyfw here.

  First, I've no use for the VPN features as I have no other office(s) so I
leave that blank. Similarly, I have no desire to block either of us from
anything on the nasty ol' 'Net so I left that blank, too.

  Second, for incoming services, I assume that I can delete everything but
smtp and dns since I do not run either publicly-available ftp or http
servers. I suppose that leaving them in place exposes me to exploits, just
as if I had them set up in the floppyfw.

  I entered my static, external IP address as well as my ISPs gateway IP
address and netmask. For dns servers I entered the local IP address of my
caching dns here followed by my ISP's #1 dns server.

  After changing the default IP address and password for the box I think
that I did all that needs to be done. Anything obvious that I missed?

  BTW, as soon as this goes live I'll have a floppyfw box (motherboard --
Pentium MMX/200MHz, I believe --, 2 NICs, 2M video card, floppy drive and
64M mixed mode RAM, along with the 14" monitor and keyboard that I'll give
to anyone who wants a firewall. It's served me very well since 1 June 1999
(when they turned on the dsl here) but I can use the space under the desk to
store more dust and dog fur and it will remove one power supply/UPS from the
electrical consumption. Well, I'll keep the UPS for the dsl modem/firewall
appliance.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From aaron at bavariati.org  Mon Jul  5 16:19:01 2004

On Mon, Jul 05, 2004 at 05:49:11AM -0700, Brian Quade wrote:

> to shut it down when I need to.  It shuts down fine with Red Hat 9 and 
> Fedora Core 2, but with debian 3.0r2 and slackware 10.0, the hard drives

I normally install apmd or acpid to enable soft power-off.  If it
installs right, you can hit the power button on the box to start a safe
power-off.  Great for non-technical users.

Keith,

  I have only very infrequent use for a CAD program so I've not followed it
lately. However, there was one (whose name I forget) that was a CAD
language, similar to using Gri for scientific plotting or the R statistical
system.

  Anyway, stay away from LinuxCAD. It's a rip-off. Well, at least it was a
rip-off 5+ years ago so I won't slander it directly. But I looked at it and
was very unhappy.

  According to the WineHQ application database, AutoCAD runs on the latest
wine; I don't know how well.

  Cycas <http://www.cycas.de/> looks like it's free for non-commercial use,
but in a limited ability version.

  Given all this, if I needed/wanted a CAD program for furniture design I'd
grab a copy of QCAD <http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue54/frost.html>. It's
gpl'd and looks like it would do just fine. Actually, if I ever again have
time for a life outside of work I might just get a copy for furniture
design.

Rich

From kevinc at doink.COM  Mon Jul  5 17:27:02 2004
From: kevinc at doink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Mon Jul  5 17:27:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: SOLUTION -- NFS rpm installation as ROOT
In-Reply-To: <20040630165341.3AF8E8F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com> 
Message-ID: <20040706002633.0F228406B@joseph.doink.com>

On 30 June 2004 at 9:53, Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:

> Do the local and remote md5sums match?

The md5sum of any rpm in question (at least the handful I tested) 
matched regardless of which machine was performing the md5sum.  When
/bin/rpm got into the act the signatures would be bad on the machine 
accessing the RPM via NFS.  I would get this error message:

error: Par-1.50-1_4kc.i586.rpm: rpmReadSignature failed: region trailer: BAD, ta
g 61 type 7 offset 64 count 16

Resigning the RPMs on the machine where the RPMs reside on a local 
disk solved the above problem for the remote machine.  root can now 
install those RPMs via NFS.

Cheers....





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul  5 17:44:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jul  5 17:44:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring Netgear FVS318
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051445380.12953@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051445380.12953@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

>   After changing the default IP address and password for the box I think
> that I did all that needs to be done. Anything obvious that I missed?

  I need to add SSH. I specify port 22 for beginning and ending ports,
correct? Is there a need to specify a port > 1024 for the other direction? I
cannot find anything that suggests SSH uses UDP at all. Do I set up that
port for TCP only?

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jul  5 18:06:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Jul  5 18:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: SOLUTION -- NFS rpm installation as ROOT
In-Reply-To: <20040706002633.0F228406B@joseph.doink.com>
References: <20040706002633.0F228406B@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <1089075906.16563.3.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Mon, 2004-07-05 at 17:26, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:

> The md5sum of any rpm in question (at least the handful I tested) 
> matched regardless of which machine was performing the md5sum.  When
> /bin/rpm got into the act the signatures would be bad on the machine 
> accessing the RPM via NFS.  I would get this error message:
> 
> error: Par-1.50-1_4kc.i586.rpm: rpmReadSignature failed: region trailer: BAD, ta
> g 61 type 7 offset 64 count 16
> 
> Resigning the RPMs on the machine where the RPMs reside on a local 
> disk solved the above problem for the remote machine.  root can now 
> install those RPMs via NFS.

You have only corrected the symptom, not fixed the problem.  There's
clearly something wrong with the NFS implementation.  RPM managed to
prevent it from doing damage by checking its RPMs; you may not be
fortunate with files that do not have built-in check-sums.  I would
recommend at the very least you take great care in transferring files
over the mount.  Then again, if md5sum works correctly, maybe RPM is
doing something unexpected or unsupported with NFS (it could be a
locking issue; I would expect RPM to try to lock the files whereas
md5sum wouldn't).

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From lug at phxlinux.org  Mon Jul  5 18:42:01 2004
From: lug at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon Jul  5 18:42:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring Netgear FVS318
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051740360.13723@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051445380.12953@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051740360.13723@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407051836140.18070@neon.netpro.to>

On Mon, 5 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I need to add SSH. I specify port 22 for beginning and ending ports,
> correct? Is there a need to specify a port > 1024 for the other direction? I
> cannot find anything that suggests SSH uses UDP at all. Do I set up that
> port for TCP only?

If you're running an SSH server on the inside of your firewall that you
want to access from outside the firewall, then yes, open port 22/TCP and
give it the IP address of your internal SSH server.  You shouldn't have to
worry about configuring anything that initiates a connection from the
inside to the outside.
~M





From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jul  5 19:18:02 2004

>that I did all that needs to be done. Anything obvious that I missed?
>
>  BTW, as soon as this goes live I'll have a floppyfw box (motherboard --
>Pentium MMX/200MHz, I believe --, 2 NICs, 2M video card, floppy drive and
>64M mixed mode RAM, along with the 14" monitor and keyboard that I'll give

>(when they turned on the dsl here) but I can use the space under the desk to

>

Rich,

We ran an FVS318  box in our office for a number of months until we 
outgrew the limited number of VPN tunnels it supported. I will say that 
the VPN support was pretty good and we had VPN tunnels with other FVS318 
appliances, OpenBSD "isakmpd", and FreeS/WAN under Linux. Unless you're 
allowing external access to any services on systems hosted inside the 
LAN side of the firewall there's not really a whole lot to configure on 
this box and so "yes it is that simple". About the only issue we've had 
with these boxes is with Dynamic DNS. It seems that many router 
appliances are poorly behaved in this area and I've had cases where 
DynDNS.org has deleted several of our host names because of repeated 
updates by the FVS318. We were told that we should be running at least 
version 2.3 of the FVS318 firmware by support personnel at DynDNS.org.

I also just setup one of these FVS318 boxes for my apartment near my 
company's headquarters. I like it that it has no fans or disk drives so 
it's totally quiet. and it also gives me a VPN tunnel into the office 
when I need it.  I know this is a Linux message list but the Netgear 
FVS318 is a nice appliance that has an easy to use web-based interface 
and the box just plain works without a whole lot of fuss IMHO.

Tony

 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net
