I tried it 2 years ago and it was worse than a rip-off, I found it to be a 
sham operation - there are 'agreements' not to diss the product and 
statements that it is 'sold as is' (translation: "Congrats, sucker!") all 
stored ONLY on the CD (which means you have to have already bought the 
product BEFORE you get to see these demands- so legally they don ot 'count.')

It got so bad that the guys changed their operation from 'LinuxCAD' to 
something else (something-CAD) for a while.)

For more payment chucles, see:
http://www.linuxcad.com/howtobuy.html

:   Given all this, if I needed/wanted a CAD program for furniture design I'd
: grab a copy of QCAD <http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue54/frost.html>. It's
: gpl'd and looks like it would do just fine.

I have designed some of my turbine parts in Q-Cad and it works just great. 
It's a 2D program like the old AutoCAD. However, it does -NOT- read in DXF 
files anymore (this was something AutoDesk changed...)

- GLL

Where Speed & Service Have Always Mattered @ http://www.ados.com

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Tue Jul  6 11:09:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Tue Jul  6 11:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on IBM ThinkPad 600E
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407041713170.9182@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407041713170.9182@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <40EAEDB0.4010201@adnap.no-ip.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

> <> I need to get the sound running on my finacee's ThinkPad 600E. 
> RealPlayer
> works fine, but it's silent.
>
> According to a couple of google sites, one of which references the other,
> the proper driver is cs4232. So, I added that to /etc/modules.conf and 
> told
> /etc/rc.d/rc.local to load it upon boot, then I manually loaded it with
> modprobe. But, no sound. Also, there's no aumix on that box -- if that 
> makes
> any difference.
>
> Do I need alsa as well as the cs4232?

OSS sound (with the cs4232 module) works just fine on my TP 600E. I'm 
running Debian, but I use a vanilla kernel.

By default, all the mixer volumes are muted. So you do need aumix (or 
comparable program) to turn up the volume. Also hit Fn-PgUp a few times. 
Hearing a beep when doing that doesn't mean you have sound working, though.

I never got ALSA working on the ThinkPad. I did try!

Evan

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jul  6 12:00:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jul  6 12:00:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WiFi on Sony Vaio PCG-V555BC: the solution
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407061152500.17934@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  To close this thread, I have the WiFi card working now on the Sony 'Black
Perl' notebook with the 3Com 3CRWE154G74 card.

  After a lot of experimentation I discovered that I need to run, as root,
the following two commands:

route add -net 0.0.0.0 gw 192.168.55.4 netmask 255.255.255.0 eth1
route add -net 192.168.55.0 gw 192.168.55.4 netmask 255.255.255.0 eth1

  Then I can ping/connect to both internal hosts and sites on the 'Net. I
cannot explain why the second line is required, but it is.

  What I have not yet tested is what it takes to get a connection when I'm
using an access point external to my office. I may have an opportunity to
try that during my trip to Corvallis this week. I think now that I can
discern and fix any problems that come up at another hot spot.

  Whew! Thanks to everyone who helped,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From sandy at herring.org  Tue Jul  6 15:54:02 2004
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue Jul  6 15:54:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: The Borg are coming
Message-ID: <20040706225328.GA22994@kippered.herring.org>

                                 -=*=-
Method and apparatus for transmitting power and data using the human body

Abstract

Methods and apparatus for distributing power and data to devices coupled to the
human body are described. The human body is used as a conductive medium, e.g.,
a bus, over which power and/or data is distributed. Power is distributed by
coupling a power source to the human body via a first set of electrodes. One or
more devise to be powered, e.g., peripheral devices, are also coupled to the
human body via additional sets of electrodes. The devices may be, e.g., a
speaker, display, watch, keyboard, etc. A pulsed DC signal or AC signal may be
used as the power source. By using multiple power supply signals of differing
frequencies, different devices can be selectively powered. Digital data and/or
other information signals, e.g., audio signals, can be modulated on the power
signal using frequency and/or amplitude modulation techniques. 
                                 -=*=-

Guess who holds the above patent...

http://tinyurl.com/28ldb

Sandy

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  6 16:44:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul  6 16:44:02 2004
Subject: Shrinkwraps and licensing (was Re: [PLUG] Amish Cabinet CAD design)
In-Reply-To: <200407060837.25410.guy1656@ados.com>
References: <20040705232232.GA1295@gate.kl-ic.com> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407051630130.13723@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <200407060837.25410.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407061640280.15963@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 6 Jul 2004, GLL wrote:
> I tried it 2 years ago and it was worse than a rip-off, I found it to be
> a sham operation - there are 'agreements' not to diss the product and
> statements that it is 'sold as is' (translation: "Congrats, sucker!")
> all stored ONLY on the CD (which means you have to have already bought
> the product BEFORE you get to see these demands- so legally they don ot
> 'count.')

IANAL, but I don't believe that's true.  While it's totally contrary to
traditional contract law, it is possible to place software license
agreements inside packaging such that the agreement bonds the owner even
though the owner did not agree at time of purchase.

I believe the original ProFTP case yielded this conclusion, but it may
have been a secondary case.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  6 17:06:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul  6 17:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: The Borg are coming
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407061649270.18759@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20040706225328.GA22994@kippered.herring.org>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407061649270.18759@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407061702390.15963@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 6 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 6 Jul 2004, Sandy Herring wrote:
> >                                  -=*=-
> > Method and apparatus for transmitting power and data using the human body
>
>   This is written up in the current issue of "The Economist". They are
> not fans of Microsoft, btw.

There was a demonstration of this back in like 1996.  It wasn't Microsoft
who did the demo, but maybe Microsoft bought that company and its
inventions.

The system was pretty simple.  A person wore a small device on a lanyard
around their neck.  The lanyard had small contacts along its surface that
contacted the skin of the neck.  When you shook hands with a person also
wearing that lanyard, you received and sent your "business card" data.  So
at the end of a long day at a conference, you would have the names, email
addresses, phone numbers, businesses and titles of all the people you met
in your little storage device.

It was neat, but easily abused and ultimately pointless.

J.
--
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org



From bthoen at gisnet.com  Tue Jul  6 18:41:02 2004
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Tue Jul  6 18:41:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: The Borg are coming
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407061702390.15963@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407061930450.18443-100000@gisnet.com>

On Tue, 6 Jul 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> The system was pretty simple.  A person wore a small device on a lanyard
> around their neck.  The lanyard had small contacts along its surface that
> contacted the skin of the neck.  When you shook hands with a person also
> wearing that lanyard, you received and sent your "business card" data.  So
> at the end of a long day at a conference, you would have the names, email
> addresses, phone numbers, businesses and titles of all the people you met
> in your little storage device.
> 
> It was neat, but easily abused and ultimately pointless.

it may seem ridiculous now, but I bet the idea of a "wearable"  computer
will grow. The super geeks at the MIT Media Lab have been fooling around
with this stuff for a few years now. It's all weird toys now, but's that's
how the PC, the civilian Internet, and even Linux got started. I bet it's
only a matter of time before human bio-interfaces for power and data
storage become practical and then popular. I'm not sure when Hans
Moravec's ideas will become reality, but that reality is coming!

- Bill Thoen

  ifdown ppp0

or 

  /etc/inet.d/network restart

seems to have no effect and I have to reboot the box to clear the error.  ifup has no

those error codes and, more importantly, how to cope with them?  The "error 6" is more prevelant

From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] Limiting reboot access to a desktop machine

On Wed, 7 Jul 2004, Eric House wrote:

> I want to allow untrusted guests to use a desktop machine that's in 
> the same room, and so need (I think) to put some sort of cage around 
> the box itself so they can't, e.g., reboot it after putting 
> something in the floppy drive.  Googling for cages etc. yields stuff 
> meant to prevent theft (which is less of a concern) but not access. 
> Does anybody know of products or vendors in the Willamette Valley

Have you thought of something a bit easier, like installing a BIOS 
password and ensuring that the main hard drive is above any removable 
media in the boot-priority list? Or will that not do the trick?

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Wed Jul  7 09:42:02 2004
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed Jul  7 09:42:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Limiting reboot access to a desktop machine
In-Reply-To: <1089216505.1697.12.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <20040707140301.GO1110@peak.org>	 <Pine.LNX.4.60.0407070727290.23744@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <1089216505.1697.12.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <40EC27A5.7090703@easystreet.com>

Derek Loree wrote:

>On Wed, 2004-07-07 at 07:29, Paul Heinlein wrote:
>  
>
>>On Wed, 7 Jul 2004, Eric House wrote:
>>
>>    
>>
>>>I want to allow untrusted guests to use a desktop machine that's in 
>>>the same room, and so need (I think) to put some sort of cage around 
>>>the box itself so they can't, e.g., reboot it after putting 
>>>something in the floppy drive.  Googling for cages etc. yields stuff 
>>>meant to prevent theft (which is less of a concern) but not access. 
>>>Does anybody know of products or vendors in the Willamette Valley 
>>>area?
>>>      
>>>
>>Have you thought of something a bit easier, like installing a BIOS 
>>password and ensuring that the main hard drive is above any removable 
>>media in the boot-priority list? Or will that not do the trick?
>>    
>>
>
>And what if the users want to save something to a floppy disk?
>
The floppy should still work.  Every Intel/AMD system I've worked on
recently have a BIOS setting which allows the user to specify a list
of devices from which the system may boot.  So, if one specifies a
one-item list of "Hard Drive 0" that keeps a malfeasant from booting
from floppy or CD.  And once the box is booted, the drives work just
fine.  Of course, if there is any possibility of the cretins actually
opening the system case, then all bets are off.

From dgc at easystreet.com  Wed Jul  7 10:28:02 2004
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Wed Jul  7 10:28:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SuSE 9.1 AMD64 Needed
In-Reply-To: <1088793352.2165.6.camel@athena.freegeek.org>
References: <1088734465.2145.10.camel@athena.freegeek.org> <1088793352.2165.6.camel@athena.freegeek.org>
Message-ID: <40EC3264.2040703@easystreet.com>

Ron Braithwaite wrote:
> On Thu, 2004-07-01 at 22:14, Ron Braithwaite wrote:
> 
>>So, does anyone have the boxed set with the AMD64 CDs (or the downloaded
>>ISOs) yet? Would you share them with me? I can show you my receipt. I
>>really did pay my money. You can respond to me directly, rather than the
>>list <ron at nutriware.com>.
> 

Have you tried Suse 9.1-amd64 on your m6809 yet?  I also have one (that
I plan to eventually use with Gentoo), but thought it might be
to try Suse 9.1 on; so I went to Fry's and picked up the boxed set.

While there are some good things...
	there was a 64 bit boot dvd

	the Suse installer can automatically resize a ntfs partition

it has not been a clean install.

The Suse installer is either very slow, or there is some clock freq
problem (maybe the "stuck at 800mhz" problem is still there?)

The Suse installer doesn't handle dhcp network connections correctly.
(It detects dhcp is needed, and starts the client, while the card
is being detected.  Then at the point where it wants to test the
connection and download updates, it tries to start the client a
second time and fails because a client is already running.)

It doesn't have a definition for the 1280x800 m6809 screen size.
(But a 1280x1024 monitor definition, and a 1280x800 desktop size did
the right thing, at least in the test sax2 run).

So far, I haven't gotten through a normal boot; it appears to hang while
generating the host key.  At that time network services aren't up,
virtual consoles aren't enabled, etc. so it's hard to see what's
happening.

dgc



From buchholz at easystreet.com  Wed Jul  7 10:37:02 2004
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed Jul  7 10:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPAM Statistics
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406301519190.8183@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301314370.9174@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>    <40E33224.7070005@dimstar.net>    <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301446480.9579@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <55429.134.134.136.1.1088632886.squirrel@134.134.136.1> <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406301519190.8183@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <40EC34A1.60803@easystreet.com>

On Wed, 30 Jun 2004, Russ Johnson wrote:
>
>  I was reading an article in eWeek ... spam has increased to 65%
>  of the email on the net.
>

On Wed, 30 Jun 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
>
>  I read recently (perhaps in the Economist) that spam has now 83%
>  of all mail traffic.
>

On Wed, 30 Jun 2004, Mark Morgan wrote:
>
>  Today's number for me: 78% has been spam. If we take Plug traffic
>  out of the equation, we rise to 97% spam.
>

On Wed, 30 Jun 2004, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> 
>  Here are my numbers from home:
> 
>            total   caught
>      month  msgs     spam   %
>    ------- -----   ------  --
>    2004-01  5746     1494  26
>    2004-02  5377     1866  34
>    2004-03  5189     2339  45
>    2004-04  5557     2812  50
>    2004-05  5530     2738  49
>    2004-06  6029     3008  49
> 
>  The "caught spam" numbers are a bit lower than total spam, but
>  for the last three or four months (since I implemented a better
>  bayesean policy) only 50-75 messages per month have slipped
>  through spamassassin.
>

At iMove, we're only doing blacklist checks (bl.spamcop.net, list.dsbl.org,
and sbl-xbl.spamhaus.org).  The primary MX server (p5.imoveinc.com) has
been running a rejection rate of ~40% (+-5%) since last February.  The
secondary MX server (p2.imoveinc.com), which should almost *never* be
used, runs with a rejection rate of about 85-90%!  It looks like the SPAM
houses don't honor MX records properly.

Easystreet publishes their statistics here:
   http://support.easystreet.com/spam/stats.html
   http://support.easystreet.com/spam/statistics.gif

A quick summary of their raw number is

   Month     Total Msgs    %blocked
  --------  ------------  ---------
  Jan-2003    5,203,753      39%
  Apr-2003    7,268,755      53%
  Jul-2003    8,133,676      55%
  Oct-2003   11,942,354      58%

  Jan-2004   14,436,481      73%
  Feb-2004   17,172,458      74%
  Mar-2004   14,272,750      73%
  Apr-2004     - n/a -       --
  May-2004   16,316,718      82%

So it looks like Rich's quote of 85% is not out of the question.
(And, unfortunately, even with all the spam that Easystreet blocks,
I *still* get way too many unreadable (Korean and Chinese) spam
in my Inbox.)

- Don

Down to three choices on Cameras

Choice one

Fujifilm 2.0 Megapixel Digital Camera w/6x Optical Zoom & SW

$174 Plus shipping

FUJI FANTASTIC! What makes a quality digital camera? Many people would
shout out "MEGAPIXELS!" but they'd be wrong. Megapixels are just one
aspect of what makes a good digital camera. You need to also look at the
lens (is it big or small? glass or plastic?), the internal electronics,
the optical zoom and finally, the manufacturer. The Fujifilm FinePix
2800 makes a great camera due to it's quality construction, electronics,
lens, optical zoom ability, and yes, megapixels. The picture quality is
so good that it runs circles around many competitors' 3 and 4 megapixel
cameras. One look at this Fujifilm camera and you'll recognize the
advancements in technology. This FinePix 2800 digital camera features a
2.0 megapixel resolution capturing images up to 1600x1200. Birthday
parties, vacation photos and any other special moments can be captured
digitally in fine detail and crisp colors, then easily shared over the
Internet with friends and family. The USB interface makes it incredibly
easy to install, edit and create wonderful phot albums LIVE SMART...BUY
IT TODAY! 

General Features: 
      * 1/2.7-inch square pixel CCD with RGB filter (2.1
        million pixels)
      * 1.92 megapixel image resolution (1600x1200, 1280x960
        and 640x480 resolutions)
      * JPEG (.jpg) image format 
      * 16MB SmartMedia card (included) 
      * 6x optical zoom (plus 2.5x digital zoom in 640x480 mode) 
      * equivilent to a 38-228mm range on a 35mm camera 
      * 2.6-feet to infinity (normal) 3.9-inch to 31.5-inch
        (macro) focal ranges
      * Image/movie deletion at the camera (single/all) 
      * USB interface (cable included) 
      * ISO 100 sensitivity setting 
      * 64 zone TTL metering, program AE exposure compensation
        in manual mode
      * 1/2 second to 1/1500 second variable shutter speeds 
      * Automatic flash using flash control sensor 
      * 1-foot to 11.5-feet (wide), 2.6-feet to 11.5-feet
        (tele) flash ranges
      * Auto, red-eye reduction, forced flash, suppressed
        flash, slow synchro flash
      * Fujinon 6x optical zoom lens f/2.8, f/4.8 and f/8.2
        aperture settings
      * 0.55-inch 110,000 pixels electronic viewfinder 
      * 1.8-inch TFT LCD displays 62,000 pixels 
      * 10 second delay self timer 
      * Display mode for viewing movies and pictures 
      * Record audio to movies 
         
        
      * Unit Dimensions: 
      * 3.7-inch wide, 3-inches high, 2.8-inch deep 
      * 9.5-ounces without batteries and media

      * Fujifilm FinePix 2800 refurbished digital camera 
      * 16MB SmartMedia memory card 
      * User's Manual 
      * Drivers Disc 
      * USB cable

        included)

        sell

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jul  7 11:27:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jul  7 11:27:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPAM Statistics
In-Reply-To: <40EC34A1.60803@easystreet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301314370.9174@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>   
 <40E33224.7070005@dimstar.net>    <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301446480.9579@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <55429.134.134.136.1.1088632886.squirrel@134.134.136.1>
 <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406301519190.8183@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
 <40EC34A1.60803@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0407071111340.23744@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 7 Jul 2004, Don Buchholz wrote:

> The secondary MX server (p2.imoveinc.com), which should almost 
> *never* be used, runs with a rejection rate of about 85-90%!  It 
> looks like the SPAM houses don't honor MX records properly.

It's a well established fact that spambots and zombies will 
deliberately deliver mail to a secondary or teriatary MX on the 
assumption that its policies (AV, spam, unknown users) aren't as 
strict as those on the primary MX.

My (unconfirmed) hunch is that many viruses take tactical advantage 
of the situation by

1. Sending infected message to bogus-user at domain-1 via domain-1's
    secondary MX with a forged sender address of real-user at domain-2.
    Since, in all likelihood, domain-1's nonprimary MX hosts don't
    enforce scanning rules, the message will get queued on the
    nonprimary MX

2. When the nonprimary MX tries to pass the message along to its final
    destination, it's rejected/bounced by domain-1's primary MX.

3. So the nonprimary MX must try to return the message as
    undeliverable, but it does so using the (forged) real-user's
    address.

4. Ultimately, real-user gets an infected message that's a) sent by a
    legitimate MX host, so it's not blackholed anywhere along the line
    and b) wrapped in the quasi-official garb of a MAILER-DAEMON
    message. The "official" look of the message might just trick
    unsuspecting lusers into opening a message they might otherwise
    delete with prejudice.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Jul  7 13:25:03 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Wed Jul  7 13:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] final-Selection-Cameras
In-Reply-To: <1089224532.4922.74.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407071224480.21683-100000@www.fnordora.org>

On 7 Jul 2004, Marv wrote:

> 
> 
> Camera usage.
> 
> Pictures in the Garden <Bright Light>
> Pictures at Drunken Lan Parties <low light poor focus>
> 
> Pls snip and vote one, two, three, or you  missed a great one!
> 
> <sorry about LONG post>
> 
> Down to three choices on Cameras
> 
> Choice one
> 
> Fujifilm 2.0 Megapixel Digital Camera w/6x Optical Zoom & SW
> 
> $174 Plus shipping

Not a good choice.

The camera has three big problems.

1) It has a shutter delay problem.  There is a percievable delay between 
when you hit the shutter release and when it actually takes the picture.  

2) Slow shutter speed.  If the subject is moving AT ALL, you will get a 
blurry picture. It claims you can set the shutter speed.  I have not found 
that setting.

3) Does not focus well in low lighting conditions.  The autofocus needs a 
fair amount of light to work correctly.  That means that if you are 
indoors and it is even the least bit dim, many or all of your shots will 
be out of focus.

I have one of these cameras.  Good for outdoor and high light photos.  
Sucks for everything else.

From Trench-Shoring at gmx.net  Wed Jul  7 14:29:02 2004
From: Trench-Shoring at gmx.net (Trench Shoring)
Date: Wed Jul  7 14:29:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] final-Selection-Cameras
In-Reply-To: <1089224532.4922.74.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
References: <1089224532.4922.74.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
Message-ID: <6.0.0.22.2.20040707141634.0289c120@mail.gmx.net>

I have a Fuji digital 2600 with 6x zoom.

I wish I had bought something with a faster reaction time. The lag between 
pushing the button when you see a perfect picture and the camera reacting 
is YEARS.
I have blown hundreds of pictures. Mostly I get a shot of the back of 
someone's head as they turn back to whatever they were doing before the 
flash finally went off. The kiss is over, the puppy moved on, The girl on 
the bicycle was no longer smiling at me, The Amsterdam Street hooker is no 
longer flashing. Damn.

If you just want garden pics they will most likely not turn away from you, 
But real life moves and I am not psychic enough to know how to push the 
button BEFORE the picture happens.

The close up mode is incredible. I have excellent shots of capacitors 
oozing goo and metal popped from its base.

Good luck
         Trench

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jul  7 14:34:01 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed Jul  7 14:34:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPAM Statistics
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0407071111340.23744@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301314370.9174@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>    <40E33224.7070005@dimstar.net>    <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301446480.9579@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <55429.134.134.136.1.1088632886.squirrel@134.134.136.1> <Pine.LNX.4.60.0406301519190.8183@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <40EC34A1.60803@easystreet.com> <Pine.LNX.4.60.0407071111340.23744@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <40EC6C27.60305@dimstar.net>

Paul Heinlein wrote:

> It's a well established fact that spambots and zombies will 
> deliberately deliver mail to a secondary or teriatary MX on the 
> assumption that its policies (AV, spam, unknown users) aren't as 
> strict as those on the primary MX.

Yup, that's the theory. I can confirm that this does happen on my mail 
server for the domain that I'm the the backup MX for.

> My (unconfirmed) hunch is that many viruses take tactical advantage of 
> the situation by

This also appears to happen.

The best way I've found to stop some of it is to require that all 
inbound mail come from a host that reverse resolves. There are probably 
better ways... SPF records?

Unfortunately, requiring reverse resolving also blocks a bunch of 
legitimate mail from domains that have clueless DNS admins.

Russ



From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jul  7 14:52:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed Jul  7 14:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] final-Selection-Cameras
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407071224480.21683-100000@www.fnordora.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407071224480.21683-100000@www.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <40EC704E.5040406@dimstar.net>

alan wrote:

>Not a good choice.
>  
>
I disagree. I have a 2800 Zoom.

>The camera has three big problems.
>
>1) It has a shutter delay problem.  There is a percievable delay between 
>when you hit the shutter release and when it actually takes the picture.  
>  
>
It does not have this delay issue if you force it to auto-focus before 
you push the shutter release completely. The delay is caused by the 
auto-focus. Push the shutter release half way, allow the camera to 
focus, and then push the shutter fully to take the pic.

>2) Slow shutter speed.  If the subject is moving AT ALL, you will get a 
>blurry picture. It claims you can set the shutter speed.  I have not found 
>that setting.
>  
>
I don't suffer from this at all. I've had blurry pics because I moved 
when there was low light, but then, I should be using a tripod if I 
don't want to use a flash in low light...

>3) Does not focus well in low lighting conditions.  The autofocus needs a 
>fair amount of light to work correctly.  That means that if you are 
>indoors and it is even the least bit dim, many or all of your shots will 
>be out of focus.
>  
>
I haven't had this problem either. I've taken some amazing pictures of 
the moon, and cityscapes at night and a campfire, without any flash or 
auxiliary lighting. I've also taken some flash pictures in low light 
that were completely amazing too.

BTW, a campfire makes a really cool desktop pic.

Russ



From mel97215 at comcast.net  Wed Jul  7 15:39:01 2004
From: mel97215 at comcast.net (Mel Andres)

Subject: [PLUG] final-Selection-Cameras
In-Reply-To: <40EC704E.5040406@dimstar.net>

	 <40EC704E.5040406@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1089239931.24500.6.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>

On Wed, 2004-07-07 at 14:51, Russ Johnson wrote:

> I haven't had this problem either. I've taken some amazing pictures of 
> the moon, and cityscapes at night and a campfire, without any flash or 
> auxiliary lighting. 
Of course, except for possibly the campfire, a flash is totally useless
in those conditions. A flash is for subjects 10-15' away. Years ago in
another (military) life, I laughed at sailors taking night shots of Hong
Kong's cityscape with flash.

Mel Andres
            <<<   Registered Linux user #347871    >>>
             SuSE 9.0 Personal	Ximian Evolution 1.4.6




From lug at phxlinux.org  Wed Jul  7 16:21:02 2004
From: lug at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed Jul  7 16:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Perl regex question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407071613500.26222@neon.netpro.to>

I have the following two types of lines:

<tr bgcolor="#EFF5FB">Something here</tr>
<tr bgcolor="#F6F9FC">Who knows what else here</tr>

Is there a way to make a single regex for storing everything between the
tr tags into array elements?  For example, I could do this with two
arrays:

@rows1 = /<tr bgcolor="\#EFF5FB">(.*?)<\/tr>/g;
@rows2 = /<tr bgcolor="\#F6F9FC">(.*?)<\/tr>/g;

But it would be nice if I could do something like this instead:

@rows = /<tr bgcolor="\#(EFF5FB|F6F9FC)">(.*?)<\/tr>/g;

...but without storing EFF5FB and F6F9FC in the array.

Thanks,
~M

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Wed Jul  7 18:34:02 2004
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)

On Wed, 7 Jul 2004, Paul Johnson wrote:

> The people running those mail servers must not know what they're doing
> or something.  Spam accounts for 5% of accepted email on a very bad day;
> I haven't seen a false positive for a very long time, either.

I think they're talking about what the filters catch, not the junk that
gets through. My Procmail filters catch about 110 spams a day to me
personally (down from 170 a day earlier in the year.) Out of the 50 or so
per day that should get through to me (mostly mailing list traffic) maybe
5-10 (10-20%) are junk that still gets through.

- Bill Thoen





From jkeroes at eli.net  Wed Jul  7 19:33:01 2004
From: jkeroes at eli.net (Joshua Keroes)
Date: Wed Jul  7 19:33:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Perl regex question
In-Reply-To: <20040708004202.30251.33722.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040708004202.30251.33722.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <0ED2882A-D087-11D8-819B-000A95C466EC@eli.net>

On Wed, 7 Jul 2004 16:20:15 -0700 (MST), Matt Alexander 
<lug at phxlinux.org> wrote:
> I have the following two types of lines:
>
> <tr bgcolor="#EFF5FB">Something here</tr>
> <tr bgcolor="#F6F9FC">Who knows what else here</tr>
>
> Is there a way to make a single regex for storing everything between 
> the
> tr tags into array elements?  For example, I could do this with two
> arrays:
>
> @rows1 = /<tr bgcolor="\#EFF5FB">(.*?)<\/tr>/g;
> @rows2 = /<tr bgcolor="\#F6F9FC">(.*?)<\/tr>/g;
>
> But it would be nice if I could do something like this instead:
>
> @rows = /<tr bgcolor="\#(EFF5FB|F6F9FC)">(.*?)<\/tr>/g;
>
> ...but without storing EFF5FB and F6F9FC in the array.


Using regexen to parse HTML will bite you in booty eventually. Here's 
the better way to do it. Note: you'll need to install HTML::TreeBuilder 
from CPAN ( i.e. sudo perl -MCPAN -e'install HTML::TreeBuilder' )

Here's a more flexible way to do it:

#!/usr/local/bin/perl -w

use strict;
use HTML::TreeBuilder;
use Test::More tests => 1;

my $tree = HTML::TreeBuilder->new;

undef $/;  # read DATA all at once
$tree->parse( <DATA> );

# Find the tags with these two bgcolors.
# This method comes from HTML::Element.
# Another handy HTML::Element method is
# find_by_tag_name().
my @tr = $tree->look_down(
   _tag    => 'tr',
   bgcolor => qr/ eff5fb | f6f9fc /xi,
);

# Now check that we found "foo", "bar", "baz",
# but not "skip".
#
# First extract the text from the tags
# e.g. <tag>text</tag>
my @tags = map { $_->as_text } @tr;

# Now compare what we got with what we should
# have gotten and print "ok" or "not ok".
is_deeply
   [ @tags ],
   [ qw/foo bar baz/ ],
   "Found the expected tags";

__DATA__
<head>
   <title>test</title>
</head>
<body>
   <table>
     <tr bgcolor="#EFF5FB">foo</tr>
     <tr bgcolor="#F6F9FC">bar</tr>
     <tr bgcolor="#000">skip</tr>
     <tr class="multiline_with_td"
         bgcolor="#F6F9FC"><td>baz</td></tr>
   </table>
</body>


-Joshua

PS HTML::TreeBuilder is a subclass of both HTML::Element and 
HTML::Parser, so you get all of their method for free. That's a lot of 
documentation to read. To get you started, check these three out: 
HTML::Parser::parse_file(), HTML::Element::look_down(), and 
HTML::Element::find_by_tag_name() .

PPS Read David Cross' "Data Munging with Perl" to learn why using 
regexen is a weak approach to HTML parsing. 
http://www.manning.com/cross/

On Wed, 7 Jul 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Whoh...  that's a new one for me.  I understand the "ternary conditional"
> to work like this (example from the perlop man page):
>
> $a = $ok ? $b : $c;
>
> But I don't understand why it works in your example...

It's not the ternary operator - it's part of an extended regular 
expression pattern. 'man perlre', grep for '?:pattern'.

David Fleck

On Wed, 2004-07-07 at 09:41, Don Buchholz wrote:
> Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> >On Wed, 2004-07-07 at 07:29, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> >  
> >
> >>On Wed, 7 Jul 2004, Eric House wrote:
> >>
> >>    
> >>
> >>>I want to allow untrusted guests to use a desktop machine that's in 
> >>>the same room, and so need (I think) to put some sort of cage around 
> >>>the box itself so they can't, e.g., reboot it after putting 
> >>>something in the floppy drive.  Googling for cages etc. yields stuff 
> >>>meant to prevent theft (which is less of a concern) but not access. 
> >>>Does anybody know of products or vendors in the Willamette Valley 
> >>>area?
> >>>      
> >>>
> >>Have you thought of something a bit easier, like installing a BIOS 
> >>password and ensuring that the main hard drive is above any removable 
> >>media in the boot-priority list? Or will that not do the trick?
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >And what if the users want to save something to a floppy disk?
> >
> The floppy should still work.  Every Intel/AMD system I've worked on
> recently have a BIOS setting which allows the user to specify a list
> of devices from which the system may boot.  So, if one specifies a
> one-item list of "Hard Drive 0" that keeps a malfeasant from booting
> from floppy or CD.  And once the box is booted, the drives work just
> fine.  Of course, if there is any possibility of the cretins actually
> opening the system case, then all bets are off.

This was more of a comment on the draw back to using a cage to limit
access to the floppy drive for booting.

Derek Loree




From charlie at schluting.com  Wed Jul  7 22:34:02 2004
From: charlie at schluting.com (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Wed Jul  7 22:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPAM Statistics
In-Reply-To: <87hdsjfhzz.fsf@ursine.ca>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301314370.9174@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<40E33224.7070005@dimstar.net>	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0406301446480.9579@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<55429.134.134.136.1.1088632886.squirrel@134.134.136.1>	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0406301519190.8183@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>	<40EC34A1.60803@easystreet.com> <87hdsjfhzz.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <40ECDCC5.8080209@schluting.com>

>>> Here are my numbers from home:
>>>           total   caught
>>>     month  msgs     spam   %
>>>   ------- -----   ------  --
>>>   2004-01  5746     1494  26
>>>   2004-02  5377     1866  34
>>>   2004-03  5189     2339  45
>>>   2004-04  5557     2812  50
>>>   2004-05  5530     2738  49
>>>   2004-06  6029     3008  49
> 
> 
> The people running those mail servers must not know what they're doing
> or something.  Spam accounts for 5% of accepted email on a very bad day;
> I haven't seen a false positive for a very long time, either.

So, everyone recieves the same amount of spam as you do? It may be true 
that they are counting denied emails (i.e. 5xx responses) too.. but not 
necessarily.
Do you post to usenet? That makes a huge difference. Publically 
advertising your email on any website that's semi-popular will get you a 
lot more spam.

Actual spam identified on my server is normally around 20-25%. Certianly 
more than 5%, but I'm pretty sure I know smtp quite well. If I counted 
5xx vs. 250 responses.. wow, that would be about 80% of all email, at 
least. I see about 5-20 dictionary attacks per day :(

-Charlie

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu Jul  8 10:28:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)

Subject: [PLUG] SCO IP license
In-Reply-To: <20040705213306.86569.qmail@web50603.mail.yahoo.com>

Robert Kopp wrote:

>--- Elliott Mitchell <ehem at m5p.com> wrote:
>  
>
>>>End users who purchase this license are granted
>>>      
>>>
>>the
>>    
>>
>>>right to use the SCO IP in Linux in binary format
>>>only. The license is available immediately and can
>>>      
>>>
>>be
>>    
>>
>>>purchased by credit card through our online store.
>>>      
>>>
>>Any idea how you're supposed to accomplish this?
>>Does this mean you can't
>>do security patches as those require source?
>>
>>    
>>
>This leaves open-source users no worse off than M$
>users, who can't do such things and must rely upon
>Bill Gates for redress. But the former are accustomed
>to having this option.

There are programs and whatnot that are not GPL, but Linux itself
doesn't have this problem.  SCO's version might.  Noone can buy
GPL software out and restrict it.  Maybe new versions of GPL
programs can be restricted, but that wouldn't stop the GPL'ed
ancestor from being improved without the restrictions.

I'm more concerned about Redhat moving to a high cost Linux
product and discontinuing software for non corporate customers.  
I don't see how using the public as guinea pigs is going to make
Linux more popular.  It's sad that the discussions leading to
Redhat's restructuring and why they dumped alpha too are
not public knowledge as far as I know.

     --  Michael Robinson

From aaron at bavariati.org  Thu Jul  8 11:50:03 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Thu Jul  8 11:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] VA Linux 2U rackmount server box -- need info
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407071616510.23666-100000@www.fnordora.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407071616510.23666-100000@www.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <20040708184922.GB16636@bavariati.org>

On Wed, Jul 07, 2004 at 04:21:54PM -0700, alan wrote:
> The place I am currently working has inherited a couple of VA Linux dual 
> proc 2U rackmount server boxes.

VA2230s or some such?  OSDL had a bunch of 'em when I worked there.

> Linux installs on it (with a bit of whacking on the install (acpi=force)).

You've prolly got an Intel Lancewood motherboard.  Check the numbers
inside and look online for BIOS upgrades.  The serial console and remote
management support is kinda nifty.

> My question is if anyone is familiar with that style of rackmount box.  It 
> has space for a couple of drive bays.  There are big fans there now.

Yeah.  It's kind of a hassle.  There's a trick to getting the front
cover and fans off so you can get to those bays, can't remember it
without looking at the box and/or knowing the model#.

> Where do I get the drive bays/mounting hardware?  After putting a DVD 
> drive in the box, there is no place to put in a drive.

California Digital.  They sell VA parts and support contracts that are
handled by script-readers in Bangalore.*

And yes, unfortunately, the VA 2U cases are custom as far as I know.


Let me know if you need another pair of eyes on the thing,
  Aaron

-- 
*No offense meant to the many excellent technicians, programmers and
engineers in Bangalore.  CD just didn't seem to have any of them. 



From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jul  8 12:10:03 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jul  8 12:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: P4 woes.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>

OK, this is dumb.

I have here a brand new 3GHz P4 processor, a brand new motherboard with
800MHz FSB or some ungodly number, and a stick of DDR-400 PC3200 RAM.

I plug all this stuff together in the appropriate configuration and no-go.
I disconnect the ATX2 connector (the four pin thingie that seems to power
the CPU alone) and the CPU fan spins when the power comes on, but no
little post beep.

Turns out the power supply is only 250W, so we replace it... thinking
we're overloading the thing (understand, this is without any devices
beyond an AGP card and keyboard -- no drives or anything.

We have a new 350W power supply.  Exact same results.

What gives?

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From aaron at bavariati.org  Thu Jul  8 12:17:02 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Thu Jul  8 12:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: P4 woes.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20040708191614.GD16636@bavariati.org>

On Thu, Jul 08, 2004 at 12:09:31PM -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> OK, this is dumb.
> 
> I have here a brand new 3GHz P4 processor, a brand new motherboard with
> 800MHz FSB or some ungodly number, and a stick of DDR-400 PC3200 RAM.
> 
> I plug all this stuff together in the appropriate configuration and no-go.
> I disconnect the ATX2 connector (the four pin thingie that seems to power
> the CPU alone) and the CPU fan spins when the power comes on, but no
> little post beep.

Try removing the RAM and video and see if you get three beeps on
powerup.  Add RAM and see if you get 8 beeps.  If not, CPU and/or mobo
is likely DOA.  

Hope you bought it locally,
  Aaron



From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Thu Jul  8 12:20:03 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Jul  8 12:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: P4 woes.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1089314843.10619.11.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Thu, 2004-07-08 at 12:09 -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> OK, this is dumb.

No, its needs are just not met.  ;-)

> I have here a brand new 3GHz P4 processor, a brand new motherboard with
> 800MHz FSB or some ungodly number, and a stick of DDR-400 PC3200 RAM.

Well, that 800MHz isn't really a true 800MHz if that makes you feel any
better.

> I plug all this stuff together in the appropriate configuration and no-go.
> I disconnect the ATX2 connector (the four pin thingie that seems to power
> the CPU alone) and the CPU fan spins when the power comes on, but no
> little post beep.

Does the CPU fan spin with the Pentium4 power cable plugged in?

> Turns out the power supply is only 250W, so we replace it... thinking
> we're overloading the thing (understand, this is without any devices
> beyond an AGP card and keyboard -- no drives or anything.
> 
> We have a new 350W power supply.  Exact same results.
> 
> What gives?

Well, the things that pop in to my head as possibilities are:

1)  The motherboard is shorting
2)  The PSU is bad
3)  The RAM is bad
4)  The CPU is bad
5)  The motherboard is bad
6)  The video card is bad
7)  The video card/RAM/CPU is improperly seated
8)  Some component isn't compatible with some other component

Now, when I have a system that is dead like that, I disassemble the
whole thing and place the motherboard on a piece of cardboard (it can't
short out on cardboard, can it?).  Plug in the CPU (and heatsink, of
course), RAM, and video card.  Make sure they're all properly seated.
Plug the power cable(s) in to the board.  Power it up (short the power
button pins with a screwdriver) and see what happens.

If it doesn't power up, you should swap out components until it does
power up to identify the defective/incompatible component.

-- 
Rob                                |  If not safe,
   Jabber: athlonrob at axpr.net   |    one can never be free.

From mel97215 at comcast.net  Thu Jul  8 12:54:02 2004
From: mel97215 at comcast.net (Mel Andres)
Date: Thu Jul  8 12:54:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: P4 woes.
In-Reply-To: <1089314843.10619.11.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1089314843.10619.11.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <1089316452.26575.5.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>

On Thu, 2004-07-08 at 12:27, AthlonRob wrote:

> Now, when I have a system that is dead like that, I disassemble the
> whole thing and place the motherboard on a piece of cardboard (it can't
> short out on cardboard, can it?). 

Well that's better than a sheet of plastic, but still a source of static
electricity. An anti-static mat with wrist strap would be the best
choice. ESD damage often results in latent component failures, rather
than failing immediately. 
-- 
Mel Andres
            <<<   Registered Linux user #347871    >>>
             SuSE 9.0 Personal	Ximian Evolution 1.4.6

> On Thu, 2004-07-08 at 12:27, AthlonRob wrote:

> Well that's better than a sheet of plastic, but still a source of static
> electricity. An anti-static mat with wrist strap would be the best
> choice. ESD damage often results in latent component failures, rather

I was actually told to use cardboard by a senior repair tech a few years
back and haven't lost a board to ESD yet.  :-)

I suppose if the weather were drier and you hit the thing just right, it
could become an issue.  But, IME, if you're using a wrist strap or
similar in Oregon, cardboard is safe.

> at his office today and fiddled a little with it, but I don't use

> at me.  Anyone have some insight/pointers to share?

Evan




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jul  8 17:51:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu Jul  8 17:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: wireless card recommendations
In-Reply-To: <20040708231702.17929.71711.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040708231702.17929.71711.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040709004959.GA27356@gate.kl-ic.com>


> "Josh Orchard" <josh at emediatedesigns.com> writes
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] wireless card recommendations
> Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> 
> Hello all,
> 
> I'm shopping for a wireless card for my IBM Thinkpad 600e to work with
> linux Fedora Core 1.  I would like to know if I should go PCMCIA or
> perhaps USB.  Is there a card manf. that anyone recommends to go with
> or stay away from?
> 
> I see Fry's has an SMC protocol G/B on sale that I would like to buy
> as I would like G/B.


1) G is a marketing gimmick.  Unless you really feel the need to move
streaming video from a computer within your premises, or you are doing
major backup file transfers with the wrong software,  then 54Mbps
provides no advantage over 11Mbps.  The pipe into your house is likely
less than 3Mbps.  OTOH, G uses a higher frequency and is far more
sensitive to loss of range and multipath.  

2) Assume most cheap wireless cards don't work with Linux.  There are
rare exceptions.  Think "winmodem", only this time it is "winradio".
Unless you know a specific box contains a specific model number, your
chances of success are probably 5%.  We've seen this over and over here;
the process always consists of

   [A]  "buy a card at Fry's", "determine chipset", "look for drivers",
        "find none", "ask for help on PLUG list", "receive ridicule"
   [B]  go to [A], repeat until clue appears
   [C]  do research and find card known to work.

3) Assuming you are too busy to make frequent visits to Fry's,  may
I suggest you purchase a known-to-work chipset and card.  802.11B
Orinoco cards are good, as is anything with a Prism2 'B chipset. 
For B/G, (assuming that restricted range is OK) the Atheros chipset
is said to have rapidly developing wifi drivers ("madwifi").   Note
that the big vendors (Linksys, D-link, etc) change chipsets like
Imelda Marcos changed shoes, so the same model number can be
associated with three or four chipsets (and only one may be Linux
compatable).

4) I strongly suggest 200mW Prism2 cards, such as the "Engenius"
AKA "Senao" cards.  They are often rebranded.  You can purchase
these from Rick at Invictus Networks in Lake Oswego, or from Netgate
in Spokane, or from numerous other mail order shops.  There are good
lists of cards and vendors at the Seattle Wireless website.

Wireless for Linux is a minefield.  For all sorts of bogus and non-bogus
reasons, there are relatively few drivers available for the cheap stuff.
That does not mean you can't find something that works, just that you
cannot find something randomly (Fry's is randomly).  

I am the king of the scrounges, but this is one place where I will spend
$90 for quality and easy install, compared to $30 for something that
doesn't work (again and again and again).  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> ... OTOH, G uses a higher frequency and is far more
> sensitive to loss of range and multipath.  
> 

G is the same frequency as B; just a different signal encoding
mechanism.  802.11A is the higher frequency standard.

dgc

On Wed, 2004-07-07 at 10:27, Dave Clemans wrote:

Be sure to specify noapm and a lot of the problems go away.

> The Suse installer is either very slow, or there is some clock freq
> problem (maybe the "stuck at 800mhz" problem is still there?)

This is due to the undefined monitor. I *wish* there was a driver for
this beautiful display, but there isn't. Here's what has worked pretty
well for me:

HorizSync   32 - 38
VertRefresh 50 - 70
Option      "dpms"
Driver      "radeon"
Depth       24
Modes       "1280x800"
Xdimension  332mm
Ydimension  208mm

Hope this helps.

> The Suse installer doesn't handle dhcp network connections correctly.
> (It detects dhcp is needed, and starts the client, while the card
> is being detected.  Then at the point where it wants to test the
> connection and download updates, it tries to start the client a
> second time and fails because a client is already running.)

This has been crazy making for me, but with Aaron Burt's help today, we
figured out (we think) that the hardware is getting into some weird
state. Booting off Knoppix26 with noapm or Morphix with noapm nopcmcia a
couple of times causes stuff to work again. We do *not* understand this
(maybe Aaron has figured it out after he left, but I'm still scratching
my head).

Also, the simple act of just plugging in an Intel wireless card caused
it to completely forget about anything to do with eth0. Basically,
something is getting fired off that clobbers the configuration.

Aaron, you want to drop some pearls of wisdom into this conversation?

> So far, I haven't gotten through a normal boot; it appears to hang while
> generating the host key.  At that time network services aren't up,
> virtual consoles aren't enabled, etc. so it's hard to see what's
> happening.

I do have mine working. Pretty much. When its going well, it is one
honking machine and I think SuSE is the way to go for AMD64. And I say
that after many years of using Mandrake and plunking down my (very) hard
earned bucks for a Mandrakeclub Silver Membership. I think I'm going to
ask for my money back on the Silver upgrade - MDKAMD64 just will not run
on the M6809, period.

Good luck and keep us posted on your progress!

-Ron




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jul  9 01:26:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Jul  9 01:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Re: wireless card recommendations
In-Reply-To: <20040709052902.3426.19930.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040709052902.3426.19930.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040709082434.GA29556@gate.kl-ic.com>

> Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > ... OTOH, G uses a higher frequency and is far more
> > sensitive to loss of range and multipath.  

> Dave Clemans <dgc at easystreet.com> writes:
> G is the same frequency as B; just a different signal encoding
> mechanism.  802.11A is the higher frequency standard.

Dave is correct.  I had seen some graphs of measured range data for
B and for G, that showed lower range for G.  However, further research
shows that G does have higher theoretical range.  G breaks the radio
spectrum up into a lot of little subbands (Orthogonal Frequency 
Division Multiplexing, or OFDM) which means the symbols in each
subband are transmitted more slowly.  The longer the symbols, the less
likely they are to interfere with each other as they take longer and
shorter paths in an environment with multiple radio-reflective surfaces.

OTOH, with multiple frequencies it is possible to get something called
"third order intermodulation", where two signals at nearby frequencies
can mix together and produce a third frequency.  To prevent this, the
electronics in the transmitter and receiver have to be well designed
and carefully tested to prevent the distortions that can result in
intermodulation.  So, G (best case) works better than B (best case).
Perhaps the graphs I had seen were for less-than-ideal cards.  Or 
perhaps I am imagining those graphs (a mind is a terrible thing).

In time, G cards and infrastructure will be more common.  For now,
almost all public wifi sites are B, and typically have less than
3Mbps backhaul to the net.  So for most practical purposes, either
B or G will do.  For Linux purposes, use what you are sure you can
find production drivers for.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jul  9 09:11:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jul  9 09:11:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] wireless card recommendations
In-Reply-To: <4637.134.244.174.76.1089315041.squirrel@134.244.174.76>
References: <4637.134.244.174.76.1089315041.squirrel@134.244.174.76>
Message-ID: <1089389531.1697.22.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2004-07-08 at 12:30, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello all,
> 
> I'm shopping for a wireless card for my IBM Thinkpad 600e to work with
> linux Fedora Core 1.  I would like to know if I should go PCMCIA or
> perhaps USB.  Is there a card manf. that anyone recommends to go with
> or stay away from?

USB can also be done, but the chances of finding one that works with no
hassles is smaller than for PCMCIA cards.  The advantage is that they
usually come with a USB cord, so you can move the device around to find
the best signal (almost like having an antenna).
> 
> I see Fry's has an SMC protocol G/B on sale that I would like to buy
> as I would like G/B.

The research to find out the exact chipset is worth it.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jul  9 09:21:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jul  9 09:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: P4 woes.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1089390134.1697.33.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2004-07-08 at 12:09, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> OK, this is dumb.
> 
> I have here a brand new 3GHz P4 processor, a brand new motherboard with
> 800MHz FSB or some ungodly number, and a stick of DDR-400 PC3200 RAM.

What is the Northbridge chipset?  What is the brand and CS level of the
RAM?  Most of the chipsets that drive the bus at 800 MHz are dual
channel on the RAM bus.  Not that one stick shouldn't work, but two
sticks will make your memory access even faster.  They tend to be kind
of picky about the CS level of the RAM, too.
> 
> I plug all this stuff together in the appropriate configuration and no-go.
> I disconnect the ATX2 connector (the four pin thingie that seems to power
> the CPU alone) and the CPU fan spins when the power comes on, but no
> little post beep.
> 
> Turns out the power supply is only 250W, so we replace it... thinking
> we're overloading the thing (understand, this is without any devices
> beyond an AGP card and keyboard -- no drives or anything.
> 
> We have a new 350W power supply.  Exact same results.

Try RAM next.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jul  9 10:25:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Jul  9 10:25:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Example of existence/non-existence of wireless drivers
Message-ID: <20040709172400.GB584@gate.kl-ic.com>

Look at the following webpage for an example of better-than-average
support for wireless cards:

http://support.dlink.com/faq/view.asp?prod_id=357

Things to note while purusing this DLINK "support" page:

1) On a typical card, the DWL-520, there are three different chipsets.
One set is PRISM-II, with good drivers (though the hostap drivers are
better than the suggested wlan-ng drivers), one chipset is ADMTEK, 
and the pointer is to a Chinese 404 page, and one chipset is REALTEK,
with pointers to drivers for the 2.4.18 and 2.4.20 kernels only.  If
you are running FC1 (2.4.22-1.2115) you are SOL.

2) Many of the cards have no drivers at all, or alpha drivers.  Alpha
means that the driver can panic the kernel or go gunnysack in some 
other way.  These drivers will mature in time (I have great hopes 
for the Atheros ) but in the beginning, you are contributing debugging
to the project.

3) You will probably be unable to tell card revision by looking at
the box.  Fry's sells manufacturer's refurbs packaged as new, so you
cannot assume the units on their shelf are the latest rev, or even
all the same in the same box.

4) Examples of G cards that have linux drivers are the DLINK G120
(rev A and B) and the G650 (rev A) using the Prism54 chipset (drivers
are in alpha), and the G520 (rev A and B) and the G650 (rev B and C)
using the Atheros chipset (with Madwifi drivers in beta).  Are we
confused yet?

SMC doesn't even mention Linux for their wireless cards,  though 
there is some offsite information.  You will note that the card
they show on their splash page is cardbus, which will not work in
older laptops.  

Again, it is better to start with chipsets and drivers you have heard
good things about, determine an adequate form factor and interface
(Cardbus vs PCMCIA) then work backwards to identify the card and
revision that you want to buy.   Think minefield;  without a good
map through it, you will get blown up.  The FCC designed the mines,
Bill Gates made them, the manufacturers placed them, and Fry's will
parachute you into the middle of them, in the dark.  That is not the
way it should be, and for most Linux peripherals it is not, but wifi
is scary that way.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Fri Jul  9 10:32:02 2004
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Fri Jul  9 10:32:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] wireless card recommendations
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D28@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
On Thu, 8 Jul 2004, Josh Orchard wrote:
>
> I'm shopping for a wireless card for my IBM Thinkpad 600e 
> to work with 
> linux Fedora Core 1.  I would like to know if I should go PCMCIA or 
> perhaps USB.  Is there a card manf. that anyone recommends 
> to go with or stay away from?

  I have an Orinoco Gold (B only) card in a laptop running FC1 that I'm very
happy with.  It seems to work better than most of the cards out there.  It
also has an external antenna jack if your location needs a little extra gain
or even a can'tenna.  

  I've loaned out the card a couple of times to people who couldn't get
other WiFi cards to work at their location.  The Orinoco Gold card has
worked fine.  

  I also have a Linksys WPC11 that ran flaky under FC1.  It used to lose
it's connection to the WAP on random occasions.  It took a reboot to clear
the condition.  I don't recommend using the Linksys with FC1.  I only use
that card in my (work) Windows laptop these days.  

> I see Fry's has an SMC protocol G/B on sale that I would 
> like to buy as I would like G/B.

The SeattleWireless Hardware Comparison is a great resource.  
http://www.seattlewireless.net/index.cgi/HardwareComparison

  I recently picked up a D-Link B/G WAP and a B/G PCI card based on the
SeattleWireless page and other info.  I'm not going to bother replacing my
PCMCIA card.  The throughput of 802.11B is OK for general web surfing.  

  The  D-Link WAP seems to work OK.  I haven't had a chance to fire up the
PCI card yet.  

Steve D...

I'd like to thank all of those Pluggers who have done so much to make this

power supply.  I shorted the PS pins with a screwdriver and get the same
results.

A slight fan twitch with both power connectors on the motherboard, full
CPU fan motion (but no beeps) when only the ATX1 connector is attached.

Fudge.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Jul  9 14:16:01 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Jul  9 14:16:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: P4 woes.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407091345140.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407081205160.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1089390134.1697.33.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407091345140.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1089408479.10618.50.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2004-07-09 at 14:02 -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> I took the motherboard out of the case and connected just the CPU and the
> power supply.  I shorted the PS pins with a screwdriver and get the same
> results.

IME, testing components by actually removing them isn't very reliable -
different boards handle these things differently.

The *necessary* components for a system to fire up are the CPU, RAM,
video card, and PSU, generally speaking.  Depending on the motherboard,
a video card may not be necessary and a CPU fan may be necessary.  I'm
sure there are other exceptions.

-- 
Rob                                |  If not safe,
   Jabber: athlonrob at axpr.net   |    one can never be free.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jul  9 15:24:02 2004

On Fri, 9 Jul 2004, Galen Seitz wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:
> > A slight fan twitch with both power connectors on the motherboard,
> > full CPU fan motion (but no beeps) when only the ATX1 connector is
> > attached.
>
> Will the power supply come up with the CPU removed?

Weird, OK.

Here's what happened:

I took off the CPU sink/fan and set it aside (still with power connected
to the header on the motherboard).  I then removed the CPU (leaving the
CPU power connector connected).

Powerup was the same as with the CPU in and the ATX2 NOT connected.  Power
supply and CPU fan come up.

So I reseated the CPU and got the same results... So something has changed
(though I can't imagine what) just in reseating the CPU.

Still no post, though... added RAM and video, same.

	 <20040709004959.GA27356@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Thu, 2004-07-08 at 20:49, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > "Josh Orchard" <josh at emediatedesigns.com> writes
> > To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > Subject: [PLUG] wireless card recommendations
> > Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > 
> > Hello all,
> > 
> > I'm shopping for a wireless card for my IBM Thinkpad 600e to work with
> > linux Fedora Core 1.  I would like to know if I should go PCMCIA or
> > perhaps USB.  Is there a card manf. that anyone recommends to go with
> > or stay away from?
> > 
> > I see Fry's has an SMC protocol G/B on sale that I would like to buy
> > as I would like G/B.
> 
> 
> 1) G is a marketing gimmick.  Unless you really feel the need to move
> streaming video from a computer within your premises, or you are doing
> major backup file transfers with the wrong software,  then 54Mbps
> provides no advantage over 11Mbps.  The pipe into your house is likely
> less than 3Mbps.  OTOH, G uses a higher frequency and is far more
> sensitive to loss of range and multipath.  

WRONG, G uses the same frequency as B.  I just uses a different encoding
scheme and will fall back to B if the signal quality is poor.

From dgc at easystreet.com  Fri Jul  9 17:42:07 2004
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Fri Jul  9 17:42:07 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SuSE 9.1 AMD64 Needed
In-Reply-To: <40EC3264.2040703@easystreet.com>
References: <1088734465.2145.10.camel@athena.freegeek.org> <1088793352.2165.6.camel@athena.freegeek.org> <40EC3264.2040703@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <40EF3B3C.1020200@easystreet.com>

Continuing....

After the initial problems I had with Suse 9.1 amd64, I decided to try a
32 bit experiment using gentoo 2004.1.

Everything was initially fine.  Switching to kernel version 2.6.7 even
solved the acpi problems that forced the initial install (using kernel
2.4.25) to use the parameters "pci=noacpi noapic".

But X windows only runs a few seconds before freezing... (e.g. display
no longer updates; mouse no longer moves).  You can still log in across
the network.  The X server is in an infinite loop; the system log has
the message...

CPU 0: Machine Check Exception: 0000000000000004
Bank 4: b200000000070f0f
Kernel panic: CPU context corrupt

which means memory might be suspect.  I ran one pass of memtest86; it
didn't find any problems.  Probably should run it longer...

dgc



From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Jul  9 18:02:01 2004
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri Jul  9 18:02:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: P4 woes. 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 09 Jul 2004 15:23:26 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407091521190.17167@shaft.bitmine.net> 
Message-ID: <20040710010046.75C808F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:

> 
> On Fri, 9 Jul 2004, Galen Seitz wrote:
> > Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:
> > > A slight fan twitch with both power connectors on the motherboard,
> > > full CPU fan motion (but no beeps) when only the ATX1 connector is
> > > attached.
> >
> > Will the power supply come up with the CPU removed?
> 
> Weird, OK.
> 
> Here's what happened:
> 
> I took off the CPU sink/fan and set it aside (still with power connected
> to the header on the motherboard).  I then removed the CPU (leaving the
> CPU power connector connected).
> 
> Powerup was the same as with the CPU in and the ATX2 NOT connected.  Power
> supply and CPU fan come up.
> 
> So I reseated the CPU and got the same results... So something has changed
> (though I can't imagine what) just in reseating the CPU.
> 
> Still no post, though... added RAM and video, same.

If you have a voltmeter, try to measure all of the supplies.
Alternatively, trying hooking up just the power cable to a sacrificial
disk drive.  If it spins up the +5 and +12 supplies are probably good.
Of course if the CPU fan runs the +12 is likely to be okay.  You could
also try hooking up a keyboard and seeing what the LEDs do.

I think the CMOS reset is a good idea, though I'll be surprised if
it cures the problem.

One other thing is to make sure the reset switch isn't shorted.

galen

From dgc at easystreet.com  Sat Jul 10 10:16:01 2004
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Sat Jul 10 10:16:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SuSE 9.1 AMD64 Needed
In-Reply-To: <40EF3B3C.1020200@easystreet.com>
References: <1088734465.2145.10.camel@athena.freegeek.org> <1088793352.2165.6.camel@athena.freegeek.org> <40EC3264.2040703@easystreet.com> <40EF3B3C.1020200@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <40F02422.50609@easystreet.com>

Dave Clemans wrote:
> 
> CPU 0: Machine Check Exception: 0000000000000004
> Bank 4: b200000000070f0f
> Kernel panic: CPU context corrupt
> 

I wonder if "Bank 4" could be video memory; the motherboard 512mb is
bank 0 and bank 1.  The motherboard memory got through a 16 hour 75
pass memtest86 run with flying colors.

The error might also be video driver related.

After a quick google search, there is another report of a 32 bit
immediate X server freeze on the m6809; that person never tried to
come in via the network to check logfiles after the freeze though.
He said his freeze was fixed by playing around with noacpi, etc.
boot parameters.  So far that doesn't help for me... I'm going to
try xorg (instead of xfree) to see what happens.  I may also go
back soon to 64bit experiments.

I also did some research on the Broadcom wireless chip in the m6809.
There shouldn't be any difficulty getting it running in 32bit mode
using the windows driver and either ndiswrapper or linuxant. 64bit
mode will be harder.  There's a short thread on a kernel mailing list
that basically says...

	it might be possible with a LOT of work to use the 32bit
ndiswrapper in a 64bit kernel by putting it in the same memory segment
as the boot/shutdown code.  But you'd have to write a big glue layer
to translate between 32bit mode, and the 64bit calls in the rest of
the kernel.

	you can't just recompile ndiswrapper with the amd64 compiler,
and then use a 64bit windows drivers (whenever they are created).
Microsoft apparently changed the ndis driver model for windows64
(which might be part of the reason why windows64 is so slow in coming
out, and has so few drivers).  The summary was that you'd have to
write a whole new "ndiswrapper" to work with windows64 ndis drivers.

There was also a comment in one mailing list that at least broadcom
chip might work with the prism54 driver, but the response to that was
skepticism.

dgc

From aaron at bavariati.org  Sat Jul 10 14:36:01 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Sat Jul 10 14:36:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Which kernel: 2.4.26 or 2.6.7?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407101340170.12982@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407101340170.12982@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040710213518.GE27490@bavariati.org>

On Sat, Jul 10, 2004 at 01:44:13PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   My Slackware-10.0 cds arrived today. It offers a choice of the 2.4.26
> (stable) kernel or the 2.6.7 (high-performance) kernel. My question is: high
> performance for what?

Lower latency, so it's more responsive.  More and better drivers.  Many
of the network drivers handle high loads with less CPU time.  

The advantages in 2.6 mainly show on hot new hardware, desktop systems
and high-performance servers.




From jason at crowderfamily.net  Sat Jul 10 14:39:02 2004
From: jason at crowderfamily.net (Jason Crowder)
Date: Sat Jul 10 14:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Which kernel: 2.4.26 or 2.6.7?
In-Reply-To: <20040710205733.GA13431@maybe.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407101340170.12982@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
    <20040710205733.GA13431@maybe.net>

Chris Jantzen said:
> On Sat, Jul 10, 2004 at 01:44:13PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>>   My Slackware-10.0 cds arrived today. It offers a choice of the 2.4.26
>> (stable) kernel or the 2.6.7 (high-performance) kernel. My question is:
>> high
>> performance for what?
>
> Supposedly 2.6 offers significantly better "desktop interactivity"
> under load, which could mean a lot for you, if I understand correctly.

I've been using 2.6 for awhile, and the biggest difference I have found is
that 2.6 offers better disk I/O handling, better swapping, and other
performance enhancers.  2.6 is very sweet and I use it for my home
workstation and can notice a big speed difference.  However, my server I
run 2.4 because it is more stable right now than I've found 2.6 to be.

new-ish portable is the Sony Vaio PCG-V505BC that -- reluctantly -- replaced
my Toshiba Portege 3025CT.

From v_yau3 at hotmail.com  Sat Jul 10 16:47:02 2004
From: v_yau3 at hotmail.com (Vincent Yau)
Date: Sat Jul 10 16:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Which kernel: 2.4.26 or 2.6.7?
Message-ID: <BAY9-F17gpYUgLoomif00023971@hotmail.com>

I have to second all the postings about performance improvement.
I upgraded all 4 boxes that I between home and work.  All of the are using
either 2.6.5 or 2.6.6 and it has significant performance improvement over 
2.4.x.

I use one of the box at home to view movies and that has the most noticable
performance improvement.

I did have problems with Fedora 2/2.6.5/XFree 86/Nvidia Quattro problem
in that this combination cannot fire up X successfully.  I moved to X.org
and everything works just fine.
My other boxes have older video cards and 2.6.x kernel ran just fine.

--Vincent

Subject: [PLUG] What the heck is an external PHYceiver
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407102036260.31331-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

I'm looking for a new MB for a PVR I'm putting together and keep running
into boards with an 'external PHYceiver' in the LAN area.  Doing some web
searching I find lots of MB's with an interface to an 'external PHYceiver'
but nothing explaing what it looks like or what the heck it really is.
   I also have an Amptron MB with a LAN port that has never worked and 
looking in the MB manual it uses similar terminology.  Never worked 
meaning though my Fedora Core 1 install sees it and recognizes it I get 
can no traffic to flow on the LAN.

So before I buy another MB that has a -- worthless to Linux -- LAN port I
thought I'd should do some checking.

Got any pointers to good reading on these thingies?


TIA,

upgraded to the 2.6.7 kernel it is unable to find my CDRW/dvd combo drive.  I 
have dug around and been unable to find any reference to this problem.  It 
does not seem to exist even to hdparm.  This is a very recent issue and I am 
stumped.  I did not have this issue with the 2.6.6 kernel under FC2 or 
Gentoo.  No I do not want to go back to using ide-scsi, if that is the only 
solution I will just change distros.  Any shots with a clue bat would be 
greatly appreciated.
-Finn

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Sat Jul 10 22:27:01 2004
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Sat Jul 10 22:27:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: What the heck is an external PHYceiver
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407102036260.31331-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407102218200.12763-100000@mail.mpcu.com>

On Sat, 10 Jul 2004, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> I'm looking for a new MB for a PVR I'm putting together and keep running
> into boards with an 'external PHYceiver' in the LAN area.  Doing some web
> searching I find lots of MB's with an interface to an 'external PHYceiver'
> but nothing explaing what it looks like or what the heck it really is.

I believe it means that the network interface has a MII (media independent 
interface) and you would have to provide the transceiver part of the 
interface.  I first saw this on cisco equipment about 8 years ago but so 
far not on pc motherboards.  The MII allows to have ethernet on copper or 
ethernet on fiber or whatever media type.  My feeling is, it would be be 
good to steer clear of such motherboards and make sure they have a RJ-45 
connector.

>    I also have an Amptron MB with a LAN port that has never worked and 
> looking in the MB manual it uses similar terminology.  Never worked 
> meaning though my Fedora Core 1 install sees it and recognizes it I get 
> can no traffic to flow on the LAN.
> 
> So before I buy another MB that has a -- worthless to Linux -- LAN port I
> thought I'd should do some checking.
> 
> Got any pointers to good reading on these thingies?
> 
> 
> TIA,
> Rod
> 




From drl at drloree.com  Sat Jul 10 22:37:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Jul 10 22:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] What the heck is an external PHYceiver
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407102036260.31331-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407102036260.31331-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <1089524287.1697.49.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2004-07-10 at 20:47, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> I'm looking for a new MB for a PVR I'm putting together and keep running
> into boards with an 'external PHYceiver' in the LAN area.  Doing some web
> searching I find lots of MB's with an interface to an 'external PHYceiver'
> but nothing explaing what it looks like or what the heck it really is.
>    I also have an Amptron MB with a LAN port that has never worked and 
> looking in the MB manual it uses similar terminology.  Never worked 
> meaning though my Fedora Core 1 install sees it and recognizes it I get 
> can no traffic to flow on the LAN.
> 
> So before I buy another MB that has a -- worthless to Linux -- LAN port I
> thought I'd should do some checking.
> 
> Got any pointers to good reading on these thingies?

It looks like it is the electronic interface that provides the Physical
link to the rest of the network interface.

http://www.davicom.com.tw/big5/download/Data%20Sheet/DM9000_Application_Notes_Ver_1_22%20061104.pdf

This link has a diagram showing one manufacturers interpretation of the
interface.

HTH,

Derek Loree





From allyn at well.com  Sun Jul 11 09:10:02 2004
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Sun Jul 11 09:10:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Email Infrastructure Installation Procedure
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.58.0407110905380.18008@well.com>

Folks:

Thank you all for the comments you gave me on my first draft
for a procedure to install and configure an email and
calendering infrastructure.

I have made some revisions to the procedure and have posted
it on my web site.

You are welcome to use this as you see fit. It does include
Postfix/Courier with LDAP authentication. It also allows for
setting up virtual accounts (no entries in the local system
passwd file). It also is integrated with Spamassassin and
Mailman.

The procedure is on www.allyn.com with a link toward the bottom
of the page, or you can go directly to www.allyn.com/new_mail.html

If any of you have a chance, can you please take a peek at this and
provide me with any more criticism or comments for anything that
is wrong or you feel is left out that is important?

Thank you very much

Mark Allyn



From aaron at bavariati.org  Sun Jul 11 12:48:02 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Sun Jul 11 12:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] yoper, 2.6.7 kernel no CDRW
In-Reply-To: <200407102122.24200.finn@graveyard-freelance.org>
References: <200407102122.24200.finn@graveyard-freelance.org>
Message-ID: <20040711194736.GA31003@bavariati.org>

On Sat, Jul 10, 2004 at 09:22:24PM +0800, Finn wrote:
> I have been playing around with Yoper Linux lately and now that I have 
> upgraded to the 2.6.7 kernel it is unable to find my CDRW/dvd combo drive.  I 
> have dug around and been unable to find any reference to this problem.  It 
> does not seem to exist even to hdparm.  This is a very recent issue and I am 
> stumped.  I did not have this issue with the 2.6.6 kernel under FC2 or 
> Gentoo.  No I do not want to go back to using ide-scsi, if that is the only 
> solution I will just change distros.  Any shots with a clue bat would be 
> greatly appreciated.

Did they ever fix IDE-SCSI in 2.6?

2.6.7 has an off-by-one bug in the AGPGART code that has various effects
on PCI stuff:

http://www.ussg.iu.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/0406.2/0391.html

I think the -mm patches have a fix for it, too.
