Subject: [PLUG] Linux dialup server problems
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407111846210.11220@neon.netpro.to>

I'm trying to configure a Fedora 2 box to accept dialup modem connections.
When I call in the phone just rings and rings and rings...
I have the Comtrol RocketModem II installed.  lsmod shows the rocket
module loaded.  dmesg shows the corresponding tty's being created:
/dev/ttyR0 - /dev/ttyR5

I've added the following lines to inittab:

R0:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR0 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR0
R1:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR1 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR1
R2:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR2 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR2
R3:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR3 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR3
R4:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR4 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR4
R5:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR5 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR5

/etc/mgetty+sendfax/login.config has the following added:

/AutoPPP/ -     a_ppp   /usr/sbin/pppd auth -chap +pap login debug modem crtscts proxyarp lock ms-dns 4.2.2.4


/etc/ppp/pap-secrets has the following:

testuser * mypassword 172.16.1.50


testuser also exists as a regular user on the system.

I ran "telinit q" and the mgetty processes show up in the ps output.

"stty -a < /dev/ttyR0" shows the modem port is functioning.

/var/log/messages is filled with lines like this:

Jul 11 18:56:26 dialup mgetty[3153]: failed in mg_init_data, dev=ttyR0, pid=3153
Jul 11 18:56:44 dialup mgetty[3154]: init chat failed, exiting...: Interrupted system call

/var/log/mgetty.log.ttyR0 has messages like this:

07/11 18:57:12 yR0  lowering DTR to reset Modem
07/11 18:57:12 yR0   tss: set speed to 115200 (10002)
07/11 18:57:12 yR0   tio_set_flow_control( HARD )
07/11 18:57:12 yR0   waiting for line to clear (VTIME), read:
07/11 18:57:13 yR0  send: AT&F[0d]
07/11 18:57:13 yR0  waiting for ``OK''
07/11 18:57:13 yR0   got:
07/11 18:57:33 yR0  timeout in chat script, waiting for `OK'
07/11 18:57:33 yR0  init chat timed out, trying force-init-chat
07/11 18:57:33 yR0  send: \d[10][03]\d\d\d+++\d\d\d[0d]\dATQ0V1H0[0d]
07/11 18:57:37 yR0  waiting for ``OK''


Any ideas what I'm missing?
Thanks,
~M

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon Jul 12 03:51:02 2004
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Mon Jul 12 03:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] I have a PERL itch
References: <mailman.1089617288.16909.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <864qodmrfq.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Chris" == Chris Penwell <romanmir at comcast.net> writes:

Chris> The downside is that I have zero experience in PERL.

Are you looking for "Perl" perhaps?  There's no such thing as "PERL",
as far as I know, unless someone has invented something recently to
fill that niche.

As for parsing that page with Perl, take a look at the HTML::Parser
module, or in particular, the HTML::TableExtract module.  You can
look at the documentation for those with "perldoc $modulename" if they're
installed, or by searching for those names in the box at search.cpan.org.

If you need a good book to start learning Perl, I'd suggest my book of
the same name, "Learning Perl", followed by "Learning Perl Objects
References and Modules" for larger programs.  If you want those same
books presented live, we offer local 4-day intensives at OGI
(cpd.ogi.edu).  Looks like the next two classes are the weeks of 8/24
and 8/30.

From publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com  Mon Jul 12 12:34:02 2004
From: publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com (Ovid)
Date: Mon Jul 12 12:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] I have a PERL itch
In-Reply-To: <B0032362955@7of9.nwnetcom.com>
Message-ID: <20040712193319.76309.qmail@web60803.mail.yahoo.com>

--- Chris Penwell <romanmir at comcast.net> wrote:
> 	Thanks for the direction. I think I may have found something that
> will work written in C. 
> 
> http://freshmeat.net/projects/htmlscrub/ 
> 
> 	I haven't tested it yet but I'm thinking it should work fairly well
> for what I want to do.

Just glancing at it suggests that similar functionality in Perl is quick 'n easy:

  use HTML::TokeParser::Simple;
  my %bad_tag       = (
    applet => 1,
    script => 1,
    font   => 1,
  );
  my @bad_attribute = qw/onclick onfocus onblur/;

  my $parser = HTML::TokeParser::Simple->new(shift @ARGV); # get filename from command line

  my $new_html = '';
  while (my $token = $parser->get_token) {
    next if $bad_tag{ $token->return_tag };
    $token->delete_attr($_) foreach @bad_attribute;
    $new_html .= $token->as_is;
  }
  print $new_html;

Cheers,
Ovid

=====
Silence is Evil            http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/philosophy/indexdecency.htm
Ovid                       http://www.perlmonks.org/index.pl?node_id=17000
Web Programming with Perl  http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/cgi_course/

From aaron at bavariati.org  Mon Jul 12 18:27:01 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Jul 12 18:27:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Testing serial port on portable
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407121806470.4997@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407121806470.4997@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040713012659.GA3535@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Jul 12, 2004 at 06:07:04PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Does anyone have a suggestion how I can test the serial port on the rear
> of an IBM ThinkPad 600E? We cannot sync the Handspring on it and everything
> works just fine on a workstation.

Null-modem cable to another PC and a terminal program on each end.
(Minicom in Linux, HyperTerminal in Windows.) I have a spare null-modem
or two kicking around if you need one.

>   Permissions, /dev/pilot, everything else seems to be fine but there's no
> communications even using pilot-xfer.

Is the PPP module loaded?  Maybe something like that is locking the
port.  I recently had to figure out that you have to unload LP before
loading the PP networking module.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul 12 19:03:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jul 12 19:03:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Testing serial port on portable
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407121849490.17167@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407121806470.4997@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

From lug at phxlinux.org  Tue Jul 13 08:19:01 2004

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407111846210.11220@neon.netpro.to>

Solved...  the program that loaded the firmware wasn't compatible with the
2.6 kernel so I reinstalled with Fedora 1 and now everything works great.

> R2:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR2 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR2
> R3:2345:respawn:/sbin/mgetty ttyR3 -m '"" AT&F OK' -D -x9 -s 115200 ttyR3

From rlucas at tercent.com  Tue Jul 13 10:16:02 2004
From: rlucas at tercent.com (Randall Lucas)
Date: Tue Jul 13 10:16:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem outdial service -- starting points for my research
Message-ID: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>

Hi PLUG,

I'm looking at a project that may involve dialing out to get telemetry 
from units that don't have always-on Internet (archaic, I know).  While 
setting up 1..n modems for small n seems trivial, if n scales much 
beyond a reasonable chassis size it seems like it could get hairy.

Is there a name for equipment meant to do mass-outdial modem work?  I 
surmise that local ISPs must have modem banks to do inbound work.  Do 
they farm out modem banks for doing outbound work as well?

If anyone has a starting place for some googling (even just some of the 
jargon used in this field), I would appreciate it.  If you have 
experience setting this stuff up professionally, please contact me 
off-list to discuss a possible work opportunity.

Best,

Randall



From raanders at acm.org  Tue Jul 13 10:26:02 2004
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue Jul 13 10:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Switching SCSI host cards
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407131012400.18529-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

I have, what looks like, a SCSI host card going south.  I bought a new one
though a different brand and in a foolish moment thought I could just
switch them.  Not so, at least in my setup.  The boot process can't find 
the new SCSI host module.

I'm looking for ideas with the least amount of heartache and discontent to 
get the system booting with the new SCSI host card.

Currently I'm thinking I'll install the new card along side the old 
one, insmod the module for it, and do a mkinitrd for the new 
configuration.
   Does this raise any red flags for anyone?
   Any better suggestions?

 
TIA,
Rod

    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"





From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Jul 13 10:38:02 2004
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Jul 13 10:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wyvern and FC1
Message-ID: <1089740223.30259.17.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

I'm stuck trying to install the Wyvern (MUD) client on my FC1 system.

It requires that I be able to run the "java" program on my PC, which I
cannot find, nor an rpm. I cannot run #java -version, no such comand or
filename.

What do I need to do?

Here's the installation guide from http://www.cabochon.com 


You can use the Cross-Platform installer on any system that has Java
1.4.1 or higher. 

      * Make sure you have J2SE 1.4.1 or newer installed on your system.
        You should be able to type "java -version" to see if it's the
        right version.
        
      * Download the Pure Java/Cross Platform Installer and place it in
        a temp folder. 
        
      * Go into the temp folder and type "java -jar install.jar". This
        will launch the installer program. 
        
      * To run the Wyvern Client, create a launcher for your system that
        contains the following command. (Assumes you've installed it in
        the directory: /wyvern/client
               java -Dwyvern.home="/wyvern/client/wyvern" \
               -cp "wyvernclient.jar;jl020.jar;jogg-0.0.5.jar;jorbis-0.0.12.jar;mp3sp.1.5.jar;vorbisspi0.7.jar" \
               wyvern.client.Client
      * Run your newly-created launcher to run the client.
-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Computers
Your key to technology that works
mikedela at ipns.com
503-702-6749 





From sean at fork.com  Tue Jul 13 10:48:02 2004
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Tue Jul 13 10:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem outdial service -- starting points for my research
In-Reply-To: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
References: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
Message-ID: <1089740798.1413.7.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I think a cisco 2600 with a modem bank is what you are looking for.  I
believe you can configure them to do dialout depending on traffic.

The nice thing about this is the routing takes care of growth.  If you
need more modems you can buy more hardware and add more routing.  The
connection will take care of itself.

When I was doing it you could buy modem banks from Cisco in groups of 6,
so I believe that you could get a total of 48 into a Cisco 2600 which
would be 2 t1's worth of dialout.

It's been a while, but I believe this is where I would start looking.



Sean

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jul 13 10:49:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jul 13 10:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem outdial service -- starting points for my research
In-Reply-To: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
References: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407131042170.16205@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 13 Jul 2004, Randall Lucas wrote:

> I'm looking at a project that may involve dialing out to get telemetry
> from units that don't have always-on Internet (archaic, I know).  While
> setting up 1..n modems for small n seems trivial, if n scales much beyond
> a reasonable chassis size it seems like it could get hairy.

> If anyone has a starting place for some googling (even just some of the
> jargon used in this field), I would appreciate it.  If you have experience
> setting this stuff up professionally, please contact me off-list to
> discuss a possible work opportunity.

Randall,

  Because you write that the data loggers do not have always-on 'Net
connections we can assume that this is not real-time data acquisition. In
this case, why not have a single modem at your data collection site the
polls the remote sites in sequence and at fixed intervals?

  The systems I have set up in the Real World involve waterproof data
loggers submerged in rivers. A tech goes out every month or two, hauls on
the hidden tether to retrieve each logger, downloads the data to a portable
computer, resets the logger and tosses it back into the water before hiding
the tether again. (Vandalism is a chronic problem out in the boonies.)

  On another project -- long ago and far away, in another galaxy named
Florida -- we had instrumented platforms set up in Lake Apopka. Data from
the instruments was sent in real time to the Water Management District's
headquarters by radio where it was caught and processed by PCs running QNX.

  There are definite solutions to your problem. Can you define it more
closely?

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

I would hook the drives up to the new SCSI controller and boot to a CD,

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jul 13 11:14:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)

Subject: [PLUG] Switching SCSI host cards

On Tue, 2004-07-13 at 10:25, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> Currently I'm thinking I'll install the new card along side the old 
> one, insmod the module for it, and do a mkinitrd for the new 
> configuration.
>    Does this raise any red flags for anyone?
>    Any better suggestions?

That's what I'd do.  In the future, you can run mkinitrd with the flag
to have it add in the module for the new controller and boot with the
new initrd after replacing the card.

Wil

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jul 13 11:55:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Jul 13 11:55:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Switching SCSI host cards
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407131012400.18529-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407131012400.18529-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <8832-79662@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 13 Jul 2004, Roderick A. Anderson raanders-at-acm.org |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I have, what looks like, a SCSI host card going south.  I bought a new
> one though a different brand and in a foolish moment thought I could
> just switch them.  Not so, at least in my setup.  The boot process can't
> find the new SCSI host module.

I have had problems in the past with different brands of SCSI controllers
presenting different Cylinder/Head/Sector geometry to the host which could
make your partition table invalid.

Get a copy of your MBR from the original card (if possible) so you can do
the appropriate translations if needed.

  -- Steve

From guy1656 at ados.com  Tue Jul 13 11:58:02 2004
From: guy1656 at ados.com (GLL)
Date: Tue Jul 13 11:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem IN-dial service?
In-Reply-To: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
References: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
Message-ID: <200407131208.14803.guy1656@ados.com>


On Tuesday 13 July 2004 10:13, Randall Lucas wrote:
: Hi PLUG,
:
: I'm looking at a project that may involve dialing out to get telemetry
: from units that don't have always-on Internet (archaic, I know).  While
: setting up 1..n modems for small n seems trivial, if n scales much
: beyond a reasonable chassis size it seems like it could get hairy.
:
: Is there a name for equipment meant to do mass-outdial modem work?  I
: surmise that local ISPs must have modem banks to do inbound work.  Do
: they farm out modem banks for doing outbound work as well?

Even before the Internet there were automated, mechanical devices which did 
the opposite - the field units dialed in and uploaded a spurt of data, then 
hung up. These could be timed to dial in according to schedule, or also 
programmed to dial in if an event occurred which required unusual attention - 
such as an overfill or fuel-low alarm at a remote storage tank.

Even earlier, home alarm systems had tape-loop devices which could send one or 
more pre-recorded messages to various telepone numbers.

The only problem is to TURN off these devices when the need ends - otherwise, 
as time passes and numbers get re-assigned you will have a storage tank in a 
long out-of-business gas station in Maine start dialing some poor sap in 
Bedford MA, every eight minutes with a 'help-me' beep whose meaning has long 
since been forgotten.

- GLL

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Where Speed & Service Have Always Mattered @ http://www.ados.com




From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue Jul 13 12:03:02 2004

>  The systems I have set up in the Real World involve waterproof data
>loggers submerged in rivers. A tech goes out every month or two, hauls on
>the hidden tether to retrieve each logger, downloads the data to a portable
>computer, resets the logger and tosses it back into the water before hiding
>the tether again. (Vandalism is a chronic problem out in the boonies.)
>
>  On another project -- long ago and far away, in another galaxy named
>Florida -- we had instrumented platforms set up in Lake Apopka. Data from
>the instruments was sent in real time to the Water Management District's
>headquarters by radio where it was caught and processed by PCs running QNX.
>
>  There are definite solutions to your problem. Can you define it more
>closely?
>
>Rich
>
>  
>
I recently built a dial out router for a friend.  MCI tried to charge 
$380 for less than
an hour of phone calls mostly under a minute a piece to a place about an 
hour's drive
away.  Phone service, at least CenturyTel's, can be hazardous to your 
pocket book.  
Consider buying phoneline simulation equipment.  I think skutch 
smiulators start at
$80 for a reasonable one with dialtone.  My guess is that you will want 
a teltone
system, though you should look beyond what E-Bay has to offer.  I wonder
if the data is real time.  After all, you can be real time when your 
probes dial a
connection if there's enough bandwidth.  Depending on how your data is 
encoded
and what you have to send, dial up may be adequate.

See if your server center can use a DSL variant that gives you twenty 
phones instead
of a high speed digital Internet connection.  You might want to research 
telephone
over WiFi and 56k radio technology as well.

Telephone service is not reasonably priced in most places.  In some 
remote locations,
it costs as much as the DSL does.  Be aware if the price is high that 
your looking at
a huge investment for scores of phonelines.  Long distance is a big 
problem, that's
why the Internet and cells phone are so hot.  Cable service is hot 
because telephone
service, usually required for DSL, is burdened by so many taxes, etc.

If your data isn't real time, recording it on site and picking up the 
recorders later may
prove to be cheaper.

     --  Michael Robinson




From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Jul 13 12:12:02 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Jul 13 12:12:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Testing serial port on portable
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407121806470.4997@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407121806470.4997@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1089745858.13169.29.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Cheap and easy.

Get a paper clip.  Short from Tx to Rv pins.  It is easier on a female
plug, so grab a cable.  Google the proper pins.  Make sure you are
grounded (on a PC, this is easy, the case is ground by the power cord. 
On a laptop that may not be).

Search dmesg, /var/log/messages for something like:

        grep -i -i tty /var/log/messages
        Jul 13 14:06:35 localhost cardmgr[13728]: executing: './serial start ttyS1'
        Jul 13 14:06:35 localhost kernel: ttyS01 at port 0x02f8 (irq = 3) is a 16550A

So open minicom as root. Pick /dev/ttyS1 (or ttyS0).  Note the ttyS01
means /dev/ttyS1.  Set to 300 baud, no handshaking (no software or
hardware).  Initialize Modem.

Type keys in minicom.  You should see them back.

If not check error logs.


On Mon, 2004-07-12 at 20:07, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Does anyone have a suggestion how I can test the serial port on the rear
> of an IBM ThinkPad 600E? We cannot sync the Handspring on it and everything
> works just fine on a workstation.
> 
>   Permissions, /dev/pilot, everything else seems to be fine but there's no
> communications even using pilot-xfer.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Rich
-- 




From cmorthland at christenson.com  Tue Jul 13 12:27:01 2004

From cstevens at gencom.us  Tue Jul 13 13:05:03 2004
From: cstevens at gencom.us (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Tue Jul 13 13:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Backup Software
In-Reply-To: <40F4300C.2040001@comcast.net>
References: <40F4300C.2040001@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1089749039.8182.46.camel@localhost>


On Tue, 2004-07-13 at 11:55, R. Haack wrote:

> I just found out from my boss that I'm responsible for backing up one of 
> our Linux servers that we've had for almost a year.  


Oh, good. That tells me that it's serving an important enough function
so as to be backed up. Excellent!


> I know there are 
> quite a few different options to do tape backups but I was wondering 
> what some of you might suggest?  We have an HP DLT IV drive for this 
> system.  


[snip]

I have used a two-teir approach for my clients. 

First, I set up a "headless" backup server for processing the backups.
Every evening, each of the servers "rsync's" their data stores to the
backup server. Here's the good part: The backup area of the backup
servers is a samba share. 

In this scenario, users can click through the network neighbor hood to
the backup server, then click the folder of the server they want (file
server, mail server, whatever), and retrieve their information
themselves. Each server has 8 folders underneath, one for each day of
the week ("I remember having that file on Wednesday...") and a folder
marked "current," which is a compilation "full" of all of the week's
folders.

The permissions on the backup server is the same as the primary servers.
This prevents someone from the clerical staff "restoring" a file from
the President's home directory.

The second level of backups is the tape drive. The tapes are often sent
to a safety deposit box in the event of a natural disaster. 

For the tape backup part I highly recommend Amanda. Amanda can be
somewhat tricky to set up but once it's set up it works great. Here are
some of the things I like best about Amanda:

  1) It is capable (and practical) of backing up users' data stored on
the PC's local hard drive through the network neighborhood

  2) It sends an email every morning to admin-configurable email
addresses that contain statistics of the previous day's backup. It's
very thourough

  3) Amanda's config files are in plain text and plain English. It also
keeps an accurate record of those files that are backed up on a daily
basis for accurate backup auditing

  4) Amanda checks itself (I do it at 2:00 in the afternoon) so that
should there be any problem (wrong tape, remote server down, etc.)
Amanda sends an email to the backup team alerting them of the trouble,
"while they can still do something about it."

  5) Restorations from Amanda tapes may be performed even if Amanda
itself is not available wich leads to...

  6) Amanda performs it's backups by coordinating the standard Unix
"dump" utility.

In short, a two-tier backup system is really a nice way to perform your
backups. I would be happy to share my scripts should you need them.


Best,

-- 
--------------------------------------------------------------
| Cooper Stevenson        | Em:  cooper at gencom.us            |
| GenCom                  | Ph:  541.924.9434                |
| "Working For IT"        | Www: http://www.gencom.us        |

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jul 13 13:18:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jul 13 13:18:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Backup Software
In-Reply-To: <40F4300C.2040001@comcast.net>
References: <40F4300C.2040001@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407131303500.16489@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 13 Jul 2004, R. Haack wrote:

> I just found out from my boss that I'm responsible for backing up one of
> our Linux servers that we've had for almost a year.  I know there are
> quite a few different options to do tape backups but I was wondering
> what some of you might suggest?  We have an HP DLT IV drive for this
> system.  Here is what I must have:
>
> - Ability to do multiple incremental backups onto a single tape.
> - Full backups
> - Restore capabilities
> - Since I'm the most experienced Linux person in my department I would
> like something straight forward that my   co-workers can use in case I'm
> on vacation or get hit by a bus or something.
> - I prefer free, but I can spend money for backup software if I need to.

  I'm sure you'll get a lot of replies using tar, rsync and other readily
available tools. I'd like to put in a plug (no pun intended) for the
software I've been using for 7 years: BRU. Yes, it's commercial but it also
just works and the support for configuration (or when there are errors or
missing information in the manual) is outstanding.

  Here everthing's run from a cron job. I have a Tandberg SLR-60 drive that
has worked flawlessly for the past 3+ years (which is more than I can say
for any of the other brands or types of drives). Anyway, one cron job runs
at 1:00 am M-Tu-W-Th and does an incremental backup of both
workstation/servers. On Friday nights (at 10:30 pm because it used to take 6
hours to do a full backup) a full backup is run. Each run automatically
verifies what has been written to tape. The only job is to remember to
switch tapes on Friday and put the weekly tape in on Monday. Of course, if
folks work on weekends you'll want to do your incrementals then, too.

  There are other vendors who advertise their pretty GUI applications. IMO,
backups should run as cron jobs so no GUI is required. And, restores should
be infrequent enough that typing on the command line should not cause
physical injury.

  I've restored everything to a new hard drive and it's worked like a charm.
I've restored single filesystems, directories and files with no problems at
all. Once I inadvertently deleted all the dot-files in my home directory. A
couple of minutes later they were all restored.

  The company also provides a bare-metal restore facility called CRU (Crash
Recovery Utility). I've never needed it so I cannot write anything about it.

  In my case, my entire business is dependent upon these machines and what
they contain. I don't mind spending money for the peace of mind I get from
this flawlessly running application. It will backup Microsoft and Apple
systems, too, as well as linux and whatever other flavors of *nix you have.
Check out <http://tolisgroup.com/>.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

nasties.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jul 13 13:37:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Jul 13 13:37:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Switching SCSI host cards
In-Reply-To: <20040713190302.8780.14977.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040713190302.8780.14977.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040713203535.GA1969@gate.kl-ic.com>

"Roderick A. Anderson" <raanders at acm.org> writes:
> I have, what looks like, a SCSI host card going south.  I bought a new one
> though a different brand and in a foolish moment thought I could just
> switch them.  Not so, at least in my setup.  The boot process can't find 
> the new SCSI host module.

SCSI is wonderful except when it isn't, which unfortunately is often.

Others have remarked on the different drivers problems and the different
CHS geometry problems, going from card to card.  Rather than a software
solution, I suggest that you find another copy of the previously working
card. 

SCSI-2 is pretty stable technology, with nothing spectacularly new since
active terminators and DMA.  So staying with an old card design isn't
particularly restrictive.  I have standardized on Adaptec 2940, have 3
deployed, and keep 3 spares.  I plan to keep using these until they
stop appearing on Ebay (95 are for sale right now), and all but one
of the cards croaks.   Then I make a transition to the most popular
card-du-jour (with Linux support) at that future time.

There are a lot of used cards on Ebay, and chances are that there is
someone on this list that has a copy of that same card.  I have an
unused pair of Buslogic BT-930 aka BA81C15 cards, and an Advansys
ABP-960, for example.  Also, Freegeek may have your card. 

For some devices, there are easy upgrade paths.  For specialized and
critical items like SCSI controllers, plan on keeping some tested
spares.  Rebuilding boot kernels and SCSI drive images is no fun.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Tue Jul 13 14:02:02 2004
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Tue Jul 13 14:02:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem outdial service -- starting points for my
 resear ch
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D35@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
Randall Lucas wrote:
> 
> I'm looking at a project that may involve dialing out to get 
> telemetry from units that don't have always-on Internet 
> (archaic, I know).  While setting up 1..n modems for small n 
> seems trivial, if n scales much beyond a reasonable chassis 
> size it seems like it could get hairy.
> 
> Is there a name for equipment meant to do mass-outdial modem 
> work?  I surmise that local ISPs must have modem banks to do 
> inbound work.  Do they farm out modem banks for doing 
> outbound work as well?

  The standard for extending a serial port over an IP network to a dial
server is RFC2217.  We use a Cisco with a ISDN T1 as the interface to the
telco network.  

RFC2217 - Telnet Com Port Control Option
http://sunsite.iisc.ernet.in/collection/rfc/rfc2217.html

The Windows client side software is DialOut/EZ.  They also have server
software.  

DialOut/EZ(tm) Redirector
http://www.tactical-sw.com/de.html

Cisco's comments on setting up an RFC2217 server:

Using Dialout/EZ with a Cisco Access Server
http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/hw/univgate/ps501/products_configuration
_example09186a00800a1992.shtml

There is an open-source RFC2217 server available:

sredird
http://www.gnu.org/directory/All_Packages_in_Directory/sredird.html


  I used sredird to set up a simple dual port server back when I was testing
all this stuff.  The software is a bit primitive, but it works OK.  A Linux
boxen with a multiport serial card, modems, and hard lines would work well
if you only need a small number of ports.

  The cost of the server and software would be a minor issue.  The recurring
telecomm costs may be the real problem.  A Cisco with a T1 WATS line may be
*much* cheaper than Linux box and POTS lines.  It depends on the number of
calls you intend to place, the LATA you're calling, and the number of ports
you need.

I'd recommend doing a little cost accounting first.  

Steve D...

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Tue Jul 13 16:48:02 2004
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Tue Jul 13 16:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RE: Modem outdial service -- starting points for my
 re search
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D39@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
Randall Lucas wrote:
> 
> Do you folks or any others know of service providers to whom 
> one can outsource this stuff, or do people who need it 
> generally just get the cisco units and the T1 and make a go of it?
> 
  Serial I/O is getting to be old technology.  Nobody does serial any more.
Cisco sold (or gave) their client software to Tactical Software.  The only
reason we still support it is because some of our users *must* send faxes
from their PC's.  

  Outsourcing to a service provider probably wouldn't be a good idea.
RFC2217 is an extension of telnet. It's inherently insecure.  You *could*
find a service provider to do special install of Cisco out-dial router over
a VPN tunnel, but it would probably be crazy expensive.  

  Any competent outsourcing shop, like Wil's Naked Ape Consulting, could get
you set up.  You may want to run "sredird" in a test environment to verify
your client side software will work correctly over RFC2217.  The server side
serial I/O stuff is pretty easy to get working.  It's the least of your
worries at this point.  Scaling up the client side to support dozens or
hundreds of lines could get complex.  

Steve D...

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue Jul 13 17:52:01 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Tue Jul 13 17:52:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem outdial service -- starting points for my resear
 ch
In-Reply-To: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D35@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
References: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D35@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Daggett, Steve wrote:

> 
>Randall Lucas wrote:
>  
>
>>I'm looking at a project that may involve dialing out to get 
>>telemetry from units that don't have always-on Internet 
>>(archaic, I know).  While setting up 1..n modems for small n 
>>seems trivial, if n scales much beyond a reasonable chassis 
>>size it seems like it could get hairy.
>>
>>Is there a name for equipment meant to do mass-outdial modem 
>>work?  I surmise that local ISPs must have modem banks to do 
>>inbound work.  Do they farm out modem banks for doing 
>>outbound work as well?
>>    
>>
>
>  The standard for extending a serial port over an IP network to a dial
>server is RFC2217.  We use a Cisco with a ISDN T1 as the interface to the
>telco network.  
>
>RFC2217 - Telnet Com Port Control Option
>http://sunsite.iisc.ernet.in/collection/rfc/rfc2217.html
>
Is the idea here to simply route instead of giving a direct dial-out 
connection
to each host in a remote network?  I'm not getting why a host
computer needs to control a modem on a server it goes out through.
My intuition is that the dial-out server should be transparent and
taking care of itself.

     --  Michael Robinson




From lhomer at comcast.net  Tue Jul 13 18:12:02 2004
From: lhomer at comcast.net (lhomer)

Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives

I have a new computer with Windows XP in the second drive, and newly
installed Suse 9.0 on the first. When logged onto the Linux drive I can
read the Windows drive, but can't write. A possible solution is to be
able to read and write the Linux drive while logged into Windows, and I
have heard this can be done. Can you tell me how?

When logged on to Linux about half the Linux drive is occupied with (an
automatically installed) Windows/C drive with the NTFS format, so I
cannot write to this partition while logged on to Linux. How do I get
rid of it, and free the space up, or how how should I reinstall Linux so
that I do not have an NTFS partition on this drive?

>PLUG mailing list

>
Check out http://www.sysrescd.org.

There is the possibility of writing to NTFS, but doing that
safely in Linux could be difficult.  Something called explore2fs
written in Delphi for Windows didn't work very well when I
tried it, but that was a long time ago.  Microsoft doesn't want to
share a computer with anyone else's OS, so it may make sense
to avoid this entirely.  It's a question of how much trouble you
want to go to to make Windows play nice with another OS.
The trouble could cost you in time or money what you can get
a second computer for.

     --  Michael Robinson




From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Tue Jul 13 18:30:03 2004
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Tue Jul 13 18:30:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem outdial service -- starting points for my
 resear ch
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D3B@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
Michael Robinson wrote:
> >
> >RFC2217 - Telnet Com Port Control Option
> >http://sunsite.iisc.ernet.in/collection/rfc/rfc2217.html
> >
> Is the idea here to simply route instead of giving a direct dial-out 
> connection
> to each host in a remote network?  I'm not getting why a host
> computer needs to control a modem on a server it goes out through.
> My intuition is that the dial-out server should be transparent and
> taking care of itself.
> 
  The idea is that the users comm program still thinks it's talking to
ttyS0, COM1, IRQ4, whatever...  A little piece of client side software magic
redirects the comm port to an IP address somewhere in the network.  The
server may have real modems on serial ports or a digital card pretending to
be a bank of modems.  

  The users comm program continues setting comm port speed, parity, stop
bits, and flow control.  It still dials ATDT and expects to see a "Connect"
message.  The only difference is that instead of talking to local hardware,
the commands are redirected over an extension of the telnet protocol to a
remote server.  

  There are many reasons to redirect the comm ports.  Like doing least cost
routing, better quality circuits, better accounting, lower connect charges,
bypassing a digital PBX, or security issues.  

Steve D...



From aaron at bavariati.org  Tue Jul 13 18:43:02 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Jul 13 18:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Modem outdial service -- starting points for my research
In-Reply-To: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
References: <40F4183B.5020907@tercent.com>
Message-ID: <20040714014207.GD6465@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Jul 13, 2004 at 10:13:31AM -0700, Randall Lucas wrote:
> Hi PLUG,
> 
> I'm looking at a project that may involve dialing out to get telemetry 
> from units that don't have always-on Internet (archaic, I know).  While 
> setting up 1..n modems for small n seems trivial, if n scales much 
> beyond a reasonable chassis size it seems like it could get hairy.

I don't understand why you need multiple modems, but commonly I've seen
folks use terminal servers with regular external modems.  There are also
terminal servers with built-in modems.

If money's short, keep an eye out for lower-speed modem units or
terminal servers, since you won't be able to do better than 36 kbaud
dialing from modem to modem anyway.

The value in using terminal servers is that the interface to the host is
TCP/IP and ethernet, so you don't have to have any special hardware in
the server to talk to it.  You can even have multiple servers talking to
it.  And since you're basically using a Telnet connection to the modem
port, it's real easy to write the software that talks to it.

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Tue Jul 13 19:24:02 2004
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue Jul 13 19:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Switching SCSI host cards
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407131012400.18529-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407131012400.18529-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <40F492F7.9070301@comcast.net>

Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

>I have, what looks like, a SCSI host card going south.  I bought a new one
>though a different brand and in a foolish moment thought I could just
>switch them.  Not so, at least in my setup.  The boot process can't find 
>the new SCSI host module.
>
>I'm looking for ideas with the least amount of heartache and discontent to 
>get the system booting with the new SCSI host card.
>
>Currently I'm thinking I'll install the new card along side the old 
>one, insmod the module for it, and do a mkinitrd for the new 
>configuration.
>   Does this raise any red flags for anyone?
>   Any better suggestions?
>
> 
>TIA,
>Rod
>  
>
You've already gotten numerous good answers but I'll pipe up and add 
that you can't just remove an existing SCSI contoller and place it with 
a different model or brand of card. The SCSI processor on the card tends 
to use it's own method of encoding data on the disk. This means that you 
can't  just swap out a SCSI controller with a different model and/or 
brand and have it read your existing data and the disk drive(s). The 
only way you can swap out a controller and have the new one work so you 
can boot your system and read your existing data  is to get the same 
brand and model so that the new card has the same processor as your 
existing card.

I've had a few SCSI controllers go bad on me over the years but I never 
had any issues since I replaced the defective card with the same brand 
and model.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

From bergie at bergie.net  Tue Jul 13 19:42:01 2004
From: bergie at bergie.net (Jason Bergstrom)
Date: Tue Jul 13 19:42:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Switching SCSI host cards
In-Reply-To: <40F492F7.9070301@comcast.net> from "Anthony Schlemmer" at Jul 13, 2004 08:57:11 PM
Message-ID: <E1BkZiJ-0007RU-2t@jack.bergie.net>

> You've already gotten numerous good answers but I'll pipe up and add 
> that you can't just remove an existing SCSI contoller and place it with 
> a different model or brand of card. The SCSI processor on the card tends 
> to use it's own method of encoding data on the disk. This means that you 
> can't  just swap out a SCSI controller with a different model and/or 
> brand and have it read your existing data and the disk drive(s). The 
> only way you can swap out a controller and have the new one work so you 
> can boot your system and read your existing data  is to get the same 
> brand and model so that the new card has the same processor as your 
> existing card.
> 
> I've had a few SCSI controllers go bad on me over the years but I never 
> had any issues since I replaced the defective card with the same brand 
> and model.
> 
> Tony
> -- 
> Anthony Schlemmer
> aschlemm at comcast.net

Not true (except maybe in a hardware raid situation).

You can use any controller that is the same bus type for the disks
and still see the data on the disks.

Having the same brand may make it easier on the software side, but
there is no disk layout specified by a non-RAID SCSI card.

Jason,
bergie at bergie.net



From root at loraksus.org  Tue Jul 13 21:33:02 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Tue Jul 13 21:33:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: windows xp virus removal 
In-Reply-To: <20040714023007.D276D8F0D@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <3744EB1B0502@loraksus.org>

Galen, there is a freeware virus scanner -
Google "Avg freeware". You have to give put your email in order to get an
activation code, but I haven't gotten spam from them and I signed up years
ago.
You probably have a ton of spyware, so I suggest downloading "spy sweeper"
I think it is the best, although shit like "cool web search" and nkvd
hijacker often reinstalls itself somehow. Disabling IE and then installing
firefox pretty much solves the IE hijacks - the crap software is still
installed but doesn't work, so. . .
"cws shredder" and "hijack this" are other good apps, be a bit careful, and
run those after spy sweeper does its work. There is a freeware version of
spy sweeper under their downloads btw. 

You can try using system restore to get back to a pre virus point, but it
will probably fail and you will be better off disabling it as it will gladly
re-infect the system for you. 

You might want to take a knoppix disk so that you can delete windows files
without windows being retarded and preventing you from doing so. Of course,
if they are running ntfs (can home run it?), you will have a joyous time
mounting the damn disk +rw without pooching the directory structure. As you
can tell, this has never happened to me.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Jul 13 21:44:02 2004
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Tue Jul 13 21:44:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Switching SCSI host cards 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Tue, 13 Jul 2004 19:41:43 PDT."
             <E1BkZiJ-0007RU-2t@jack.bergie.net> 
Message-ID: <20040714044316.050738F0D@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Jason Bergstrom <bergie at bergie.net> wrote:

> > You've already gotten numerous good answers but I'll pipe up and add 
> > that you can't just remove an existing SCSI contoller and place it with 
> > a different model or brand of card. The SCSI processor on the card tends 
> > to use it's own method of encoding data on the disk. This means that you 
> > can't  just swap out a SCSI controller with a different model and/or 
> > brand and have it read your existing data and the disk drive(s). The 
> > only way you can swap out a controller and have the new one work so you 
> > can boot your system and read your existing data  is to get the same 
> > brand and model so that the new card has the same processor as your 
> > existing card.
> > 
> > I've had a few SCSI controllers go bad on me over the years but I never 
> > had any issues since I replaced the defective card with the same brand 
> > and model.
> > 
> > Tony
> > -- 
> > Anthony Schlemmer
> > aschlemm at comcast.net
> 
> Not true (except maybe in a hardware raid situation).
> 
> You can use any controller that is the same bus type for the disks
> and still see the data on the disks.
> 
> Having the same brand may make it easier on the software side, but
> there is no disk layout specified by a non-RAID SCSI card.
> 

Agreed.  This only comes into play at boot time when a scsi controller
has to map CHS into a linear block number.  It's possible that the use
of LBA by todays BIOS' has eliminated this issue. 

Once the kernel is running, a SCSI disk will appear the same to any
non-RAID SCSI controller.

galen




From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Tue Jul 13 21:49:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Tue Jul 13 21:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1089780662.6038.8.camel@timmy>

On Tue, 2004-07-13 at 18:10, lhomer wrote:
> I have a new computer with Windows XP in the second drive, and newly
> installed Suse 9.0 on the first. When logged onto the Linux drive I can
> read the Windows drive, but can't write. A possible solution is to be
> able to read and write the Linux drive while logged into Windows, and I
> have heard this can be done. Can you tell me how?

For anything except ext2/3, this is impossible (IIRC). For ext2/3 it is
expensive.

There is a read-write NTFS Linux driver called Captive:

http://www.jankratochvil.net/project/captive/

> When logged on to Linux about half the Linux drive is occupied with (an
> automatically installed) Windows/C drive with the NTFS format, so I
> cannot write to this partition while logged on to Linux. How do I get
> rid of it, and free the space up?

One option is to simply unmount it and reformat it. As long as you don't
have any data on it, this should go well. If you want a partition to
access from Windows and Linux, then make it a FAT32 partition.

The other option is to delete the partition, enlarge the Linux
partition, and then enlarge the filesystem.

I would go into detail here, but I'm pressed for time. Good luck!

Evan

> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

On Tue, 2004-07-13 at 21:34, Karol Kulaga wrote:
> Galen, there is a freeware virus scanner -
> Google "Avg freeware". You have to give put your email in order to get an
> activation code, but I haven't gotten spam from them and I signed up years
> ago.
> You probably have a ton of spyware, so I suggest downloading "spy sweeper"
> I think it is the best, although shit like "cool web search" and nkvd
> hijacker often reinstalls itself somehow. Disabling IE and then installing
> firefox pretty much solves the IE hijacks - the crap software is still
> installed but doesn't work, so. . .
> "cws shredder" and "hijack this" are other good apps, be a bit careful, and
> run those after spy sweeper does its work. There is a freeware version of
> spy sweeper under their downloads btw. 
> 
> You can try using system restore to get back to a pre virus point, but it
> will probably fail and you will be better off disabling it as it will gladly
> re-infect the system for you.

file server.

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Tue Jul 13 22:18:02 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Tue Jul 13 22:18:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard replacement
Message-ID: <20040714051623.13041.qmail@web50609.mail.yahoo.com>

My contemplated project is not Linux-specific, except
that I intend to install Linux on the computer being
modified. I would appreciate any advice that is
offered.

My Pavilion 7950 appears to have a defective
motherboard. Getting another one exactly like it
appears to be unlikely, and perhaps not even
desirable. It uses SDRAM and a 1.2-GHz Athlon
processor.

KSI's KM2M motherboard sells for around $60. It
accepts either SDRAM or DDR, so my investment in the
former would not be wasted. If my current processor
can be assumed to be socket-A, I could even use the
same processor, unless I wanted to upgrade it. The
manual that came with the computer is vague, and does
not say for sure whether the processor is socket-A,
although most AMD processors seem to be.

Usually by the time the motherboard of a computer is
defective, it's time to put the computer out on the
curb early in the morning. But perhaps I can get a
little more use out of the Pavilion.

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

From lamsokvr at xprt.net  Tue Jul 13 23:55:03 2004

On Tue, 2004-07-13 at 23:39, Robert Kopp wrote:
> --- Marv <lamsokvr at xprt.net> wrote:
> 
> > Is this [KM2M] a standard ATX  motherboard??
> > 
> I think they actually use the designation "mini." It
> will definitely fit (24.5 x 23.8 cm), even in the same case.
> 


CPU 
? Supports Socket A for AMD? Athlon(tm)/Athlon(tm) XP/Duron(tm)
Processor 
? Supports up to Athlon XP 2600+ processor. 

Chipset 
? VIA? ProSavageDDR(tm) KM266 Chipset
- FSB @200/266MHz 
- Integrated ProSavage8(tm) 2D/3D Graphic Controller, Up to 32MB Shared
Memory
- AGP 4x and high bandwidth V-link host controller. 
- Advanced memory controller supports PC2100 DDR266 technology. 
? VIA? VT8235 Chipset
- 533MB/sec Vlink client controller.
- Direct sound ready AC97 digital audio controller.
- Ultra DMA 66/100/133 master mode EIDE controller.
- Supports both ACPI and legacy APM power management.
- 6 ports USB 2.0 controller.
- Integrated Ethernet MAC. 

FSB 
? 100/133MHz (200/266MHz) clocks are supported. 

Main Memory 
? Supports four memory banks by using two 184-pin DDR DIMMs or two
168-pin SDRAM DIMMs.
? Supports a maximum memory size of 2GB.
? Supports 2.5v DDR SDRAM DIMM or 3.3v SDRAM DIMM 


Looks like a keeper to me!!!!


NOTE: MSI not KSI....


Good luck.

On Tuesday 13 July 2004 21:51, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> On Tue, 2004-07-13 at 18:10, lhomer wrote:
> > I have a new computer with Windows XP in the second drive, and newly
> > installed Suse 9.0 on the first. When logged onto the Linux drive I can
> > read the Windows drive, but can't write. A possible solution is to be
> > able to read and write the Linux drive while logged into Windows, and I
> > have heard this can be done. Can you tell me how?
>
> For anything except ext2/3, this is impossible (IIRC). For ext2/3 it is
> expensive.
>

The part about ext2/3 is a little confusing to me. After looking at references 
to this software on the web I concluded it is a partition resizer which must 
also have the capability of changing the format of the partition. But if I 
reinstall Linux with a FAT32 partition shouldn't Windows XP be able to read 
and write that partition without any further need for ext2/3?

> There is a read-write NTFS Linux driver called Captive:
>
> http://www.jankratochvil.net/project/captive/
>
> > When logged on to Linux about half the Linux drive is occupied with (an
> > automatically installed) Windows/C drive with the NTFS format, so I
> > cannot write to this partition while logged on to Linux. How do I get
> > rid of it, and free the space up?
>
> One option is to simply unmount it and reformat it. As long as you don't
> have any data on it, this should go well. If you want a partition to
> access from Windows and Linux, then make it a FAT32 partition.
>
> The other option is to delete the partition, enlarge the Linux
> partition, and then enlarge the filesystem.
>
> I would go into detail here, but I'm pressed for time. Good luck!

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Wed Jul 14 08:39:05 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Wed Jul 14 08:39:05 2004
Subject: [PLUG] How to convice kudzu to really leave my USB devices there?
Message-ID: <1089819439.13140.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>

So here is the scenario:

At office I have a couple of USB devices:  KVM, Mouse, Keyboard.

At home I have nothing.

When I get home and power, Kudzu notices the missing USB devices, every
time.  I tell it to ignore, I say keep, next cycle, it asks again.

It does not ask at work when I boot.

So, I could disable kudzu or some other hack, but is there a way to keep
kudzu, but make it respect the "keep configurations" forever?

This is RH fedora (FC1).


--

From gepr at tempusdictum.com  Wed Jul 14 09:41:02 2004
From: gepr at tempusdictum.com (glen e. p. ropella)
Date: Wed Jul 14 09:41:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <1089780662.6038.8.camel@timmy>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com>
	<1089780662.6038.8.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <16629.24813.615009.299094@eris.dischordia.net>

=><=><= "eh" == Evan Heidtmann <clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com> writes:

eh> There is a read-write NTFS Linux driver called Captive:
eh> http://www.jankratochvil.net/project/captive/

Last time I reconfigured my kernel, I seem to remember there being an
experimental option that would allow you to write to NTFS partitions
from Linux.  It had all sorts of warnings about how dangerous it was
and all; but, you might give that a try.

I'd play with it on an expendable NTFS partition first just to see
how dangerous it actually is.

Here's the documentation for the flag:

> CONFIG_NTFS_RW:
>
> If you say Y here, you will (maybe) be able to write to NTFS file
> systems as well as read from them. The read-write support in NTFS
> is far from being complete and is not well tested. If you say Y
> here, back up your NTFS volume first, since it will probably get
> damaged. Also, download the Linux-NTFS project distribution from
> Sourceforge at <http://linux-ntfs.sf.net/> and always run the
> included ntfsfix utility after writing to an NTFS partition from
> Linux to fix some of the damage done by the driver. You should run
> ntfsfix _after_ unmounting the partition in Linux but _before_
> rebooting into Windows. When Windows next boots, chkdsk will be
> run automatically to fix the remaining damage.
> Please note that write support is limited to Windows NT4 and
> earlier versions.
>
> If unsure, say N.

I'm using kernel version 2.4.24; so, perhaps a 2.6 kernel will have
better NTFS support?

-- 
glen e. p. ropella              =><=                           Hail Eris!
H: 503.630.4505                              http://www.ropella.net/~gepr
M: 971.219.3846                               http://www.tempusdictum.com




From gmickels at yahoo.com  Wed Jul 14 09:47:02 2004
From: gmickels at yahoo.com (Garrett Mickelson)
Date: Wed Jul 14 09:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] How to convice kudzu to really leave my USB devices
	there?
In-Reply-To: <1089819439.13140.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1089819439.13140.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1089823599.4820.27.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Hello Zot,
I had a situation where I had a Canon BJ4300 printer connected via
parallel cable detected by Kudzu in Fedora Core 2. When I moved the
system w/o the printer, Kudzu asked about it. I said to keep the
configuration, and it did not ask again. Therefore I assume it is one of
two issues. a) Fedora Core 2 does not have this issue, or more likely b)
because of the relatively new hotplug - udev stuff that may be in FC1
(not certain) it could be causing issues with kudzu. I don't know enough
about how it all works to be much help, but as you research why and a
resolution, these might be good jumping off points. Have you chimed in
to #fedora on the freenode irc server? There may be someone there that
can help.

-Garrett

Subject: [PLUG] PDA sync problems on ThinkPad 600E
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407140944580.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I'm having fits trying to get a Handspring Visor Pro to sync with jpilot
on the IBM ThinkPad 600E. Perhaps someone here has some insight or
suggestions.

  First I tried the serial cradle we have for it. Set
/dev/jpilot->/dev/ttyS0, defined ~/.bash_profile/PILOTPORT=/dev/ttyS0 (and
exported it), specified /dev/ttyS0 in jpilot's settings. Permissions on
/dev/ttyS0 are 666. Will not sync; cannot connect.

  Second try was with the default USB cradle. Changed everything (shown
above) to ttyUSB0. When I test with 'pilot-xfer --list' I immediately see,
"port not connected".

  Third, the jpilot wiki notes that the Visor uses USB1. So, I convert the
above to USB1. Same results: port not connected.

  Now, I may have bought a defective machine with a non-working serial port.
But, a non-working USB port, too? Has anyone any ideas what's going on here
or what I can do to get this working? Is this a project for this Saturday's
clinic?

TIA,

Rich

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Jul 14 09:58:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Jul 14 09:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Big files, little RAM, little disk space... oh, and some Perl
Message-ID: <1089825039.29164.60.camel@dell.linux.box>

I'm working on importing some XML files into a database using perl.  The
files are available only via HTTP and are currently about 6MB compressed
(gzip), 40MB uncompressed.  While I do currently have the disk space for
this, these file are going to likely quadruple in size in the next few
months and I might not be able to handle all that.  Besides, I hate
putting things on disk in the first place.

So what I'm trying to do is this:  Read the gzip'd XML files from the
HTTP server as though they were local uncompressed files *without*
reading them entirely into RAM.  Using PerlIO::gzip, I can read the
compressed files as though they were not compressed, but I can't
currently read the HTTP files as if they were local.

Has anybody conquered this issue before?  I'd rather not write my own IO
driver for HTTP... no sense reinventing the wheel, you know?  :-)

Ideally this script I'm writing will read through the compressed XML
files as though they were local uncompressed files... I'm iterating
through them to save RAM at the moment.

Any pointers?  Am I nuts? ...errr... don't answer that one.

-- 
Rob                                |  If not safe,
   Jabber: athlonrob at axpr.net   |    one can never be free.

First, try this:

# ifconfig eth0

If that returns something that isn't an error, then you've already got 
the driver loaded. Otherwise, try this:

# modprobe pcnet_cs

Evan

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jul 14 10:28:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jul 14 10:28:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PDA sync problems on ThinkPad 600E -- SOLVED
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407140944580.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407140944580.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141024440.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 14 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I'm having fits trying to get a Handspring Visor Pro to sync with jpilot
> on the IBM ThinkPad 600E. Perhaps someone here has some insight or
> suggestions.

  Problem solved. It helps to find a HOWTO that describes what modules need
to be loaded for communications to occur. I was lacking both usbserial.c and
visor.c. I had usb_core and usb_uhci (and, I think, one other) but they
weren't enough.

  Whew! Now to get sound working for her on this machine ....

Rich

From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Jul 14 10:54:01 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed Jul 14 10:54:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Ensuring modules are loaded during boot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141031470.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141031470.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040714175332.GA18660@aracnet.com>

I don't think there's a way to do it in /etc/modules.conf (now 
/etc/modprobe.conf on FC2).

Most redhat-ish distros will check for file /etc/rc.modules and 
execute it at boot time. But don't just list module names in 
/etc/rc.modules. It's run as a shell script, so put the full
commands as in:

   modprobe visor
   modprobe usbserial

Terry

On Wed, Jul 14, 2004 at 10:32:59AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:

On my Debian system, you just put the name of the module (without the .o 
or .ko extension) in /etc/modules.

From mel97215 at comcast.net  Wed Jul 14 11:57:02 2004
From: mel97215 at comcast.net (Mel Andres)
Date: Wed Jul 14 11:57:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <40F581FB.9070906@comcast.net>

lhomer wrote:
> 
> When logged on to Linux about half the Linux drive is occupied with (an
> automatically installed) Windows/C drive with the NTFS format, so I
> cannot write to this partition while logged on to Linux. How do I get
> rid of it, and free the space up, or how how should I reinstall Linux so
> that I do not have an NTFS partition on this drive?
> 
That automatically installed Windows/C drive is in fact the other disk 
with the installed WinXP. Linux simply recognized it and mounted it. If 
you free up that space, you'll no linger have a dual boot system. One 
possible solution is to repartition the windows disk with two 
partitions. The first you would format with NTFS, and install WinXP 
there. The second partition, format with FAT. Then, when you boot Linux, 
you will have a Windows/C partition mounted as NTFS, and a Windows/D 
partition mounted as vfat. You set up you WinXP system so that files you 
want to access read/write are on the D drive (My Documents, etc.). This 
way, all of your WinXP system files (on the Windows/C partition) are 
protected from accidently being deleted or overwritten while in Linux. 
You mentioned that this was a new system, so there should be few 
personal files to save first.

   Mel

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Jul 14 12:11:02 2004
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Wed Jul 14 12:11:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Big files, little RAM, little disk space... oh, and some Perl
References: <mailman.1089824288.31304.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86smbu5rx6.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "AthlonRob" == AthlonRob  <AthlonRob at axpr.net> writes:

AthlonRob> So what I'm trying to do is this:  Read the gzip'd XML files from the
AthlonRob> HTTP server as though they were local uncompressed files *without*
AthlonRob> reading them entirely into RAM.  Using PerlIO::gzip, I can read the
AthlonRob> compressed files as though they were not compressed, but I can't
AthlonRob> currently read the HTTP files as if they were local.

AthlonRob> Has anybody conquered this issue before?  I'd rather not write my own IO
AthlonRob> driver for HTTP... no sense reinventing the wheel, you know?  :-)

I'd just go the braindead simple way:

        open INHANDLE, "lwp-request http://foo/bar | gzcat |") or die;

and start reading INHANDLE, or pass that to your XML parser.  The processes
up the pipe line will be blocked as needed, so you'll never have more
than a few dozen K of RAM burning.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!

From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Jul 14 13:30:11 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed Jul 14 13:30:11 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Ensuring modules are loaded during boot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141129530.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141031470.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <20040714175332.GA18660@aracnet.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141129530.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040714202913.GA24268@aracnet.com>

On Wed, Jul 14, 2004 at 11:32:06AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 14 Jul 2004, Terry Griffin wrote:
> 
> > Most redhat-ish distros will check for file /etc/rc.modules and execute it
> > at boot time. But don't just list module names in /etc/rc.modules. It's
> > run as a shell script, so put the full commands as in:
> >
> >    modprobe visor
> >    modprobe usbserial
> 
> Terry,
> 
>   Many thanks. I just stuck them at the end of /etc/rc.d/rc.local rather
> than putting them in /etc/rc.d/rc.M (it's a Slackware system). It works. I
> was curious why I needed to load them like that since other USB modules are
> automatically loaded.
> 
>   FWIW, the order needs to be reversed, I believe, because visor uses
> usbserial.
>

It should work anyway. The modprobe utility will load any other modules
that are required by the one you requested. There are some odd cases where 
this won't work, in which case it can usually be fixed with a setting in 
/etc/modules.conf.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jul 14 13:53:01 2004

Date: Wed Jul 14 13:53:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Ensuring modules are loaded during boot
In-Reply-To: <20040714202913.GA24268@aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141031470.20713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

From ehem at m5p.com  Wed Jul 14 14:17:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Wed Jul 14 14:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard replacement
In-Reply-To: <20040714134316.21544.94988.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200407142116.i6ELGIqf072314@m5p.com>

>From: Robert Kopp <iconoklastic at yahoo.com>
> My Pavilion 7950 appears to have a defective
> motherboard. Getting another one exactly like it
> appears to be unlikely, and perhaps not even
> desirable. It uses SDRAM and a 1.2-GHz Athlon
> processor.
> 
> KSI's KM2M motherboard sells for around $60. It
> accepts either SDRAM or DDR, so my investment in the
> former would not be wasted. If my current processor
> can be assumed to be socket-A, I could even use the
> same processor, unless I wanted to upgrade it. The
> manual that came with the computer is vague, and does
> not say for sure whether the processor is socket-A,
> although most AMD processors seem to be.
> 
> Usually by the time the motherboard of a computer is
> defective, it's time to put the computer out on the
> curb early in the morning. But perhaps I can get a
> little more use out of the Pavilion.

Given the speed that would be a socket A processor. Be careful when
moving the processor as the core is fully exposed. The big thing to watch
for is whether the power supply is an actual ATX one versus a proprietary
one.

Processors of that speed though are pretty cheap. Unless you're planning
for an AMD64 upgrade in the near future a faster processor and memory
might be worthwhile.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jul 14 16:42:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jul 14 16:42:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] LaTeX and LyX
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407141630430.21996@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  Earlier this year Ed Sawicki and I tried to get a LaTeX/LyX SIG going but
no one other than Geoff showed up at the meetings. I realize that most of
the denizens here are system and network administrators whose writing tends
to consist of shell scripts, perl/php programs and memos to users.

  However, if there are folks here who write more than the occasional, brief
letter or invoice (which can be done with LyX/LaTeX but is much easier in
OO.o), then the LyX GUI front end to LaTeX is the way to go. I've written
all my articles and reports with LyX the past several years and I'm using it
to write my book. Trying to do that with a word processor I'll leave for the
masochists.

  If there is interest in learning how to use this fantastic typesetting
software please contact me off the list. I would like to get a SIG going or
offer tutorials and help duing clinics.

  The subscribers to the lyx-users mail list are outstanding in their
support but there are benefits to having local resources, too. If you are a
student and need to write term papers, a thesis or a dissertation, LyX is
the way to go. If you are writing manuals and other technical documentation
that is better when professionally typeset, LyX is the way to go.

  Lemme' know if you're interested.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From rlucas at tercent.com  Wed Jul 14 18:42:02 2004

Hi folks,

Guru needed for paid contract; simple scripts you've probably already 
written.

I need a set of installation materials and procedures to install woody, 
a specific kernel (for Dell), and certain packages, to go from bare 
metal to "ready for production."  Ideally, this would all be on one 
bootable CD, and would update itself from the net, but at a minimum, it 
would need to be a script runnable after the bare bones install.

I can give more requirements off-list.  Briefly, they include:
-NTP clients up and running for accurate time.
-Firewall up and running with appropriate holes punched through and best 
practice things in place (stopping the ping of death and all that jazz)
-Portsentry up and running for extra overkill.
-Tripwire
-Logrotate
-Apache
-Pine
-Java
-Apt-get for regular security updates
-anything I am forgetting that you justify as best practice
-checklist of any human things that then need to be done (ideally none)

My ideal for this would be to purchase the services of an experienced 
Debian guru, and then post the completed script(s) open-sourced to the 
web for others who share my needs (read: those who know Debian, know it 
works, don't have a mongo-script go get to production-ready and don't 
have time to piece one together by trial and error).

Ideally, you are such a Debian guru as to have *already written this 
system* or know of a tool that can do this, and used it for installs 
many times over -- for me, you'll just tweak it, explain it, and ship 
it.  Compensation to be cash and possible future contract work.  Please 
contact off-list.




From lhomer at comcast.net  Wed Jul 14 19:00:03 2004
From: lhomer at comcast.net (lhomer)
Date: Wed Jul 14 19:00:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <40F581FB.9070906@comcast.net>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com> <40F581FB.9070906@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net>

On Wednesday 14 July 2004 11:56, Mel Andres wrote:
> lhomer wrote:
> > When logged on to Linux about half the Linux drive is occupied with (an
> > automatically installed) Windows/C drive with the NTFS format, so I
> > cannot write to this partition while logged on to Linux. How do I get
> > rid of it, and free the space up, or how how should I reinstall Linux so
> > that I do not have an NTFS partition on this drive?
>
> That automatically installed Windows/C drive is in fact the other disk
> with the installed WinXP. Linux simply recognized it and mounted it. If
> you free up that space, you'll no linger have a dual boot system. One
> possible solution is to repartition the windows disk with two
> partitions. The first you would format with NTFS, and install WinXP
> there. The second partition, format with FAT. Then, when you boot Linux,
> you will have a Windows/C partition mounted as NTFS, and a Windows/D
> partition mounted as vfat. You set up you WinXP system so that files you
> want to access read/write are on the D drive (My Documents, etc.). This
> way, all of your WinXP system files (on the Windows/C partition) are
> protected from accidently being deleted or overwritten while in Linux.
> You mentioned that this was a new system, so there should be few
> personal files to save first.
>
>    Mel

I need to clarify my starting point. I had Windows XP on one physical drive, 
and Linux on a second physical drive. The automatic Suse installation 
partitioned my Linux drive into hda1 (an NTFS partition), hda2 (1 Gbyte swap, 
reiser format, and hda3(the rest, reiser). It also recognized a windows/D 
drive already formatted NTFS. While logged onto linux I could read both NTFS 
partitions but not write to either. While logged onto windows xp, I could 
read or write to the windows drive and to the NTFS partition on the Linux 
drive.

Next try. Reinstall Linux with the Linux NTFS partition converted to FAT32. 
Now I can read and write to that partition from linux, and I can read and 
write to that partition from windows. What I cannot do is write to the 
Windows drive while logged into Linux.

Next download, install compact software as suggested

http://www.jankratochvil.net/project/captive/

seemed to install ok, and renames the icon which brings up the windows drive, 
but I still can't write to that drive. The permissions still have that drive 
tagged as read only and wont let me change them.

Next try?? Perhaps I could add a FAT32 partition to the Window Drive. Then I 
would be able to read and write to part of the Windows drive, just as Windows 
can read and write to the FAT32 partition. If this were to work, it would 
meet my present needs, since I dont intend to meddle with Windows system 
files while logged onto Linux, and dont plan to install rpms from Windows.

What do you think? What should I try next? The group's advice has been very 
helpful to me so far in mapping out a strategy which has me part way to my 
goal. Thank you.




From mel97215 at comcast.net  Wed Jul 14 20:39:02 2004
From: mel97215 at comcast.net (Mel Andres)
Date: Wed Jul 14 20:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com> <40F581FB.9070906@comcast.net> <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <40F5FC45.60407@comcast.net>

lhomer wrote:
>  
> I need to clarify my starting point. I had Windows XP on one physical drive, 
> and Linux on a second physical drive. The automatic Suse installation 
> partitioned my Linux drive into hda1 (an NTFS partition), hda2 (1 Gbyte swap, 
> reiser format, and hda3(the rest, reiser). It also recognized a windows/D 
> drive already formatted NTFS. While logged onto linux I could read both NTFS 
> partitions but not write to either. While logged onto windows xp, I could 
> read or write to the windows drive and to the NTFS partition on the Linux 
> drive.

While booted into linux, go to an xterm window (Konsole), and type:
mount
Then copy the output and paste it into a reply. It should look similar 
to mine:
mel at d8qbcf21:~> mount
/dev/hda7 on / type reiserfs (rw)
proc on /proc type proc (rw)
devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,mode=0620,gid=5)
/dev/hda5 on /boot type ext2 (rw)
/dev/hda2 on /windows/C type ntfs 
(ro,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,nls=iso8859-1)
/dev/hda3 on /windows/D type vfat 
(rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,iocharset=iso8859-1,code=437)
tmpfs on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
mel at d8qbcf21:~>

The difference being that you should have some lines mounted on 
/dev/hdbX (X=some number). The hda lines are partitions on one disk, and 
the hdb lines are the other hard drive's partitions.  In my case, I dual 
boot on a single disk. While booted into WinXP, the system doesn't even 
know the Linux partition exists. But, while in Linux, (almost always) I 
can read and write to the D drive which is mounted vfat. The NTFS 
partition mounted as C, and is read only. It will be the same C and D 
drives in WinXP.

> 
> Next try. Reinstall Linux with the Linux NTFS partition converted to FAT32. 
> Now I can read and write to that partition from linux, and I can read and 
> write to that partition from windows. What I cannot do is write to the 
> Windows drive while logged into Linux.

You will have to reformat that partition. Be sure that no files are 
there that you need. If Suse created the partition, it should be empty 
because Suse won't install the other OS. Ensure that /, /boot are on the 
same hd letter (hdaX or hdbX), as the one you intend to reformat.

> 
> Next download, install compact software as suggested
> 
> http://www.jankratochvil.net/project/captive/
> 
> seemed to install ok, and renames the icon which brings up the windows drive, 
> but I still can't write to that drive. The permissions still have that drive 
> tagged as read only and wont let me change them.
That's a "feature" of NTFS.

> 
> Next try?? Perhaps I could add a FAT32 partition to the Window Drive. Then I 
> would be able to read and write to part of the Windows drive, just as Windows 
> can read and write to the FAT32 partition. If this were to work, it would 
> meet my present needs, since I dont intend to meddle with Windows system 
> files while logged onto Linux, and dont plan to install rpms from Windows.
That was the general idea I was going with. Create a FAT partition, 
because it can be accessed read/write from both operating systems.
> 
> What do you think? What should I try next? The group's advice has been very 
> helpful to me so far in mapping out a strategy which has me part way to my 
> goal. Thank you.

Are you in the Portland area? You might consider bringing it all in to a 
Saturday clinic.

	Mel
