From ian at znark.com  Wed Jul 14 23:09:01 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed Jul 14 23:09:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wyvern and FC1
In-Reply-To: <1089833508.1320.2.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1089740223.30259.17.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>	 <1089743181.4955.14.camel@dan.parkrose.k12.or.us> <1089833508.1320.2.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <40F61F2C.5080908@znark.com>

Mike De La Mater wrote:
> 
> I have something else wrong, then. I have the files in
> /usr/java/jre1.4.2_04/bin/ and /usr/java/jre1.4.2_05/bin/, including the
> executable file "java", but it still fails to invoke from a command
> prompt, as root and as a user.
> 
> Is there a path command that allows it to run from there? 
> 
> Java works fine in Mozilla.
> 
> Is there something else I am missing?
> 

Either put /usr/java/jre1.4.2_05/bin in your PATH environment variable, 
or create a symlink in /usr/bin.

export PATH=$PATH:/usr/java/jre1.4.2_05/bin

ln -sf /usr/java/j2re1.4.2_05/bin/java /usr/bin

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/



From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Wed Jul 14 23:14:02 2004
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Wed Jul 14 23:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wyvern and FC1
In-Reply-To: <1089833508.1320.2.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1089740223.30259.17.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>	 <1089743181.4955.14.camel@dan.parkrose.k12.or.us> <1089833508.1320.2.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <40F62056.1080702@parkrose.k12.or.us>

Mike De La Mater wrote:
> > I have something else wrong, then. I have the files in
> /usr/java/jre1.4.2_04/bin/ and /usr/java/jre1.4.2_05/bin/, including the
> executable file "java", but it still fails to invoke from a command
> prompt, as root and as a user.
> 
> Is there a path command that allows it to run from there? 

You could either run it using the full path, i.e.:

$ /usr/java/jre1.4.2_05/bin/java -version

or add that folder to your path (assuming bash is your shell):

$ export PATH=$PATH:/usr/java/jre1.4.2_05/bin

Then you should be able to just do:

$ java -version

To do that permenantly, tack on the path to the appropriate part of your 
.bashrc

--
Dan Young
Parkrose School District

From drl at drloree.com  Thu Jul 15 02:08:01 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Jul 15 02:08:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com>
	 <40F581FB.9070906@comcast.net>  <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1089882638.12992.47.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2004-07-14 at 18:50, lhomer wrote:
[snip]
> I need to clarify my starting point. I had Windows XP on one physical drive, 
> and Linux on a second physical drive. The automatic Suse installation 
> partitioned my Linux drive into hda1 (an NTFS partition), hda2 (1 Gbyte swap, 
> reiser format, and hda3(the rest, reiser). It also recognized a windows/D 
> drive already formatted NTFS. While logged onto linux I could read both NTFS 
> partitions but not write to either. While logged onto windows xp, I could 
> read or write to the windows drive and to the NTFS partition on the Linux 
> drive.
> 
> Next try. Reinstall Linux with the Linux NTFS partition converted to FAT32. 
> Now I can read and write to that partition from linux, and I can read and 
> write to that partition from windows. What I cannot do is write to the 
> Windows drive while logged into Linux.
> 
> Next download, install compact software as suggested
> 
> http://www.jankratochvil.net/project/captive/
> 
> seemed to install ok, and renames the icon which brings up the windows drive, 
> but I still can't write to that drive. The permissions still have that drive 
> tagged as read only and wont let me change them.
> 
> Next try?? Perhaps I could add a FAT32 partition to the Window Drive. Then I 
> would be able to read and write to part of the Windows drive, just as Windows 
> can read and write to the FAT32 partition. If this were to work, it would 
> meet my present needs, since I dont intend to meddle with Windows system 
> files while logged onto Linux, and dont plan to install rpms from Windows.
> 
> What do you think? What should I try next? The group's advice has been very 
> helpful to me so far in mapping out a strategy which has me part way to my 
> goal. Thank you.

What you really need is a linux server, running on that old PII that XP
choked and regurgitated on.  Meets all of your requirements and more.:)

I always like to have a linux box around when I'm running Winbloze, it
just makes life easier somehow.

Derek Loree





From lhomer at comcast.net  Thu Jul 15 07:10:02 2004
From: lhomer at comcast.net (lhomer)
Date: Thu Jul 15 07:10:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <40F5FC45.60407@comcast.net>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com> <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net> <40F5FC45.60407@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <200407150707.33445.lhomer@comcast.net>

On Wednesday 14 July 2004 20:38, Mel Andres wrote:
> lhomer wrote:
> > I need to clarify my starting point. I had Windows XP on one physical
> > drive, and Linux on a second physical drive. The automatic Suse
> > installation partitioned my Linux drive into hda1 (an NTFS partition),
> > hda2 (1 Gbyte swap, reiser format, and hda3(the rest, reiser). It also
> > recognized a windows/D drive already formatted NTFS. While logged onto
> > linux I could read both NTFS partitions but not write to either. While
> > logged onto windows xp, I could read or write to the windows drive and to
> > the NTFS partition on the Linux drive.
>
> While booted into linux, go to an xterm window (Konsole), and type:
> mount
> Then copy the output and paste it into a reply. It should look similar
> to mine:
> mel at d8qbcf21:~> mount
> /dev/hda7 on / type reiserfs (rw)
> proc on /proc type proc (rw)
> devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,mode=0620,gid=5)
> /dev/hda5 on /boot type ext2 (rw)
> /dev/hda2 on /windows/C type ntfs
> (ro,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,nls=iso8859-1)
> /dev/hda3 on /windows/D type vfat
> (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,iocharset=iso8859-1,code=437)
> tmpfs on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
> usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
> mel at d8qbcf21:~>

Here it is:

lhomer at linux:~> mount
/dev/hde3 on / type reiserfs (rw)
proc on /proc type proc (rw)
devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,mode=0620,gid=5)
/dev/hde1 on /boot type ext2 (rw)
/dev/hdg1 on /windows/C type vfat 
(rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,iocharset=iso8859-1,code=437)
tmpfs on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
lhomer at linux:~>
lhomer at linux:~>



>
> The difference being that you should have some lines mounted on
> /dev/hdbX (X=some number). The hda lines are partitions on one disk, and
> the hdb lines are the other hard drive's partitions.  In my case, I dual
> boot on a single disk. While booted into WinXP, the system doesn't even
> know the Linux partition exists. But, while in Linux, (almost always) I
> can read and write to the D drive which is mounted vfat. The NTFS
> partition mounted as C, and is read only. It will be the same C and D
> drives in WinXP.
>
> > Next try. Reinstall Linux with the Linux NTFS partition converted to
> > FAT32. Now I can read and write to that partition from linux, and I can
> > read and write to that partition from windows. What I cannot do is write
> > to the Windows drive while logged into Linux.
>
> You will have to reformat that partition. Be sure that no files are
> there that you need. If Suse created the partition, it should be empty
> because Suse won't install the other OS. Ensure that /, /boot are on the
> same hd letter (hdaX or hdbX), as the one you intend to reformat.
>
> > Next download, install compact software as suggested
> >
> > http://www.jankratochvil.net/project/captive/
> >
> > seemed to install ok, and renames the icon which brings up the windows
> > drive, but I still can't write to that drive. The permissions still have
> > that drive tagged as read only and wont let me change them.
>
> That's a "feature" of NTFS.
>
> > Next try?? Perhaps I could add a FAT32 partition to the Window Drive.
> > Then I would be able to read and write to part of the Windows drive, just
> > as Windows can read and write to the FAT32 partition. If this were to
> > work, it would meet my present needs, since I dont intend to meddle with
> > Windows system files while logged onto Linux, and dont plan to install
> > rpms from Windows.
>
> That was the general idea I was going with. Create a FAT partition,
> because it can be accessed read/write from both operating systems.
>
> > What do you think? What should I try next? The group's advice has been
> > very helpful to me so far in mapping out a strategy which has me part way
> > to my goal. Thank you.
>
> Are you in the Portland area? You might consider bringing it all in to a
> Saturday clinic.
>
> 	Mel

Date: Thu Jul 15 07:20:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] guru needed - Debian production install scripts - small contract;

In-Reply-To: <40F5E065.9010805@tercent.com>

If you don't find anyone from here, check the Debian consultants
page.  It has seven or so people in the pacnw who list themselves
as experts.

   http://www.debian.org/consultants/

=><=><= "rl" == Randall Lucas <rlucas at tercent.com> writes:

rl> Hi folks,
rl> Guru needed for paid contract; simple scripts you've probably already 
rl> written.

rl> I need a set of installation materials and procedures to install woody, 
rl> a specific kernel (for Dell), and certain packages, to go from bare 
rl> metal to "ready for production."  Ideally, this would all be on one 
rl> bootable CD, and would update itself from the net, but at a minimum, it 
rl> would need to be a script runnable after the bare bones install.

rl> I can give more requirements off-list.  Briefly, they include:
rl> -NTP clients up and running for accurate time.
rl> -Firewall up and running with appropriate holes punched through and best 
rl> practice things in place (stopping the ping of death and all that jazz)
rl> -Portsentry up and running for extra overkill.
rl> -Tripwire
rl> -Logrotate
rl> -Apache
rl> -Pine
rl> -Java
rl> -Apt-get for regular security updates
rl> -anything I am forgetting that you justify as best practice
rl> -checklist of any human things that then need to be done (ideally none)

rl> My ideal for this would be to purchase the services of an experienced 
rl> Debian guru, and then post the completed script(s) open-sourced to the 
rl> web for others who share my needs (read: those who know Debian, know it 
rl> works, don't have a mongo-script go get to production-ready and don't 
rl> have time to piece one together by trial and error).

rl> Ideally, you are such a Debian guru as to have *already written this 
rl> system* or know of a tool that can do this, and used it for installs 
rl> many times over -- for me, you'll just tweak it, explain it, and ship 
rl> it.  Compensation to be cash and possible future contract work.  Please 
rl> contact off-list.


rl> _______________________________________________
rl> PLUG mailing list
rl> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
rl> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

OOPS..I am running two dual boot systems in transition and got confused. Here 
is the one I am trying to refine.

lhomer at linux:~> mount
/dev/hda3 on / type reiserfs (rw)
proc on /proc type proc (rw)
devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,mode=0620,gid=5)
/dev/hda1 on /windows/C type vfat 
(rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,iocharset=iso8859-1,code=437)
/dev/hdb1 on /windows/D type ntfs 
(ro,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,nls=iso8859-1)
tmpfs on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
lhomer at linux:~>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jul 15 09:10:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Jul 15 09:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Netgear FVS318 Problems
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407150903540.26238@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  Yesterday evening I tried to move my network to the new Netgear FVS318. I
failed in the attempt.

  With all local hosts and the WAP connected to the local ports on the 318 I
could ping and connect from one box to the other. But, I could not get to
the 'Net by ping, browser or anything else.

  After putting everything back to the Linksys switch and floppyfw box I
connected my notebook to the 318. Now I can ping its IP address (set on the
local subnet) but I can no longer reach the admin page with mozilla. The
username and password are rejected. After I try to cancel I see mozilla
display in each of the four window frames: "Warning: system authentification
fail, please contact your system administrator for correct information."

  Do I have options other than resetting the 318 and starting from scratch?

Thanks,

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From aschlemm at comcast.net  Thu Jul 15 11:42:01 2004
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu Jul 15 11:42:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Netgear FVS318 Problems
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407150903540.26238@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407150903540.26238@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <40F6CFB7.6040702@comcast.net>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>  Yesterday evening I tried to move my network to the new Netgear FVS318. I
>failed in the attempt.
>
>  With all local hosts and the WAP connected to the local ports on the 318 I
>could ping and connect from one box to the other. But, I could not get to
>the 'Net by ping, browser or anything else.
>
>  After putting everything back to the Linksys switch and floppyfw box I
>connected my notebook to the 318. Now I can ping its IP address (set on the
>local subnet) but I can no longer reach the admin page with mozilla. The
>username and password are rejected. After I try to cancel I see mozilla
>display in each of the four window frames: "Warning: system authentification
>fail, please contact your system administrator for correct information."
>
>  Do I have options other than resetting the 318 and starting from scratch?
>
>Thanks,
>
>Rich
>
>  
>
 I've used this same unit for quite some time both in office and 
personal uses for the last 1 1/2 years with several different units 
since we had people using them at home for VPN connectivity to the 
office. I do have connection issues with my company supplied WinXP 
laptop that I dual boot into SuSE Professional. On the XP side I have 
the McAfee Privacy Service and it appears to mess up both IE and Mozilla 
so that I'm unable to login to the FVS318. If I disable the privacy 
service I can get logged into the firewall but  after a while I lose the 
connection to the firewall and cannot get any response. I have to use 
Linux to actually mange the unit because of the problems with WinXP.

One thing you might consider doing if you find you need to ever reset 
the unit is to save the configuration offline in a file and then you can 
restore the configuration back so your configuration settings are not 
lost. The unit(s) we have in the company I work for have been 
bulletproof and the only time I've had to reset a unit was after a 
firmware upgrade. To be safe I would also make sure that you're running 
the latest non-Beta version of the firmware which I believe is 2.3? I 
bought a FVS318 about a month ago and it didn't have the latest firmware 
and so had to upgrade.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net




From raanders at acm.org  Thu Jul 15 12:00:03 2004
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu Jul 15 12:00:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WVMOT
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407151139390.31617-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

Way, very, mucho Off Topic ... Windows shares ... but I'm out of ideas.

If anyone can, or is willing to help we can go off list with this.

Though it started as a Linux access to a SMB/CIF share issue.

In my never ending quest to make the Windows systems I have to deal with
do more automagically instead of requiring a pot-full of mousing around
and clicking I realized I was dealing with far too many Windows shares.  

So I was going to treat one server as a central share point (network
storage?) and have all the CGIs (Windows/IIS and Linux/Apache) use a
common area for writing to.  Guess what?  I can't get a CGI running under
IIS to write to a share on another Windows system.

I can create a share on the Linux box, but besides making the Technical
Manager upset, Windows doesn't deal with file it 'thinks' other processes
might be using.  Heck it won't even let me open a file for viewing
sometimes if it gets it in it's pointy little headed self that some other
program might be using it.

So after hours of search on Microsoft's site, using Google, and 
labmice.com I am stymied.

In the mean time I'm doing/dealing with it the way it is and will make my 
admin scripts/CGIs on the Linux boxes do what is needed and hopefully get 
a solution some day.  Heck I'm for dumping the Windows stuff and doing it 
all a new (GNU? ;-) way.

So any pointers or ideas (off list) are welcome.


TIA,
Rod
-- 
    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"





From chaz at bctonline.com  Thu Jul 15 12:12:02 2004
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)
Date: Thu Jul 15 12:12:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WVMOT
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407151139390.31617-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <000d01c46a9f$8630dcb0$0a140a0a@sys10>

This smells like a permissions issue.
I would first look at the share perms.
They should be wide open allowing you to control access at the NTFS level.
-chaz

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Thu Jul 15 13:24:01 2004

Rich Shepard wrote:

>On Thu, 15 Jul 2004, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
>
>  
>
>>To be safe I would also make sure that you're running the latest non-Beta
>>version of the firmware which I believe is 2.3? I bought a FVS318 about a
>>month ago and it didn't have the latest firmware and so had to upgrade.
>>    
>>
>
>Tony,
>
>  I'm starting from scratch. It is not that difficult, but this time I'll
>check the firmware version (yes, the latest is 2.3; I had downloaded the
>wrong file before) and figure out how to save the configuration to a file.
>
>  New question that may be related to my inability to access the 'Net with
>it. I've assigned the 318 the IP address of my floppyfw box (they're not on
>the network simultaneously so there's no conflict) because all hosts have
>that IP address as the gateway. But, ... I just realized that when I set up
>the gateway in the 318 it must be the external gateway address of my ISP.
>Correct?
>
>Thanks,
>
>Rich
>
>  
>
You have to be specific when say "gateway".  On the inside LAN you would 
setup the default gateway for all of your systems so they use the FVS318 
as their gateway. On the  WAN side of the firewall you would use the 
default gateway your ISP supplies to you or you get it via DHCP if you 
have a dynamically assigned IP address. I tend to use DHCP on the LAN 
side with these FVS318 units and the DHCP server always gives the unit's 
LAN IP address as the default gateway.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Thu Jul 15 14:09:02 2004
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Thu Jul 15 14:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] what is a launcher
Message-ID: <200407152107.i6FL7qxS019382@barrierb241.nike.com>

> I've got the client installed, worked like a charm. Now this:
> 
> > To run the Wyvern Client, create a launcher for your system that 
> > contains the following command. (Assumes you've installed it in the 
> > directory: /wyvern/client
>         >       java -Dwyvern.home="/wyvern/client/wyvern" \
>          >      -cp 
> "wyvernclient.jar;jl020.jar;jogg-0.0.5.jar;jorbis-0.0.12.jar;m
p3sp.1.5.jar;vorbisspi0.7.jar" \
>          >      wyvern.client.Client
>         > Run your newly-created launcher to run the client.
> > On Unix-based systems, the semicolons in the "-cp" 
> parameter should be
> > replaced with colons.
> 
> 
> When I enter this into a terminal, I get the error:
> 
> > Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: 
> > wyvern/client/Client
> 
> FWIW there is no file named /wyvern/client/Client

The "launcher" is bassically a script that sets up the classpath and calls java with the correct arguments. In this case you want to have the jars mentioned above on your classpath when you call java. Either use the CLASSPATH environment variable or use the -cp option to java as above. The expample above is using a ";" as a classpath seperator. This is a windows thing. If you are on unix, use a ":" for the classpath seperator. The class wyvern.client.Client is probably in one of the jar files. If I had to guess, I'd say look in the wyvernclient.jar. As long as this jar is on your classpath the class should be found by the java vm.

-Rob Anderson

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Thu Jul 15 17:15:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Thu Jul 15 17:15:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ssh question
In-Reply-To: <071520042348.19168.40F717E5000C5B1500004AE022007358349B029A08020E03040709@comcast.net>
References: <071520042348.19168.40F717E5000C5B1500004AE022007358349B029A08020E03040709@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <40F7210E.3030702@adnap.no-ip.com>

gilmanhunt at comcast.net wrote:

> I'm sorry to ask this, but I can't figure out what words to put into
> google to get what I want out. I recall that there is a command I can
> use from one computer to connect to another computer to have the
> second computer open up a ssh tunnel back to computer one (and then
> my command on computer one's done and there's still a ssh tunnel
> going.).
> 
> I'm trying to configure mysql replication over ssh, and I think I
> have it mostly figured out, but I need this part to demonstrate what
> it's doing- I want my home box to replicate my workstation's box's
> mysql, but don't want to ask my boss to open another port through the
> firewall.
> 
> Any words of wisdom?

I don't think I understand exactly what you want, but I do know the 
general area. This command will allow you to connect to port 10000 on 
client and have it behave like port 3306 on server:

user at client $ ssh -L10000:localhost:3306 user at server

This will do the reverse (port 10000 on server is equivalent to port 
3306 on client):

user at client $ ssh -R10000:localhost:3306 user at server

The manpage for ssh explains these options rather well. I think the 
phrase you want for Google is "ssh tcp port forwarding"

Evan





From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Thu Jul 15 17:20:03 2004
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Thu Jul 15 17:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ssh question
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D51@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
gilmanhunt at comcast.net wrote:
> 
> I'm sorry to ask this, but I can't figure out what words to 
> put into google to get what I want out. I recall that there 
> is a command I can use from one computer to connect to 
> another computer to have the second computer open up a ssh 
> tunnel back to computer one (and then my command on computer 
> one's done and there's still a ssh tunnel going.). 

You're going to hate this...

The command is:
ssh <IP Addr or Hostname> <command>

Example:
ssh <remotehost> /usr/X11R6/bin/xcalc

See:
man ssh

Steve D...



From lug at phxlinux.org  Thu Jul 15 17:52:02 2004
From: lug at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Jul 15 17:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ssh question
In-Reply-To: <071520042348.19168.40F717E5000C5B1500004AE022007358349B029A08020E03040709@comcast.net>
References: <071520042348.19168.40F717E5000C5B1500004AE022007358349B029A08020E03040709@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407151749130.2428@neon.netpro.to>

On Thu, 15 Jul 2004 gilmanhunt at comcast.net wrote:

> I'm sorry to ask this, but I can't figure out what words to put into google to get what I want out. I recall that there is a command I can use from one computer to connect to another computer to have the second computer open up a ssh tunnel back to computer one (and then my command on computer one's done and there's still a ssh tunnel going.).
>
> I'm trying to configure mysql replication over ssh, and I think I have it mostly figured out, but I need this part to demonstrate what it's doing- I want my home box to replicate my workstation's box's mysql, but don't want to ask my boss to open another port through the firewall.
>
> Any words of wisdom?

Here's how I setup my reverse SSH tunnels to bypass the firewall at work
and access my work computer from home:

>From work computer:

ssh -f -N home.computer.com -R 31337:localhost:22

>From home computer:

ssh -p 31337 localhost

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu Jul 15 23:28:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Creating a patch...
Message-ID: <40F772A1.2060202@robinson-west.com>

I copied Redhat 7.3's stock postfix init script to a safe location and 
modified
it.  I now want to create a patch to go from the original version to my 
newer
one.  

Is there some way to script different stop behavior based on whether
or not the system is shutting down that's easy?   My point in using
a ramdrive is to avoid excessive writing to slow nonvolatile storage.  
I'm also trying to keep non classified email messages away from
hard to erase media.

I could do a special sstop that doesn't record the contents of the 
ramdrive,
but I prefer to make stop smarter.  I experimentally checked the runlevel
in the script.  I don't think the runlevel is 0 or 6 when init is killing
processes servicing a halt/reboot request.  Oddly, I can echo the
runlevel during ordinary stop requests, but the runlevel won't echo
during a shutdown.  I was trying a combination of the
runlevel command and cut to get it.  I assume the delimiter for
cut is '\W' and that the field of interest is always the second one.

I want a patch that's compatible with gnu's patch utility commonly used
with the kernel source.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul 16 03:07:01 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Fri Jul 16 03:07:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <40F487FE.8080509@robinson-west.com>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com> <40F487FE.8080509@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <40F7A5E2.3090004@robinson-west.com>

Michael Robinson wrote:

> lhomer wrote:
>
>> I have a new computer with Windows XP in the second drive, and newly
>> installed Suse 9.0 on the first. When logged onto the Linux drive I can
>> read the Windows drive, but can't write. A possible solution is to be
>> able to read and write the Linux drive while logged into Windows, and I
>> have heard this can be done. Can you tell me how?
>>
>> When logged on to Linux about half the Linux drive is occupied with (an
>> automatically installed) Windows/C drive with the NTFS format, so I
>> cannot write to this partition while logged on to Linux. How do I get
>> rid of it, and free the space up, or how how should I reinstall Linux so
>> that I do not have an NTFS partition on this drive?
>>
>>
>> _______________________________________________
>> PLUG mailing list
>> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
Can you uninstall one hard drive and clean up the other drive's
partitions with a knoppix cd, or a cd from http://www.sysrescd.org?

Back up the data that matters.  I've never heard of a new computer being
built with two hard drives and Windows XP partitions across both.  The
big problem will likely be drive letters changing if you attempt to free up
one of those drives from Windows.  Linux is superior because it doesn't
have drive letters.  If a cdrom moves because a partition is gone, that
can be a real pain.  A program called xosl, http://www.xosl.org,
used to be able to help with the drive letter problem via partition
hiding.  The idea, essentially, was to allow multiple copies of Windows,
Windows and a mirror, or even Windows and dos to be installed on the
same drive without more than one hard drive partition showing upon
booting any of the installed Microsoft systems.
  
I don't know if the nonfree partition magic extends the power of xosl
to Windows XP, or not.  My copy of xosl, or ranish at least, does not
support NTFS.  NTFS used to need a fat partition for booting, but
I don't know that this is true in your case or if it has only been true
on Alpha systems.

When you boot Windows XP, are the two NTFS partitions visible?

Do you have Windows XP installation disks?

Can you safely remove both hard drives, or is there only one drive?

Do you need to share files between Windows and Linux, for sure?

Is this a laptop, or a full size?

I needed qtparted, but a fairly recent(  like last term ) version.  I 
safely shrunk
a Windows XP partition using that.  I believe it can delete NTFS partitions
also.  I've removed NTFS on my old Alpha system, but I think that was the
through the firmware, low level.  Does Microsoft think NTFS is more secure
simply because it's specifics are a secret?  What does it have that FAT32
lacks?  I've heard that NTFS security breaks preventing people from
accessing their files.  

My recommendation with Windows is to seriously consider using drive trays
and installing only Linux on one drive and only Windows on another.  With
two drive trays, the first one set to boot, you can switch out operating 
systems
easily.  If you need to use files on a Windows partition in Linux, 
consider a
Linux supported USB drive tray to load the Windows drive in when you're
running Linux.  USB is plug and play, so you can hook the tray up after 
Linux
has booted.    

If you are just wanting to back up NTFS under Linux, consider dd.  Trouble
is, you have to know the number of blocks.  A 1.44 meg floppy disk is 14400
for block size.  I wonder if tar can be used directly on a device file.

There is vmware and wine, I think you can run the NTFS drive in a Windows
emulator.

Google for explore2fs.

    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."

From lhomer at comcast.net  Fri Jul 16 08:01:02 2004
From: lhomer at comcast.net (lhomer)
Date: Fri Jul 16 08:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <40F7A5E2.3090004@robinson-west.com>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com> <40F487FE.8080509@robinson-west.com> <40F7A5E2.3090004@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <200407160642.17658.lhomer@comcast.net>

On Friday 16 July 2004 02:54, Michael Robinson wrote:
> Michael Robinson wrote:
> > lhomer wrote:
> >> I have a new computer with Windows XP in the second drive, and newly
> >> installed Suse 9.0 on the first. When logged onto the Linux drive I can
> >> read the Windows drive, but can't write. A possible solution is to be
> >> able to read and write the Linux drive while logged into Windows, and I
> >> have heard this can be done. Can you tell me how?
> >>
> >> When logged on to Linux about half the Linux drive is occupied with (an
> >> automatically installed) Windows/C drive with the NTFS format, so I
> >> cannot write to this partition while logged on to Linux. How do I get
> >> rid of it, and free the space up, or how how should I reinstall Linux so
> >> that I do not have an NTFS partition on this drive?
> >>
> >>
> >> _______________________________________________
> >> PLUG mailing list
> >> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> >> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
> Can you uninstall one hard drive and clean up the other drive's
> partitions with a knoppix cd, or a cd from http://www.sysrescd.org?
>
> Back up the data that matters.  I've never heard of a new computer being
> built with two hard drives and Windows XP partitions across both.  The
> big problem will likely be drive letters changing if you attempt to free up
> one of those drives from Windows.  Linux is superior because it doesn't
> have drive letters.  If a cdrom moves because a partition is gone, that
> can be a real pain.  A program called xosl, http://www.xosl.org,
> used to be able to help with the drive letter problem via partition
> hiding.  The idea, essentially, was to allow multiple copies of Windows,
> Windows and a mirror, or even Windows and dos to be installed on the
> same drive without more than one hard drive partition showing upon
> booting any of the installed Microsoft systems.
>
> I don't know if the nonfree partition magic extends the power of xosl
> to Windows XP, or not.  My copy of xosl, or ranish at least, does not
> support NTFS.  NTFS used to need a fat partition for booting, but
> I don't know that this is true in your case or if it has only been true
> on Alpha systems.
>
> When you boot Windows XP, are the two NTFS partitions visible?
>
> Do you have Windows XP installation disks?
>
> Can you safely remove both hard drives, or is there only one drive?
>
> Do you need to share files between Windows and Linux, for sure?
>
> Is this a laptop, or a full size?
>
Full size. It came with  Windows Xp in a single partition on one disk, and I 
installed Suse 9.0 Linux on the other. Suse made an NTFS partition on the 
Linux disk. I could read and write to that partition while logged onto XP, 
but not while logged onto Linux. I changed the Linux NTFS partition to FAT32 
by reinstalling Linux. Now I can read and write to that FAT32 partition on 
the Linux disk while logged into either system which satisfies my immediate 
needs.

I gather that I could reinstall XP with a FAT32 partition, and could then 
write to the XP disk while logged into either operating system, but I am not 
anxious to meddle with Windows XP. I would rather spend my time learning 
Linux things. In time linux distributions will offer read/write capabilities 
with NTFS.

> I needed qtparted, but a fairly recent(  like last term ) version.  I
> safely shrunk
> a Windows XP partition using that.  I believe it can delete NTFS partitions
> also.  I've removed NTFS on my old Alpha system, but I think that was the
> through the firmware, low level.  Does Microsoft think NTFS is more secure
> simply because it's specifics are a secret?  What does it have that FAT32
> lacks?  I've heard that NTFS security breaks preventing people from
> accessing their files.
>
> My recommendation with Windows is to seriously consider using drive trays
> and installing only Linux on one drive and only Windows on another.  With
> two drive trays, the first one set to boot, you can switch out operating
> systems
> easily.  If you need to use files on a Windows partition in Linux,
> consider a
> Linux supported USB drive tray to load the Windows drive in when you're
> running Linux.  USB is plug and play, so you can hook the tray up after
> Linux
> has booted.
>
> If you are just wanting to back up NTFS under Linux, consider dd.  Trouble
> is, you have to know the number of blocks.  A 1.44 meg floppy disk is 14400
> for block size.  I wonder if tar can be used directly on a device file.
>
> There is vmware and wine, I think you can run the NTFS drive in a Windows
> emulator.
>
> Google for explore2fs.
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From mel97215 at comcast.net  Fri Jul 16 09:10:03 2004
From: mel97215 at comcast.net (Mel Andres)
Date: Fri Jul 16 09:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <200407150732.21771.lhomer@comcast.net>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com> <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net> <40F5FC45.60407@comcast.net> <200407150732.21771.lhomer@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <40F7FDE2.6040405@comcast.net>

lhomer wrote:

> 
> OOPS..I am running two dual boot systems in transition and got confused. Here 
> is the one I am trying to refine.
> 
> lhomer at linux:~> mount
> /dev/hda3 on / type reiserfs (rw)
> proc on /proc type proc (rw)
> devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,mode=0620,gid=5)
> /dev/hda1 on /windows/C type vfat 
> (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,iocharset=iso8859-1,code=437)
> /dev/hdb1 on /windows/D type ntfs 
> (ro,noexec,nosuid,nodev,gid=100,umask=0002,nls=iso8859-1)
> tmpfs on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
> usbdevfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
> lhomer at linux:~>
> 
Ok, in your case windows/C is on the same drive as linux:
/dev/hda3 on / type reiserfs (rw)
        ^
/dev/hda1 on /windows/C type vfat
        ^
and you can read and write to files in windows/C because it is a FAT 
partition.

Your WinXP boot drive shows up as window/D under linux:
/dev/hdb1 on /windows/D type ntfs
        ^
With this setup, it could be confusing when switching between the two 
operating systems. When you boot up WinXP, it will be drive C, and the 
FAT partition on the linux drive would probably be seen as drive D. Just 
the opposite of when booted as linux. You could edit /etc/mtab to switch 
the drive letters.

   Mel

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Fri Jul 16 09:54:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Fri Jul 16 09:54:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dual boot, dual drives
In-Reply-To: <40F7FDE2.6040405@comcast.net>
References: <001d01c4693f$52386420$6501a8c0@attbi.com> <200407141850.01786.lhomer@comcast.net> <40F5FC45.60407@comcast.net> <200407150732.21771.lhomer@comcast.net> <40F7FDE2.6040405@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <40F80B24.8040000@adnap.no-ip.com>

Mel Andres wrote:
> With this setup, it could be confusing when switching between the two 
> operating systems. When you boot up WinXP, it will be drive C, and the 
> FAT partition on the linux drive would probably be seen as drive D. Just 
> the opposite of when booted as linux. You could edit /etc/mtab to switch 
> the drive letters.

That's /etc/fstab. /etc/mtab is used by mount to determine what 
filesystems are mounted where.

Evan

From root at loraksus.org  Fri Jul 16 11:01:02 2004

Don't think so. I have the same model and it's always just worked when I
plugged it in. The DSL modem is in bridging mode, so it doesn't do any
router functions, just translates the packets for you. Verizon does use
bootp around here, so if you do switch out devices without cloning the mac
addy, you will get a new IP. How is DHCP working for you btw?

Karol,

  Verizon doesn't provide IP addresses, my ISP does. I spoke with one of
their techies this morning: no specific MAC address required and the line is
still clear and fast. He expressed surprise that I've been a customer of
theirs for 5+ years. But, I've had no problems the past 4+ years; as you
write, it just works.

  Don't do DHCP. All static IP addresses.

  After a terribly frustrating almost-3 hours of trying to reply to a
Netgear e-mail message (can't contact them that way), failed Web pages, a
support tech who left me on hold for 5 minutes, then one who kept insisting
my DSL modem had a bad port, they finally acknowledged that it's the new,
Netgear router that's internally broken. The only way I get the Internet
light to turn on is when it's patched to one of its own lan ports.

  So, now I've filled out an RMA request for ebuyer.com (no phone number on
their Web site) and I'll go through the whole Linksys smear again. What a
PITA!

From krisa at subtend.net  Fri Jul 16 14:23:02 2004

On Fri, Jul 16, 2004 at 01:35:20PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 16 Jul 2004, Dan Haskell wrote:
> 
> > One thing to bear in mind is that none of our regular volunteers - as far
> > as I know - are wifi experts. If it's just a basic install, then I'm sure
> > they'll get you going. If it requires a lot of specialized knowledge they
> > may not.
> 
>   ... and if the BEFW11S4 is flaky no amount of specialized knowledge will
> help. Been there; done that. Twice. At least the WAP45G is running reliably.

I've had problems with my BEFW11S4, but were always fixed with the latest
firmware.

For example, a couple months ago the DHCP server would decide to give someone an
address based on moon alignment.  The latest firmware at the time fixed that.
Then this week, I wanted to change my PTP assigned subnet from a /28 to a /24.  It
would not allow me to do this simple mask change.  The latest firmware at the time
(this Wednesday) fixed that too.  

Their quality control is poor, but at least a fix was always available.

-- 
I'm just a packet pusher.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jul 16 16:17:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jul 16 16:17:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on ThinkPad 600E
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407161610030.1016@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I'm bringing my fiancee's ThinkPad 600E to the clinic tomorrow for help
getting the sound to work. I've been futzing with this off-and-on all week
and it has me beat.

  By googling I found several sites referencing the problem. I tried a few
of the solutions, but none worked here. The most promising -- and latest
attempt -- is to create an rc.sound file that loads the cs4232 driver and
the cmix volume control. Downloaded, built and installed the latter and all
looks good. lsmod shows the proper modules loaded and ready to go.
RealPlayer8 is also installed and ready to go, but it shows video silently.

  I discovered that on my Sony Vaio the sound works only when the unit is
plugged into the wall. Perhaps this is because the cpu speed is
automatically decreased when running on battery and realplayer considers it
too slow. I don't know. Anyway, I've tried getting sound on the IBM only
when it's running on AC and it's not working for me.

  Hope someone who knows sound issues will be there tomorrow.

Thanks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From chaz at bctonline.com  Fri Jul 16 23:10:03 2004
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)
Date: Fri Jul 16 23:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WVMOT
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407151302230.32385-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <002201c46bc4$90221010$0a140a0a@sys10>

Don't know much specifically about IIS, but I'd wager that the CGI process
is being spawned with access rights less than admin.  A less probable
possibility is that things are set up such that admin can't get through for
security reasons. You might try creating an endless loop CGI so it persists
long enough for you to look at its stats.
-chaz

> What do you mean by NAT Box?

I have a Debian box connected to a modem connecting to
the internet....  <Dial-up>

I have a nic card coming from the dial-up computer to 
the Router...

Before I had the router.  I just connected the other computer
to a hub and the hub connected to the other computer <Debian> which
did NAT <Network address translation>.. That way I had both
computers on the net with one dial up..
> 
> > I am thinking I made a BIG mistake..
> > 

I wasn't sure the Linksys box would work through the 
Debian box..??

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Jul 17 05:03:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Jul 17 05:03:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linksys-BEFW11s4
In-Reply-To: <1090049070.2644.7.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
References: <200407162136.OAA28632@smtp.gssf.org>  <1090048400.1132.3.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
 <1090049070.2644.7.camel@clark2.kosmal.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407170459450.32532@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 17 Jul 2004, Marv wrote:
>
> I have a Debian box connected to a modem connecting to the internet....
> <Dial-up>
>
> I have a nic card coming from the dial-up computer to the Router...
>
> Before I had the router.  I just connected the other computer to a hub
> and the hub connected to the other computer <Debian> which did NAT
> <Network address translation>.. That way I had both computers on the net
> with one dial up..
>
> I wasn't sure the Linksys box would work through the
> Debian box..??

What's the goal?

You can use the Debian box to route to the public network and NAT the
boxes behind it and just use the Linksys device as a switch, if that's
what you'd like.

Or you can let the Linksys device do the routing and switching and NAT
(HAT, really, I assume) and just use the Debian box as a bridge (really, a
point-to-point router with different media on each interface).

There are all kinds of configurations to make those two boxes do things
together.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

New Releases
----------------------------------------------------------------
***Perl 6 and Parrot Essentials, 2nd Edition
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 059600737X
"Perl 6 and Parrot Essentials, 2nd Edition" provides an insider's look at
what's coming in the widely anticipated Perl 6. It uncovers groundbreaking
new developments in Parrot, and the most revolutionary change in the
language itself, Apocalypse 12 on objects. The book also expands coverage
of Apocalypse 5 (regular expressions) and Apocalypse 6 (subroutines). This
is the only book to reveal all the ingenious developments that will make
Perl 6 more powerful and easier to use.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/059600737X/index.html

Chapter 10, "Parrot Intermediate Representation," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/059600737X/chapter/index.html


***Mastering Oracle SQL, 2nd Edition
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006322
Updated to cover Oracle 10g, this new edition has a stronger focus on
practical, expert best practices and on Oracle-specific SQL techniques
than any other book on the market. The book covers Oracle's library of
built-in functions, query-writing features, regular expression support,
new aggregate and analytic functions, the native XML datatype, XMLType,
and more. For those who want to harness the power of Oracle SQL, this
essential guide for putting Oracle SQL to work will prove invaluable.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/0596006322/

Chapter 7, "Set Operations," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/0596006322/chapter/index.html


***Mac OS X Panther in a Nutshell, 2nd Edition
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006063
"Mac OS X Panther in a Nutshell, 2nd Edition" offers a thorough treatment
of Mac OS X Panther, from its BSD Unix foundation to the finer points of
its user interface. It familiarizes readers with the Finder and the Dock,
file management, system configuration, network administration issues, and
more, including a clear picture of what's new. The book also includes the
most complete Unix command reference found in print--with each command and
option painstakingly tested and checked against Panther.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/macpantherian/

Chapter 13, "Security Basics," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/macpantherian/chapter/index.html


***Just a Geek
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 059600768X
Wil Wheaton has never been one to take the conventional path to success.
Despite early stardom through his childhood role in the motion picture
"Stand By Me," and growing up on television as Wesley Crusher on "Star
Trek: The Next Generation," Wil left Hollywood in pursuit of happiness,
purpose, and a viable means of paying the bills. In this, his newest book,
Wil shares his deeply personal and difficult journey to find himself with
stories that reveal an honesty and disarming humanity.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/jag/

A sample chapter, titled "Alone Again, or ...," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/jag/chapter/index.html


***Version Control with Subversion
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596004486
 "Version Control with Subversion" introduces the powerful new versioning
tool designed to be the successor to CVS. The book starts with an
introduction to Subversion, followed by a guided tour of its capabilities.
Later chapters cover more complex topics of branching, repository
administration, and other advanced features. If you've never used version
control in your software projects, this book has everything you need to
get started. If you're a seasoned CVS user, it will help you make a
painless leap to Subversion.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/0596004486/

Chapter 2, "Basic Concepts," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/0596004486/chapter/index.html


***3D Game-Based Filmmaking: The Art of Machinima 
Publisher: Paraglyph Press
ISBN: 1932111859
Machinima will revolutionize the computer animation industry, and this
book will serve as the industry bible for emerging filmmakers. It expertly
covers the latest technology in filmmaking, the history of Machinima, the
major players, and where the Machinima movement is going. The book clearly
explains Machinima and covers the basics you'll need to get started
including necessary hardware and software, and other production tools and
installation.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1932111859/


***Eclipse Cookbook
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596007108
"Eclipse Cookbook" demystifies Eclipse with practical recipes for more
than 800 situations you may encounter--from deploying a web application
automatically to reverse engineering compiled code and from renaming all
references to a class across multiple packages to initializing the SWT JNI
libraries. Perfect as a companion to the recently released "Eclipse" book
by the same author, this latest O'Reilly cookbook will help Java
programmers at all levels take advantage of the powerful and convenient
Eclipse in their daily work.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/eclipseckbk/

Chapter 6, "Using Eclipse in Teams," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/eclipseckbk/chapter/index.html


***Flash Hacks
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006454
This collection of 100 Flash tips and tricks covers optimization, creating
interesting effects, ActionScript programming, sound and video effects,
and much more--and you don't need to be an expert to use them (although
you'll certainly look like one). Ranging from practical hacks to the fun
and quirky, the book covers Flash MX, Flash MX 2004, and Flash MX
Professional 2004. If you're ready to explore and experiment with Flash,
this is the book for you. 
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/flashhks/index.html

Five sample hacks are available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/flashhks/chapter/index.html


***The Spam Letters
Publisher: No Starch Press
ISBN: 1593270321
>From the man behind TheSpamLetters.com comes a collection of brilliant and
entertaining correspondence with the people who send out mass junk
emailings (a.k.a. spam). Compiled from the nearly 200 entries written by
Jonathan Land, "The Spam Letters" taunts, prods, and parodies the faceless
salespeople in your inbox, giving you a chuckle at their expense. If you
hate spam, you'll love "The Spam Letters."
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1593270321/


***Online Investing Hacks
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006772
For the geek who's an investor, and the investor who's a geek, we present
100 industrial-strength, bleeding-edge tips, tools, and techniques for
analyzing and managing online portfolios. This book provides hacks on
screening investments, executing trades, investing in mutual funds,
portfolio management, financial planning, and much more. Online Investing
Hacks is for people who get jazzed by cool online tools and services, and
who want to have some fun while trying to strike it rich (or at least not
lose their shirt). 
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/0596006772/

Ten sample hacks, are available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/0596006772/chapter/index.html

================================================
News From O'Reilly & Beyond
================================================
---------------------
General News
---------------------
***O'Reilly Releases Spanish-Language Titles
O'Reilly has been helping English speakers tame and control their
computers for over 25 years, and we're now offering eight of our most 
popular titles in Spanish: four books from the Hacks series, three pocket
guides,  and the bestseller, "PC Annoyances."
http://press.oreilly.com/pub/pr/1188


***History of Programming Languages
O'Reilly has produced a poster on the history of programming languages
that plots over 50 languages on a multi-layered, color-coded timeline,
based on a diagram created by Eric Levenez. Download the poster in PDF
format. You can also find full-size copies at Team O'Reilly bookstores,
and at O'Reilly conferences, such as this July's Open Source Convention.
http://www.oreilly.com/pub/a/oreilly/news/languageposter_0504.html


***Stealing the Network: A Prequel 
Ryan Russell, one of the coauthors of "Stealing the Network: How to Own a
Continent" (from Syngress), has written a "prequel" that depicts a
'70s-era security hack, set at a tech company back East. If you've been
curious about "Stealing the Network," this short bit of fiction provides a
real sense of the concept behind the book. And be sure to respond to the
talkback at the end of this tale -- we'd like to hear your theory.
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/security/2004/07/01/stealthenetwork.html

---------------------
Open Source
---------------------
*** How to Write a Basic Gtk# Program with Mono
Gtk#, the Mono API for the GTK+ UI toolkit, is the open source alternative
to Windows.Forms. This article shows how to install Mono on Windows, how
Gtk# works, and how to write a simple Gtk# program. This kind of
mini-project is just the sort you'll find in O'Reilly's upcoming "Mono: A
Developer's Notebook."
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/excerpt/MonoTDN_chap1/index.html


***Unix Printing Basics 
For some reason, consumer-level printing has never been easy on any OS,
including Unix. Unless you're in the know, it seems like a mess of
spoolers, filters, and drivers. Fortunately, new versions of Ghostscript
and foomatic make configuring printing easier. Dru Lavigne explains the
basics of Unix printer installation and configuration.
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/bsd/2004/07/08/FreeBSD_Basics.html

---------------------
Mac
---------------------
***Announcing the 2004 Mac OS X Innovators Contest 
The second Mac OS X Innovators contest is open and ready for your entry.
Here are the links and info you need to shine a light on your great idea.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/developer/2004/07/06/innovators.html


***Hacking Mac OS X Panther 
Rael Dornfest, coauthor of "Mac OS X Panther Hacks," has selected three
hacks from the book for your sampling pleasure. The first two detail how
to find anyone in your Address Book who has an Amazon Wish List, and how
to build a GUI to your Unix scripts with some Perl or Python glue code;
the third is just for fun.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/excerpt/pantherhacks/index.html


***Steve Jobs Introduces Tiger at WWDC 2004 
So many things to talk about at WWDC. So many things that can't be said.
Here's an overview of what can be disclosed, including hardware
announcements and a preview of Tiger, Apple's next version of Mac OS X.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2004/07/01/wwdc.html

---------------------
Windows
---------------------
***Top Three Windows RSS Readers 
Which are the best RSS readers out there? Wei-Meng Lee picks his favorites
and gives you guided tours of them all.
http://www.windowsdevcenter.com/pub/a/windows/2004/07/06/rss_readers.html


***Surf the Web Anonymously 
When you surf the Web, your life is an open book, open to anyone who wants
to look. J.W. Olsen looks at two anonymous surfing programs that promise
to fix the problem.
http://www.windowsdevcenter.com/pub/a/windows/2004/06/29/Anonymity.html

---------------------
Java
---------------------
***Spring in Action 
In this excerpt from "Better, Faster, Lighter Java," authors Bruce Tate
and Justin Gehtland provide an example of Spring (their counter-example to
the J2EE Pet Store application) in action, to show why you too will come
to appreciate this simple framework as elegant and important. 
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/excerpt/BFLJava_chap8/index.html


***Inside Class Loaders: Debugging 
Andreas Schaefer continues his examination of class loading in Java with a
look at what can cause problems in advance class-loading scenarios and how
to patch class loaders to help debug the problem.
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2004/06/30/classloader2.html

---------------------
.NET
---------------------
***Refactoring in Whidbey 
Code refactoring means restructuring your code so that the original
intention of the code is preserved. In this article, Wei-Meng Lee walks
you through Whidbey's new support for code refactoring.
http://www.ondotnet.com/pub/a/dotnet/2004/06/28/whidbey_refactoring.html


***ASP.NET Forms Security, Part 2 
In his previous column, Jesse Liberty showed how to add web form security
to your ASP.NET 2.0 application, and how to add users. In this follow-up,
he demonstrates how easy it is to create and manage roles. 
http://www.ondotnet.com/pub/a/dotnet/2004/06/28/liberty_whidbey.html


Until next time--

Marsee

  Position Title:            System Administrator

*Department:             Technology*

*Reports to:                Director of System Administration*


    Date Prepared:            June 2004

 

*About Us*: @Once is one of the industry's leading e-mail marketing and 
interactive web solution providers.  Using a consultative approach, 
@Once has both the strategic and technical resources needed to build 
direct online marketing programs, which drive revenue, build brand 
awareness and strengthen customer loyalty and trust.  With proven 
success in the cultivation and retention of a client's customer base, 
@Once is known for developing and implementing sophisticated, highly 
personalized, permission-based e-mail and interactive web solutions that 
drive results.

 

Headquartered in Portland, Oregon, @Once helps clients maximize the 
Lifetime Value (LTV) of each of their customers.  This includes 
leveraging a combination of the nation's top professional services, 
database marketing, and program management expertise while adhering to 
strict consumer privacy guidelines.  @Once is a licensee of the TRUSTe 
Privacy Program and a member of the NAI (Network Advertising Initiative).

 

Backed by the strongest commitment to client success in the industry, 
marketing giants such as Nike, Nintendo, Home Shopping Network, SC 
Johnson and Warner Bros. have chosen @Once to build consumer confidence 
and maintain long-lasting customer relationships.

 

@Once provides competitive salaries and a generous benefits package 
including company-paid medical, dental and prescription insurance for 
full-time employees _and_ dependents, disability insurance and lots 
more.  The Business Journal has listed @Once among the Top 100 Fastest 
Growing Privately Held Companies for the past two years.

 

*Position:*  We are seeking an analytical, detail-oriented and dedicated 
individual to assist in maintaining, enhancing, integrating and 
supporting our UNIX, Linux and Windows-based environment.  This position 
will play a key role in our System Administration team, supporting both 
production facilities as well as infrastructure.  This person should be 
highly self-motivated, enjoy daily challenges, and be able to be 
immediately productive with all aspects of operations of an 
enterprise-critical network.  The applicant will need to be able to 
direct and team with others without requiring detailed supervision or 
guidance.

 

*Key Responsibilities:*

* *

    * Configure, maintain and troubleshoot servers, desktop computers,
      networking and office equipment
    * Primary person responsible for PC and Mac desktop workstations
    * Maintain various system health monitoring tools
    * Participate in the development and implementation of procedures
      for disaster recovery
    * Recommend and analyze system enhancements and upgrades, including
      new solutions
    * Security monitoring and routine audit of servers, routers, firewalls**
    * Document systems and procedures
    * Log and maintain all manuals and software
    * Support development teams on system deployments and performance
      optimizations
    * Provide support to end-users
    * Conduct training of end-users
    * Assist as needed in ongoing projects**
    * Close, daily interaction with other System Administrators, DBAs,
      and Developers**
    * Rotating 24x7 on-call schedule, with responsibility to see
      problems through to resolution**
    * Available to occasionally work evenings or weekends for
      large-scale or high-priority projects**

 

*Key Qualifications:*

* *

    * 2+ years Sys Admin experience in a 24x7 Sun Solaris (UNIX)
      production environment (certification preferred) with solid
      understanding of virtual memory, file systems, and job control
    * Expert understanding of file system and network sections of the
      Linux kernel (prefer Redhat or SUSE distributions) preferred
      (certification desired)
    * Significant BIND (DNS) experience
    * Knowledge of Routing and Virtual Private Networks (VPN)
    * Familiarity administering Cisco equipment
    * Good knowledge of Internet security practices
    * Firm understanding of TCP/IP networking principles
    * Microsoft Windows OS and PC Hardware administration experience
      required, certifications preferred
    * Macintosh OS and Hardware administration experience required,
      certifications preferred
    * Ability to troubleshoot and solve advanced software and hardware
      problems quickly and completely
    * Ability to define and implement procedures that assure system
      reliability
    * Demonstrated Help desk and troubleshooting skills through issue
      resolution
    * Desktop Support background, preferably supporting Microsoft
      Windows, Office and Apple products
    * Strong client service orientation
    * Prefer Web Application support experience (such as Apache, Tomcat,
      JBoss)
    * Prefer strong hardware experience in Sun and Intel environments
    * Prefer Cisco Networking experience
    * Project Leadership skills preferred
    * Team Lead skills desirable
    * Must work well under pressure, be sensitive to deadlines, be able
      to interact in a team environment, and be able to adapt quickly to
      change**
    * Exceptional oral and written communication skills are essential
    * Additionally, candidate should be self-motivated and work well
      with end-users, management, and internal and external customers
      (possess great people skills)

 

*Education:  *BS and 5+ years experience, or MS and 3+ years experience, 
or related technical expertise is preferred

 

 

This description has been designed to indicate the general nature and 
level of work performed by employees within this position.  The actual 
duties, responsibilities, and qualifications may vary slightly based on 
assignment.

 

 

If you or anyone you know would be interested in hearing more about this 
opportunity, please contact the Recruiting Manager, HR at once.com 
<mailto:HR at once.com?subject=System%20Administrator>

On Sat, 2004-07-17 at 08:08, Marvin wrote:
> On Sat, 17 Jul 2004 05:02:20 -0700 (PDT)
> Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:
> 
> >
> >On Sat, 17 Jul 2004, Marv wrote:
> >>
> >> I have a Debian box connected to a modem connecting to the internet....
> >> <Dial-up>
> >>
> >> I have a nic card coming from the dial-up computer to the Router...
> >>
> >> Before I had the router.  I just connected the other computer to a hub
> >> and the hub connected to the other computer <Debian> which did NAT
> >> <Network address translation>.. That way I had both computers on the net
> >> with one dial up..
> >>
> >> I wasn't sure the Linksys box would work through the
> >> Debian box..??
> >
> >What's the goal?
> 
> 
> The Linksys router is a WAP..That way I can
> do WI-Fi with my laptop...
> <My bad for not mentioning before>

This makes sense, and AFAIK, the Linksys will route private IP
addresses, which means it should work without any changes to the Debian
configuration, as long as the LAN is on a different subnet then the
subnet the Debian box and the WAN port of the Linksys are on.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

  The floppy drive in my server was an antique dual-format model (5.25" &
3.5"). Each time I had to reboot the system the BIOS complained about a
floppy drive malfunction (which didn't seem to stop it from working, but
...). So, as long as I had to disassemble the box to replace the power
supply I replaced that unit with a 3.5" drive. New cable, too, 'cause the
old one has an edge connector, not a pin connector.

  So, red stripe to the outside (the only way the cable will fit the drive),
and the power connector on the only way it fits and I still get the same
BIOS warning at boot. And, now the light on the floppy is on continuously.

  Any ideas what I did wrong? This is a new one on me.

Thanks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From aaron at bavariati.org  Sat Jul 17 13:58:01 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Sat Jul 17 13:58:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Hardware question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407171327020.2334@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407171327020.2334@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040717205729.GA23867@bavariati.org>

On Sat, Jul 17, 2004 at 01:30:44PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   So, red stripe to the outside (the only way the cable will fit the drive),
> and the power connector on the only way it fits and I still get the same
> BIOS warning at boot. And, now the light on the floppy is on continuously.

Floppy light on continuously = ribbon cable backwards.
Make the cable fit or flip it around on the motherboard end.

From root at loraksus.org  Sat Jul 17 17:08:02 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Sat Jul 17 17:08:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Hardware question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407171327020.2334@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

You might have 2 drives enabled in the BIOS, i.e. a: is 3.5", b: is 5.25".
Disable the 5.25" drive.

From ac7xc-lnx at wvi.com  Sat Jul 17 22:24:02 2004
From: ac7xc-lnx at wvi.com (Keith)
Date: Sat Jul 17 22:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS on Red Hat 9 server
In-Reply-To: <40F82881.7080900@brianquade.net>
References: <40F82881.7080900@brianquade.net>
Message-ID: <452kf0deuguj1ritgjm723irfpe4tcu9ei@4ax.com>

On Fri, 16 Jul 2004 12:12:01 -0700, you wrote:

>I am using:
>CUPS 1.1.7-13.3.0.3 (the update for Red Hat 9)
>foomatic 2.0.2-15
>ghostscript 7.05-32
>hpijs 1.3-32
>
>I have an HP Deskjet 940 C printer.

 Most often this is a setting in your printcap or other printer format
file. I had the same problem with a Lexmark Z23 and I switched the
format from 8 1/2 x 11 to Executive format. I later fixed it but can't
recall exactly what I did in which file. 
 If you can live with Executive format then don't sweat it. 






From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Jul 18 10:32:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Jul 18 10:32:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Floppies and flipped cables
In-Reply-To: <20040718134228.3917.20853.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040718134228.3917.20853.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040718171142.GA15255@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Sat, 2004-07-17 at 13:30, Rich Shepard wrote:
...
> and the power connector on the only way it fits and I still get the same
> BIOS warning at boot. And, now the light on the floppy is on continuously

Wil writes:

> Floppy cable connected backwards?  Perhaps on the mobo?

This happens fairly often.  I have rolls of little colored sticky dots,
about 6mm diameter.  Before a motherboard or drive disappears into a
cabinet, I stick a colored dot near the pin 1 end of the drive or
connector.  This makes future cable changes a lot easier and safer.

Note, sometimes pin1 is not marked explicitly on a motherboard or in
a manual.  However, on typical circuit boards and connectors with
"through hole" (not surface mounted) pins, the connector comes through
to the back side of the board.  The pads for most of the connector pins
are round, but pin 1 is usually square.  You will only be able to see
that with the motherboard out of the case, of course.

Keyed connectors are supposed to eliminate the possibility of inverting
a cable, but sometimes enthusiasm makes a connector fit when it shouldn't.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Many floppy drives are constructed in such a way that the cable will fit
either way.  It is a royal pain to get it right when you already have
the drive mounted in the machine.

From lug at phxlinux.org  Sun Jul 18 14:46:02 2004
From: lug at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sun Jul 18 14:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] serial port and minicom problems
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181440520.16680@neon.netpro.to>

I have a phone system with a serial cable connected to a Linux box.  When
I've previously connected the serial cable to a Windows box, hyperterm
would see the phone system messages that it spits out as new calls come
in, etc.  So now I'm trying to do the same thing with minicom.  I've got
the serial port /dev/ttyS0 and the speed 19200 8N1 configured and minicom
shows it's connected, but I never see anything from the phone system
displayed to the screen.  Am I missing a configuration setting in minicom
somewhere?  Perhaps something in the "modem and dialing" parameters makes
minicom think it's talking to a modem?

The next step is to write a script that will connect periodically and
retrieve this same information, but I'd like to see that things are
working in minicom first.
Thanks,
~M




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Jul 18 14:52:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Jul 18 14:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] serial port and minicom problems
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181440520.16680@neon.netpro.to>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181440520.16680@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <1090187499.4183.33.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Sun, 2004-07-18 at 14:45, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I have a phone system with a serial cable connected to a Linux box.  When
> I've previously connected the serial cable to a Windows box, hyperterm
> would see the phone system messages that it spits out as new calls come
> in, etc.  So now I'm trying to do the same thing with minicom.  I've got
> the serial port /dev/ttyS0 and the speed 19200 8N1 configured and minicom
> shows it's connected, but I never see anything from the phone system
> displayed to the screen.  Am I missing a configuration setting in minicom
> somewhere?  Perhaps something in the "modem and dialing" parameters makes
> minicom think it's talking to a modem?

Perhaps you need to change the setting of flow-control?  "None",
XON/XOFF, RTS/CTS.

Wil

Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From lug at phxlinux.org  Sun Jul 18 15:20:03 2004

Subject: [PLUG] OT: computer/network consulting advice
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181509290.16680@neon.netpro.to>

I'm toying with the idea of starting my own computer/network consulting
business.  At this point I'm just collecting information and I'd like to
hear from others that are currently doing this type of work or have done
it in the past.

How was your experience?  What were the major hurdles to getting started?
What methods did you use to solicit new business?  Was it a constant daily
chore to find new business or were you able acquire a solid base of
customers that provided enough work to keep food on the table?  Did you
run into any problems with other companies with similar names, and if so,
how was this resolved?  What was a typical day like?  There is an enormous
amount of differing technologies deployed and it's close to impossible to
be an expert in all areas, so if a customer had a tech need that you were
not proficient with, did you still take the work and learn on the job?
Any additional information would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks,
~M

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sun Jul 18 15:55:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] OT: computer/network consulting advice

> There is an enormous
> amount of differing technologies deployed and it's close to impossible to
> be an expert in all areas, so if a customer had a tech need that you were
> not proficient with, did you still take the work and learn on the job?

Outsource... if your customer relies on you for all their IT needs, then
if you can't implement something they want implemented and implement it
well, look for somebody else who can.  Being in the business, you're
able to be an effective middle-man.

Get yourself a network you can rely on.  If you need to do X, you go ask
John over there for help...

From romanmir at comcast.net  Sun Jul 18 19:41:02 2004
From: romanmir at comcast.net (Chris Penwell)

Subject: [PLUG] I no longer have a PERL itch...

> 	I'm looking to slurp the McMenamins's movie page once a week, and parse
> that into a webpage along the lines of what I have attached.

> 	The rule that was used for the attached page was as follows:

> able to find a section that would be very parsable. It would look for the

From lug at phxlinux.org  Sun Jul 18 20:08:02 2004
From: lug at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sun Jul 18 20:08:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] I no longer have a PERL itch...
In-Reply-To: <200407181939.29788.romanmir@comcast.net>
References: <200407120026.26486.romanmir@comcast.net> <200407181939.29788.romanmir@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407182006400.17171@neon.netpro.to>

On Sun, 18 Jul 2004, Chris Penwell wrote:

> ...having solved the problem with the attached 4 lines of bash code..
>
> #!/bin/bash
>
> #change directories
> cd ~/movies
>
> #Start Fresh
> rm -rf *.*
>
> #snag the page itself
> wget -O output.txt http://www.mcmenamins.com/index.php?type=theater
>
> #generate our output
> cat output.txt | grep strong>listings.html
>
> #display said page
> ~/firefox/firefox ~/movies/listings.html


You could make it a little shorter too:


#!/bin/bash

wget -O - "http://www.mcmenamins.com/index.php?type=theater" | grep strong > ~/movies/mcmen.html

~/firefox/firefox ~/movies/mcmen.html


It'd be cool if you could pipe HTML directly to Firefox...






From david.fetter at fetterconsulting.com  Sun Jul 18 21:01:02 2004
From: david.fetter at fetterconsulting.com (David M. Fetter)
Date: Sun Jul 18 21:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: computer/network consulting advice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181509290.16680@neon.netpro.to>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181509290.16680@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <40FB4744.7090502@fetterconsulting.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Matt Alexander wrote:
| I'm toying with the idea of starting my own computer/network consulting
| business.  At this point I'm just collecting information and I'd like to
| hear from others that are currently doing this type of work or have done
| it in the past.
|
| How was your experience?

So far it's ok.

~ What were the major hurdles to getting started?

My major hurdle right now is finding clients who will work with my
schedule.  I already have a full time job and I desire the stability it
provides.  My schedule there is relatively flexible but I do need to
show up Monday through Friday.  The hours I work on those days can be
somewhat flexible.  What that means is that I can't come into a client's
place and do work 8-5 for them.  It seems many of them want exactly just
that.

| What methods did you use to solicit new business?

My main method is word of mouth because given my dilemma that I
explained above, advertising will only mean I get calls from many people
who are expecting me to work at their location from 8-5 for a few days
(or however long it takes) until the project work is done.  Word of
mouth does two things for me.  The potential clients already know of my
scheduling constraints so if they contact me they are most likely
willing to work with that.  In addition, the potential client also knows
that my work is done well because essentially it's a referral from
another person that has seen my work and have been happy with it.

~  Was it a constant daily
| chore to find new business or were you able acquire a solid base of
| customers that provided enough work to keep food on the table?

It's a constant daily chore.  That's why I decided to just take a stable
regular job and do the consulting work on the side.

~ Did you
| run into any problems with other companies with similar names, and if so,
| how was this resolved?

Yes.  My original business name was SETEC-Astronomy, taken from that
movie Sneakers.  This caused too much confusion for potential clients
and others because they thought I did something to do with astronomy.  I
just changed my business name to reflect that of my last name, which is
Fetter Consulting.

Oh, and I had one guy who actually had a different business name, but he
straight up stole my web content verbatim.  I contacted him and told
him.  He replied and said it was his cousin who did the work or
something like that and he removed it, which he actually did.

~  What was a typical day like?

Evaluate what they are really asking for.  Explain to them what it will
take in both time and products.  Then start the work giving them an
outline of the schedule I will work with them on as well as providing
them with all of my contact information should they have an emergency.
Generally, I can leave my regular work with no issue should such a thing
arise.

~  There is an enormous
| amount of differing technologies deployed and it's close to impossible to
| be an expert in all areas, so if a customer had a tech need that you were
| not proficient with, did you still take the work and learn on the job?

I keep a close list of others who I have worked with throughout my
career in the industry.  Should something of that nature come up then I
will recommend the client to them.  This way I can at least have an idea
of the persons work quality so if nothing else my recommendation will be
remembered by the client and I will still be top of the list for future
work.

| Any additional information would be greatly appreciated.

Good luck.  It seems to me that in these times, it's still relatively
risky business to put your entire income into consulting.  I would
recommend at least having a part-time regular job along with the
consulting, but that's just me.

| Thanks,
| ~M
- --
David M. Fetter - http://www.fetterconsulting.com/

"The world is full of power and energy and a person can go far by just
skimming off a tiny bit of it." Neal Stephenson - Snow Crash
