From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jul 18 21:38:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Jul 18 21:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: computer/network consulting advice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181509290.16680@neon.netpro.to>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181509290.16680@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407182134470.2825@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 18 Jul 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I'm toying with the idea of starting my own computer/network consulting
> business.  At this point I'm just collecting information and I'd like to
> hear from others that are currently doing this type of work or have done
> it in the past.

Matt,

  Answer three questions for yourself:

  1.) What business am I in? In other words, exactly what products or
services do you offer?

  2.) Who is my market? To whom will you sell those services?

  3.) Why should they buy from me rather than from one of my competitors?
What makes you unique and not an off-the-shelf commodity?

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Sun Jul 18 21:44:02 2004
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Sun Jul 18 21:44:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: serial port and minicom problems
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181440520.16680@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407182131021.19671-100000@mail.mpcu.com>

On Sun, 18 Jul 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I have a phone system with a serial cable connected to a Linux box.  When
> I've previously connected the serial cable to a Windows box, hyperterm
> would see the phone system messages that it spits out as new calls come
> in, etc.  So now I'm trying to do the same thing with minicom.  I've got
> the serial port /dev/ttyS0 and the speed 19200 8N1 configured and minicom
> shows it's connected, but I never see anything from the phone system
> displayed to the screen.  Am I missing a configuration setting in minicom
> somewhere?  Perhaps something in the "modem and dialing" parameters makes
> minicom think it's talking to a modem?

I do the same for a KX-T123211D, the output is called SMDR.  I discovered 
a program called ttywatch a couple of years ago.  It provides redirecting 
output to syslog as well as permiting you to telnet to a port on the host 
and interact with the the phone system without interupting the recording.

> 
> The next step is to write a script that will connect periodically and
> retrieve this same information, but I'd like to see that things are
> working in minicom first.
> Thanks,
> ~M
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

a) you had better hope ~/movies exists.  The '>' stomps everything
   that needs stomping.

b) "*.*" is sort of a DOS-ism.  A plain '*' would do the trick, if
   that was desirable (which it isn't in this case).

b) if Randal sees that `cat foo | grep', he'll howl.  Try `grep < foo'
   instead.  

I like Matt's condensation a lot better.

will this other emulator run the software I need to use?

of the no-cost options. This may change some day, but it is a consideration.

From miken at hotsushi.com  Mon Jul 19 08:41:01 2004

Hi,

Some of the instructors at work are discussing why Windows is used to teach 
programming.  One reason is the GUI IDE and a questions was:

"Or is there some slick, visual, possibly XWindows-based Unix environment 
available that would meet Visual Studio's standard of presentation?"

Any developers out there have some open source recommendations I can promote?

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Jul 19 08:54:02 2004
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Mon Jul 19 08:54:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] GUI IDE?
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.2.20040719083220.0192cba8@www.hotsushi.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.2.20040719083220.0192cba8@www.hotsushi.com>
Message-ID: <1090252372.2218.29.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Mon, 2004-07-19 at 08:40 -0700, Mike Neal wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> Some of the instructors at work are discussing why Windows is used to teach 
> programming.  One reason is the GUI IDE and a questions was:
> 
> "Or is there some slick, visual, possibly XWindows-based Unix environment 
> available that would meet Visual Studio's standard of presentation?"
> 
> Any developers out there have some open source recommendations I can promote?
> 
> Thanks,
> Mike

There are a number of them, Eclipse is the first to come to mind,
however.  I'm pretty sure Emacs can be set up to behave similarly.  But
the real question you should be asking is "is Windows used to teach
programming?"  For at least one University in the Portland area the
answer is a resounding "no".  Sure, you can use Windows to write your
programs, but they must compile with gcc and, at least some professors,
require they be submitted as shars.  Of course, I've also heard nasty
rumors that they switched from C++ to Java for the undergrad courses, so
I'm not sure where that leaves us...

-- 
Shahms E. King <shahms at shahms.com>
Multnomah ESD

Public Key:
http://shahms.mesd.k12.or.us/~sking/shahms.asc

courses, but they were mentioned in my PSU CS courses.  PSU requires
projects be submitted as shars when you're dealing with multiple files,
as well.

PCC was said to have switched to Java a few years ago, but then switched
back, according to my PSU professor.

On Mon, 19 Jul 2004, Mike Neal wrote:

> available that would meet Visual Studio's standard of presentation?"

Mike,

  I have no idea what eye candy is provided by Visual Studio, but take a
look at Eclipse <http://www.eclipse.org/>. It developed from IBM's GUI
Websphere and is now its own organization. It is the emacs of the GUI world.

  My uses include java, UML and database schemas. I'm adding EMF (the
Eclipse Modeling Framework) and there should be C/C++ support any minute
now. As a matter of fact, it could be the subject of a semester's course all
by itself. :-)

From Trench-Shoring at gmx.net  Mon Jul 19 11:48:02 2004
From: Trench-Shoring at gmx.net (Trench Shoring)
Date: Mon Jul 19 11:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.
 100]>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
Message-ID: <6.0.0.22.2.20040719114110.02883150@mail.gmx.net>

My Vonage nightmare:

On a good day the echos are just a little bit annoying. One a bad day the 
lag between talk and listen makes all but the most conversation impossible.

I setup my VOIP unit on the inside of my firewall and the after hours of 
tech support, on the outside of my firewall.
It was a three month experience in frustration and tech support incompetence.
Now that it is over I am VERY suspicious of using Comcast as my bandwidth. 
I know many folks who have excellent Vonage service using DSL, but none who 
use comcast.

Best of luck.

From sloshr at gmail.com  Mon Jul 19 12:25:02 2004
From: sloshr at gmail.com (Ryan Schlosser)
Date: Mon Jul 19 12:25:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@172.27.1.100>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@172.27.1.100>
Message-ID: <78574cf8040719122332ec576b@mail.gmail.com>

On Mon, 19 Jul 2004 11:22:32 -0700, John Telford <john at johntelford.com> wrote:
 
> I'd appreciate learning about others experiences with Vonage and VOIP.
> 

I used Vonage with Comcast for 7 months, December of 2003 to end of June 2004.

The month of February, we had major problems wiht poor reception,
broken calls, etc.  Not sure if it was a Vonage problem, or a comcast
problem, but it seemed to resolve itself.

As long as we didn't do a lot of big file transfers, our phone calls
would sound very acceptable.

There was a small problem of a slight buzzing on our handset, and
somewhere I read in Vonage technical support that particular cordless
phones do have some sort of humming.  Supposedly if we'd gotten a non
wireless phone, the problem would have gone away.  Never tried it tho.

The Vonage tech support response has been good.

I really like the feature set that Vonage provides, including the
ability to check voicemail via a webpage, and call forwarding to
anywhere.  There's a lot more options, but that's what jumps out at me
that I use quite a bit.



From lug at phxlinux.org  Mon Jul 19 12:32:01 2004
From: lug at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon Jul 19 12:32:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407191227590.20934@neon.netpro.to>

On Mon, 19 Jul 2004, John Telford wrote:

> I'm think about switching phone service to Vonage - VOIP because doing
> so cuts my monthly phone bill in half.
>
> I'd appreciate learning about others experiences with Vonage and VOIP.

I've been extremely happy with Vonage.  I've got it setup at home in front
of my router.  This is the recommended setup so that the Motorola VoIP box
can prioritize the VoIP traffic.  I and others have not been able to tell
any difference between it and a regular POTS line.  I've also made
international calls and the quality is great.  The international rates are
better than most calling cards too.
No, I don't work for Vonage.  I've just been very happy with their service.
~M




From lug at phxlinux.org  Mon Jul 19 12:35:03 2004
From: lug at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon Jul 19 12:35:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407191233120.20934@neon.netpro.to>

On Mon, 19 Jul 2004, John Telford wrote:

> I'm think about switching phone service to Vonage - VOIP because doing
> so cuts my monthly phone bill in half.
>
> I'd appreciate learning about others experiences with Vonage and VOIP.

One other thing...  there's no contract, so if you're not happy with it
then you can call up and cancel immediately.




From stever at woo-hoo.com  Mon Jul 19 12:36:02 2004
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Mon Jul 19 12:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
Message-ID: <52969.209.210.3.17.1090265710.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> I'm think about switching phone service to Vonage - VOIP because doing
> so cuts my monthly phone bill in half.
>
> I'd appreciate learning about others experiences with Vonage and VOIP.

Am reasonably satisfied with the performance on a T1 line.  However had to
do some QOS on both sides so that the VOIP does not get stuttery when
downloading and saturating the link.  I have the Motorola ATA.

Voice quality, even on 80kbps, is of course not as good as POTS.  Better
than cell, but there is definitely a noticeable lag.  Most of my VOIP
packets head to a network in Phoenix, AZ (from PNW) and latency is only
40ms.  I think that there must be some significant other unseen distance
the packets fly generating the noticeable lag.  Voice collisions (both
parties talk at the same time because of the lag) happen often enough to
annoy me.

Price is good.  One thing that was not clear to me before ordering is that
Vonage does not charge you for incoming calls.  Thankfully most of my
minutes are incoming.  I have the $14.99/mo plan and never came close to
going over.

I can recommend it as a second line; my wife was tired of the POTS line
always being busy.  As an alternative (I have one of those multi-line
radio shack phones) it is worth the $15/mo plan.

From jason at vancleve.com  Mon Jul 19 12:52:02 2004
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon Jul 19 12:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] GUI IDE?
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.2.20040719083220.0192cba8@www.hotsushi.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.2.20040719083220.0192cba8@www.hotsushi.com>
Message-ID: <20040719125804.722366e5.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Mike Neal, on Mon, 19 Jul 2004 08:40:35 -0700:

> environment available that would meet Visual Studio's standard of
> presentation?"

What does "standard of presentation" mean?  Does it mean the aesthetic
effects of the general look-and-feel, rather than actual features?

I used to use SlickEdit, which has a Linux port.  That was basically
designed to look like Visual Studio, but I don't even like its look much
any more.

Besides which, most newer IDEs have a highly configurable UI.  The
Java-based JEdit (open source), for instance, can rearrange, dock or
float all of its child windows, and the text buffer area can have a
margin, line numbers, even a background image, depending on your
preferences.  Add to that all the different pluggable looks and feels
available in Java.  (My workmate sometimes looks at my monitor and asks
what IDE I'm using:  I tell him it's the same one he's using.)

--Jason V. C.

--
My other computer is your IIS server.

From root at loraksus.org  Mon Jul 19 13:04:01 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Mon Jul 19 13:04:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407191227590.20934@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <545931F80C27@loraksus.org>

Ok, to sum up my experiences
Vonage on Comcast - sucks, haven't tried dsl. That said, I continuously get
about 19ms ping to their servers, so there really shouldn't be any major
reasons for lag, but ok, whatever.

Vonage pass through / prioritize traffic mode - works great if you don't
mind resetting the damn box every 15 minutes. I had 2 of the Motorola's,
both randomly locked up, support was useless, so I said screw it and set it
up as below.

                        -> Vonage box on separate public (i.e. $3/mth) IP
DSL / Cable Modem -> Hub 
                        -> Rest of your network (router, etc)

That's not saying it won't work in another config, but it works reliably* in
this config. 

* As long as you keep the Motorola away from cordless phone base stations.
(I don't know why, but it works)

The Motorola's also only have 10 static port forwards and don't support upnp
iirc. There is a DMZ mode, but, again, passing a bunch of traffic through it
sucks.
Their rates - great. 
Their hold times for support - shitty (over 10-15 minutes). These are, of
course, cell phone minutes that you will be burning. 
Faxing? Well, if you want to fax, I'd advise a bottle of pepto bismol per
page.
Sound quality? Skype beats it hands down. 





From root at loraksus.org  Mon Jul 19 14:20:03 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Mon Jul 19 14:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: computer/network consulting advice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0407181509290.16680@neon.netpro.to>
Message-ID: <549EA9A95B0B@loraksus.org>

Brush up on your small claims court knowledge and try to get informed about
contract law. The law is a wee bit different in Washington, so you might
want to isolate your business to Oregon. 

I've done a fair bit on the side, but never really had the motivation needed
to do it on a full time basis. Most places are great to deal with, but the
~5% that are NPBs will cause you 99% of the angst and that sometimes makes
the job really suck. Try to talk to people in their industry, if a business
is going to screw you on money, they probably have done the same thing to
someone in the past (someone here maybe mentioned suppliers, other
contractors, etc).

I suppose there are also a bunch of guidelines to follow, they get the root
password after they pay, get EVERYTHING in writing, get people to sign off,
don't let their dumbass paper MCSE employees touch the server until everyone
signs off, etc, etc, etc. I'm sure other people have a comprehensive list. 
If you're going to do a maintenance agreement, be clear that that doesn't
cover Arthur knocking the server off a 5' table onto a concrete floor. Or
water damage. Or. . . 

If you have to hire someone to help you, be nice to them, be very nice and
pay really well. You probably will have to use them again, and if you were a
scrooge, they might have "other things to do". Just keep in mind you would
get nothing without them, so. . .

There are projects where you will want to run out screaming 5 minutes after
you walk in. Follow your gut and do so. Personally, I don't care if it means
eating mac and cheese with tuna for the next two weeks, $50/hr is not worth
coughing up blood from a newly formed ulcer. Don't be afraid to tell them
they need to clean up their server room / kill the dust bunnies / rats
before you will work in it / bring new hardware in. Bring a camera. Take a
lot of pictures.

You'll probably find yourself uninstalling spyware / porno ware for $45-$60
an hour as part of day to day operations. I sort of found a niche where
businesses that have an IT department located off site call me in to remove
adware, porno popups, and scrub their machines of crap in the history /
cache so they don't have to call their IT departments ;) I don't mind. It
helps to be discreet. A similar situation exists with housewives and / or
husbands, although sometimes it gets a little weird. 

If you were going to do this full time, I'd target home users, it's usually
easy and short work, but there are a lot more people who need help compared
to businesses. There really isn't much on-call support out there, and it is
very expensive, so undercutting established businesses with a brick and
mortar building in the area should not be difficult. 
You will probably do a lot more teaching than fixing for these folks too, so
communication skills help. 

Anyways. . .
Good Luck

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]
On Behalf Of Matt Alexander
Sent: Sunday, July 18, 2004 3:19 PM
To: PDXLINUX
Subject: [PLUG] OT: computer/network consulting advice

I'm toying with the idea of starting my own computer/network consulting
business.  At this point I'm just collecting information and I'd like to
hear from others that are currently doing this type of work or have done
it in the past.

How was your experience?  What were the major hurdles to getting started?
What methods did you use to solicit new business?  Was it a constant daily
chore to find new business or were you able acquire a solid base of
customers that provided enough work to keep food on the table?  Did you
run into any problems with other companies with similar names, and if so,
how was this resolved?  What was a typical day like?  There is an enormous
amount of differing technologies deployed and it's close to impossible to
be an expert in all areas, so if a customer had a tech need that you were
not proficient with, did you still take the work and learn on the job?
Any additional information would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks,
~M

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jul 19 16:17:01 2004
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon Jul 19 16:17:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
Message-ID: <40FC561D.3040805@comcast.net>

John Telford wrote:

>I'm think about switching phone service to Vonage - VOIP because doing
>so cuts my monthly phone bill in half.
>
>I'd appreciate learning about others experiences with Vonage and VOIP.
>
>...John
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>John Telford - Owner - JohnTelford.com LLC
>503-292-6865 - fax: 503-292-3094
>Email: john at johntelford.com   Weblog:      ITnews.johntelford.com
>  Web:  www.johntelford.com    Links: lotsoflinks.johntelford.com
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
>  
>
The company I work for is heavily involved with VoIP and so we decided 
to give Vonage a try and attempt to go without a PBX in our office...It 
has been a QoS nightmare! When we first started using it we'd have cases 
where the Vonage side would just go silent for 10 to 20 seconds before 
we'd hear a voice again during a call. Other times the voices are quite 
jumpy to the point it was impossible to discern what the other party was 
saying. I thing part of the problem for our office is that there was 
some poor planning done and so the entire office, both data and VoIP, is 
done on a single T1. It also doesn't help that the Cisco router our ISP 
provided for our T1 has no QoS features available in it..

I figured with all of the office T1 limitations I'd give Vonage a try at 
home where I have Comcast Cable Modem Service. I tried a Win32 client on 
my XP laptop and while the quality of what I heard on my side was good, 
everyone that had to listen to me complained about lousey voice quality 
from my end of the call. For now I just keep my Vonage client 
unregistered and so anyone calling my office Vonage number gets me on my 
cell phone which has much better voice quality. Recently things were so 
bad that we had a few POTS lines installed in our office just so we have 
a few phones capable of decent QoS.

We're in the process of switching over to SIP IP phones in the office 
and those people that are lucky enough to have a handset say the voice 
quality is much better with a dedicated handset. I think some of the 
problems with the Vonage client that we have in the office (besides the 
single T1) is that WinXP seems to cause the gaps of silence in the 
Vonage call when other activities occur. e.g. Resize a window or do some 
work in another application while a call is in progress. We're adding a 
second T1 to our office which will be dedicated for our VoIP services 
and we have a dedicated Asterisks PBX Linux server in both our offices 
now so I'm hopeful that we'll finally have decent VoIP service in our 
office by the time we all get SIP phone handsets on our desks. It would 
be great to have a decent SIP phone client I could use on my laptop so I 
don't have to use my own personal Verizon Wireless minutes for company 
business but right now it's the only way to get reliable phone service 
for me.

I've posted my company's Vonage problems when others have asked about 
the service and I've received some pretty hateful comments for anonymous 
posters saying I didn't know what I was talking about and their 
experience has been great. I have to wonder if they're a Vonage shill or 
something if they post anonymously.

YMMV,

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net




From aaron at bavariati.org  Mon Jul 19 17:06:02 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Jul 19 17:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <40FC561D.3040805@comcast.net>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]> <40FC561D.3040805@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20040720000504.GA31736@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Jul 19, 2004 at 06:15:41PM -0500, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> John Telford wrote:
> >I'd appreciate learning about others experiences with Vonage and VOIP.

> The company I work for is heavily involved with VoIP and so we decided 
> to give Vonage a try and attempt to go without a PBX in our office...It 
> has been a QoS nightmare!

Darn Winders stuff.

Last place I contracted at was in the telephony business, and used
Asterisk servers pretty heavily.  Worked great.  They had a T1 split
between phone and internet backhaul to ELI, using an Asterisk box as a
PBX and to handle VoIP.  They were planning on switching to an Asterisk
box co-lo'd at ELI to terminate their phone lines (they already had a
block of phone numbers) and then trunking them via internet to an
Asterisk box at the office, which would act as a PBX.  Asterisk has a
really good trunking protocol.  Great for branch offices and such.

Asterisk, BTW, runs on Linux and FreeBSD.  Quite nicely, I might add,
with the Digium T1 cards.

A "who knew telephony would be so cool?" B



From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jul 19 17:11:02 2004
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)

Subject: [PLUG] GUI IDE?

>>programming.  One reason is the GUI IDE and a questions was:

>>available that would meet Visual Studio's standard of presentation?"
>>

>
>There are a number of them, Eclipse is the first to come to mind,
>however.  I'm pretty sure Emacs can be set up to behave similarly.  But
>the real question you should be asking is "is Windows used to teach
>programming?"  For at least one University in the Portland area the
>answer is a resounding "no".  Sure, you can use Windows to write your
>programs, but they must compile with gcc and, at least some professors,
>require they be submitted as shars.  Of course, I've also heard nasty
>rumors that they switched from C++ to Java for the undergrad courses, so
>I'm not sure where that leaves us...
>
>  
>
As a guy that learned BASIC and Pascal before I ever learned anything 
about C, I don't know if learning with Java is necessarily a bad thing 
IMHO.  Trying to learn C++ as a first programming language would make it 
very difficult on beginners. Perhaps people that have grown up around 
computers are much more capable than people were in my college days 
where we were babied on books like Karel the Robot before we even got to 
do any real Pascal coding on a CDC Cyber system.

For anyone that doesn't know anything about Karel the Robot more 
information can be found here:

http://www.mtsu.edu/~untch/karel/

I know I feel that I was a much better programmer with C since I learned 
it after having to walk the very straight and narrow path that Pascal 
forces upon the programmer and so I continued many of the good practices 
I learned in Pascal when I started doing C programming in 1984.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

From root at loraksus.org  Mon Jul 19 19:46:02 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Mon Jul 19 19:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <545931F80C27@loraksus.org>
Message-ID: <55C902CC05DA@loraksus.org>

Oh, yeah, I've had a weird issue with the Motorola gateways they send you. 
As far as I can tell, Comcast's DHCP servers work like bootp servers, where
the ip given is linked to the MAC. Apparently multiple Motorola are sent out
with the same mac addy, which screws up dhcp for me and probably a bunch of
other people using their "fixed units" "out of the box".

I'm not sure if that is a screw-up on Motorola's end or on Vonage's end. I
wouldn't be surprised either way. The solution, is, of course, to spin the
magical wheel of mac addys, and pick one that is hopefully not being used by
a Comcast customer. Fun Fun FUC^BN!!!!

I'm pretty sure there is an ieee spec that is titled something like "Don't
ship multiple devices with the same mac addy dumbshits".  





From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue Jul 20 08:16:02 2004
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)

Subject: [PLUG] I no longer have a PERL itch...

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 20 10:52:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Jul 20 10:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] I no longer have a PERL itch...
In-Reply-To: <1090217438.26057.9.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <200407120026.26486.romanmir@comcast.net>
	<200407181939.29788.romanmir@comcast.net>
	<86acxw7euz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<1090217438.26057.9.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <86iscimurq.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "AR" == AthlonRob  <AthlonRob at axpr.net> writes:

Russell> b) if Randal sees that `cat foo | grep', he'll howl.  Try
Russell> `grep < foo' instead.

AR> Well, anybody should... 'tis UUOC!

AR> And, actually, I would guess it's probably more efficient to let
AR> grep open the file itself.

AR> grep string foo

AR> Of course, that's splitting hairs.

Hmm.  Valuing empiricism, I tried it:

   $ time (for i in $(seq 1 10000) ; do ; grep property < ucita200.txt > /dev/null ; done)
   (; for i in $(seq 1 10000); do; grep property < ucita200.txt > /dev/null; done  11.95s user 29.98s system 102% cpu 40.824 total

   $ time (for i in $(seq 1 10000) ; do ; grep property ucita200.txt > /dev/null ; done)
   (; for i in $(seq 1 10000); do; grep property ucita200.txt > /dev/null; done;   11.97s user 30.35s system 102% cpu 41.121 total

Slight, if inconsequential, advantage to the stdin redirection.  And
for comparison, here is the UUOC version:

   $ time (for i in $(seq 1 10000) ; do ; cat ucita200.txt | grep property > /dev/null ; done) 
   (; for i in $(seq 1 10000); do; cat ucita200.txt | grep property > /dev/null;   23.65s user 80.47s system 146% cpu 1:10.92 total


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com



From v_yau3 at hotmail.com  Tue Jul 20 10:53:02 2004
From: v_yau3 at hotmail.com (Vincent Yau)
Date: Tue Jul 20 10:53:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
Message-ID: <BAY9-F40e7CGedQSzxw0005e6ec@hotmail.com>

I have Comcast and I put the Vonage box (Motorola ATA) in between
my router and my cable modem which is the recommended setup.
It has been setup since April and we really enjoyed the service.
Did not give us problem at all.  There were one day
that the service was down (while my internet is up) and
it was brought back up in a few hours.  Caller ID failed for
2 days but it was resolved upon rebooting the Motorola box.

Domestic and Canadian calls have GREAT quality.  International calls
were acceptable, not as good as domestic calls though.

I would highly recommend it and as is the case for us, we saved a lot
on our phone bill.  The feature set is also very handy.
We were travelling in June and also around July 4th
and all calls were forwarded to us just fine.

At PSU, CS202 does the latter half in Java (a recent change). Then the
compilers course is done entirely in Java. There are some others in
upper division as well.

> What does "standard of presentation" mean?  Does it mean the aesthetic
> effects of the general look-and-feel, rather than actual features?

Visual Studio has some really slick context-sensitive API
documentation features that are rare elsewhere (you can kind of get it
in emacs if you look deeply enough, but it's not nearly as
slick). Plus Microsoft has the advantage of total control over the
API's, eh? :-) I don't use Visual Studio really at all, so that's all
I know off the top of my head for features.

How many pins?

Radio Shack has null modem 9-pin adapters.  (They convert a 9-pin cable to 
null modem without having to buy a whole new cable.)

Oregon Electronics also has cables of various sorts.

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Tue Jul 20 13:04:01 2004
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: Tue Jul 20 13:04:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Floppies and flipped cables
In-Reply-To: <1090186705.17892.7.camel@zontar.fnordora.org>
References: <20040718134228.3917.20853.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <20040718171142.GA15255@gate.kl-ic.com>
	 <1090186705.17892.7.camel@zontar.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <1090353784.1240.7.camel@kokopelli>

On Sun, 2004-07-18 at 17:38, Alan wrote:
> On Sun, 2004-07-18 at 10:11, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > On Sat, 2004-07-17 at 13:30, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > ...
> > > and the power connector on the only way it fits and I still get the same
> > > BIOS warning at boot. And, now the light on the floppy is on continuously
> > 
> > Wil writes:
> > 
> > > Floppy cable connected backwards?  Perhaps on the mobo?
> > 
> > This happens fairly often.  I have rolls of little colored sticky dots,
> > about 6mm diameter.  Before a motherboard or drive disappears into a
> > cabinet, I stick a colored dot near the pin 1 end of the drive or
> > connector.  This makes future cable changes a lot easier and safer.
> > 
> > Note, sometimes pin1 is not marked explicitly on a motherboard or in
> > a manual.  However, on typical circuit boards and connectors with
> > "through hole" (not surface mounted) pins, the connector comes through
> > to the back side of the board.  The pads for most of the connector pins
> > are round, but pin 1 is usually square.  You will only be able to see
> > that with the motherboard out of the case, of course.
> > 
> > Keyed connectors are supposed to eliminate the possibility of inverting
> > a cable, but sometimes enthusiasm makes a connector fit when it shouldn't.
> 
> Many floppy drives are constructed in such a way that the cable will fit
> either way.  It is a royal pain to get it right when you already have
> the drive mounted in the machine.

What is even more fun, is floppy cables have two kinds of keying, a
missing pin and a "key" on the side of the connector.  I have seen
floppy drives, with a "punch-out" in the circut board next to the
connector to clear the external key, and said drive did not have the
"punch-out" punched. So the drive would accept an adapter that did not
have an enternal key, or a cable that did not have an external key, but
would force you to put a cable with an external key in the wrong way,
unless you removed the little bit of circut board.
-- 
Brian Beattie   LFS12947 | "Honor isn't about making the right choices.
beattie at beattie-home.net | It's about dealing with the consequences."
www.beattie-home.net     | -- Midori Koto

Quoth Chris Jantzen, on Tue, 20 Jul 2004 11:43:07 -0700:

> On Mon, Jul 19, 2004 at 12:58:04PM -0700, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> 
> Visual Studio has some really slick context-sensitive API
> documentation features that are rare elsewhere (you can kind of get it
> in emacs if you look deeply enough, but it's not nearly as
> slick). Plus Microsoft has the advantage of total control over the

I'm guessing you, like me, value a pop-up code-completion feature which
will show your Javadoc comments inline?  SlickEdit did this pretty well.
 JEdit has a few different plugins for it, but at this point, none of
them really works.  Idea can do it too, but that's no longer free.

I'm not sure about Eclipse or NetBeans, but I'd like to know.  People
who've never used such a feature just don't realize how expedient it is.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 20 21:04:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Jul 20 21:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] transmitting double-floats over a socket
Message-ID: <86y8lem2h4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

I am working on a master-slave parallel processing problem.  The
master is running on an implementation of Scheme called Gauche, and
the slave is a C++ program.  I need to pass some of the results back
as double floats over the network socket.  What is a good way to
communicate them in a lossless way.  There is a function in
Scheme-land called (decode-float x) that returns three integer values
(m, e, s) such that s * m * 2^e reconstructs the float.  IEEE floats
make my head hurt.  Is there an easy way to construct these three
integers in C?  Is there another, better way?  I know I could just
printf("%.53g",x) (or <some other bignum>) but that is so graceless.

Any ideas?

Thanks!

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

Another graceless suggestion would be to find the IEEE binary datatype
definition and then use bitmasking and bitshifting to extract the
three integers and spit them out. That's just me talking without
putting more than about five minutes thought into it, though.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jul 21 00:26:01 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Jul 21 00:26:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] transmitting double-floats over a socket
References: <86y8lem2h4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86r7r5n7nd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

Russell Senior wrote:

> I am working on a master-slave parallel processing problem.  The
> master is running on an implementation of Scheme called Gauche, and
> the slave is a C++ program.  I need to pass some of the results back
> as double floats over the network socket.  What is a good way to
> communicate them in a lossless way.  There is a function in
> Scheme-land called (decode-float x) that returns three integer values
> (m, e, s) such that s * m * 2^e reconstructs the float.  IEEE floats
> make my head hurt.  Is there an easy way to construct these three
> integers in C?  Is there another, better way?  I know I could just
> printf("%.53g",x) (or <some other bignum>) but that is so graceless.
> 
> Any ideas?

Okay you folks made me woozy, I hope you are proud.

This actually seems to have gotten easier since the last time I
remember working on this, due to the ever handy long long (64-bit
integer).

It amounts to this:

union decode {
   double d;
   unsigned long long l;
};

void
print_decoded_double(double value) {
   union decode v;
   
   v.d = value;
   unsigned sign = v.l >> 63;
   signed exponent = v.l << 1 >> 53; 
   unsigned long long mantissa = v.l << 12 >> 12;

   if(exponent)
      mantissa |= (unsigned long long) (1 << 20) << 32;

   exponent -= 1023 + 52; // 1st part exponent bias, 2nd mantissa bias

   printf("(* %d %llu (expt 2d0 %d))",  // or equivalent
      sign ? -1 : 1, mantissa, exponent);

   return;
}

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com



From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Wed Jul 21 01:39:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Wed Jul 21 01:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <52969.209.210.3.17.1090265710.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: 
	<r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]> 
	<52969.209.210.3.17.1090265710.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <1090398346.9018.88.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Mon, 2004-07-19 at 12:35, Steven Raymond wrote:
> > I'm think about switching phone service to Vonage - VOIP because doing
> > so cuts my monthly phone bill in half.
> >
> > I'd appreciate learning about others experiences with Vonage and VOIP.
> 
> Am reasonably satisfied with the performance on a T1 line.  However had to
> do some QOS on both sides so that the VOIP does not get stuttery when
> downloading and saturating the link.  I have the Motorola ATA.
> 
> Voice quality, even on 80kbps, is of course not as good as POTS.  Better
> than cell, but there is definitely a noticeable lag.  Most of my VOIP
> packets head to a network in Phoenix, AZ (from PNW) and latency is only
> 40ms.  I think that there must be some significant other unseen distance
> the packets fly generating the noticeable lag.  Voice collisions (both
> parties talk at the same time because of the lag) happen often enough to
> annoy me.
> 
> Price is good.  One thing that was not clear to me before ordering is that
> Vonage does not charge you for incoming calls.  Thankfully most of my
> minutes are incoming.  I have the $14.99/mo plan and never came close to
> going over.
> 
> I can recommend it as a second line; my wife was tired of the POTS line
> always being busy.  As an alternative (I have one of those multi-line
> radio shack phones) it is worth the $15/mo plan.


Doesn't voice over POTS only use about 2400 baud?  
I don't see why Vonage would require more 
bandwidth than POTS, unless packet overhead is
making a big difference.  Doesn't Vonage work 
over udp?  With Comcast, are Vonage packets 
not being favored adequately over the packets 
of other bandwidth intensive applications?  

With the shared bandwidth aspect of cable, 
is anything being done by Comcast to control 
bandwidth hogging?

Is there latency because POTS is a full duplex signal
where Vonage is only half duplex?

Can Vonage service be ordered without committing to 
Comcast's cable Internet and TV services?  That 
$15/mo is deceptive if you have to order other 
services.      



The speed cable Internet is quoted at, is that 
the speed the cable infrastructure runs at, or 
only a fraction of it?  There are a number of 
comparisons between cable and DSL on the radio, 
etc. The comparison of apples to oranges makes 
me wonder what to really believe.  DSL bandwidth
is private where cable bandwidth is public.
The use of cable bandwidth is also more 
politically restrictive than DSL, or at least 
that's what I've been led to believe.

What POTS and DSL cost is a concern, but the 
cable companies clearly lack the reputation 
and possibly consumer interest to compete in 
non traditional areas.  I don't see cable 
extending beyond television rapidly in very 
many areas.  I haven't read very many 
testimonials yet of satisfaction with 
cable Internet and other non television 
cable services in this thread.



In my area...

CenturyTel forces purchase of POTS service 
because the line maintenance methods used 
don't include checking to see if there 
is only a DSL signal.  If the 
pair running your DSL got grabbed to replace 
another line, that probably wouldn't go over 
too well.  It's annoying to be forced into 
POTS though because it runs about $30/mo.  
That's extended, but not being able to 
call locally outside of Scappoose would 
be really inconvenient.  I don't think 
you can get an extended line and add 
a second one without.  You'd only 
save $12 a month, though you could 
probably drop call waiting too.
The cheapest for a second 500k DSL
line in Scappose would probably be
$63/month by the time you get the
phone line to run it on.

     Michael Robinson




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jul 21 02:14:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Jul 21 02:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <1090398346.9018.88.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
  <52969.209.210.3.17.1090265710.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
 <1090398346.9018.88.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407210154360.32532@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 21 Jul 2004, Darkhorse wrote:
> Doesn't voice over POTS only use about 2400 baud?

A DS0 (single line) is 64Kbps.  One bit is used for signalling, so you get
7 bits for data and 8000 bytes per second.  That gives you 56Kbps for
voice -- 8KHz sampling rate, mono, 7 bit.

> Can Vonage service be ordered without committing to Comcast's cable
> Internet and TV services?  That $15/mo is deceptive if you have to order
> other services.

Vonage can be run over your existing broadband internet connection.  It's
not related to Comcast.

> It's annoying to be forced into POTS though because it runs about
> $30/mo.  That's extended, but not being able to call locally outside of
> Scappoose would be really inconvenient.  I don't think you can get an
> extended line and add a second one without.  You'd only save $12 a
> month, though you could probably drop call waiting too.

Talk to your telephone company.  There is usually a very limited line that
can be hand for just a few dollars each month... this is the kind of line
used for alarm systems and the like.  They are usually associated with
VERY high per use charges.

> The cheapest for a second 500k DSL line in Scappose would probably be
> $63/month by the time you get the phone line to run it on.

Why would you need a second DSL line?  Just upgrade your bandwidth. I can
get 6 megabits.

J.

	<20040719124432.2e52bd13.jason@vancleve.com>

	<20040720164055.2fb06df5.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1090367964.4045.153.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
	<86wu0y1aug.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<20040721085940.0aad05ad.jason@vancleve.com>
	<86ekn5mivv.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20040721104452.128c3152.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Russell Senior, on 21 Jul 2004 09:20:52 -0700:

> It is the equivalent of sprinkling your mathematical expressions with
> additions of zero or multiplications of one.  The gratuitously
> encumbered expressions create an identical result, and yet they are
> harder to read for the visual noise.

<devils-advocate>It is not exactly that.  Adding "+ 0" or "* 1" to a
mathematical expression is entirely gratuitous, whereas "cat x |" is
not.  Either that or "< x" is required.

In some cases, using cat may actually be easier to read (it is to me,
but perhaps only because I'm more used to it).  In the OOPL world, we
encourage intuitive, readable code, even at the expense of performance.

Voltaire said, "the best is the enemy of the good".</devils-advocate>

--Jason V. C.

--
Remember this lesson from cartoon TV:  if you ever accidently run off a
cliff, don't ever look down.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Wed Jul 21 12:00:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Wed Jul 21 12:00:02 2004
Subject: OT Re: [PLUG] Vonage - VOIP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407210154360.32532@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: 
	<r02010100-1034-9A32485AD9B011D89AB0000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>
	<52969.209.210.3.17.1090265710.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
	<1090398346.9018.88.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> 
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0407210154360.32532@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1090435622.13879.31.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> Why would you need a second DSL line?  Just upgrade your bandwidth. I can
> get 6 megabits.

We're capped at 800 kb/s, it's $30/month extra to go from 500 to 800.
You pay enough for the upgrade in Scappose, you can just about 
get a second line and rent a second router.  If you want a megabit 
via DSL in Scappoose, you have to use two lines.  We have
a $25/month 5 ip subnet ( actually it's an 8 ).  Drop the subnet
back down to 1 ip adding the cost of the 300k upgrade, that's
$45-50.  If you go with 256k service, that gives you close 
to as much as the upgrade with a second phone, course you're 
trading off ip addresses.  The $4/month alarm line idea is 
a good one if you can receive faxes on it.  

If we can do Vonage and drop all the EAS, etc. off of our
existing phoneline, that may offer a nice alternative.

     --  Michael Robinson

	<20040721104452.128c3152.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <86smblkwq2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> writes:

Russell> It is the equivalent of sprinkling your mathematical
Russell> expressions with additions of zero or multiplications of one.
Russell> The gratuitously encumbered expressions create an identical
Russell> result, and yet they are harder to read for the visual noise.

Jason> <devils-advocate>It is not exactly that.  Adding "+ 0" or "* 1"
Jason> to a mathematical expression is entirely gratuitous, whereas
Jason> "cat x |" is not.  Either that or "< x" is required.

<all-I-ask-is-that-you-obey-me-as-you-would-the-word-of-god>
It *is* entirely gratuitous to run a whole program to create a data
stream when a '<' will do just as nicely without running the extra
program, and really just as clearly.  

The 'cat' program is there to string multiple files together.  It is
*sometimes* used to blurt the contents of a file onto the screen for
inspection, but as soon as you have another program to feed it to, a
simple '< foo' is better.</>

From mikeraz at patch.com  Wed Jul 21 14:01:01 2004
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Wed Jul 21 14:01:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Microsoft news
In-Reply-To: <20040721180457.GA2335@maybe.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407210940480.16185@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <20040721180457.GA2335@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <20040721210052.GD6560@patch.com>

On Wed, Jul 21, 2004 at 11:04:57AM -0700, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> As I understand it, these kinds of actions have the effect of pumping
> up the market price of remaining available stock. Then officers can
> sell off their own personal shares at an increased profit. So I
> wouldn't consider this some kind of altruistic door prize. :-)

This isn't "pumping up" in the gratuitous, pump and dump sense.  For the 
investor both the dividend and stock buy back are GoodThings.

The dividend returns cash to your pocket.  All other things being equal
this makes shares of the stock more valuable.

The buy back program means that the shares you hold represent a fractionally
larger portion of the enterprise.  Again, all other things being equal,
each share is more valuable.

when it is bad, it is better than nothing.

From dp at news4neighbors.net  Wed Jul 21 14:04:02 2004
From: dp at news4neighbors.net (David Pool)
Date: Wed Jul 21 14:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Penguin Day Event July 24th
Message-ID: <40FEDA07.5020000@news4neighbors.net>

This coming Saturday July 24th there's an event happening at Free Geek 
that's aimed at solving the barriers to F/OSS adoption by nonprofits. 
Penguin Day, as it's being called, follows a format laid down at the 
first Penguin Day in Philly earlier this year. We'll be doing some 
interactive discussions in the morning and some hands on presentations 
in the afternoon.

The target audience is nonprofit IT staff, nonprofit IT consultants, 
developers and funders. If you are or know someone who would benefit 
from this event please pass along the invitation. More info can be found at:

http://portland.penguinday.org

Space is limited to 60 people and we're at about 45 today.

thanks,

David Pool



From john at meissen.org  Wed Jul 21 14:58:02 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Wed Jul 21 14:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] transmitting double-floats over a socket
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Wed, 21 Jul 2004 06:41:45 PDT.)
             <20040721134145.24037.25067.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20040721215741.CD317222D8@john.meissen.org>

Russell Senior wrote:
> union decode {
>    double d;
>    unsigned long long l;
> };
> 
> void
> print_decoded_double(double value) {
>    union decode v;
>    
>    v.d = value;
>    unsigned sign = v.l >> 63;
>    signed exponent = v.l << 1 >> 53; 
>    unsigned long long mantissa = v.l << 12 >> 12;
>  etc.,etc.
> 

Does that actually work? Back when I worked on compilers the language
lawyers in the company said that those results were undefined, and
that after passing through the optimizer you were pretty much guaranteed
garbage. From a practical standpoint it might work, but the language
only let you take out what you put in. I.e., the construct was there to
allow multiple uses for the same location, not for data conversion.
But maybe ANSI changed all that in the years since then....

john-







From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jul 21 16:17:01 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Jul 21 16:17:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] transmitting double-floats over a socket
In-Reply-To: <20040721215741.CD317222D8@john.meissen.org>
References: <20040721215741.CD317222D8@john.meissen.org>
Message-ID: <86fz7lkl2f.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "John" == John Meissen <john at meissen.org> writes:

[ code snipped ]

John> Does that actually work? 

It seems to work.

John> Back when I worked on compilers the language lawyers in the
John> company said that those results were undefined, and that after
John> passing through the optimizer you were pretty much guaranteed
John> garbage. From a practical standpoint it might work, but the
John> language only let you take out what you put in. I.e., the
John> construct was there to allow multiple uses for the same
John> location, not for data conversion.  But maybe ANSI changed all
John> that in the years since then....

I have no idea.  IANALL.  ;-)

I am having a hard time seeing how it couldn't work (at least in this
simple case).  Can you explain?

Hmm.  My Harbison&Steele,2ed says that "It is _not_ portable to assign
one union component and then reference another component".  And the
WG14/N843 committee draft (August 3, 1998) says in Section 6.5.2.3
(5): "With one exception, if the value of a member of a union object
is used when the most recent store to the object was to a different
member, the behavior is implementation-defined."  Evidently this union
technique is called "type-punning", and apparently it works on GCC.

I am only intending to use GCC, so I guess I am relatively safe.

Anyway, what is the alternative?

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From john at meissen.org  Wed Jul 21 17:05:03 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Wed Jul 21 17:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] transmitting double-floats over a socket
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Wed, 21 Jul 2004 16:38:02 PDT.)
             <20040721233802.22996.86151.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20040722000416.9DDAC222D8@john.meissen.org>

Russell Senior said:
> I am having a hard time seeing how it couldn't work (at least in this simple
> case).  Can you explain? 

I could easily see where, especially if there wasn't any persistent 
storage involved, the compiler might treat v.d as a reference to a
floating point register and v.l as a reference to an integer register.
There's no dependency between the different parts of the union, so
the initial value could get stored in the floating point register and
the rest operates on the random garbage in the integer register. 

> Anyway, what is the alternative? 

Use pointers?

 double d;
 unsigned long long *l;
 l = (unsigned long long *)&d;

 unsigned sign = *l >> 63;
 signed exponent = *l << 1 >> 53; 
 unsigned long long mantissa = *l << 12 >> 12;

john-





From shahms at shahms.com  Wed Jul 21 17:36:01 2004
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Wed Jul 21 17:36:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] transmitting double-floats over a socket
In-Reply-To: <86fz7lkl2f.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20040721215741.CD317222D8@john.meissen.org>
	 <86fz7lkl2f.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1090456524.29624.24.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Wed, 2004-07-21 at 16:16 -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "John" == John Meissen <john at meissen.org> writes:
> 
> [ code snipped ]
> 
> John> Does that actually work? 
> 
> It seems to work.

The answer is it will "usually" work, for varying definitions of usually
and work.

> John> Back when I worked on compilers the language lawyers in the
> John> company said that those results were undefined, and that after
> John> passing through the optimizer you were pretty much guaranteed
> John> garbage. From a practical standpoint it might work, but the
> John> language only let you take out what you put in. I.e., the
> John> construct was there to allow multiple uses for the same
> John> location, not for data conversion.  But maybe ANSI changed all
> John> that in the years since then....
> 
> I have no idea.  IANALL.  ;-)

ANSI has changed, just not that part ;-)
After a quick perusal of the C99 standard, I can't find anything
specifically addressing it, but I have a memory of it being defined as
undefined ;-) There is a line that says a union may hold the value of at
most one of its members, but that a pointer to a union object, suitably
converted, points to each of its members.

So 

union { double d; int i; } u;
int i;

u.d = 1.0;
i = u.i;       /* invalid */
i = *(int*)&u; /* valid? */

> I am having a hard time seeing how it couldn't work (at least in this
> simple case).  Can you explain?

The standard also says that any storage belonging to one member of a
union but not another is left in an unspecified state.  On GCC ix86
double and long long are the same size, but that's not guaranteed.  If
they are of different sizes, the values stored in the "extra" bytes are
undefined and could lead to problems.  Essentially, the standard says
that from the compiler's perspective the only "type" that matters is the
type of the last assigned member.  Except when you're dealing with
pointers and sizeof() ;-P

> Hmm.  My Harbison&Steele,2ed says that "It is _not_ portable to assign
> one union component and then reference another component".  And the
> WG14/N843 committee draft (August 3, 1998) says in Section 6.5.2.3
> (5): "With one exception, if the value of a member of a union object
> is used when the most recent store to the object was to a different
> member, the behavior is implementation-defined."  Evidently this union
> technique is called "type-punning", and apparently it works on GCC.
> 
> I am only intending to use GCC, so I guess I am relatively safe.
> 
> Anyway, what is the alternative?

Pointers is your best option, although I personally lean towards using
"unsigned char" which the C standard says is the only guaranteed
conversion that won't change the bit representation (like casting to
int), especially if you're just transmitting them over a socket.  Then
again, if you're just transmitting them over a socket casting the
address to a void* and using sizeof(double) will work just fine.

-- 
Shahms E. King <shahms at shahms.com>
Multnomah ESD

Public Key:
http://shahms.mesd.k12.or.us/~sking/shahms.asc

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Wed Jul 21 17:47:02 2004
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed Jul 21 17:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] transmitting double-floats over a socket
In-Reply-To: <86acxtmhoo.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86y8lem2h4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <20040721070219.GA711@maybe.net> <86acxtmhoo.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <40FF0E68.6040704@comcast.net>

Russell Senior wrote:

>>>>>>"Chris" == Chris Jantzen <chris at maybe.net> writes:
>>>>>>            
>>>>>>
>
>Chris> Another graceless suggestion would be to find the IEEE binary
>Chris> datatype definition and then use bitmasking and bitshifting to
>Chris> extract the three integers and spit them out. That's just me
>Chris> talking without putting more than about five minutes thought
>Chris> into it, though.
>
>Thanks, it is certainly an improvement in grace over the
>printf("%.53g",x) bludgery.  This is reminding me of the related issue
>of RPC value passing using XDR (and me never finding a good[1]
>reference for that and/or the tools one used in relation to it) and
>the like.
>
>[1] where "good" is defined as me being able to comprehend it.
>
>  
>
Years ago when I was working at OSI on their NetExpert product my first 
assignment was working on the interprocess message handling daemon. At 
the time it was done using ONC RPC. I found an ONC RPC book from OReilly 
that was invaluable to me since I had mosly just toyed around with doing 
some simple RPC interfaces The messaging daemon was very serious stuff 
so I figured I needed a real reference book with lots of meat. We cached 
messages in the daemon if a destination process wasn't registered or was 
down and if the unsent message count grew too large we'd write the 
messages to files for later retrival. 

Nowadays if I need to do any sort of messaging in a client/server 
environment I use a CORBA ORB (usually omniORB) and write interfaces 
using IDL. For quick and somewhat dirty through I suppose ONC RPC would 
be OK as well but it's been years since I used RPCs. I've held on to my 
OReilly RPC book as I didn't know if it's still in print  or not.

FWIW I did find it listed on their website still so maybe it is 
available altough for simpe ONC RPC programming there must be something 
free on the web (I didn't look):

http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/rpc/index.html

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

> Russell> It is the equivalent of sprinkling your mathematical
> Russell> expressions with additions of zero or multiplications of one.
> Russell> The gratuitously encumbered expressions create an identical
> Russell> result, and yet they are harder to read for the visual noise.
>
> Jason> <devils-advocate>It is not exactly that.  Adding "+ 0" or "* 1"
> Jason> to a mathematical expression is entirely gratuitous, whereas
> Jason> "cat x |" is not.  Either that or "< x" is required.
>
> <all-I-ask-is-that-you-obey-me-as-you-would-the-word-of-god>
> It *is* entirely gratuitous to run a whole program to create a data
> stream when a '<' will do just as nicely without running the extra
> program, and really just as clearly.
>
> The 'cat' program is there to string multiple files together.  It is
> *sometimes* used to blurt the contents of a file onto the screen for
> inspection, but as soon as you have another program to feed it to, a
> simple '< foo' is better.</>

<while-the-discourse-is-good,-the-problem-has-been-solved>
Guys,

The two biggest problems have been addressed. The original problem: which was 
pointed out to me as a fairly easy one or two line bash script. And the one 
of ignorance: which had to do with a better way to do it. In other words, I 
learned something in the process. (a few things, actually.) 

Now in my case, the UUOC wasn't as big of an issue, as my desktop machine (the 
one in question,) spends most of it's life bored out of it's skull.  However, 
I agree that in a server environment squeezing operations out of every single 
cycle possible is what is strived for. 

But let's call it a victory, already. Maybe over a brew, (or not,) 
Whaddya say?



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jul 21 18:17:01 2004

>>>>> "Shahms" == Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com> writes:

Shahms> Pointers is your best option, although I personally lean
Shahms> towards using "unsigned char" which the C standard says is the
Shahms> only guaranteed conversion that won't change the bit
Shahms> representation (like casting to int), especially if you're
Shahms> just transmitting them over a socket.  Then again, if you're
Shahms> just transmitting them over a socket casting the address to a
Shahms> void* and using sizeof(double) will work just fine.

Oh, I am planning to have the C++ slave side send the numbers in ASCII
text representing the three integers.  The Gauche/Scheme master side
wouldn't know (I don't think) what to do with a binary double.

In Lisp-land, there is a pair of papers from 1990 about printing and
reading floats in such a way as to guarantee the same value goes all
the way around.

  "How to Read Floating Point Numbers Accurately", William D. Clinger

and 

  "How to print floating point numbers accurately", Guy Steele,
  Jr. and Jon L White.

From jason at vancleve.com  Thu Jul 22 09:55:03 2004

I know this one will be a snap for some of yous:  what's the proper
header for threading emails?  I'm on a certain mailing list, and when I
last posted, I got a reply with "Re: " prepended to the subject, as
usual.  Yet my client, Sypheed claws, did not correlate it, as it
normally does (it appears at the bottom of the folder, rather than
indented below my message).

what most clients are using, but my email has an "X-ELNK-Trace" instead.
 Is that wrong, as I suspect?  Whether or no, replies to my emails are
usually threaded properly, so I'm perplexed over this case.

From shahms at shahms.com  Thu Jul 22 10:05:03 2004
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Thu Jul 22 10:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Threading Headers
In-Reply-To: <20040722100242.14c6b0ad.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20040722100242.14c6b0ad.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1090515882.29624.31.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Thu, 2004-07-22 at 10:02 -0700, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I know this one will be a snap for some of yous:  what's the proper
> header for threading emails?  I'm on a certain mailing list, and when I
> last posted, I got a reply with "Re: " prepended to the subject, as
> usual.  Yet my client, Sypheed claws, did not correlate it, as it
> normally does (it appears at the bottom of the folder, rather than
> indented below my message).
> 
> The headers from both emails are below.  It looks like "Thread-Index" is
> what most clients are using, but my email has an "X-ELNK-Trace" instead.
>  Is that wrong, as I suspect?  Whether or no, replies to my emails are
> usually threaded properly, so I'm perplexed over this case.

Well, I'm not sure how the "Thread-Index" and "Thread-Topic" headers are
supposed to be used, but the header that is most frequently used is the
"In-Reply-To" header in combination with the "Message-Id" from the email
that the reply is "in reply to".

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jul 22 11:45:03 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jul 22 11:45:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Threading Headers
In-Reply-To: <20040722113236.2183cacc.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20040722100242.14c6b0ad.jason@vancleve.com>
 <1090515882.29624.31.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us> <1090516040.29771.8.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
 <20040722113236.2183cacc.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407221141590.32532@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 22 Jul 2004, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> So should I surmise that In-Reply-To is the (de facto?) standard, and
> that M$ Outhouse (TM) is playing the usual M$ Game (TM) by using
> Thread-Index instead?

I've never heard of Thread-Index before.  In-Reply-To is just the
MessageID of the message to which one is replying.  It's really the only
sensible way to thread because it's independent of subject (to
keep appropriate subject headers in straying threads) and can be
constructed from ANY valid email message.

J.
--

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> writes:

Jason> I see.  So should I surmise that In-Reply-To is the (de facto?)
Jason> standard, [...]

The RFC822 and now RFC2822 standard, so more that defacto.  As of July
22, 2004, RFC822 is the Official Internet Protocol Standard, and 2822
is a Proposed Standard.  See:

  <http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfcxx00.html>

See also the "References" header.

--

seniorr at aracnet.com

From gluebert at comcast.net  Thu Jul 22 13:35:03 2004
From: gluebert at comcast.net (R. Haack)
Date: Thu Jul 22 13:35:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Cloning Drives/Cloning Around
Message-ID: <410024A4.3080909@comcast.net>

Hey Guys,

Here is what I would like to do.

I have two 200GB SATA drives.  The first drive contains all of my Fedora 
install.  The second drive is currently blank, no partitions, no 
nothing.  I'm going to turn this system into an email server, but we 
don't really care if we do regular backups on the server since email 
comes and goes it would be a moving target.  What I want to do though is 
copy everything from the first drive to the second drive and make it so 
that if the first drive dies, I can switch to the second drive with 
little effort and pickup pretty much were we left off.  So what 
programs/processes can I run to clone the first disk to the second disk?

Thanks in Advance.

Robert Haack





From pmvw at earthlink.net  Thu Jul 22 13:54:01 2004
From: pmvw at earthlink.net (Piet van Weel)

From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]
On Behalf Of R. Haack
Sent: Thursday, July 22, 2004 1:34 PM
To: Portland Linux Users Group
Subject: [PLUG] Cloning Drives/Cloning Around



Hey Guys,

Here is what I would like to do.

I have two 200GB SATA drives.  The first drive contains all of my Fedora 
install.  The second drive is currently blank, no partitions, no 
nothing.  I'm going to turn this system into an email server, but we 
don't really care if we do regular backups on the server since email 
comes and goes it would be a moving target.  What I want to do though is 
copy everything from the first drive to the second drive and make it so 
that if the first drive dies, I can switch to the second drive with 
little effort and pickup pretty much were we left off.  So what 
programs/processes can I run to clone the first disk to the second disk?

Thanks in Advance.

Robert Haack



_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug




From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Thu Jul 22 13:54:14 2004
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Thu Jul 22 13:54:14 2004
Subject: [PLUG] X emulator on Windows
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D72@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
Vincent Yau asks:
> 
> Is there another X client I can use besides Cygwin?

(Actually, the Windows box is the X Server.  The *nix box is the client.  X
is a little strange about the client/server roles.) 

  I use the commercial product "Hummingbird Exceed 9.0" to remote X
applications to Windows from Solaris and Linux workstations.  

Exceed Family 
http://www.hummingbird.com/products/nc/exceed/index.html

  You'll need the "Connectivity Secure Shell" software if you want to run
over an SSL tunnel.

  You may also want to look into VNC if you don't care to purchase
commercial software.  There are Open Source VNC clients for Windows.  The
modern Linux distro's seem to come out of the box with VNC installed.  

Steve D...



From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jul 22 14:01:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jul 22 14:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Cloning Drives/Cloning Around
In-Reply-To: <410024A4.3080909@comcast.net>
References: <410024A4.3080909@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407221357080.32532@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 22 Jul 2004, R. Haack wrote:
> Here is what I would like to do.
>
> I have two 200GB SATA drives.
> I'm going to turn this system into an email server, but we don't really
> care if we do regular backups on the server since email comes and goes
> it would be a moving target.

Uh, woah.  200GB for email?  I'll trade you two 15GGBs... I promise you
won't run out of space.

> What I want to do though is copy everything from the first drive to the
> second drive and make it so that if the first drive dies, I can switch
> to the second drive with little effort and pickup pretty much were we
> left off.

Well, you could just make a CD of the final installation and copy out /etc
every so often.

Hell, you could run it off a CD with a shared memory filesystem for /tmp
and bits of /var and just make a big RAID mirror out of the other two
drives.

Sounds to me like you've got way more hardware than you need, though.

And I really can't recommend not running backups on your mail server.
Lots of people use IMAP clients and keep everything on the server.

J.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jul 22 14:06:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Jul 22 14:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Cloning Drives/Cloning Around
In-Reply-To: <410024A4.3080909@comcast.net>
References: <410024A4.3080909@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1090530320.29771.20.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2004-07-22 at 13:33, R. Haack wrote:
> Hey Guys,
> 
> Here is what I would like to do.
> 
> I have two 200GB SATA drives.  The first drive contains all of my Fedora 
> install.  The second drive is currently blank, no partitions, no 
> nothing.  I'm going to turn this system into an email server, but we 
> don't really care if we do regular backups on the server since email 
> comes and goes it would be a moving target.  What I want to do though is 
> copy everything from the first drive to the second drive and make it so 
> that if the first drive dies, I can switch to the second drive with 
> little effort and pickup pretty much were we left off.  So what 
> programs/processes can I run to clone the first disk to the second disk?

You want to set up a RAID1 mirror between the drives.  On the second
drive, create partitions with the same geometry as the first drive. 
You'll have to read up a bit on configuring RAID & MD (multple devices)
if you're not familiar with it.  In short, create a one-device MD for
each of your partitions (except swap).  Then create filesystems on each
MD.  Then mount them in your running system, and use cp/tar/rsync/etc in
single-user mode to copy your existing filesystems onto the new ones. 
Then modify your fstab, grub config, etc. for the second drive and boot
into the RAID devices on the second drive.  Finally, add the partitions
from the first drive to the raidtab and let the mirror be
reconstructed.  (It'll take a good while w/200GB.)

For swap, just make two swap partitions and enable them both to have the
same priority with 'pri=1' in the fstab.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Thu Jul 22 18:43:02 2004
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Thu Jul 22 18:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] (off topic) WAP protocol question
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D3D75@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
Ovid asks:
> 
> On a Blackberry Wireless, I'm getting the following error 
> message when surfing one of our Web
> sites:
> 
>   WAP Session Abort 8:
>   User Acknowledgement not received.
> 
> We have no documentation and I've been googling like mad to 
> find the meaning of the error, but no luck.  Can anyone offer 
> pointers?

Google for "WTP User Acknowledgement".  There is some info.  

  I'm no WAP expert, but I'd say that you're WAP (Wireless Access Protocol)
site is operating in WTP (Wireless Transaction Protocol) User
Acknowledgement mode.  It looks like you're not receiving a User
Acknowledgement within the timeout period.  

  I'd say contact the vendor of the server side software and find out what
the "Abort 8" means and what conditions generate that error.  (Maybe...
Suspended?)  You may be able to tweak the server side code to get it out of
end-to-end acknowledgement mode.  

  The WAP Forum guys wrote the specs.  It may be difficult to get the actual
docs without paying or joining.  

Open Mobile Alliance (WAP Forum)
http://www.wapforum.com/

This may work... 

See Chapter 7.3 - User Acknowledgement
Wireless Transaction Protocol - Version 10-Jul-2001
<http://www.openmobilealliance.org/tech/affiliates/wap/wap-224-wtp-20010710-
a.pdf>

Steve D...

On Thu, 2004-07-22 at 20:09 +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> I know Cygwin has X shipped with it and I enjoy using it.
> But Cygwin has so many other stuff that sometimes I just
> want to display X traffic onto my Windows client
> (remote is some sort of Unix hosts).
> 
> Is there another X client I can use besides Cygwin?

Actually, you want an X server to run under Windows, not an X client.
And yeah, there's one... it has a hummingbird for its logo, it may even
be called hummingbird, I think.  Hmmm... maybe it was a butterfly?
Anyway, it wasn't free.  I think there used to be a third one, as well.

IMHO, Cygwin is the only real viable option, given its cost and the fact
that it works.

The X server was called Humingbird Exceed. It's neither free or cheap 
and so Cygwin does the job very well IMHO. Exceed is still avaiable but 
I don't know how popular it is nowt given that Cygwin has a pretty 
decent X server that's free. I did use Exceed it when I worked a 
contract at Boeing CAG in Seattle and had Win2K machine. At tjhe company 
I work for now which is a startup we use PuTTY for ssh CLI session and 
Cygwin when we need to run X stuff from our Linux servers. We had some 
people whining about Cygwin as they wanted to have a more tightly 
integrated X solution with the Windows desktop but they lost out 
beccause of the  the high cost of Exceed compared to the Cygwin solution.

Many of our people in engineering are Unix/Linux users and so they like 
having Cygwin to given whem a Unix-like interface on their WinXP laptops 
although we have a number of defectors that have flattened their laptops 
and have installed Linux and are getting buy without Windows at all.

Tony

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Jul 22 21:56:01 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu Jul 22 21:56:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Actiontec GT701-wg
Message-ID: <20040723045428.72598.qmail@web50604.mail.yahoo.com>

I use Qwest DSL for Internet access, using a Cisco 678
modem. This arrangement has been satisfactory.
However, if the modem doesn't last forever, and I
continue to use Qwest, they would replace it with an
Actiontec GT701-wg. Do some members of this list
currently use the Actiontec? If so, how well does it
work with Linux?

The reason I ask is that Cisco modems are still
available through Ebay and other sources, and if the
Actiontec future looks dismal, I suppose some would
recommend getting another Cisco before they disappear.
I unplug the one I currently use when no one is using
a computer, in the belief that allowing it to cool
will extend its life. 

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jul 22 22:22:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Jul 22 22:22:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Actiontec GT701-wg
In-Reply-To: <20040723045428.72598.qmail@web50604.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040723045428.72598.qmail@web50604.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1090560113.4239.10.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2004-07-22 at 21:54, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I use Qwest DSL for Internet access, using a Cisco 678
> modem. This arrangement has been satisfactory.
> However, if the modem doesn't last forever, and I
> continue to use Qwest, they would replace it with an
> Actiontec GT701-wg. Do some members of this list
> currently use the Actiontec? If so, how well does it
> work with Linux?

Some of my partners have them; they seem to work okay.  Well, I cannot
attest to the exact model, but it is the Actiontec with PCMCIA slot for
wireless.  You have to buy Actiontec's wireless card, but it works and
is okay.  We haven't had too many problems with it, and we've frequently
had half a dozen systems between the wired and wireless networks at a
time (mostly wireless).  I found a "fun" feature of the built-in DHCP
server that it won't if it's configured to hand out only a single DNS
address; duplicating the same IP made it work though.

> The reason I ask is that Cisco modems are still
> available through Ebay and other sources, and if the
> Actiontec future looks dismal, I suppose some would
> recommend getting another Cisco before they disappear.
> I unplug the one I currently use when no one is using
> a computer, in the belief that allowing it to cool
> will extend its life. 

The 675's definitely had cooling problems.  My 678 has been in more or
less continuous operation in my basement in 24x7 operation for over 3
years.

Wil

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> writes:

Jason> Hmm.  This seems to contrast what Messrs. Cooley and Senior

Either can be used.  One nice feature of the References header is that
it includes some substantial portion of the whole chain of messages
(although not guaranteed to be complete).  That allows a more robust
threading in the case where some messages of the thread are missing.

I had one fail after about 6 months, and I think heat was a factor.

pencils to increase airflow underneath, and now cable-tied to an old
inverted drive cage which provides a *lot* more airflow underneath.
And as long as I don't change my Qwest service in *any* way, I've got
two backup 675s ready to go in case this one fails.
