From fixin at peak.org  Fri Jul 23 07:26:01 2004
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Fri Jul 23 07:26:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Actiontec GT701-wg
In-Reply-To: <20040723052503.30600.10832.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040723052503.30600.10832.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040723142503.GH783@peak.org>

> Date: Thu, 22 Jul 2004 21:54:28 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Robert Kopp <iconoklastic at yahoo.com>
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] Actiontec GT701-wg
> Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> 
> I use Qwest DSL for Internet access, using a Cisco 678
> modem. This arrangement has been satisfactory.
> However, if the modem doesn't last forever, and I
> continue to use Qwest, they would replace it with an
> Actiontec GT701-wg. Do some members of this list
> currently use the Actiontec? If so, how well does it
> work with Linux?

I've been using one for maybe six months.  It was a pain to set up,
but has been fine since.  IIRC there were three adjustments I had to
make in order to live with it.

1) The firmware isn't very reliable and every few days the thing gets
   into a state where you need to power-cycle it.  So I bought a $9
   lamp timer at RadioShack in order to preemptively cycle it every
   night.  I can now travel for a week and always have access back in;
   without the timer I'd lose connectivity after maybe three days.

2) I use ez-ipupd to bind my Qwest-assigned dynamic IP address to a
   domainname.  In order to get the IP address off of the Actiontec I
   had to write a script using wget that scrapes it off of the browser
   interface.  Another script runs every five minutes and calls
   ez-ipupd if the address has changed, as it sometimes does.

3) The Actiontec by default wants to be your router, firewall, DHCP
   server, etc. -- but unfortunately isn't as good at those as LEAF, a
   floppy-based firewall project.  Configuring the thing to get out of
   the way wasn't easy.  IIRC it meant turning off some stuff,
   assigning my router a static IP and then forwarding all ports to
   that IP.  Surprisingly, some of the Qwest tech support people were
   helpful with this.

--Eric
-- 
******************************************************************************
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*    Crosswords 4.0.6 for PocketPC is out!: <http://xwords.sourceforge.net>  *
******************************************************************************

From steve at wirex.net  Fri Jul 23 09:24:01 2004
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Fri Jul 23 09:24:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] X emulator on Windows
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F19Wk6P7P1jN3d00045ebf@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F19Wk6P7P1jN3d00045ebf@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20040723162114.GA12275@wirex.net>

On Thu, Jul 22, 2004 at 08:09:44PM +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> Is there another X [server] I can use besides Cygwin?

There are/were several commercial X servers for windows; people have
already mention Hummingbird's Exceed, which was decent when I toyed with
it 6-7 years ago. Long ago (win 3.1) days, I used WRQ's Reflection X
(their Reflections series supports a lot of oddball terminal emulation,
which my job at the time required).  Dunno if it's still the case, but
Reflection X let you use either Windows or whatever *nix window manager
of your choice (running on the remote host, of course) to manage your
desktop -- it was an odd experience to have to have my win 3.1 apps
running within a SunOS openwin desktop in 1995.

--

http://NxNW.org/~steve/                            immunix.org

Exceed is indeed not cheap.  However, I does a very good job of operating in
complex visual environments.  I ran into this when evaluating X servers for
use as enterprise management consoles.  OpenView (the IM software in use)
would overwhelm the other products we tried.  Only Exceed would stay up.
You have to need it pretty bad to put up with the cost though...
-chaz

libraries, but I don't know what they are because my Gentoo picked them

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jul 23 19:45:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jul 23 19:45:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A CUPS problem
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407231939370.2209@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I've been trying to print a pdf file of a purchased book. The printer
stopped after the frontmatter, then after the summary, then after chapter 1.
Each time, CUPS (via /usr/sbin/printers) showed the parallel port was busy.
So, I killed the process, then the jobs in the queue and restarted
everything.

  Now, however, CUPS sees that printer as waiting for the parallel port to
become un-busy, but it never times out. There is no parallel port process
open. I cannot -- as a user or as root -- delete that printer definition and
recreate it. The latter used to be my last-ditch remedy. I deleted the line
for that printer definition in /etc/printcap but it makes no difference. The
printer is stuck with a non-existent problem and everything is hung up.

  Does anyone have a suggestion to get the printing system working again?
Stopping and re-startig CUPS doesn't help. Neither did a reboot! I'm
stymied.

Thanks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jul 23 20:05:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jul 23 20:05:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A CUPS problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407231939370.2209@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407231939370.2209@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407232002310.2346@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 23 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Does anyone have a suggestion to get the printing system working again?
> Stopping and re-startig CUPS doesn't help. Neither did a reboot! I'm
> stymied.

  Fixed the little bugger. I edited /etc/cups/printers.conf and changed the
status from 'stopped' to 'idle', removed the status message, then restarted
cups.

  Why it hangs up printing this 424-page document I've no idea.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From stever at woo-hoo.com  Fri Jul 23 21:55:03 2004
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Fri Jul 23 21:55:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Classless IN-ADDR.ARPA delegation
In-Reply-To: <20040723230844.GB11183@maybe.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407231459250.19742-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
        <20040723230844.GB11183@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <59757.209.210.31.11.1090644853.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> On Fri, Jul 23, 2004 at 03:35:39PM -0700, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
>> Since this isn't all that applicable to most people I'm prefectly
>> willing  to take the discussion off list.
>
> I'm sure many of us have some experience with CIDR, but you never
> elaborated on what your question really *is*. :-)
>

Am wondering if he wants to know how to have reverse DNS delegated to his
own name server, when his neblock is > /24?  The in-addr.arpa zone files
expect that it is covering at least a /24 of space (I think; am typically
dumb about this subject).

Here is a link I have used for a /27 which works fine.  The $GENERATE
keyword tells your name server to refer to the authoritative servers for
the rest of the /24 that is not yours.

<http://www.eli.net/technical/dns_subnet_delegation.shtml>

HTH

From brent at servuhome.net  Sat Jul 24 02:53:02 2004
From: brent at servuhome.net (Brent)
Date: Sat Jul 24 02:53:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Classless IN-ADDR.ARPA delegation
In-Reply-To: <59757.209.210.31.11.1090644853.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407231459250.19742-100000@main.cyber-office.net>        <20040723230844.GB11183@maybe.net> <59757.209.210.31.11.1090644853.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <1090662449.410230313ae12@webmail.servuhome.net>

I implemented this a long while ago, where normaly reverse would not be
totaly delegated to you, this was a way to "cheat".
http://www.dns.net/dnsrd/rfc/rfc2317.html

For more info, you can direct e-mail me, and I can pull up notes on
how exactly we did it, but right now my mind is running thin.

Brent Jones

From raanders at acm.org  Sat Jul 24 05:55:02 2004
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sat Jul 24 05:55:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Classless IN-ADDR.ARPA delegation
In-Reply-To: <20040723230844.GB11183@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0407240544180.22715-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Fri, 23 Jul 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:

> On Fri, Jul 23, 2004 at 03:35:39PM -0700, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> > Since this isn't all that applicable to most people I'm prefectly willing 
> > to take the discussion off list.
> 
> I'm sure many of us have some experience with CIDR, but you never
> elaborated on what your question really *is*. :-)

I was looking for a clue and after several more hours I tripped and hit 
myself with the (clue-)stick.  It still isn't working completely but I did 
get a portion of it to work.
   The issue was with the instruction I got from our upstream provider.  
They had me name a domain entry incorrectly.  Theeefore the 'pointer' they
had made pointed to the wrong thing.  I'm still pretty new to this as our
other major upstream provider does the reverses -- even the subclassed
ranges -- differently.
   It now works from the primary name server system when I do a dig +trace
-x 1.2.3.4 so I think my other mon-working portion is a cache issue on the
other name servers.

My head hurts so I'll probably stop pounding it against the wall for a 
bit.  Do a little yard work and let teh back-brain work on it.

Thanks to Chris, Steven, and Brent for the time to make me think more 
clearly.


Rod
-- 
    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jul 24 13:44:01 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sat Jul 24 13:44:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] the heatwave ate my harddisk
Message-ID: <86y8l9b0fl.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

... but probably not directly.  The machine is upstairs in an
un-airconditioned house, and to reduce anthropogenic warming I
shutdown the machine during the day, a machine that hadn't been
powered off in probably at least a year.  When it came back up, it
started chirping and the machine decided it wasn't there anymore.
Ironically, I was thinking twice about whether it was wise to shutdown
and almost all of the disk failures I've experienced occur on
power-back-up.

It was one of the 80gig IBM deskstar disks, another of which had died
earlier and (heh) was still sitting in the box.  When things cooled
down this morning I yanked both of them.  Luckily, the newly dead one
was just holding some backup data and build trees.  The earlier dead
one held a more valuable Ars Digita University lecture archive.  See:

  <http://www.aduni.org/drives/>

Eventually I'd like to get another copy.  I got my previous copy from
a generous local who invited me over to his garage to do a
disk-to-disk copy.  This time I might be inclined to put it in an
external usually-off enclosure though.

--

From fixin at peak.org  Sat Jul 24 15:56:02 2004
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Sat Jul 24 15:56:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] UML networking: packets disappear after leaving router
In-Reply-To: <20040724134209.11911.77902.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040724134209.11911.77902.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040724225449.GL783@peak.org>

I'm experiencing a networking problem running UML (user-mode-linux).
ping is working, but tcp-based apps aren't.  I've used tcpdump on my
router to determine that packets from uml are being passed to the WAN,
but tcpdump on the other end says they never arrive.  So something
about packets from the uml instance causes them to get dropped
somewhere after they leave my network.

The setup:

Internet       ActionTec        LEAF             Debian Desktop
via      <-->  DSL       <-->   router/   <-->   with UML
Qwest          Modem            firewall         instance "inside"
                          ^
                          |
                          +-- packets get this far, then disappear.

uml communicates with its host via a bridge.  The host (bridge) is
192.168.1.3, and the uml instance uses 192.168.1.253.  The router's
LAN interface is 192.168.1.254.  Networking within the LAN works fine,
and the uml instance appears to be a full-fledged member of the LAN.
It can ping and telnet to both its host and other machines, and all of
them can ping it.  (There are no servers on it for others to try
connecting to.)

Telnet packets leave the uml instance, cross the bridge and are routed
(and NATted) by the LEAF firewall.  They are then passed to the DSL
modem.  I have no way of tracing them beyond this point, but know that
they don't reach the telnet server on the other side.  Qwest tech
support (which was both clueful and helpful) didn't see any way the
modem could be interfering, but also didn't have the ability to check
whether my packets were making it to the first hop on their network.

Other hosts on my lan, including the machine the uml instance lives
on, can telnet to that same server just fine.

It's quite possible that I've screwed uml<-->host networking up, but
I'm out of my depth understanding how.  For example, the flags are
different on the tcp packets leaving the LEAF firewall.  Here are one
from the uml instance and one from another host.  The one with SWE
flags gets dropped, and the one with just S for flags gets through.

22:19:15.926143 192.168.0.9.1027 > c-67-160-213-181.client.comcast.net.telnet: SWE 943229592:943229592(0) win 5840 <mss 1460,sackOK,timestamp 25444 0,nop,wscale 0> (DF) [tos 0x10] 

22:19:21.958940 192.168.0.9.1046 > c-67-160-213-181.client.comcast.net.telnet: S 1098209015:1098209015(0) win 5840 <mss 1460,sackOK,timestamp 739556 0,nop,wscale 0> (DF) [tos 0x10] 

I don't know enough about TCP to make sense of this, but will start
reading.  Any other suggestions?  Has anybody seen this before, or
something like it?

Thanks,

--Eric

-- 
******************************************************************************
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*    Crosswords 4.0.6 for PocketPC is out!: <http://xwords.sourceforge.net>  *
******************************************************************************

From michael at mphpress.com  Sat Jul 24 22:10:03 2004
From: michael at mphpress.com (Michael P. Hopcroft)
Date: Sat Jul 24 22:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Which is a better buy
Message-ID: <410340C5.4000307@mphpress.com>

    This is moe a general computer question, but what in your guy's 
opinion would be a better buy -- a DVD-RW drive or an extarenal hard drive?
    Also, can anyone recommend a store where I can get a really good 
price for either of these items?

    Michael Hopcroft




From ehem at m5p.com  Sat Jul 24 22:55:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sat Jul 24 22:55:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Which is a better buy
In-Reply-To: <20040725051003.16070.41737.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200407250554.i6P5sEdq031411@m5p.com>

> From: "Michael P. Hopcroft" <michael at mphpress.com>
>     This is moe a general computer question, but what in your guy's 
> opinion would be a better buy -- a DVD-RW drive or an extarenal hard drive?

Everyone's favorite answer, it depends. Once you've covered the cost of
the drive, DVD media is cheaper per unit of data. For small amounts of
data DVDs will also be lighter. Also no concerns about destroying DVDs
from a small shock.

OTOH, with a hard disk gives you a tremendous amount of data in a small
package. You can stick >200GB in a pretty small package. Also it is a
single blob for all that data rather than a stack of disks. Faster for
reading and writing. More expensive initially though.


Note, go for an 8x (or faster) dual format drive. The 8x drives have a
laser powerful enough to write DVD+R-DL media (dual layer), slower drives
won't be able to write them.

>     Also, can anyone recommend a store where I can get a really good 
> price for either of these items?

All your favorite stores. ENU. If you're willing to risk being fried
then Fry's has the $80 DVD drive of the week special.

From root at loraksus.org  Sun Jul 25 01:09:02 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Sun Jul 25 01:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Which is a better buy
In-Reply-To: <200407250554.i6P5sEdq031411@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <BA7274CE0@loraksus.org>

Long post, but if you want a 120gb drive for $45, scroll to the bottom. 

Personally, most of the stuff I burn is home movies and the such, and the
DVD is really handy for that. That said, I'd probably go for the hard drive
if I didn't have 7 in my box right now ;)

The only real issues with dvds is that 
1. It's a pain to get the data back / use it.
2. The failure rate on DVD+-Rs

#1 really can't be avoided, so if you need access to the data when you
aren't around to insert the DVD, you'll probably go for the hard drive. 

#2 isn't an issue if you're burning fault tolerant data (dvd-video, "raid"
sets in backups, etc
There is a program that creates "raid" sets, which is really damn slow, but
works pretty well. It's a sourceforge project that I don't remember the name
of right now, but is pretty cool.

An external drive is really nice if you do multiple backups and can walk
around with the enclosure. 
I would reccomend getting an enclosure with a standard power cable (i.e.
same as to your computer and monitor) so you don't have to drag a wall wart
around - or, better yet, get one that runs on battery power (I use a 20gb
archos mp3 player that I got off Amazon for $120, it is tiny and works great
as both an external hdd and a mp3 player, I usually leave the big external
drive at home) 

If you have data that you don't just want to archive, go for an internal hdd
and get an enclosure. You can usually save quite a bit of money going that
way, see the end of my email for details about the $75 120GB drive ;)

Of course, if you're going to talk about dvds, there is the issue of media
to consider. You could use the cheap crap, but DVD-R's are about $65 for 100
if you buy the good stuff and realistically, that is what you will want to
buy. 
(If you buy the cheap stuff, in ~6-8 months you will see CRC errors on some
areas on about ~10-15% of the disks. That is a real pain in the ass. Of
course, hard drives take power, generate heat, noise and can also crash and
then you lose all your data as opposed to 15% * x# of dvds)

If you're going to buy anything, forget FRYd, the last 4 times I've gone
there to buy something, I've had to come back and deal with little Napoleon
Anthony, their wanna be manager / motherfucker in charge of "FRYd Return
World".
Yes, Anthony, if you're reading this, when the revolution comes, I'll be the
one going MUHAHAHA as they escort you to your very own lamp post.

I digress. 

Save yourself some gas money and avoid it. Their prices aren't that great
either. ENU's prices are usually better and I think they pay their employees
a little better Frys does.

If you want to go online, I trust newegg, so go for something like the NEC
2510 dual layer +- etc etc for $76. 

http://www.newegg.com/app/viewproductdesc.asp?DEPA=0&description=27-152-025&
ATT=CD+DVD+Burners+RW+Dr&CMP=OTC-B1zrat3

or a liteon w/everything for $85
http://www.newegg.com/app/viewproductdesc.asp?DEPA=0&description=27-106-952&
ATT=CD+DVD+Burners+RW+Dr&CMP=OTC-B1zrat3

Dual layer media is still expensive, who knows how well it will work out /
and the real shelf life of the disks at this point. 

If you're going to buy a hard drive, wait for a deal to come out on the
forums at fatwallet.com. Great place, you might have to do some work, but it
is worth it to get a 120GB HDD for $45.

Actually, you don't have to wait ;)
http://fatwallet.com/t/18/341370/

$75 out of pocket for a 120 GB drive. There is also a $30 rebate on the
drive, which puts the price after 6 months and hours of angst and 2 new
stomach ulcers at $45. 

You can get an external enclosure for about $30; make sure it has usb 2.0,
etc, etc. Check reviews because some enclosures really suck (I've had some
issues with transfer speeds, some have heat issues too, get one with a fan)

120Gb is about 30 DVDs, more if you use raid and you have a pretty good
chance of not having any of that data go bad, not that bad of a deal. It
should take you a while to fill. 

On a side note, I have a rack mount (4u) 7 bay scsi array w/ hotswap that
supports full size SCSI drives for sale with the 32mb smart array PCI or
EISA controllers.
Right now, It is filled with 7 4.? GB drives (but the drives can be upgraded
and I have a bunch of spare blades) and the whole bundle can be had for $200
OBO ;)

I've never seen one of these up close, so maybe there is a better way,
but if you can pop the box open and remove the disk, you could plug it
into another linux box (as an "auxilliary" drive), mount it and change
the password, then plug it back into your netwinder (or appropriate
mutations of that approach).

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Jul 25 21:14:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Jul 25 21:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A CUPS problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407232002310.2346@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407231939370.2209@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407232002310.2346@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1090815218.21587.9.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Fri, 2004-07-23 at 20:03, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 23 Jul 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> >   Does anyone have a suggestion to get the printing system working again?
> > Stopping and re-startig CUPS doesn't help. Neither did a reboot! I'm
> > stymied.
> 
>   Fixed the little bugger. I edited /etc/cups/printers.conf and changed the
> status from 'stopped' to 'idle', removed the status message, then restarted
> cups.

You might try /usr/bin/enable to change the status (you'll need the full
path; there's also a shell function called 'enable').

>   Why it hangs up printing this 424-page document I've no idea.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul 26 08:25:03 2004

On Mon, 26 Jul 2004, Michael H. Collins wrote:

> It is just a phishing trip to try to harvest more emails and/or
> spreading virii.  the ones i get usually have a suspicious attachment.
> It is not coming from th real plug server i would wager.

Michael,

  They do have the usual winduhs virus attachments, but the last hop to here
was from the PLUG mail server. Tracing back, one originated in India and the
other in western Europe. I would like those originating IP addresses to be
blocked at the PLUG server level.

  On a similar note, for the past week I've been getting spam messages from
Wil Cooley's domain. It ain't him -- most come from Phelps Dodge Corporation
in Phoenix -- but that's the putative return address.

  PITA, eh? I have an SPF record in my DNS file, but apparently not
everyone's using a MTA capable of querying it. (I know I'm not -- yet --
'cause postfix-2.0.x doesn't have the ability and I'm waiting to complete
the migration to my new box before upgrading to postfix-2.1.x.)

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From john at johntelford.com  Mon Jul 26 09:19:02 2004
From: john at johntelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Mon Jul 26 09:19:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail SMTP Access
Message-ID: <r02010200-1034-74075528DF1F11D8A97A000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>

I'm signing clients up for the Postini preemptive email security service
<http://www.postini.com>.  

The Postini service filters all inbound email for spam, viruses, and
worms.  I'll be changing client MX record to point to a postini.com SMTP
server instead of my Sendmail SMTP server. 

I want to prevent black hats from bypassing the postini SMTP server and
sending SMTP traffic directly to my SMTP server.

How can I configure my SMTP server to only accept traffic from the
postini service using the /etc/mail/access file?  

Thanks ...John

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Jul 26 10:18:02 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)

Subject: [PLUG] DVD Burner
In-Reply-To: <20040726163856.32959.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>

> I am outfitting a new computer and am thinking about
> getting a DVD burner, instead of using drives already
> on hand. Lite-On's 8x is on sale at Circuit City, and
> one of the reviewers was a Linux enthusiast. Is anyone
> on this list enthusiastic about the DVD burner they
> currently use? (Or unenthusiastic, as the case may be.)

The Lite-Ons are supposed to be pretty good.  (The cd burner I have from 
them has worked well.)

I have a Pioneer DVD burner.  It is very quiet. (Almost too quiet.  It it 
was not for the light on the front, you would not know it was on.)  
Unfortunatly mine is only a 4x drive.  Speed is helpful when you need to 
make backups.





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Jul 26 10:25:03 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Jul 26 10:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] DVD Burner
In-Reply-To: <20040726163856.32959.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040726163856.32959.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <28978-88040@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 26 Jul 2004, Robert Kopp iconoklastic-at-yahoo.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I am outfitting a new computer and am thinking about getting a DVD
> burner, instead of using drives already on hand. Lite-On's 8x is on sale
> at Circuit City, and one of the reviewers was a Linux enthusiast. Is
> anyone on this list enthusiastic about the DVD burner they currently
> use? (Or unenthusiastic, as the case may be.)

I have a Plextor external USB/Firewire DVD drive (PX-708UF) that works
very well.  I've had no coasters under Linux that were due to a hardware
problem.  I use it on multiple PCs and the only problem was on one Win2k
box when it was connected via Firewire the box would bluescreen.

http://www.plextor.com/english/products/708UF.html

(I've had a couple coasters because mkisofs silently skips files larger
than 2GB, but I'm working on a patch for this.)

The only problem with the Plextor is the price:

http://osdn.pricegrabber.com/search_getprod.php/masterid=1239366

$192 after rebate?*  Ouch!

However, if you plan to have it for a while, the legendary Plextor
reliability and standards compliance might be worth it.  (I still have my
original 4Plex CD-ROM in service...)  Plextor has been very good to me in
the past, so I keep paying extra to get quality hardware.  I've never had
problems writing CDs or DVDs that others couldn't read with this drive-- a
common problem I've had when using cheaper burners or cheaper readers.

  -- Steve

* From newegg.com

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Jul 26 10:47:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Jul 26 10:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] piping audio
Message-ID: <20040726174550.GA2790@gate.kl-ic.com>

I want to do something like:    ./myprogram | audioplayer  
or:                             ./myprogram > /dev/audioplayer

... where "audioplayer" is some program or device that absorbs
and buffers and plays sound data until it sees an EOF, and does
appropriate speed throttling, and "myprogram" is some hack of my
own that generates sound data in some simple uncompressed format.  
Assume, say, 44Ksamples/sec (or whatever), and that I have a fast
machine and program that can make those samples quickly enough.

While there are probably libraries that I can include in a program
to drive sound, I would like to use pipes and redirects (allowing
me to hack functionality in shell scripts, and fool around on the
command line).  No GUIs if possible.

What is the easiest way to do this?  Am I asking for the wrong
thing?  Can you suggest a website with examples?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Subject: [PLUG] Snooping on a serial line
Message-ID: <4105597E.8050808@adnap.no-ip.com>

traffic going back and forth over the line?

use to just watch the traffic?

Evan



From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Jul 26 13:00:03 2004
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Mon Jul 26 13:00:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Snooping on a serial line
In-Reply-To: <4105597E.8050808@adnap.no-ip.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407261257040.16775-100000@mail.mpcu.com>

On Mon, 26 Jul 2004, Evan Heidtmann wrote:

> I'm working on a serial driver for a telescope. How can I see the 
> traffic going back and forth over the line?
> 
> I found 'ttysnopp', but it doesn't seem to be able to do what I want. 
> 'minicom' shows that the device is connected and functioning. What can I 
> use to just watch the traffic?


The only cheap way I'm aware of is by using a program called ttywatch.  As 
as a deamon it attaches to the serial port and redirects output to syslog.  
You can also telnet to the tcp port, 3000 I think, to do interactive 
things, it's input/output is redirected to syslog.

and typed startx, not knowing if it even had x
installed or configured.  It did some fancy stuff, and
then the screen went blank.  And never came back.  I
tried to get other terminals to come up, but no luck. 
It seemed to me to be not responding at all, so I
ended up doing a hard shutdown on the little thing and
now it just keeps rebooting with some file system
error.  I tried to use fsck on it but came up with
memory errors. I checked the partition tables with
fdisk from the recovery partition(hda4) and it stated
that the partitions overlapped...

Is there anybody who wouldnt mind donating some time
with me to fix some of the issues that might be
fixable, or to burn the latest copy of the images for
it? I can get hold of a backpack cd for it, or load
the images onto a windows host, and grab them via

old isa nic's, bnc and 10base as well as a few pci
nics, and several small hubs that need power cords....

the images for loading from cd and from a windows
server.  

Thanks in advance.

John

Fry's is good for tools and media.  Things that do not have parts that 
fail.

They do have a bad problem with putting back returned product to the 
shelves without addiquate testing.  (Which is why you never buy anything 
that has been already opened.)  I have also been told that a sufficient 
quanity of what they sell are referbs, not new, but i do not know for 
certain if that is true.

Theydo carry some very useful things, but you really need to know what you 
are doing to avoid return trips.





From nick2canz at yahoo.com  Mon Jul 26 14:04:02 2004
From: nick2canz at yahoo.com (Nick Wehr)
Date: Mon Jul 26 14:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RE: DVD Burner
Message-ID: <20040726210303.21383.qmail@web50901.mail.yahoo.com>

I have a DVD burner (a Richoh) and got it working with no real problems,
however, I haven't got to play with DVDRW yet...  anyways - I have mainly used
it to make DVD movie backups and must say that I was really disappointed to
learn that all my movie DVDs were in DVD9 format, whereas all burners (that I
know of) right now use and burn to DVD5.  So you don't get a exact duplicate. 
The best you can do is use linux utilities to shrink it to fit.  So I figured
I'd be better off waiting for a true DVD9 copier for my movies.  As for data
and stuff it works fine.  That's my take on it.  Peace out.

From chris at maybe.net  Mon Jul 26 14:11:02 2004

FWIW-Dual layer burners do exists, and there's even firmware hacks to
upgrade two models of single layer burns to dual layer. However, at
the moment the blank media costs almost as much as a new movie would.

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Jul 26 14:22:01 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Mon Jul 26 14:22:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RE: DVD Burner
In-Reply-To: <20040726210303.21383.qmail@web50901.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407261322420.27324-100000@www.fnordora.org>

On Mon, 26 Jul 2004, Nick Wehr wrote:

> I have a DVD burner (a Richoh) and got it working with no real problems,
> however, I haven't got to play with DVDRW yet...  anyways - I have mainly used
> it to make DVD movie backups and must say that I was really disappointed to
> learn that all my movie DVDs were in DVD9 format, whereas all burners (that I
> know of) right now use and burn to DVD5.  So you don't get a exact duplicate. 
> The best you can do is use linux utilities to shrink it to fit.  So I figured
> I'd be better off waiting for a true DVD9 copier for my movies.  As for data
> and stuff it works fine.  That's my take on it.  Peace out.

The current 8x drives are supposed to be able to dual layer media.  
(Requires a more powerful laser than the older drives have.)  I have seen 
8x media available, but no dual layer media yet.

As for rw media, you just have to have an application that will allow you 
to erase the media. K3B will do it.  xcdroast with the proDVD add-in will 
as well.  (k3b is *much* better and does not require a closed source 
driver.)

You don't want an exact duplicate if the dvd was encrypted or region 
coded.  You will want to use something like transcode or dvd::copy to 
remove these impediments.

From v_yau3 at hotmail.com  Mon Jul 26 14:47:02 2004
From: v_yau3 at hotmail.com (Vincent Yau)
Date: Mon Jul 26 14:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] piping audio
Message-ID: <BAY9-F41MPcAKlfpJ6X0000fdc4@hotmail.com>

I had this need last year and I believed someone on this
list offered this solution:

  run an audio cable from your sound card output
to your input.  Play 'myprogram" and then run
some audio capture software.

It worked for me.



>From: Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com>
>Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
>To: PLUG <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
>Subject: [PLUG] piping audio
>Date: Mon, 26 Jul 2004 10:45:50 -0700
>
>
>I want to do something like:    ./myprogram | audioplayer
>or:                             ./myprogram > /dev/audioplayer
>
>... where "audioplayer" is some program or device that absorbs
>and buffers and plays sound data until it sees an EOF, and does
>appropriate speed throttling, and "myprogram" is some hack of my
>own that generates sound data in some simple uncompressed format.
>Assume, say, 44Ksamples/sec (or whatever), and that I have a fast
>machine and program that can make those samples quickly enough.
>
>While there are probably libraries that I can include in a program
>to drive sound, I would like to use pipes and redirects (allowing
>me to hack functionality in shell scripts, and fool around on the
>command line).  No GUIs if possible.
>
>What is the easiest way to do this?  Am I asking for the wrong
>thing?  Can you suggest a website with examples?
>

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Mon Jul 26 18:50:03 2004
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Mon Jul 26 18:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] sub-kilobuck laptop
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407261802490.29584@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0407261935370.9612-100000@gisnet.com>

On Mon, 26 Jul 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> There's a Dell Inspiron 1000 that is really cheap.  Knowledge and
> experiences?

That's Dell's basic Windows laptop. Does fine with enough memory for the 
basic office suite. Screen's a bit small, though. I've had an Inspiron 
5000 for the last few years running W2K, and it's been great. Dell's 
warrantee is good (I've used it twice, and they honored it quickly and did 
the job effectively.) 

The guy next door to me's got a Dell Inspiron 1000 and likes it too. He
loaded Win2K on one drive and RH 8 on another, so he just changes drives
for whatever OS he wants. The machine's hard drive plug has gotten a bit
flaky over the last 3 years, but it's not designed for swapping drives as
a regular thing.

We've also got two sub-Kbuck Toshibas in the shop. But nobody wanted to 
run Windows on them so they've got RH 9 instead, and they've been perfect 
so far (but it's only been about a year.)

One thing regarding Windows... don't go light on the RAM, especially if 
your laptops are going to be sporting ExPee!

- Bill Thoen





From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jul 26 18:59:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Jul 26 18:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] sub-kilobuck laptop

Message-ID: <1090894012.25850.11.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2004-07-26 at 19:56 -0600, Bill Thoen wrote:
> One thing regarding Windows... don't go light on the RAM, especially if 
> your laptops are going to be sporting ExPee!

I think that should be true of any laptop at all... don't go light on
the RAM if you can avoid it, you'll just be shopping for RAM later on.

Although, price out aftermarket RAM before paying to have the
manufacturer put extra RAM in.

From barryb at proaxis.com  Mon Jul 26 19:15:02 2004

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Jul 26 23:01:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Jul 26 23:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] piping audio (2)
Message-ID: <20040727060007.GA6125@gate.kl-ic.com>

Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> I want to do something like:    ./myprogram | audioplayer
> or:                             ./myprogram > /dev/audioplayer

Roger Creswick informed me that I can do a simple:

cat file.wav > /dev/dsp

... to output a file.  After a little fruitless fooling around, I
learned how to make a program do that, which I will discuss here.

The first thing to know is that /dev/dsp is unbuffered ;  the program
that feeds it has to push in a big enough chunk of bytes so that it
does not underrun the data fed to it.  There is a 44 byte header on
a .WAV file, and that, plus enough sound samples to last through a
few interrupts, must be shoved as one chunk into /dev/dsp .  I 
ended up writing a 4096B buffer, with the 44 bytes of header and 
4052 bytes of data, into /dev/dsp as the first chunk of data.  4KB
is probably way overkill, I'll let someone else figure out (on a
slow machine) what a more reasonable limit is.

The second thing to know, at least on my thinkpad T30 laptop, is you
can pick any sample rate you want as long as it is 16000 Hz.  The WAV
header has all sorts of control fields, but the sample-rate field did
not appear to affect anything.  I would prefer faster, because I want
to make some high frequencies, but the audio output filters appear to
eat everything above 5000 Hz.

The third thing to know is that the maximum length sound file you
can generate with a program is 18 hours, for single channel 16 bit
audio.  There are some length fields that limit the number of bytes
to 2^31, and thus the number of samples to 2^30, which at 16000 Hz
is 67K sec or 18.6 hours.  However, if you shove multiple sound files
in, one immediately after the other, they will play seamlessly.
I am designing an app that makes a continuous sound (which is why
making a WAV file on disk is not acceptable) but I can build the
continuous sound out of computed, stitched .WAV files.

That said, I got a cheezy program going.  While running, it consumes
less than a percent of resources (it doesn't even show in the first
45 lines of "top").  Which is good, because I will need that compute
power elsewhere.

---

BTW, what I am doing with this is making something called a "tinnitus
masker".  I have a permanent jet-engine-loud hiss in my left ear.  If
notice me talking too loud,  it is because I sometimes forget and try
to talk over it :-\ .  If I run loud white noise into that ear, it
causes the sound processing circuits in my brain to lower the amplitude
of everything from that ear - including the tinnitus - for some time
afterwards, which helps me get to sleep.  Right now, I am just making
random white noise, but I can run the random samples through a band
equalizer filter and "color" the noise.  Pipes make this a lot easier,
since I can add and subtract bands with lots of 5dB bandstop filters,
one feeding the other, until I have found the right shape .  Then I
can "freeze" the result in a single, simple filter.  

Now, if I could also build higher frequency hiss, I could make a demo
of what my own ear hiss sounds like.  Oh well...

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From bsr at spek.org  Mon Jul 26 23:32:01 2004
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Mon Jul 26 23:32:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] sub-kilobuck laptop
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407261802490.29584@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407261802490.29584@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <4105F6BA.8000201@spek.org>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> There's a Dell Inspiron 1000 that is really cheap.  Knowledge and
> experiences?

I've got a Dell Inspiron 1100 w/a 2Ghz celeron which was under $1000. 
I'm not particularly satisfied with it - I use it only occasionally, and 
my general dissatisfaction does have something to do with it simply 
being a Windows box and being somewhat unfamiliar, but it's pretty much 
a giant heavy slow laptop with a crappy screen.  Battery life is 
actually pretty decent at 4+ hours.  I favor my ancient and 
slow-but-light with the dead battery laptop over the shiny new Dell on a 
daily basis.  That said I've never had a specific problem with it but 
that could be from disuse.  I'd still not recommend it.

If you don't actually need "Windows" but really just need MS Office you 
might consider an entry level iBook, they're "cheap" and good.  Be aware 
that if you need IE for some corporate IT web application you might 
actually need Windows because IE for OSX is vastly different than IE for 
Windows.

--Brent

that it has a PCMCIA slot. Being a bit older, it's a tad heavier than

used other laptops provided by previous employers, I know there are 
better choices. I miss the thinkpad 600X I use to have. But, if I were 
choosing a new laptop today, I'd probably look real close at HP, or 
Sony. Primarily because I think of IBM as another evil empire monopoly 
in one sense. (But not as evil an M$ because of their open source 
support.) ;-)

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jul 27 10:33:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Jul 27 10:33:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re:  Sub-kilobuck laptops
Message-ID: <20040727173149.GB10283@gate.kl-ic.com>

Jeme's target - a slower laptop that is Windoze (and hopefully later
Linux) compatable, for less than $1K - should be reachable.  The idea
of buying a used T2x series laptop from IBM is a good one.  However,
budget for (1) a warranty, (2) a padded carry bag, (3) more RAM,
(4) more AC adapters.  The latter three are best found aftermarket.

Other things to look for:  swappable CD/Floppy and USB.  2 PCMCIA
slots, 32 bit cardbus strongly suggested.  I like the little erasertip
trackpoint devices, others hate them. Trackpads appeal to some, I find
them far too easy to accidentally tap while using - older folks with a
tendency towards palsy/parkinsons can't use trackpads.  Try out the
various pointing devices on other folk's laptops - for at least an hour
each - before deciding.   My T30 has both, and I can switch between
them with the Xconfig.

Things may have changed, but I have had very bad experiences with Dell's
factory service, and others have had similar problems. I have seen Dell
take 4 months to perform a repair, while IBM takes less than 24 hours. 
Laptops are a lot of components in a poorly ventilated case, with a lot
more stress than a desktop usually gets.  The reliability suffers, and
you can expect about one service return per year for a laptop powered
up 24x7.  Warranty service is cheaper than pay-on-the-spot.

Note that the IBM 72W AC adapters (3.5(?)mm barrel, 16V 4.5A ) work
with earlier models as far back as the TP560, and probably into the
future.  I have adapters scattered all over, every place I linger
with the laptop - I hate crawling behind the sofa to unplug things.

When you finally go Linux, plan buying a hard drive carrier for the
swap bay.  When I am on a trip, I carry a spare identical hard drive
in the carrier, and at night I do a "dd" from hda to hdc, which copies
a 40GB drive in about an hour.  But as you know, I am obsessive about
backups...

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jul 27 14:46:01 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Jul 27 14:46:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Development tool to trace function calls
Message-ID: <14025-88664@sneakemail.com>

Folks:

Anyone who's had to debug some nasty OS/application problem knows how
useful "strace" can be for showing just what failed and how.  It's also
helpful to use gdb to catch a backtrace of the function calls after a
failure.

Does anyone know of a utility that will show a continuous log of function
calls as a program is running?  I've seen profilers that will show the
total number of times and time spent in a particular function, but nothing
that keeps a real-time trace of just what is being called.

For example, below is a sample of what I'd like to see for the following
pseudo-C-code:

-----
function increment(arg) {
  arg++;
}

main() {
  int val = 1;
  for (i=1 ; i<3 ; i++) {
    increment(val);
  }
}
-----

This mythical utility that I'm looking for would output:

-----
main()
increment(1)
increment(2)
increment(3)
-----

I suspect it would be dependent on proper debugging code or even profiling
code being present.

Is there something like this out there?  Some mode of GDB I'm not familiar
with?

Thanks,

  -- Steve Bonds



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jul 27 15:01:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Jul 27 15:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Development tool to trace function calls
In-Reply-To: <14025-88664@sneakemail.com>
References: <14025-88664@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <1090965645.32002.15.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Tue, 2004-07-27 at 14:45, Steve Bonds wrote:

> Does anyone know of a utility that will show a continuous log of function
> calls as a program is running?  I've seen profilers that will show the
> total number of times and time spent in a particular function, but nothing
> that keeps a real-time trace of just what is being called.

In essence, you want something that attaches to a process and then works
like GDB doing a 'step' through every function call?  Yeah, I've wished
for that too...  I've suspected it might be possible to script GDB in
something like 'while(true) step', but never quite knew enough about GDB
to do it.  If you find something, please share!

Wil

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul 27 17:46:01 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul 27 17:46:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] wikiwikiblogcalendar
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407271739060.6421@shaft.bitmine.net>

OK, so I've got this idea and I don't want to start from scratch.

I want a website with three integrated things:  A wiki, a blog, and a
calendar.

In my mind, the blog portion would just have a series of articles posted
sequentially with datestamps and user comments.

The wiki would be a wiki like most others.

The calendar would just show when things are happening and have links to
the things.

Here's the catch:

I want to use wikiwords in my blog and have them link to the wiki.  I want
to use some kind of calendar words in my wiki and my blog and have them
create events in my calendar.

So if I type "Hey, I'm going to OaksParkRollerRink on 200407231830.", I'd
like a link to my wiki page on OaksParkRollerRink and a link to my
calendar entry for 6:30pm on 23 July, 2004 (where maybe even a link exists
to OaksParkRollerRink... but that's wishful thinking).

Has anybody ever heard of such a thing?

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

posting, messaging, comments, polls, calendar, weblinks, and more! It can
run on many different operating systems, and uses PHP4 and MySQL."

From bsr at spek.org  Tue Jul 27 20:53:01 2004
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Tue Jul 27 20:53:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] wikiwikiblogcalendar
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407271739060.6421@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407271739060.6421@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1090986696.4801.37.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

On Tue, 2004-07-27 at 17:45 -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> I want a website with three integrated things:  A wiki, a blog, and a
> calendar.
.....
> Has anybody ever heard of such a thing?

Not explicitly, I don't know why since it's a good idea.

If you don't mind your blog actually being a wiki you can massage one of
the wikis that have a calendar plugin into doing that.

Or massage a pluginable weblog tool to link into a wiki w/calendaring if
you prefer a more "structured" blog.  One combination that does that
might be  Wordpress with WP-Wikify[1] and a wiki you like.  Linking back
to the blog from the wiki in some automagic CamelCase way would be cool
too - in a wiki like PmWiki that would be an easy feature to add, it
might be in your favorite one too.

[1] http://www.andrewsw.com/wiki/moin.cgi/WP-Wikify

--Brent

> 
> OK, so I've got this idea and I don't want to start from scratch.
> 
> I want a website with three integrated things:  A wiki, a blog, and a
> calendar.

TikiWiki might work.  It has all three.

I use it myself, and know that WikiWords work in the blog.  I don't use
the calandering, so you'll have to experiment with it.

Open Source CMS has a demo of TikiWiki setup:
http://www.opensourcecms.com/

There is also the project page:
http://tikiwiki.org/

It has TONS of features, most of which can be disabled if you don't need
them.

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Tue Jul 27 22:07:01 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Tue Jul 27 22:07:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless: USB vs. PCMCIA
Message-ID: <1090991350.8857.121.camel@timmy>

I'm just starting to look at wireless options for my laptop.

I have a ThinkPad 600E right now, but I plan to upgrade within a year.
But I want the wireless now. So whatever I buy, it needs to work with
both this ancient machine and whatever I buy down the road.

The two major choices seem to be USB and PCMCIA. I have the following
concerns:

1) Bandwidth

My current PCMCIA ethernet adapter is limited to ~1MByte/s, apparently
by the CPU speed and the processing involved in the PCMCIA bus. USB 1.1
has a theoretical limit of 12Mbit/s (1.5MB/s), but USB 2.0 is a good
deal faster. http://pcmcia.org says the PCMCIA bus is limited to 10MB/s
at the absolute slowest. How do USB and PCMCIA wireless cards perform in
actual use?

2) Convenience

The USB device seems inconvenient because it is a separate device. Is
this a problem for anyone?

3) Signal

Derek Loree mentioned a few weeks ago that the USB adapter has the
advantage that it can be moved around to find the best signal. How
useful is this in practice? How does the signal strength and reach of
the PCMCIA cards compare?

Thank you for any information or opinions,

Evan




From aaron at bavariati.org  Tue Jul 27 23:21:02 2004
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Jul 27 23:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless: USB vs. PCMCIA
In-Reply-To: <1090991350.8857.121.camel@timmy>
References: <1090991350.8857.121.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040728062036.GB1593@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Jul 27, 2004 at 10:09:11PM -0700, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> 1) Bandwidth
> 
> My current PCMCIA ethernet adapter is limited to ~1MByte/s, apparently
> by the CPU speed and the processing involved in the PCMCIA bus. USB 1.1
> has a theoretical limit of 12Mbit/s (1.5MB/s), but USB 2.0 is a good
> deal faster. http://pcmcia.org says the PCMCIA bus is limited to 10MB/s
> at the absolute slowest. How do USB and PCMCIA wireless cards perform in
> actual use?

Well, your ethernet card *should* be working at full speed.  In theory,
a PCMCIA 802.11G card could work faster than USB, but I'd be surprised
if there was a noticable difference with real-world signals.

> 2) Convenience
> 
> The USB device seems inconvenient because it is a separate device. Is
> this a problem for anyone?

I use my USB WiFi adaptor on my desktop, so I can't comment.  But a
PCMCIA WiFi card still sticks out a bit.  If you expect to use WiFi
quite a lot, esp. at cafes, go PCMCIA 'cos the USB dongle has to be
plugged in after you get the laptop out, while a PCMCIA can be left in
all the time if you're careful.

> 3) Signal
> 
> Derek Loree mentioned a few weeks ago that the USB adapter has the
> advantage that it can be moved around to find the best signal. How
> useful is this in practice? How does the signal strength and reach of
> the PCMCIA cards compare?

Works great for me in a permanent installation.  On a laptop in a cafe
or whatever, it's just a giant unnecessary hassle that makes you look
like a dork. :)

I recently picked up an Orinoco Gold off eBay for real cheap, like $11
w/shipping.  Orinocos are old and have really good driver support.
OTOH, Office Despot has a USB WiFi dongle for $20.  But then you get to
install the wlan-ng drivers or whatever.



From ian at znark.com  Tue Jul 27 23:33:02 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Tue Jul 27 23:33:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] yum upgrade from rh 7.2 to 7.3?
In-Reply-To: <20040727233101.5C0A68F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <20040727233101.5C0A68F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <41074872.7060707@znark.com>

Galen Seitz wrote:
> Has anyone used yum to upgrade from RH 7.2 to 7.3?  I'd like to know
> if this is relatively easy, or fraught with peril.
> 

I have upgraded multiple machines from RH 7.2 to 7.3 with apt.  It 
worked quite smoothly; there aren't too many major differences between 
those versions.  I have heard of people doing that upgrade with yum.

I would suggest using apt, mainly because RH 7.x use an older version of 
yum (1.0.x instead of 2.0.x with RH9 and later) that doesn't work as 
well.  The apt package from freshrpms.net works well.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Wed Jul 28 05:18:01 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Wed Jul 28 05:18:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Fax and answering machine problems...
Message-ID: <41079695.90005@robinson-west.com>

First of all, faxing really stinks.  You're making a phone call which 
isn't in many cases free.  It blocks your phone.  I have DSL and want
to trick an HP fax printer into dialing my Internet gateway server
on a simulated phone line.  Why?  So that I can turn faxes into
emails.  If there is a similar trick done on the recipient end,
the fax turned email should revert back to a fax.

The answering macine part is that I have one I really don't
like, a Uniden model with no programming instructions.  I have
a 56k internal Conexant fax modem that Linux seems to support.
I figure I can roll my own answering machine.

There's the problem of having to turn the answering machine
off for faxing.  I guess I can implement an off button on the
local web page.  Does anyone have good pointers for mgetty-voice
and if I can do audio emails
( the audio being the phone message attached as an ogg file. )
with postfix?

The cheapest phone line in Scappoose is $13/month.  Toll lines
are not allowed supposedly.  Even with a toll line, I could say
please call me back at this other number.  The good news is
that the DSL is being upgraded from a maximum speed of 768k
to 1.5 Megabits service.  Fiber optic cable is being used
to replace the copper cable going to the exchange box
located at the Callahan/Old Portland road intersection.

Is it really taxes imposed by the PUD, or is CenturyTel just
expensive in Scappose?

      Michael Robinson

FWIW,

Given that a PCMCIA WIFI card isn't very expensive these days I wouldn't 
worry about moving it to your new laptop if you plan to upgrade. I went 
a year with a PCMCIA WIFI card and while it worked well it was a pain as 
it stuck out of the my laptop.  My new laptop has a mini-PCI WIFI card 
so it's inside with nothing hanging out. I like not having to remove the 
PCMCIA card before I put my laptop into my carrying case. We have a 
number of Dell and IBM laptops in our office and they all have the WIFI 
cards inside and no one has an external PCMCIA WIFI card expect one 
summer intern we have  using an old Dell 5000e laptop.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jul 28 06:29:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jul 28 06:29:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless: USB vs. PCMCIA
In-Reply-To: <1090991350.8857.121.camel@timmy>
References: <1090991350.8857.121.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407280623180.16431@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 27 Jul 2004, Evan Heidtmann wrote:

> I have a ThinkPad 600E right now, but I plan to upgrade within a year.
> But I want the wireless now. So whatever I buy, it needs to work with
> both this ancient machine and whatever I buy down the road.

Evan,

  We have a Lucent/Orinoco Gold pcmcia card in the 600E here. We don't do
massive file transfers over the air, just e-mail, Web browsing and the
occasional printing from OO.o. It works fine from approximately 35 feet
distance -- through wooden walls in the house -- to the Linksys WAP54G
access point.

  This is, of course, a small subset of your concerns, but it is our recent
experience with this laptop. (Still haven't gotten sound to work, but that's
a very low priority after all my work- and book-related deadlines.)

  A newer portable will undoubtably either include WiFi built in or use a
cardbus adapter rather than a pcmcia adapter. Either way you may find it
advantageous to get the 600E functioning with the Lucent/Orinoco Gold and
determine the appropriate path for your new machine when you get it.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From drl at drloree.com  Wed Jul 28 10:14:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Jul 28 10:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless: USB vs. PCMCIA
In-Reply-To: <1090991350.8857.121.camel@timmy>
References: <1090991350.8857.121.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <1091034911.3349.574.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2004-07-27 at 22:09, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> I'm just starting to look at wireless options for my laptop.
> 
> I have a ThinkPad 600E right now, but I plan to upgrade within a year.
> But I want the wireless now. So whatever I buy, it needs to work with
> both this ancient machine and whatever I buy down the road.
> 
> The two major choices seem to be USB and PCMCIA. I have the following
> concerns:
> 
> 1) Bandwidth
> 
> My current PCMCIA ethernet adapter is limited to ~1MByte/s, apparently
> by the CPU speed and the processing involved in the PCMCIA bus. USB 1.1
> has a theoretical limit of 12Mbit/s (1.5MB/s), but USB 2.0 is a good
> deal faster. http://pcmcia.org says the PCMCIA bus is limited to 10MB/s
> at the absolute slowest. How do USB and PCMCIA wireless cards perform in
> actual use?

Both of these are faster than my broadband connection, which is the real
limit I am concerned with overcoming.  You might want to figure out
which version of USB your laptop has.
> 
> 2) Convenience
> 
> The USB device seems inconvenient because it is a separate device. Is
> this a problem for anyone?

It is very convenient for my uses.  I have clients with servers that
where set up to auto-magically configure a USB wireless device, that way
I can run in, plug in the wireless device, then run out to my laptop in
my truck and not bother the client any more or not use any of their
workstations while I login to the server.
> 
> 3) Signal
> 
> Derek Loree mentioned a few weeks ago that the USB adapter has the
> advantage that it can be moved around to find the best signal. How
> useful is this in practice? How does the signal strength and reach of
> the PCMCIA cards compare?

All of the USB devices that I have seen do not have removable
(replaceable) antennae, and they are all somewhat laking in power.  So
the big question is, how are you going to be using your wireless
device?  Is it mostly so you can roam around the house with your laptop,
do you want to go WAR driving, or do you want to be able to go to coffee
shops and utilize the connection there?

Big note, just like PCMCIA devices, the chipsets of USB devices are not
advertised and can change within the same model, some chipsets are
supported by linux and some are not.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Wed Jul 28 12:12:02 2004

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407281146530.17393@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

Top level directories on my OpenBSD 3.5 system:

drwxr-xr-x  14 root  wheel      512 Jul 26 20:21 .
drwxr-xr-x  14 root  wheel      512 Jul 26 20:21 ..
-rw-r--r--   2 root  wheel      754 Mar 29 11:47 .cshrc
-rw-r--r--   2 root  wheel      237 Mar 29 11:47 .profile
drwxr-xr-x   2 root  wheel      512 Mar 29 11:47 altroot
drwxr-xr-x   2 root  wheel     1024 Mar 29 11:52 bin
-rw-r--r--   1 root  wheel    42132 Jul 26 20:21 boot
-rw-r--r--   1 root  wheel  5074980 Jul 26 20:20 bsd
-rw-r--r--   1 root  wheel  4605537 Jul 26 20:20 bsd.rd
drwxr-xr-x   3 root  wheel    19968 Jul 27 18:51 dev
drwxr-xr-x  19 root  wheel     2048 Jul 27 23:01 etc
drwxr-xr-x   7 root  wheel      512 Jul 27 18:53 home
drwxr-xr-x   2 root  wheel      512 Mar 29 11:47 mnt
drwx------   3 root  wheel      512 Jul 27 12:32 root
drwxr-xr-x   2 root  wheel     2048 Mar 29 11:57 sbin
drwxr-xr-x   2 root  wheel      512 Mar 29 11:47 stand
lrwxr-xr-x   1 root  wheel       11 Jul 26 20:20 sys -> usr/src/sys
drwxrwxrwt   2 root  wheel      512 Jul 28 01:30 tmp
drwxr-xr-x  15 root  wheel      512 Mar 29 11:47 usr
drwxr-xr-x  23 root  wheel      512 Jul 27 18:47 var

-Scott

From sloshr at gmail.com  Wed Jul 28 12:29:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] /proc equivalent in OpenBSD?
In-Reply-To: <20040728182912.22724.qmail@web40803.mail.yahoo.com>

On Wed, 28 Jul 2004 11:29:12 -0700 (PDT), Scott Van Hoosen
<svanhoosen at yahoo.com> wrote:
> I've recently set up an OpenBSD box for my mail server. I'm wondering
> if there is something in OpenBSD equivalent to /proc in Linux, where I
> can check server info such as CPU, memory, IRQ's, etc.
> 
> Thanks in advance,
> 
> -Scott
> 

Googling your question found this article - I'm wondering if that sets
you off on the right path?

http://archives.neohapsis.com/archives/openbsd/2002-10/0118.html



From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Wed Jul 28 12:50:02 2004
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Wed Jul 28 12:50:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] /proc equivalent in OpenBSD?
In-Reply-To: <78574cf8040728122873606726@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20040728194913.6052.qmail@web40810.mail.yahoo.com>

Thanks, the link you found answered my question. Here's what worked for
me:

  mkdir /proc
  mount_procfs -o linux /proc /proc

The "-o linux" option sets it up Linux-style.

-Scott

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jul 28 13:46:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed Jul 28 13:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Solaris question about packages
Message-ID: <41081061.5070404@dimstar.net>

How do I find out what package a particular binary came from on a 
Solaris machine?

I know that it was installed from a solaris package, I just want to know 
which one.

Specifically, I want to know what package the files in /usr/ucb 
(University of California at Berkley) came from.

Thanks!

Russ

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jul 28 13:59:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jul 28 13:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Solaris question about packages
In-Reply-To: <41081061.5070404@dimstar.net>
References: <41081061.5070404@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407281353290.22326@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 28 Jul 2004, Russ Johnson wrote:

> How do I find out what package a particular binary came from on a 
> Solaris machine?

I think that most /usr/ucb/files are installed via the SUNWscpu 
package.

Sadly, I don't think the Solaris package manager provides a nice 
equivalent of "rpm -qf filename" (though I'd love to know that I'm 
wrong on that score). If you want to double-check my SUNWscpu 
guess, try this instead:

   grep /usr/ucb/cc /var/sadm/install/contents

Or, more completely

   for f in /usr/ucb/*; do
     grep $f /var/sadm/install/contents
   done

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jul 28 14:09:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed Jul 28 14:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Solaris question about packages
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407281353290.22326@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <41081061.5070404@dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407281353290.22326@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <410815E7.70207@dimstar.net>

Paul Heinlein wrote:

> I think that most /usr/ucb/files are installed via the SUNWscpu package.
>
> Sadly, I don't think the Solaris package manager provides a nice 
> equivalent of "rpm -qf filename" (though I'd love to know that I'm 
> wrong on that score). If you want to double-check my SUNWscpu guess, 
> try this instead:
>
>   grep /usr/ucb/cc /var/sadm/install/contents
>
> Or, more completely
>
>   for f in /usr/ucb/*; do
>     grep $f /var/sadm/install/contents
>   done

Well, since I posted that, I was pointed to this page: 

http://www.sundot.com/unix/solaris/handysol.shtml

Which contains the incantation: pkgchk -lp /usr/bin/ls

Which will reveal the package of the file /usr/bin/ls.

You are correct. The files I want to know about are from the SUNWscpu 
package.

Thanks for your help!




From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jul 28 14:14:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jul 28 14:14:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] New docs, just for fun
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407281404550.22326@pecos.madboa.com>

I've been away on vacation for the past few weeks, so I've been scarce 
on mailing lists across the land. :-) I tend to get out of bed an hour 
or two before anyone else in my household, so my vacation gave me some 
free time to do some writing (among other things). So, just in case 
anyone is interested, here are some articles on which I've recently 
spent some time:

* Notes on UTF-8 and locales
   Brief notes on using UTF-8 and locales on Linux systems.
   [http://www.madboa.com/geek/bits/utf8.html]

* OpenSSL Command-Line HOWTO
   The openssl application that ships with the OpenSSL libraries can
   perform a wide range of crypto operations. This HOWTO provides some
   cookbook-style recipes for using it.
   [http://www.madboa.com/geek/openssl/]

* Sendmail SMTP AUTH Quick Start
   How to enable SMTP AUTH on a Linux system running sendmail.
   [http://www.madboa.com/geek/bits/sendmail-auth.html]

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Wed Jul 28 16:25:03 2004
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Wed Jul 28 16:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] /proc equivalent in OpenBSD?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407281350090.17930@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040728232416.17808.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>

Rich,

It was set up in a similar fashion:
  mkdir /kern
  mount_kernfs /kern /kern

Here are some of the goodies:

# ls
boottime   hostname   machine    osrelease  physmem    usermem
byteorder  hz         model      osrev      posix      version
copyright  ipsec      msgbuf     ostype     rootdev
domainname loadavg    ncpu       pagesize   time
# cat usermem
536043520
# cat version
OpenBSD 3.5 (GENERIC) #34: Mon Mar 29 12:24:55 MST 2004
    deraadt at i386.openbsd.org:/usr/src/sys/arch/i386/compile/GENERIC
# cat posix
199009
# cat time
1091057314 152024
# cat physmem
536391680
# cat machine
i386
# cat model
Intel(R) Celeron(TM) CPU 1300MHz ("GenuineIntel" 686-class)
# cat loadavg
466 333 218 2048
# cat ncpu
1

-Scott

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Wed Jul 28 20:24:02 2004
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed Jul 28 20:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] /proc equivalent in OpenBSD?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407281656170.18759@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20040728232416.17808.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407281656170.18759@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <41086D9B.60702@comcast.net>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>On Wed, 28 Jul 2004, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
>
>  
>
>>It was set up in a similar fashion:
>>  mkdir /kern
>>  mount_kernfs /kern /kern
>>
>>Here are some of the goodies:
>>
>># ls
>>boottime   hostname   machine    osrelease  physmem    usermem
>>byteorder  hz         model      osrev      posix      version
>>copyright  ipsec      msgbuf     ostype     rootdev
>>domainname loadavg    ncpu       pagesize   time
>>    
>>
>
>  Interesting! Thanks, Scott.
>
>  I've read so many good things about OpenBSD that I may put it on my old
>notebook just for giggles.
>
>  Do you -- or anyone else here -- know where there might be information on
>the office productivity applications that run on it? I know it's dandy for
>firewalls, but I've seen only FreeBSD ports of apps, not OpenBSD. I've no
>idea of the differences among the various *BSDs.
>
>Thanks,
>
>Rich
>
>  
>
Rich,

There's a extensive collection of ports and packages available online 
for OpenBSD. The pre-compiled packages are easily installed using the 
"pkg_add" command. If you're curious as to what packages exist for 
OpenBSD checkout the following link:

http://www.openbsd.org/ports.html

The OpenBSD CD set includes some of the more common packages but the 
full collection is available online. The only thing about OpenBSD is 
that is doesn't have a flashy GUI-based installer.  Everything is 
text-based and you have to hand configure files using a text editor. 
Once you've got the basic system installed the "afterboot(8)" man page 
gives you a lot of good information in terms of the system configuration:

http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/man.cgi?query=afterboot&apropos=0&sektion=0&manpath=OpenBSD+Current&arch=i386&format=html

I've never understood Linux's man pages as many seem out of date as the 
standard seems to be to us info rather than man pages in the Linux 
distirbutions I've looked at over the years. With OpenBSD they do a very 
good job of maintaining their man pages with each release. Looks like we 
may have another convert in to midst but I only use OpenBSD in a non-GUI 
mode for a dual or triple homed firewall. It's firewalling abilities are 
superior to Linux's "iptables" and the rule syntax is much more natural 
IMHO.

For my OpenBSD systems I keep the configuration files in a CVS server 
and then pull them out once I have network connectivity. It allows me to 
install and configure a working system very quickly. Since I use OpenBSD 
as my home's firewall I keep two older systems around with dual NICs. It 
allows me to install the newest release of OpenBSD on a system and then 
I can swap out my running firewall box with the newest version of 
OpenBSD. My home network is a critical infastructure for me so I have to 
make sure the firewall and internet gateway are working or I run the 
risk of getting in trouble with my better half.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net




From cstevens at gencom.us  Wed Jul 28 23:36:02 2004
From: cstevens at gencom.us (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Wed Jul 28 23:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MWVLUG Mailing List RSS Feeds
Message-ID: <1091084137.6036.101.camel@geisha.coopnkass.com>

All,

I have implemented automatic RSS feeds of three Oregon mailing lists on
MWVLUG's web site here:

  http://www.mwvlug.org

Along the left column you will see 25 of the latest subjects updated
every hour. This means that you can see what's going on for the
(currently) PLUG, EUGLUG, and OSULUG mailing lists at a glance.

I would like to make this state-wide; if you have links to the other
mailing lists please let me know.


Best,

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Thu Jul 29 09:57:02 2004
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Thu Jul 29 09:57:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Bad Hard Drive on Raid
Message-ID: <1404.216.99.218.67.1091120868.squirrel@216.99.218.67>

Good Morning all.

Well, last night I was doing some checking of my system and notice one
partition on one drive was not up on the raid.  Okay.  It is still
running as it is Raid 5.  So, I remove it and add it back into the
raid and it starts to sync back up.  Then I start the mdadm with
monitor.  This was running before but stopped when I rebooted I'm
sure.

So, Then I get all these emails that all partitions that that
Drive(Drive G) was using all stopped.  Hmm.  I decided to check out
the partitions and reformat or see where the problem lies.  Well, fsck
or fdisk can not see the partition.  Report it as zero bits on fsck
and fdisk says it can't be read.

Now, I need to either repair it somehow or replace it.  Shouldn't I be
able to see the partition in fdisk and fsck even if the partition is
not active in the raid?  Any suggestions to where the problem may be? 
I'm about to go buy another 120GB HD and put one in but would like any
suggestions as to trouble shooting steps that maybe I should be able
to do.

Thanks,

Josh



From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Jul 29 15:08:01 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)

Subject: [PLUG] ASUS A7V8X-MX motherboard
Message-ID: <20040729220728.27356.qmail@web50609.mail.yahoo.com>

This board seems to have problems with all the Linux
distros I have tried thus far. Knoppix 3.3 works with
the LAN and display adapter, but not the sound.
Mandrake 9.2 detects the display adapter, but is
unable to use it. SuSE doesn't seem to cope with
either the display adapter or the LAN.

If there are people on this list successfully using
this board, I would be interested to know what
distributions they are using.

Robert "Tim" Kopp

Message-ID: <20040730011600.91363.qmail@web50603.mail.yahoo.com>

--- alan <alan at clueserver.org> wrote:

> On Thu, 29 Jul 2004, Robert Kopp wrote:
> 
> > This board seems to have problems with all the
> Linux
> > distros I have tried thus far. Knoppix 3.3 works
> with
> > the LAN and display adapter, but not the sound.
> > Mandrake 9.2 detects the display adapter, but is
> > unable to use it. SuSE doesn't seem to cope with
> > either the display adapter or the LAN.

> Do you have any info on the chipsets used by the
> board?
> 
> What does /proc/pci show for lan, sound and video?
> 
> Is it sharing irqs with some other device?

A Linux graphics driver is available from their Web
site. I suppose that means using an "expert" install
and copying it from removable media. I downloaded it
under Win XP and am going to look at the docs that go
with it.

I am downloading Knoppix 3.4 right now. When it is
done, it should enable me to see if this distro at
least has solved all the hardware problems. (Even with
3.3, the graphics were displayed correctly.)

Robert "Tim" Kopp

Date: Thu Jul 29 20:08:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Timex tmx2 mp3/watch/USB File Store not working under Linux (long)
Message-ID: <1091156776.7392.58.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I just bought a Timex tmx2 mp3/watch/USB File Store

Linux 2.2.26 (self built) does not seem to see it right.  It would on
the same laptop under win xp as a normal usb file device.  My old USB
dongle worked, as did others.  Base system is Fedora Core1 with recent

It shows up in the dmesq and messages, but fdisk is freaked out, it sees
4 whacked partitions...

I am going to rebuild with more USB debugging, but by all rights windows just saw a standard file store, with a fat partition.

Attempts to mount -v vfat did not work.

From mikeraz at patch.com  Thu Jul 29 22:06:01 2004
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Thu Jul 29 22:06:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] wikiwikiblogcalendar
In-Reply-To: <861xiwab5i.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407271739060.6421@shaft.bitmine.net> <86d62gagz0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <861xiwab5i.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20040730050536.GC10478@patch.com>

On Tue, Jul 27, 2004 at 11:39:05PM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> Duh.  And also look at Mike Rasmussen's site:
> 
>   <http://meme.patch.com/>
> 
> That's got a calendar thingy on it and he uses it as a blog.  
> Also see Adam Shand's site:
>   <http://www.spack.org/wiki/AdamShand>

Yes, Adam and I use the same stuff.  It doesn't do one of Jeme's
requests:

    I want to use some kind of calendar words in my wiki and my blog
    and have them create events in my calendar.

Which it doesn't do.  One makes calendar entries by clicking on the 
date in the calendar.  

I was going to suggest TikiWiki because it strives to integrate 
everything.  The PmWiki suggestion might pan out too.

Another approach would be to build a module (Got Python?) of Moin
Moin which would function like a named hyperlink

   CalendarEntry(YYYYMMDD,Title,Text of entry)

Which would:

   Create a wiki calendar page in the form CalYYYYMMDD populated with Text of entry
   display title

then add 

   CalendarDisplay(YYYY,MM) (parameters optional, default to current month

that would show the caledar.

One thing I do not like about the blogging portion of MoinMoin is that the page
names are in the form  CalendarName_2fYYYY_2dMM_2dDD.  I'd rather title my pages
and have the date information pulled from another source.  

The blogification, or date ordered display, of writings should, IMNSHO, be an 
optional display of the web sites pages.  It should be just as easy to pull
up an listing of pages ordered by some other criteria.  Or to display pages 
on a subject of interest.  A time stream of expression seems too confined.
Another option might be Blosxom with the Wiki add in. 


--

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jul 29 22:40:03 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Jul 29 22:40:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] parallel scheduling
Message-ID: <86llh25a02.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

I am working on an "embarrassingly" parallel processing problem.  I
want a process to iterate exactly N times total on M processors all of
which run at different speeds (pardon the ASCII mathematical
notation):

  __ M
  \  N = N
  /_  i
    i=1

where N_i is the contribution of the i-th of M processors, and am
looking for a way to manage to stop exactly at N.  Is there a
canonical way to manage this?

My initial thought was that I'd have the slaves report back progress
N_i at regular intervals as they go and the master process will tell
them to stop and report results at some point.  But when things are
getting close to N, _who_ does the master tell to stop _when_ so as to
gracefully stop at exactly N.

Now, it happens that if I was to go over N, it wouldn't hurt anything
computationally (in fact it will improve accuracy of the resulting
computation to have more iterations), but it offends my aesthetic
sensibilities to not be able to stop at the correct N.  

I assume someone smart has solved this kind of problem already.  A
nice simple algorithm would be best.  Any ideas or pointers?

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com
