From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jul 30 01:34:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Fri Jul 30 01:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] parallel scheduling
In-Reply-To: <86llh25a02.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86llh25a02.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <861xit6gin.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> I assume someone smart has solved this kind of problem
Russell> already.  A nice simple algorithm would be best.  Any ideas
Russell> or pointers?

I was sent some ideas by email, none of which directly answered the
problem, however, stimulated by them I thought of a solution that
ought to work.

Firstly, I don't want to constantly feed results back to the master,
because they are somewhat voluminous and because of the collation work
that would be involved, which leaves out just chunking results back
and throwing away the ones that arrive late.  I'd rather just feed
back progress information which is short (basically an integer) and
only provide full results at the end.

Here's the idea.  The master provides each slave an upper limit
stopping point where the slave will pause to await further
instructions.  Every so many iterations (at an interval substantially
smaller than the upper limit) the slave reports progress and also
checks on stopping point updates (which might go down or up).  The
master uses average progress to adjust per-slave stopping points.
Because the slaves won't go past the upper limits without permission,
I can guarantee I won't get too many overall.  Because future slave
performance is estimated from current results, I get reasonably good
load balancing (with close-to-minimal running time) with a fairly
simple algorithm.  This is also vaguely TCP-ish.

Any more thoughts?

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com



From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jul 30 02:04:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Jul 30 02:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] wikiwikiblogcalendar
In-Reply-To: <20040730050536.GC10478@patch.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407271739060.6421@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <86d62gagz0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <861xiwab5i.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
 <20040730050536.GC10478@patch.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0407300152020.6421@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 29 Jul 2004, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> On Tue, Jul 27, 2004 at 11:39:05PM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> > Duh.  And also look at Mike Rasmussen's site:
> >
> >   <http://meme.patch.com/>
> >
> > That's got a calendar thingy on it and he uses it as a blog.
> > Also see Adam Shand's site:
> >   <http://www.spack.org/wiki/AdamShand>
>
> Yes, Adam and I use the same stuff.  It doesn't do one of Jeme's
> requests:
>
>     I want to use some kind of calendar words in my wiki and my blog and
>     have them create events in my calendar.
>
> Which it doesn't do.  One makes calendar entries by clicking on the date
> in the calendar.

Well, it wasn't so much a requirement as a cool sounding feature.

If the system could blog and wiki (and wikiwords in the blog linked to the
wiki portion and backlinks in the wikiword included the blog entry), then
it does nearly everything I want.

At that point, assuming the bliki (Ward's name for such a creature) is
modular, integrating with almost any web calendar seems not too too tough.

In fact, it's a little tempting to take existing perl blog, wiki, and
calendar modules and plug it all together.  The only thing that doesn't
appear trivial is making the backlinks work into the blogspace and adding
some kind of date-time parser into the wikiword link generator to link to
the calendar.

> I was going to suggest TikiWiki because it strives to integrate
> everything.  The PmWiki suggestion might pan out too.

I'm still perusing the options.  Of course, I kind of want to stick to
perl because I know it best, but I don't know it so well that I would do a
much better job than some other language that I just started to learn.

I kind of want to put my foot down at PHP.  I think that shit's just bad
news.

> Another approach would be to build a module (Got Python?) of Moin Moin
> which would function like a named hyperlink
>
>    CalendarEntry(YYYYMMDD,Title,Text of entry)
>
> Which would:
>
>    Create a wiki calendar page in the form CalYYYYMMDD populated with
>    Text of entry display title
>
> then add
>
>    CalendarDisplay(YYYY,MM) (parameters optional, default to current
>    month
>
> that would show the caledar.

Good ideas, sure.  Defaulting to the current month would be neat.  If you
could do natural language date parsing, that would be SUPER cool... so you
could just use terms like "next Wednesday" and it would get linked as a
wikiword, but the generation of the link would be done at blog entry time,
so it would know exactly which date is referenced.

That would certainly be out of my ability if I wasn't already vaguely
aware that it's been done and therefore probably exists as a module
somewhere (at least the parser).

> One thing I do not like about the blogging portion of MoinMoin is that
> the page names are in the form CalendarName_2fYYYY_2dMM_2dDD.  I'd
> rather title my pages and have the date information pulled from another
> source.

Ah, see, I think that's exactly the right way to do it.  If you want an
IDEA that you can link to and modify as time progresses, it should be a
wiki page, not a blog entry.  The blog entries are to capture a state of
mind as much as an idea.  So the wikiwords in the blog entries are there
to link to the larger ideas and give you a space to develop those ideas,
but the blog entry itself shouldn't really be editable after the fact.
Certainly not like a wiki page, anyway.

> The blogification, or date ordered display, of writings should, IMNSHO,
> be an optional display of the web sites pages.  It should be just as
> easy to pull up an listing of pages ordered by some other criteria.  Or
> to display pages on a subject of interest.  A time stream of expression
> seems too confined. Another option might be Blosxom with the Wiki add
> in.

Some people DO handle things this way, but all they're REALLY doing is
creating a new wiki page for some subject heading in their blog and the
blog page is nothing more than a "recent changes" page in their wiki.

I think this is a poor idea for the reasons stated above.  A wiki and a
blog serve two totally different purposes, but references between them can
be very informative.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul 30 02:09:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Fri Jul 30 02:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Is this a decent modem to be building a Linux based answering
 machine with?
Message-ID: <1091178459.3453.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&rd=1&item=3496020608&ssPageName=STRK:MEWA:IT

I have an HSF type modem that LinuxAnt drivers support, but their HSF
drivers don't include voice support.

The referenced modem has class 1, but not class 2 fax.  If I can ignore
fax calls without turning my answering machine off, I'm happy.  I might
be able to use efax.com in order to avoid causing long distance charges
for people faxing me.  Without a telephone line simulator and a good set
of modems, I don't see how I'm going to transparently fool faxes I want
to send out into going out over a DSL line.  My thought is a special
email setup transforming outgoing faxes into outgoing emails.  After
that, I either need an intermediary to translate the email back 
into a fax and send it locally to the intended recipient, or clients 
who are happy with email. 

Why is there such a shortage of high quality, Linux compatible,
voice/data/fax modems?  Am I looking in the wrong place?
Seems like someone should be producing them unless embedded
devices are taking over.

Why is it that some modems can't answer the phone?  That seems like the
simplest thing ever.

     --  Michael Robinson

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Jul 30 06:34:02 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Fri Jul 30 06:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Timex tmx2 mp3/watch/USB File Store not working under
	Linux (long)
In-Reply-To: <1091156776.7392.58.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1091156776.7392.58.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1091194325.8914.0.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Turns out I just had to mount the whole drive (/dev/sdb) and not a partition.

Worked great.




From lhomer at comcast.net  Fri Jul 30 07:31:02 2004
From: lhomer at comcast.net (louis homer)
Date: Fri Jul 30 07:31:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] parallel scheduling
In-Reply-To: <86llh25a02.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86llh25a02.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <200407300732.13023.lhomer@comcast.net>

On Thursday 29 July 2004 22:39, Russell Senior wrote:

Do you have access to timing? If you do then when you are half way there in 
xxx seconds you know you need to go xxx seconds more. This wont be exact, but 
you could refine by shutting all but one down just before 2*xxx seconds and 
then counting in the usual way.

What are you doing now? Calculating N periodically?

> I am working on an "embarrassingly" parallel processing problem.  I
> want a process to iterate exactly N times total on M processors all of
> which run at different speeds (pardon the ASCII mathematical
> notation):
>
>   __ M
>   \  N = N
>   /_  i
>     i=1
>
> where N_i is the contribution of the i-th of M processors, and am
> looking for a way to manage to stop exactly at N.  Is there a
> canonical way to manage this?
>
> My initial thought was that I'd have the slaves report back progress
> N_i at regular intervals as they go and the master process will tell
> them to stop and report results at some point.  But when things are
> getting close to N, _who_ does the master tell to stop _when_ so as to
> gracefully stop at exactly N.
>
> Now, it happens that if I was to go over N, it wouldn't hurt anything
> computationally (in fact it will improve accuracy of the resulting
> computation to have more iterations), but it offends my aesthetic
> sensibilities to not be able to stop at the correct N.
>
> I assume someone smart has solved this kind of problem already.  A
> nice simple algorithm would be best.  Any ideas or pointers?




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jul 30 08:00:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Jul 30 08:00:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless: USB vs. PCMCIA
In-Reply-To: <1091161970.6059.4.camel@timmy>

> It's the "3COM Corp OFFICECONNECT WIRELESS 802.11G ( 3CRWE154G72 )". Is
> this card known to change chipsets on the sly, or is it a good choice?

Evan,

  This is the one I have for my Sony PCG-V505BC. It's one of the two
recommended/sold by EmperorLinux (the other being the Orinoco Gold) and --
after a _lot_ of work by the techs there (and Kurt, here) it's working like
a charm. Uses the Prism54 driver (aka prism2) and the latest firmware.agent.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Jul 30 09:03:02 2004
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri Jul 30 09:03:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Is this a decent modem to be building a Linux based answering machine with? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 30 Jul 2004 08:14:36 PDT."
             <2165-61800@sneakemail.com> 
Message-ID: <20040730160134.B54788F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Steve Bonds <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com> wrote:

> On Fri, 30 Jul 2004, Michael H. Collins mike-at-linuxlink.com |PDX Linux|
> wrote:
> 
> > get a real modem..  most external ones are hardware modems instead of
> > winmodems.
> 
> I've never seen an external modem that would allow one to record the
> incomng voice.  That RS-232 serial link just doesn't cut it.
> 

While I've never used it, my MultiTech MT5634MSV modem claims to have
voice recording capability.  The data rate for voice wouldn't
necessarily overtax a serial line.

  8 bits/sample(Alaw or ulaw) * 8 ksamples/s = 64 kbits/s

64kbps is possible at 115kbaud.  If the modem does any sort of
compression, you get even more headroom.

Here's a list of voice modems I found with a Google search.  I have no
idea how many of these are still available.

  http://www.blackice.com/voicemodems.htm


galen




From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul 30 09:08:01 2004

It's another Intel internal hardware modem pci based.  I don't know how
to find out if this works in Linux as far as voice is concerned.

I'm watching a guy's Intel hardware modem listing on Ebay who claims his
modem works in Linux and that it can do voice.  I'd almost want to buy
it from just to support what he's doing advertising Linux even if he's
wrong. 

There are these Diamond USB modems which apparently have voice and
something called call hold, though a lot of them suggest you 
have to have call waiting service.  I know it sounds lame, but 
perhaps a USB modem is more likely to have voice support than a 
PCI one.  Trouble is, do any voice capable USB modems work fully 
with Linux?  It has to be USB1 spec.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jul 30 10:04:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jul 30 10:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] apache ssl
In-Reply-To: <410A7AC1.30604@linuxlink.com>

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407301001590.22326@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 30 Jul 2004, Michael H. Collins wrote:

> Could one have the passphrase for ssl in a file and start it thusly?  I don't 
> think so and dont have a ssl box I can take down at the moment.
>
> 'apachectl startssl < cat sslkey.txt`

The SSLPassPhraseDialog runtime directive is helpful in this regard:

   http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_ssl.html#sslpassphrasedialog

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

  There is a manufacturer -- I believe of knives -- in California who took

several linux conferences.

systems software and applications programming. Then I'd contact every
business in a 50-mile radius with a presentation on the BSA, how businesses
have reacted and an offer to prepare a proposal to move them to FOSS.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jul 30 10:55:03 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jul 30 10:55:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] apache ssl
In-Reply-To: <410A884B.2080407@linuxlink.com>
References: <410A7AC1.30604@linuxlink.com>  <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407301001590.22326@pecos.madboa.com>
 <1091207694.29599.2.camel@denk.nakedape.priv> <410A884B.2080407@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407301050250.22326@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 30 Jul 2004, Michael H. Collins wrote:

> Wil Cooley wrote:
>> If you're gonna do that, though, you might as well remove the 
>> passphrase on the key.
>
> That is what I was thinking.  Whare really are the security risks 
> behind that the documentation refers to?

If someone is able to swipe your private key (and get DNS sufficiently 
jimmied) then s/he can get a system to masquerade as your secure host. 
A passphrase on your key makes it that much more difficult for the 
thief to use.

Of course, if someone swipes your key, s/he has probably already 
rooted your box -- unless you're doing something silly like sending 
your key somewhere via e-mail or keeping it in an unprotected 
directory.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul 30 11:02:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)

> Here's a list of voice modems I found with a Google search.  I have no
> idea how many of these are still available.
> 
>   http://www.blackice.com/voicemodems.htm
> 
> 
> galen

Thanks ;-)  The guy I listed as a seller of a Linux compatible internal
pci voice modem is someone I'm giving a try.  The guys in California, 
so it should get to me shortly.  I want an internal since my
Intel D815EEA2 motherboard doesn't have a second serial port 
as far as I can tell.  I had an external which ran into cable problems,
they frayed over time.  External modems aren't as secure as internal
models either.  It's a hardware based Intel modem I'm getting, it 
might even work on my PC164 Alpha system.

Why didn't someone a long time ago integrate a 56k modem on a
pci based ne2000 clone?  Classic nic ports have been faster than
serial for a long time, they are more than fast enough to
support modem speeds.  Linux has solid ne2000 drivers.




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Jul 30 11:06:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri Jul 30 11:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] apache ssl
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407301050250.22326@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <410A7AC1.30604@linuxlink.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407301001590.22326@pecos.madboa.com>
	 <1091207694.29599.2.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
	 <410A884B.2080407@linuxlink.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.61.0407301050250.22326@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <1091210717.29599.13.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Fri, 2004-07-30 at 10:54, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> If someone is able to swipe your private key (and get DNS sufficiently 
> jimmied) then s/he can get a system to masquerade as your secure host. 
> A passphrase on your key makes it that much more difficult for the 
> thief to use.

Not only that, if he's captured your SSL-protected network traffic, he
could then decrypt it.  At least, I think so.  Having the passphrase to
the key on the server with the key only means the cracker has to find it
instead of swiping the key directly.

> Of course, if someone swipes your key, s/he has probably already 
> rooted your box -- unless you're doing something silly like sending 
> your key somewhere via e-mail or keeping it in an unprotected 
> directory.

I'm sure none of us have *ever* done anything like that ;)

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul 30 13:21:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)

Subject: [PLUG] Is this a decent modem to be building a Linux based
	answering machine with?
In-Reply-To: <1091213155.10557.36.camel@dell.linux.box>

	<1091213155.10557.36.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <1091218799.6740.103.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

 
> And how, exactly, would you tell an ne2K to dial a phone number?  Or
> answer a phone?  Or send a fax?
> 
> Naw, they're two different kinds of hardware doing two different things.
> 
> -- 
> Rob                                |  If not safe,
>    Jabber: athlonrob at axpr.net   |    one can never be free.

It's not that hard to put an 8 bit computer on a hardware modem
and hook it to an ethernet port.  8 bit computers aren't 
expensive either.  It's the mainframe concept of multiple well 
designed computers intended for small tasks working together.
PIC micro controllers are cheap these days.  That's what makes
the MARS rovers possible.  Couldn't IBM XT's run ethernet?




From freyley at gmx.net  Fri Jul 30 14:21:02 2004
From: freyley at gmx.net (freyley at gmx.net)
Date: Fri Jul 30 14:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ASUS A7V8X-MX motherboard
In-Reply-To: <20040729220728.27356.qmail@web50609.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040729220728.27356.qmail@web50609.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1091222408.7497.13.camel@zadie>

On Thu, 2004-07-29 at 15:07, Robert Kopp wrote:
> This board seems to have problems with all the Linux
> distros I have tried thus far. Knoppix 3.3 works with
> the LAN and display adapter, but not the sound.
> Mandrake 9.2 detects the display adapter, but is
> unable to use it. SuSE doesn't seem to cope with
> either the display adapter or the LAN.

The Video is Via Unichrome Graphics, which does not seem to have much
support. Knoppix is almost certainly using the VESA driver to do it.

The Sound is an ADI AD1980 chipset, which is an AC'97 codec chip, and
should therefore be minimally supported by that driver. ALSA, however,
claims to support the AD1980 chipset, so a 2.6 kernel should work with
this (in theory). My 2.4 kernel only has AD chipsets in the 18xx ranges,
so seems not to.

the LAN is a VIA VT6103 chipset, which should be the via-rhine driver
without too many problems.

Jeff

> If there are people on this list successfully using
> this board, I would be interested to know what
> distributions they are using.
> 
> =====
> Robert "Tim" Kopp
> http://analytic.tripod.com/
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
> 




From freyley at gmx.net  Fri Jul 30 14:32:01 2004
From: freyley at gmx.net (freyley at gmx.net)
Date: Fri Jul 30 14:32:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ASUS A7V8X-MX motherboard
In-Reply-To: <1091222408.7497.13.camel@zadie>
References: <20040729220728.27356.qmail@web50609.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <1091222408.7497.13.camel@zadie>
Message-ID: <1091223074.7500.17.camel@zadie>

On Fri, 2004-07-30 at 14:20, freyley at gmx.net wrote:
> On Thu, 2004-07-29 at 15:07, Robert Kopp wrote:
> > This board seems to have problems with all the Linux
> > distros I have tried thus far. Knoppix 3.3 works with
> > the LAN and display adapter, but not the sound.
> > Mandrake 9.2 detects the display adapter, but is
> > unable to use it. SuSE doesn't seem to cope with
> > either the display adapter or the LAN.
> 
> The Video is Via Unichrome Graphics, which does not seem to have much
> support. Knoppix is almost certainly using the VESA driver to do it.
> 
> The Sound is an ADI AD1980 chipset, which is an AC'97 codec chip, and
> should therefore be minimally supported by that driver. ALSA, however,
> claims to support the AD1980 chipset, so a 2.6 kernel should work with
> this (in theory). My 2.4 kernel only has AD chipsets in the 18xx ranges,
> so seems not to.
> 
> the LAN is a VIA VT6103 chipset, which should be the via-rhine driver
> without too many problems.
> 
> Jeff

Let me add to this that what you can do, if you want, is grab the file
/etc/X11/XF86Config-4 off the Knoppix boot, and place it in the same
place on any of the other installs, and you should get working video
(though it may have irritants around the edges), and you can modprobe
via-rhine and get working network on any of the others, and as for
sound, you're likely going to have to upgrade the kernel to 2.6 or use
the 2.6 boot on one of the newer distros, and should be able to get
sound with that.

Jeff

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul 30 15:43:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Fri Jul 30 15:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The BSA Strikes Again -- Locally
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0407301124180.14991-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0407301124180.14991-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
Message-ID: <1091227333.6744.128.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> 
> As for getting in the door: Megalosoft's EULA specifies their right to
> audit software use at customer sites. So Harry's agreed to this when they
> did the click-through dance.
> 
> http://www.networkclue.com/os/Windows/licensing/audit.php
> 

What's to stop an angry person from walking into a company with illegal
software just to get the company fined?  This attitude of the BSA is
extremely litigious, will they even sue over copyrighted software 
that's ancient?  Technically, if your computers are off when they 
come to audit you I don't think they can bust you.  I think fair 
use allows multiple copies of software as long as you don't use 
run more copies than the licenses you have simultaneously.

What's costing jobs is the liability of touching much of the
software and even hardware out there today.  Instead of becoming
a service industry based around open source and open standards
there's the Megalosoft culture.  Auditing a restaurant is just
disgusting.

Those click EULA's are so hard to read, just how binding are they
anyways?




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 30 16:31:01 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)

Subject: [PLUG] The BSA Strikes Again -- Locally
In-Reply-To: <1091227333.6744.128.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Message-ID: <14706-73193@sneakemail.com>

On Fri, 30 Jul 2004, Darkhorse plug_0-at-robinson-west.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Those click EULA's are so hard to read, just how binding are they
> anyways?

Click-through EULAs have been enforced in the past.  For some examples,
see:

http://www.phillipsnizer.com/library/topics/click_wrap.cfm

There's also the question of whether the people who click the EULA can
speak "for the company" and extend the liability to the entire company.
If a corporate officer clicks the agreement, it's pretty cut-and-dried,
but how often is that the case?  ;-)

  -- Steve



From chaz at bctonline.com  Fri Jul 30 18:18:02 2004
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)
Date: Fri Jul 30 18:18:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] parallel scheduling
In-Reply-To: <86llh25a02.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <B0005721364@dilbert.bctonline.com>

Not sure how to interpret your diagram.
I used to work at Ncube and had to deal with this sort of thing.
You can call me to chat about it if you want.
503-632-4181
-chaz

> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]
> On Behalf Of Russell Senior
> Sent: Thursday, July 29, 2004 10:40 PM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] parallel scheduling
> 
> 
> I am working on an "embarrassingly" parallel processing problem.  I
> want a process to iterate exactly N times total on M processors all of
> which run at different speeds (pardon the ASCII mathematical
> notation):
> 
>   __ M
>   \  N = N
>   /_  i
>     i=1
> 
> where N_i is the contribution of the i-th of M processors, and am
> looking for a way to manage to stop exactly at N.  Is there a
> canonical way to manage this?
> 
> My initial thought was that I'd have the slaves report back progress
> N_i at regular intervals as they go and the master process will tell
> them to stop and report results at some point.  But when things are
> getting close to N, _who_ does the master tell to stop _when_ so as to
> gracefully stop at exactly N.
> 
> Now, it happens that if I was to go over N, it wouldn't hurt anything
> computationally (in fact it will improve accuracy of the resulting
> computation to have more iterations), but it offends my aesthetic
> sensibilities to not be able to stop at the correct N.
> 
> I assume someone smart has solved this kind of problem already.  A
> nice simple algorithm would be best.  Any ideas or pointers?
> 
> --
> Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
> seniorr at aracnet.com
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

> Click-through EULAs have been enforced in the past.  For some examples,
> see:
> 
> http://www.phillipsnizer.com/library/topics/click_wrap.cfm
> 
> There's also the question of whether the people who click the EULA can
> speak "for the company" and extend the liability to the entire company.
> If a corporate officer clicks the agreement, it's pretty cut-and-dried,
> but how often is that the case?  ;-)
> 
>   -- Steve

We were required to attend SAMI training where I work. It was hammered
home that both the company and the employee are liable.

Sandy
--

Peck of Pickled Pisces               __  o               http://herring.org/

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sat Jul 31 00:17:01 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Sat Jul 31 00:17:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The BSA Strikes Again -- Locally
In-Reply-To: <20040731024557.GA13306@kippered.herring.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0407301124180.14991-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
	<1091227333.6744.128.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	<14706-73193@sneakemail.com>  <20040731024557.GA13306@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <1091258160.6740.183.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> 
> We were required to attend SAMI training where I work. It was hammered
> home that both the company and the employee are liable.
> 
> Sandy
> -- 
> Sandy Herring, RHCE                        o              sandy at herring.org
> Peck of Pickled Pisces               __  o               http://herring.org/
> UNIX or Web authoring questions?  |\/ o\  o  http://herring.org/finger.html
> ->http://herring.org/techie.html  |/\__/     http://herring.org/pub-key.asc

Are there any caps on liability?  Why fine grandma $100k for 
potentially an honest mistake on her part?  I don't disagree 
with this SAMI training, but I must admit that the legal 
situation with EULA's is frightening. Imagine if SCO could 
get IP rights to Linux.  If I owned IP and someone didn't 
have a license, why couldn't I just force them to pay the 
normal price for one?  If enough people are honest enough 
for me to profit fairly, I don't see how some infringement 
on my IP via illegal copying makes any difference.  It 
concerns me that protections that can be tripped on so 
violently aren't phased out.

What has driven the courts to mete out egregious fines?  

In a practical sense, especially considering computers 
that have a network or cdrom boot feature that can't be 
disabled, how can software use and copying be 
controlled?  Specifically, HP latops come to 
mind.

Maybe the message from Microsoft is simply, don't use
our software.  If it costs a lot and there's $100k
liability, that's a good argument for OSS.

Is there a grass roots effort to encourage 
negative purchasing in order to curb the 
BSA's excessive enforcement policies?  
A way for the consumer to fight back 
against a pending liability crisis?
If these big software companies lose 
enough money, will they reconsider the
BSA's tactics?  Is it safe to join in
an outcry?




From root at loraksus.org  Sat Jul 31 05:24:02 2004
From: root at loraksus.org (Karol Kulaga)
Date: Sat Jul 31 05:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The BSA Strikes Again -- Locally
In-Reply-To: <1091258160.6740.183.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <7B04140D6F@loraksus.org>

> Are there any caps on liability?  

Well, they probably won't fine a company more than they can pay. After all,
if someone tells a company to pay them a million and you only have $250,000,
they probably are not going to see any of that money. 

> Why fine grandma $100k for potentially an honest mistake on her part?  

Because they can. Also, a ton of money collected by the BSA stays in the BSA
- i.e. this money isn't returned to the vendor(s). It is also easier to prey
on the weak if you get the right judge. I believe a bunch of guys in the 20s
and 30s followed a similar business plan.
People also sell what I like to call "protection racket" software. Basically
a simple database to track licenses, etc. 

> If I owned IP and someone didn't have a license, why couldn't I just force
> them to pay the normal price for one?

Because the court fees are a bitch and probably not worth the time and
effort to collect $300 or even $5000. Anything above that and you get into
court where you have to pay lawyers. 

>If enough people are honest enough for me to profit fairly, I don't see how
> some infringement on my IP via illegal copying makes any difference.  

BECAUSE THE COMPANY IS LOSING MONEY!! OH MY GOD THEY ARE KILLING US AND WILL
MAKE US FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY! DAMN THOSE TERRORIST PIRATES!!!

Just ignore logic and most of their strategies will make sense. For example,
a college student pirates Photoshop / autocad. If you ignore the fact that
the college student doesn't have enough money to buy Photoshop and couldn't
buy it even he wanted to (i.e. you couldn't possibly ever get a dime for the
product from the college student), you could consider that the college
student is stealing from you. 
If one has a brain capable of something called "thinking" however . . .

> It concerns me that protections that can be tripped on so violently aren't
> phased out.

Have you bribed your congressman lately? No? Guess where a bunch of BSA
money goes. 

> What has driven the courts to mete out egregious fines?  

Congressmen need shiny new cars, drugs, hookers and people to hide bodies
for them. The BSA needs money to bribe aggressively. 
Everything costs money. 

> Maybe the message from Microsoft is simply, don't use our software.  If it
> costs a lot and there's $100k liability, that's a good argument for OSS.

People are sheep and are about as intelligent. Whatever comes pre-installed
on their emachines and dells is probably what they are going to use. 

> A way for the consumer to fight back against a pending liability crisis?

You can usually negotiate - i.e. in exchange for reducing the fine, we will
buy the whole MS big ass licensing package for the next 10 years that
includes a ton of stuff that we will never use. Again, you can't get blood
from a rock. You can attempt a long term settlement and drive your small
business into the ground.

> If these big software companies lose enough money, will they reconsider 
> the BSA's tactics?  

Nope, they will blame any losses on piracy. By "they" I mean the group who
gives the numbers to the companies - the BSA. 
The BSA likes reporting big numbers.

> Is it safe to join in an outcry?

Depends if your licenses are up to date and everything is documented. A
bunch of schools went through audits and ended up having to pay even though
they had the licenses, they didn't have the right kind of documentation or
something equally inane. 
Why schools? Because, you know, student employees can be treated like shit
and don't have close to the same rights as regular employees. The BSA loves
disgruntled employees.

If you don't like BSA... Why give overpriced $$$ to any of these companies?

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Sat Jul 31 07:26:02 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Sat Jul 31 07:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Is this a decent modem to be building a Linux based
	answering machine with?
In-Reply-To: <1091202785.6740.10.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1091178459.3453.22.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <410A46A3.8040809@linuxlink.com> <2165-61800@sneakemail.com>
	 <410A67D7.3050507@linuxlink.com>
	 <1091202785.6740.10.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1091283884.7361.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>

www.asteriskpbx.org

digium has a cheap modem that works great with asterisk and works as an
actual pbx.  Now it turns out that they used a standard winmodem, and
most winmodems/softmodems can do voice with the right commands.  You can
find el cheapo cards on ebay and the net that are the same card as the
XP100, but have a slightly different ID.  Minor modification of the
source will make it work.  But then you are not supporting digium, which
puts lots of resources into asterisk (GPL).  Oh yeah, you get support
with that cheap card from digium.  You probably want that.  They will
really help get you moving.  For $100 you get a lot of support
apparently.

You can "dumb" down asterisk to a pbx to an answering machine, or you
could just switch to VOIP, or have a hybrid:  The PBX can answer the
phone after X rings, and you can go outbound from a SIP phone in the
house to the PBX out the analog line.  Other wise you answer the phoen
normally.  Or you can SIP/VOIP out your broadband connection.  Fun for
testing!

I see the asterisk page now lists the clone, which is cool for honesty
and openness.


Clone (Not sure of cost).
http://www.malabs.com/product.asp?product_sku=56926&item_no=FM%2DINL92SW&show=b&pass=&shopid=

Digium ($100)
http://www.digium.com/index.php?menu=wildcard_x100p

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jul 31 13:14:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat Jul 31 13:14:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Printing Problems
In-Reply-To: <410cdb72.441681@mail.aracnet.com>
References: <410cdb72.441681@mail.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407311306340.5138@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 31 Jul 2004, Prutzer wrote:

> after installing SuSE 9.0 on my box, it fails to print. It won't allow
> me to do any kind of printer administration because the box goes into
> lock up if I try. I've clean installed twice and in both installs, it
> sees the printer, prints a test page and finishes. Once I reboot, it
> all goes to heck in a hand basket.

Harry,

  Can you be more specific? What printing system are you using (lpr, lprng,
cups, something else)?

  What do you mean by "It won't allow me to do any kind of printer
administration because the box goes into lock up if I try."? Do you have
/etc/printcap? If you have cups installed, you should have
/etc/cups/printers.conf. Also with cups, are you using the bui to reach
<http://localhost:631>?

  If the installation process recognizes the printer and successfully sends
a test page, but this ability is lost upon a reboot, it means that the
printing system daemon is not being loaded during the boot process. I've no
idea how SuSE does things, but in Red Hat this would be
/etc/rc.d/rc3.d/S99cups (which points to /etc/rc.d/init.d/cups start); SuSE
has the equivalent.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Sat Jul 31 13:38:02 2004
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Sat Jul 31 13:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] More Printing Problems
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407311306340.5138@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040731203716.79632.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>

I am also having a printing problem on SuSE 9.1. When I first installed
it a few weeks ago, I could print perfectly to an old Apple
Laserwriter, and to a newer Epson Stylus C80 inkjet. A few days later,
I could not print to either.

I'm using CUPS. The CUPS service is running, and can be stopped and
started again without problem with /etc/rc.d/cups (start|stop).

When I try to test a printer from Yast, I get the following error
message:

  An error occurred while communicating with the CUPS server
  while saving queue y2test.
  cups(File)DoRequest error: client-error-request-value-too-long

I click Ok, then get this error:

  Unable to print test page.
  Output from lpr:
  lpr: unable to print file: client-error-request-value-too-long

Numberous google searches on these error messages came up with several
other people with similar issues, but no working solution.

I have uninstalled CUPS, then reinstalled it, from Yast, but the
problem persists.

-Scott

--- Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

> On Sat, 31 Jul 2004, Prutzer wrote:
> 
> > after installing SuSE 9.0 on my box, it fails to print. It won't
> allow
> > me to do any kind of printer administration because the box goes
> into
> > lock up if I try. I've clean installed twice and in both installs,
> it
> > sees the printer, prints a test page and finishes. Once I reboot,
> it
> > all goes to heck in a hand basket.
> 
> Harry,
> 
>   Can you be more specific? What printing system are you using (lpr,
> lprng,
> cups, something else)?
> 
>   What do you mean by "It won't allow me to do any kind of printer
> administration because the box goes into lock up if I try."? Do you
> have
> /etc/printcap? If you have cups installed, you should have
> /etc/cups/printers.conf. Also with cups, are you using the bui to
> reach
> <http://localhost:631>?
> 
>   If the installation process recognizes the printer and successfully
> sends
> a test page, but this ability is lost upon a reboot, it means that
> the
> printing system daemon is not being loaded during the boot process.
> I've no
> idea how SuSE does things, but in Red Hat this would be
> /etc/rc.d/rc3.d/S99cups (which points to /etc/rc.d/init.d/cups
> start); SuSE
> has the equivalent.
> 
> Rich
> 
> -- 
> Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
> Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
> <http://www.appl-ecosys.com>
>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Subject: [PLUG] Firefox-0.9.2 installation problems
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407311520180.5902@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  This is quite frustrating. On my old Red Hat box I installed firefox-0.8.0
with no problems into /usr/local/firefox. I'm now trying to replace mozilla
with firefox-0.9.2 on my new Slackware box and I just cannot figure out the
magic combination.

  If I, as a user, try to install it in any directory (not /usr/local/ as I
don't have write access to that) it fails because it cannot find xpistub.so.
That library is present in both /usr/lib/mozilla-1.4/ and
/usr/local/mozilla. On the RH box it's located in /usr/local/mozilla/.

  I cannot install as root because: if I 'su' or 'su -', the installer
cannot open the already open X display and will not use the existing one or,
if I exit X and log in as root on a different terminal, Xfce comes up but
the mouse is stuck. Sigh.

  Don't remember how I replaced mozilla with firefox on the RH box, but it's
worked like a charm. Any and all suggestions on how I should proceed on the
new box are greatly appreciated.

Thanks,

Rich

From aaron at bavariati.org  Sat Jul 31 18:23:05 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Firefox-0.9.2 installation problems

Message-ID: <20040801012221.GA19031@bavariati.org>

On Sat, Jul 31, 2004 at 03:27:05PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I cannot install as root because: if I 'su' or 'su -', the installer
> cannot open the already open X display and will not use the existing one or,
> if I exit X and log in as root on a different terminal, Xfce comes up but
> the mouse is stuck. Sigh.

Gah.  No idea why logging into X as root breaks the mouse, and I don't
know how to properly fix it so root can access a regular user's X
session, but I cheat by logging in as e.g. 'aaron', opening an xterm,
su'ing to root, then doing a 'cp /home/aaron/.Xauthority /root'.
This works until I next log in.

Good luck,
  Aaron

On Sat, 2004-07-31 at 20:56, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Sat, 2004-07-31 at 18:56, Mel Andres wrote:
> > It may be something SuSE specific. However there is nothing in the man 
> > or info pages on it. The command was posted on an Ximian newsgroup 
> > (IIRC) as a means to open the red-carpet GUI as a user.

> name?  My Fedora Core 2 system doesn't have it either.
> 
> Wil

I did a bit of a search through redhat's site, and Fedora's little
subdomain, and came up with nothing. So I'll just add the Debian way to
this.

jeff at zadie:~$ apt-cache search sux
sux - wrapper around su which will transfer your X credentials
jeff at zadie:~$ apt-cache show sux
Package: sux
Priority: optional
Section: admin
Installed-Size: 64
Maintainer: Millis Miller <millis at faztek.org>
Architecture: all
Version: 1.0.1-3
Recommends: xbase-clients
Filename: pool/main/s/sux/sux_1.0.1-3_all.deb
Size: 8560
MD5sum: 868e114a14297b521a55a329c45c7d3b
Description: wrapper around su which will transfer your X credentials
 Sux is a wrapper around the standard su command which will transfer
 your X credentials to the target user.
 .
 http://sourceforge.net/projects/sux/
 ( from http://fgouget.free.fr/sux/ )
 

Gotta give debian credit for a bunch of things, and one of those is
packages.debian.org which would give you this even if you didn't have a
debian system. 

And, amusingly enough, the "Project Home Page" for sux (linked off the
sourceforge site) is

packages.qa.debian.org/s/sux.html

Jeff




From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Jul 31 22:39:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Jul 31 22:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Firefox-0.9.2 installation problems
In-Reply-To: <1091337674.1959.5.camel@zadie>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407311520180.5902@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <410C3BBA.4010506@comcast.net>

	 <410C4DCA.5040902@comcast.net>
	 <1091332585.21172.2.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
	 <1091337674.1959.5.camel@zadie>
Message-ID: <1091338761.10563.73.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sat, 2004-07-31 at 22:21 -0700, freyley at gmx.net wrote:
> I did a bit of a search through redhat's site, and Fedora's little
> subdomain, and came up with nothing. So I'll just add the Debian way to
> this.

FWIW, Gentoo (or any portage-enabled system):

rob at dell ~ $ emerge -s sux
Searching...
[ Results for search key : sux ]
[ Applications found : 1 ]
  
*  x11-misc/sux
      Latest version available: 1.0-r1
      Latest version installed: [ Not Installed ]
      Size of downloaded files: 9 kB
      Homepage:    http://fgouget.free.fr/sux/sux-readme.shtml
      Description: "su" wrapper which transfers X credentials
      License:     X11

And all that info is available on the web at http://packages.gentoo.org/
in case you aren't Gentoo-inclined.  :-)

-- 
Rob                                |  If not safe,
   Jabber: athlonrob at axpr.net   |    one can never be free.





From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jul 31 23:02:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sat Jul 31 23:02:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Firefox-0.9.2 installation problems
In-Reply-To: <20040801012221.GA19031@bavariati.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0407311520180.5902@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<20040801012221.GA19031@bavariati.org>
Message-ID: <86ekmrv1lf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Aaron" == Aaron Burt <aaron at bavariati.org> writes:

Aaron> Gah.  No idea why logging into X as root breaks the mouse, and
Aaron> I don't know how to properly fix it so root can access a
Aaron> regular user's X session, but I cheat by logging in as
Aaron> e.g. 'aaron', opening an xterm, su'ing to root, then doing a
Aaron> 'cp /home/aaron/.Xauthority /root'.  This works until I next
Aaron> log in.

Another trick that can work is to slogin to localhost as root, as in:

  $ slogin root at localhost 

If root is allowed to login via ssh, and X forwarding is enabled in
ssh, then this should work too.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com
